fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: • City dealing rooms are notorious for Hoovering up all available talent and leaving academia, manufacturing and public services with the second-raters.
fields.body:
 City dealing rooms are notorious for Hoovering up all available talent and leaving academia, manufacturing and public services with the second-raters.

As the following story illustrates, the trading-floor intelligentsia puts Bloomsbury to shame. It is February 16 in a foreign-exchange dealing room "somewhere in EC2", and an in-house economist was talking the stripey-shirts through new government data.

The figures showed average earnings rising sharply by 5.5% a year, a rise blamed, inter alia, on millennium bonus payments. One brainbox bellowed from the floor: "Oi, these millennium payments - are they a one-off?"

Some time later, the analyst was number-crunching a report by the National Institute for Economic and Social Research into the effects of leaving Europe. Another bellow from the floor: "Who's this bloke Niesr?" Anyone have Lord Keynes's mobile number?

 Elsewhere in the realm of great thoughts being thunk, the monetary policy committee - which has just seen Willem Buiter replaced by Steven Nickell - is likely to announce a second new appointment shortly, we understand.

Charles Goodhart's contract is up mid-year and Gordon Brown wants a fresh face to replace him. Given that Messrs Nickell, Buiter and Goodhart are all LSE-connected - as are MPC members Mervyn King and Sushil Wadhwani - the smart money has to be on another Houghton Streeter.

 In the same neck of the woods, the Bank of England is one outfit that takes seriously the need to rehabilitate offenders. Bent suits who chose not to comply with Britain's pre-1980 exchange control regime can sleep easily: the Bank confirmed this week that most case files have been destroyed and the few that survive are not publicly available. Gives a whole new meaning to "spent conviction", doesn't it?

 Meanwhile, Richard Ward, chief executive of the International Petroleum Exchange, heaved a sigh of relief this week when members voted unanimously to ditch mutual status and become a for-profit public company on April 3, ending six months of feuding and wrangling. Dr Ward has been getting in some experience for the change in his spare time, serving as governor of one of the few independent schools to operate on a for-profit rather than charitable basis. We'll spare the blushes of the academy in question in the light of a cryptic remark from Dr Ward on the trials and tribulations of governorship. Asked if it had been good training for life after April 3, he replied: "[It] was good training for life before April 3".

 Up the road from the exchange, there was much chortling as the Great Eastern Hotel next to Liverpool Street station reopened this week; the hostelry was long famous for its, er, short-term room-rental policy. Less well known is the Great Eastern's role in the fringe banking crisis of nearly 30 years ago. Triumph Investments, one of the fringier of the fringe outfits, held its annual meeting there in 1973. On the platform, the Triumph types were suitably triumphalist, but later boss-man

Tom Whyte was seen in one of the Eastern's telephone kiosks speaking nervously into the receiver and with a complexion to match his name.

At least one investor took this as a sign to bale out along with his sister, in the nick of time as it turned out. Those who have bet the farm on bubble.com must be hoping the Eastern's reopening isn't some sort of omen.

 It's been simply ages since we ran a decent comp, so to make up here's an open-ended prize offer, in which the number of bottles of Canard-Duch ne that we distribute is limited only by the quality of the entries (this is known as the "new paradigm" or, if you prefer, the bubbly-bubble).

The rules are simple. Submit the name of any company, product, "service" or economic agency every syllable of which is misleading/inaccurate/a lie. Examples: Long-Term Capital Management, Thameslink City Flyer, working families tax credit.

Our inspiration comes from Germany, home of the brown-envelope loving "Christian Democratic Union".

 Finally, on the subject of the above mentioned "City Flyer", there is a nasty shock in store for anyone perusing internet factsheet on the "flyer's" parent company, supplied by Railway Forum. Thameslink's franchise period, it states, is: "5112 years". No, no! As you were. The correct version is "5 years".

fields.headline: Senior service
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor looks at holidays for older travellers
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor looks at holidays for older travellers
fields.body:
Saga Holidays
Mention "older travellers" and the words Saga Holidays tend to spring to mind. The company undoubtedly leads the field for the over-50s, and its website is at pains to point out that there are virtually no single-room supplements. Saga organises a number of cruises and coach tours, but the range of destinations now includes Latin America, Africa and Borneo. Brochures can be ordered online.

Classic Ski
Mature but energetic travellers who want to revive or practise their skiing could visit Classic Ski. Most of the company's clients are between the ages of 45 and 70, and tuition is in groups of six. There are four Alpine resorts to choose from and insurance is included in the price of the holiday. Prices start at £798 per week for March, but you'll obviously have to move quickly.

Walking Safari Company
The Walking Safari Company organises short walks in the Sierras of Andalucia, Extremadura and the Lot valley, and its clientele tends to be aged between 40 and 80. Pack animals, such as mules and ponies, carry refreshments and bring up the rear of the walking party. The support vehicle transports weary walkers and luggage. Prices start at around £1,200 - more if you are travelling alone.

Walking Connection
Incidentally, would-be walkers who feel they need to limber up before a holiday should visit the Walking Connection for tips and online instruction. They are intended chiefly for serious and competitive walkers, but the advice is useful for anyone embarking on a journey on foot.

Lonely Planet's Thorn Tree
Lonely Planet's Thorn Tree is a vast online bulletin board that includes a section for older travellers. Here you'll find people interested in home exchanges, those looking for a travelling companion, and others recommending destinations and giving advice. Like any talkboard, it occasionally descends into trivia and hysteria, but the Tree is still well worth visiting.

Worldwise guide
If you are travelling alone and concerned about personal safety, the somewhat conservative Worldwise guide, supported by the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, has some blunt and generally pertinent advice.

Senior Search
A vast number of US websites are devoted to "seniors" travel; a disturbing number are of poor quality or major in the attractions of Florida. You may, however, find Senior Search's travel section useful.

webTitle: Overseas players should be over here

fields.headline: Overseas players should be over here
fields.trailText: It is an article of faith for English cricket that overseas players are bad for the game. This view must be exposed for the nonsense that it is.
fields.body:
It is an article of faith for English cricket that overseas players are bad for the game. This view must be exposed for the nonsense that it is. Regulations concerning overseas players should be liberalised.

The restriction of one overseas player per Championship match was introduced in the early eighties to facilitate the development of English players. To say that this initiative failed to usher in a period of prosperity for the national team is a whopping understatement.

The standard of county cricket is low, the gap between domestic and Test cricket wide. With England players increasingly absent from the county game, it will get wider. More overseas players are needed in each county team. Graeme Fowler wrote in February's WCM:

"County cricket is often described as soft. When Sylvester Clarke's name was on the scorecard it wasn't - it definitely wasn't."

May to September is no longer the exclusive preserve of the English game. Counties should be able to contract players for a few weeks only, so as to work around the international schedule. To make this possible they should be able to sign four overseas players a season with two allowed to play in any one game.

In the seventies the presence of several foreign players in a team did restrict opportunities for some players. Kent supporters will recall that Bob Woolmer had to score a Test century against Australia to earn promotion from the county's lower order. Now that there is greater freedom of movement, promising players are in a stronger position: if the Woolmers of today do not get a fair chance, they move on.

It is no coincidence that the richest crop of young players in the last 30 years - Gooch, Gatting, Gower and Botham - emerged together in the mid-seventies when the overseas influx was at its peak. They learned from Test players in their own teams and honed their skills against those in others.

But wouldn't the signing of foreigners reduce the money available to pay home talent? With luck, yes. The ambition-sapping comfort zone of fat contracts and company cars would shrink. Transfers of the superannuated would reduce too. Rob Bailey, Darren Bicknell, John Morris and Trevor Ward, to name four of the 30-somethings shifting bases this winter, will not play for England in the future. They are as a much a block to young talent as any overseas player, but lack the charisma or audience-appeal of the foreign stars.

Which brings us to another advantage. News that Brett Lee, Shaun Pollock or Sachin Tendulkar are playing at the local county ground for six weeks only should produce queues at the gates, provided that games are scheduled for times and places when the public want to watch.

This proposal would produce an instantaneous improvement in the standard of county cricket. Are the ECB bold enough to make the move?

Peter Hoare is a 40-year-old Kent supporter living in New Zealand

fields.headline: Soccer diary
fields.trailText: Becks not quite on the Wright track; Graham Taylor's familial defeats; Animal corner parts one and two.
fields.body:
You are a blond England star married to a pop star in an all-girl group. Your club thinks you are overdoing the off-field activities. Nothing's new.

This is what the 1950s magazine Football Parade wrote of the former England captain Billy Wright, who was married to Joy from the Beverley Sisters.

"He is a teetotaller, does not smoke, goes to bed early and lives modestly. Because he is such an ideal for youngsters to follow, Billy has many invitations to attend youth clubs, team dinners, the presentation of prizes and similar functions.

"He's such a good-natured chap that he cheerfully obliged until Wolves found that he was taking too much out of himself and asked him to call a halt."

 And you thought Peter Beardsley could only talk with his feet. Asked on Radio 4's Today programme whether England could beat Argentina, the former Newcastle player silenced his detractors by replying with a perfect example of poetic antithesis.

"If everyone plays as he can,

"There's no reason why we can't."

 Watford's Graham Taylor does not like losing, despite his habit of smiling each time the Premiership's bottom side suffer another defeat. In fact Taylor's true feelings on the subject of losing can be verified by the following snapshot from his private life.

"If I have five races with my five-year-old grand-daughter across my back lawn, I never let her win 5-0," the former England manager callously admits. "It's always 4-1.

"My excuse, when she gets upset, is that life is about winning and losing. But really that one win is for me.

"I get some stick from my wife for not letting our granddaughter win all five but I just can't do it."

By the way, Watford fans praying for divine intervention to arrest their season's decline might like to know that the Chicago Theological Seminary has a Graham Taylor Chapel (our Chicago correspondent reliably informs us).

 Of all the tributes paid to Sir Stanley Matthews this week, one in particular caught the eye, bearing in mind the current rumpus over ill-discipline. It came from Alan Mullery. "On or off the pitch, Stanley Matthews had class. People used to kick him to bits when they played against him and he just used to look at them."

 Animal Corner, part one: Atletico Madrid got themselves into a bit of a flap last Sunday when just before kick-off in the game against Espanyol flocks of pigeons landed on the pitch and pecked the goalmouths clean of most of the grass.

Faced with large patches of dirt, red-faced club officials admitted that the problem was nothing new. However, all efforts to discourage the birds had failed. The club's list of cunning plans included leaving pigeon carcasses on the pitch and introducing stadium cats.

"We are looking for another solution," said an Atletico official, obviously trying to claw back the initiative.

 Animal corner, part two: fans threw dead fish on to the pitch during Hungary's home game with Australia on Wednesday in protest at a cyanide spill by a part-Australian-owned company which killed wildlife in two Danube tributaries. We mention this because Hungary had a stinker too, losing 3-0.

 A reader suggests that if Gazza is going to play in Australia, he should join the Sydney Marconi Stallions - as he could do with a stable background.

webTitle: Thistle's Canadian strikes gold in LA

fields.headline: Thistle's Canadian strikes gold in LA
fields.trailText: Not content with defeating Celtic, Caledonian Thistle midfielder Richard Hastings has now inspired Canada's progress through the Concacaf Gold Cup to a final showdown on Sunday against Colombia..
fields.body:
Joy unconfined in the Scottish highlands is not often transposed to Los Angeles, but for Richard Hastings the two places have turned the past month into one of dramatic success.

Not content with performing heroics for Inverness Caledonian Thistle against Celtic in the Scottish Cup, the midfielder has now inspired Canada's impressive progress through the Concacaf Gold Cup. After playing in the City of Angels in yesterday's semi-final win against Trinidad and Tobago, he will return there for tomorrow's final against Colombia.

The only likeness Hastings may have spotted between the Caledonian Stadium and the 92,000-capacity Memorial Coliseum was that a crowd of only 2,800 was present for the 1-0 semi-final victory. More will be expected to watch Canada take on Faustino Asprilla and company, but the allure of the tournament for the American public evaporated when the hosts were knocked out in the quarter- finals, along with the holders and favourites Mexico.

British interest in the competition will continue to ride with Canada, whose squad also includes West Ham's goalkeeper Craig Forrest, Nottingham Forest's defender Jim Brennan and Paul Peschisolido of Fulham.

For Canada this is their finest achievement since qualifying for the 1986 World Cup. If only the rest of the world shared their enthusiasm.

webTitle: Tamworth to the Aztec via St Kitts

fields.headline: Tamworth to the Aztec via St Kitts
fields.standfirst: Striker Smith forsakes Dr Martens for place in sun
fields.trailText: Tamworth striker Gary Smith hopes to become the Doctor Martens League club's first international footballer when St Kitts play a two-leg World Cup zonal qualifier against the Turks and Caicos Islands next month.
fields.body:
Margate fans will hardly raise an eyebrow when they see that Gary Smith, a 33-year-old IT student with no league experience, is missing from this afternoon's opposition line-up. But the Tamworth striker has good reason not to be at Hartsdown Park for the Doctor Martens League fixture.

Instead Smith will be touching down in the Caribbean islands of St Kitts and Nevis to begin squad training with their national team. And next month, when St Kitts play a two-leg World Cup zonal qualifier against the Turks and Caicos Islands, he hopes to become Tamworth's first international footballer.

It does not even end there: if they can beat Turks and Caicos (and they should, given that both legs are in St Kitts as their opponents have no suitable facilities) Smith could then find himself playing against Mexico in the 100,000-capacity Aztec Stadium...

As the rain lashes down on the Lamb Ground, Tamworth's assistant manager Andy Dwyer says the club's new star may be late. "He doesn't like the rain, you see," Dwyer explains. "He's more used to palm trees, sun and bikinis nowadays."

Considering that Smith has visited St Kitts only twice, his first call-up came as a surprise. "A fax arrived from St Kitts a fortnight ago but I just thought one of the lads was taking the mickey," he says. "I was shocked. Me, at the ripe old age of 33, going to play international football?

A telephone call from the St Kitts and Nevis manager Cec Podd, who played 494 games for Bradford from 1970-1983, confirmed it was no wind-up.

"It's just unbelievable," says Smith. "I went over there at Christmas to visit my family for a couple of weeks. I needed to try and keep fit and one of the lads from the national side, Keith Gums [who was recently on trial at Hull], invited me to play in a National XI versus a Foreign XI game. I played with the foreigners and we beat them 6-2, and I scored twice.

"It was just a kickabout. There was no intention to impress anybody."

But impress he did, Podd taking him to one side after the match, although Smith had little idea as to the identity of the inquisitive gentleman.

"He kept saying to me, 'Stay fit, stay fit'," Smith says. "I just thought, 'All right mate, I'll stay fit. Calm down.' Then the fax arrived telling me I'm in the squad. It's unbelievable."

"It's very flattering for the lad," says the Tamworth manager Paul Hendrie - the father of Aston Villa and England's Lee - who has lost Smith's services for more than a month. "We'll miss him, but this is a once-in-a-lifetime chance, something he'll have forever."

The call-up has not guaranteed Smith a first-team place at Tamworth, though; he was on the bench for last Saturday's 1-1 draw with Burton Albion. "The gaffer's wrapping me in cotton wool," Smith says. "He'd hate for me to pick up an injury. Mind you, he can't leave an international out that much; if he does I'll be knocking on his door. How many of the others have got a full cap?"

Quite how the standard at the National Stadium in Basseterre on March 18 will compare with the Lamb remains to be seen. The Turks and Caicos are ranked 196 in the world, 57 below St Kitts and Nevis.

"I'd never heard of them," Smith says. "But I doubt they've heard of Tamworth either. I've been looking up on the internet to see how St Kitts rank against them and we're miles ahead; we've got to beat these guys. If we win we could play Jamaica, Mexico or USA. Can you imagine? Playing in the Aztec in front of 100,000 people; I think I'd just run out and collapse."

Smith knows little about his own side either: "Their home shirt is red and I'm pretty sure they play in green away. Hopefully I'll get a couple of strips to take home with me, although if I score I'll probably get carried away and throw them into the crowd. Apparently, because of the heat, they start training at seven in the morning. I'm a student; how am I going to get up for that?"

Smith met up with four other British-based St Kitts players at Gatwick yesterday, including the Millwall midfielder Bobby Bowry and Bury's Lutel James. A sixth player, the Oxford striker Kevin Francis, Smith's cousin, is still recovering from injury.

"I've had the wind-ups," Smith says. "The lads tell people not to talk to me because I'm an international, but everyone's been great. The manager's chuffed to bits - he's never coached an international before - and my mum's so proud. To get this chance at this age is a great honour."

It does not even end there: if they can beat Turks and Caicos (and they should, given that both legs are in St Kitts as their opponents have no suitable facilities) Smith could then find himself playing against Mexico in the 100,000-capacity Aztec Stadium... As the rain lashes down on the Lamb Ground, Tamworth's assistant manager Andy Dwyer says the club's new star may be late. "He doesn't like the rain, you see," Dwyer explains. "He's more used to palm trees, sun and bikinis nowadays." Considering that Smith has visited St Kitts only twice, his first call-up came as a surprise. "A fax arrived from St Kitts a fortnight ago but I just thought one of the lads was taking the mickey," he says. "I was shocked. Me, at the ripe old age of 33, going to play international football? A telephone call from the St Kitts and Nevis manager Cec Podd, who played 494 games for Bradford from 1970-1983, confirmed it was no wind-up. "It's just unbelievable," says Smith. "I went over there at Christmas to visit my family for a couple of weeks. I needed to try and keep fit and one of the lads from the national side, Keith Gums [who was recently on trial at Hull], invited me to play in a National XI versus a Foreign XI game. I played with the foreigners and we beat them 6-2, and I scored twice. "It was just a kickabout. There was no intention to impress anybody." But impress he did, Podd taking him to one side after the match, although Smith had little idea as to the identity of the inquisitive gentleman. "He kept saying to me, 'Stay fit, stay fit'," Smith says. "I just thought, 'All right mate, I'll stay fit. Calm down.' Then the fax arrived telling me I'm in the squad. It's unbelievable." "It's very flattering for the lad," says the Tamworth manager Paul Hendrie - the father of Aston Villa and England's Lee - who has lost Smith's services for more than a month. "We'll miss him, but this is a once-in-a-lifetime chance, something he'll have forever." The call-up has not guaranteed Smith a first-team place at Tamworth, though; he was on the bench for last Saturday's 1-1 draw with Burton Albion. "The gaffer's wrapping me in cotton wool," Smith says. "He'd hate for me to pick up an injury. Mind you, he can't leave an international out that much; if he does I'll be knocking on his door. How many of the others have got a full cap?" Quite how the standard at the National Stadium in Basseterre on March 18 will compare with the Lamb remains to be seen. The Turks and Caicos are ranked 196 in the world, 57 below St Kitts and Nevis. "I'd never heard of them," Smith says. "But I doubt they've heard of Tamworth either. I've been looking up on the internet to see how St Kitts rank against them and we're miles ahead; we've got to beat these guys. If we win we could play Jamaica, Mexico or USA. Can you imagine? Playing in the Aztec in front of 100,000 people; I think I'd just run out and collapse." Smith knows little about his own side either: "Their home shirt is red and I'm pretty sure they play in green away. Hopefully I'll get a couple of strips to take home with me, although if I score I'll probably get carried away and throw them into the crowd. Apparently, because of the heat, they start training at seven in the morning. I'm a student; how am I going to get up for that?" Smith met up with four other British-based St Kitts players at Gatwick yesterday, including the Millwall midfielder Bobby Bowry and Bury's Lutel James. A sixth player, the Oxford striker Kevin Francis, Smith's cousin, is still recovering from injury. "I've had the wind-ups," Smith says. "The lads tell people not to talk to me because I'm an international, but everyone's been great. The manager's chuffed to bits - he's never coached an international before - and my mum's so proud. To get this chance at this age is a great honour."

fields.headline: Hammam brings down curtain
fields.standfirst:
The Governor does the unthinkable and calls time at Wimbledon
The sayings of Sam
fields.trailText: The Governor does the unthinkable and calls time at Wimbledon by selling his 20% share in the club to the Norwegian businessman Bjorn Rune Gjelsten.
fields.body:
It was a fitting way for a remarkable era to end. Once Sam Hammam had announced yesterday morning that he was selling his 20% share in Wimbledon to the Norwegian businessman Bjorn Rune Gjelsten, he was given a send-off neither he nor his dry-cleaner will forget in a hurry.

Whipped off his feet by a clutch of players at the club's training ground, Hammam was dumped in a puddle of Lake Superior proportions. Before wriggling out he had water kicked over his suit and in his face. The last remaining member of the original Crazy Gang could hardly have scripted it better.

Not that it was all fun and games. Hammam looked close to tears as he explained why he was relinquishing control after more than 22 years. His relationship with the Norwegian businessmen who took a ma jority stake in 1997 had become increasingly fraught. Finally, he acknowledged it was unworkable.

"The lack of harmony was like a cancer eating into the club," he said. "Naturally I am not happy this is happening. I believe like John Wayne said in one of his movies 'A man's gotta do what a man's gotta do' and I'm doing that. I am not bitter, just stunned."

Hammam will stay on as a director and will advise Gjelsten, the new chairman, during the period of transition. But his power, his real involvement with the club he hauled from non-League football to the top flight is gone.

The "Governor" had high hopes when he sold 80% of Wimbledon to Gjelsten and Kjell-Inge Rokke for an estimated £30m. There was talk of big investment, of taking the Premiership side to unprecedented heights.

"Unfortunately," Hammam said, "things did not work out like the brochure promised. Kjell became entangled in many things and was unable to give any love or attention to Wimbledon. In two years and eight months he was able to attend only one home game.

"Bjorn was far too busy running the empire and could only give us attention in dribs and drabs, mainly over the phone. We had to do something. A lot of options were discussed but we could not find a way through."

Hammam, frustrated by a chronic lack of communication and unable to run affairs as he wished, concluded his departure was the best solution. For him Wimbledon was a love affair; for Rokke it seemed to be a business. The most public fall-out came in December when Hammam refused to sell players to meet a short-term deficit of around £3m and Rokke installed a chief executive, to overhaul the running of the club.

Hammam hinted at a deep mistrust when he said Gjelsten, who took a stake as part of the original deal but sold it to Rokke, was "the only one who can convince Kjell to do things that he might not be comfortable doing otherwise". They are friends and business partners. Gjelsten, unlike Rokke, is a football man.

And so Hammam has sold out for an estimated £1m. "Peanuts," was how he described it, though he has not done badly from an initial investment of around £40,000.

The suddenness of Hammam's departure is appropriate given the way he arrived. In 1977 he sent his wife from civil war-ravaged Lebanon to London to give birth and he was asked on a visit to Wimbledon (he was a fan of the tennis) to help the local football club. Despite not knowing a goalline from a clothes line, he agreed. That was Wimbledon's first year in the Football League. By 1986 they were in the top flight.

The rise he oversaw on meagre resources will surely never be repeated. Even without a ground, Wimbledon have continued to prosper and Hammam has been central to it all, helping to foster the togetherness, showing his love on the touchline. "Wimbledon is my heroin," he once said.

At times the man from the Lebanese mountain village of Dhourshweir seems to be on something. He would get drunk with the players, sit in on team talks, put a clause in Bobby Gould's contract allowing him to change the team up to 45 minutes before kick-off, and even scribbled grafitti on the dressing-room wall at West Ham to gee up his players. They won.

"He is unique," said the captain Robbie Earle. "When I came to meet him and discuss a move from Port Vale he picked me up at Euston and went to his house. He brought me into the study, locked the door and put the key down his pants. Then he said to me I could have the key and leave but if I did we would never speak again. So I decided to sign and that sums up Sam perfectly."

No one could doubt Hammam's commitment to Wimbledon. "I'd rather die and have vultures eat my inside than merge with Crystal Palace," he insisted in 1992.

"It's a sad day and a big shock for us all," Earle said. "Everybody had a personal relationship with him. There is apprehension among the players. We all know we are at a crossroads. The new owners have made the right noises but it is their actions that will show us what they want to do."

Gjelsten insisted Wimbledon had nothing to worry about at a club where another Norwegian, Egil Olsen, was installed as manager last June. No, players would not be sold. Yes, a new stadium was a priority. Yes, the club would be treated as a passion not a business. "Sam knows we will invest and do the right things," he said. "I really hope I can convince Sam to come with us."

What Rokke and Gjelsten have achieved at Molde bodes well. The Norwegian club play at a new ground and reached this season's Champions League. But Hammam, "the mother and father of Wimbledon", will be missed.

Sir Alex Ferguson has assured David Beckham he will be recalled to the Manchester United side to face Wimbledon at Selhurst Park today if he overcomes an ankle injury sustained in England's game against Argentina.

fields.headline: Di Canio and Alcock reunion
fields.trailText: It is 17 months since Paul di Canio's push on Paul Alcock landed him with a record 11-match ban and a £10,000 fine. Today they come face to face again when West Ham take on Everton.
fields.body:
Paolo di Canio will be seen on televisions across the land today advertising a sportswear company with the logo Push Yourself. It is apt, then, that the Italian's performance on the pitch, should he recover from a hamstring injury, will be refereed by Paul Alcock.

It is 17 months since his push on Alcock landed him with a record 11-match ban and a £10,000 fine, and West Ham's match against Everton promises to be the first time since then that the pair share the same piece of turf. Di Canio, though, has not trained for two days and is doubtful.

He has been anxious to play down the incident and says he has made his peace with Alcock. "There is no ill-feeling between us any more. We have put that in the past and shaken hands on it. As far as I am concerned that is history now."

Another feud that could be reignited is at Selhurst Park where Manchester United will be refereed by David Elleray for the first time since the chairman Martin Edwards accused him of favouring Arsenal and Chelsea in last season's championship race. Reconciliation, if there has been any, has been kept private.

Elleray sent off Denis Irwin and awarded Liverpool a debatable penalty at Anfield in a 2-2 draw in May and Edwards said later: "If Arsenal or Chelsea win the Premiership this season by either one or two points, I trust they will strike a special commemorative medal for Mr Elleray because he will have done it for them."

A friendlier relationship will be renewed at Highbury where Arsène Wenger comes up against Glenn Hoddle, a player at Monaco when the Frenchman was in charge. Hoddle, now manager of Southampton, was encouraged to become a coach by Wenger.

"When he came from Tottenham to Monaco as a player it was easy to see how deeply he thought about the game," said Wenger. "I thought he was a good choice for the England manager's job, even though he was still quite young."

Coventry completed a hat-trick of signings yesterday, buying Colin Hendry from Rangers for about £800,000 and the Peruvian striker and Israel Zuniga from Melgar for the same fee. In addition the Swedish goalkeeper Magnus Hedman has signed a new four-year deal.

fields.headline: Advocaat bites back
fields.trailText: Rangers play at Dundee tomorrow night but their manager Dick Advocaat is as much concerned about this year's Olympics in Sydney as he is about the match at Dens Park.
fields.body:
Rangers play at Dundee tomorrow night but their manager Dick Advocaat is as much concerned about this year's Olympics in Sydney as he is about the match at Dens Park.

Advocaat is bothered that foreign players are disappearing to compete for their national teams, which he sees as biting the hand that feeds them. His mood has not been lightened by news that the International Olympic Committee president Juan Samaranch and Fifa are to meet to discuss a rule change so that the under-23 sides who currently play in the Olympics can be reinforced by as many as seven over-age players

That would mean Advocaat losing the services of the Australian defenders Craig Moore and Tony Vidmar this autumn at a time when Rangers will be hoping to challenge in the Champions League. Holland's Giovanni van Bronckhorst and the United States' Claudio Reyna might also be affected.

"That could mean us losing games and I would be getting my own head hammered," Advocaat said. "The clubs pay their wages but the national associations seem to decide when they play for us."

Rangers have lost Reyna for the Gold Cup, having already been without the Australians this year. Advocaat admits he would be safer buying Europeans, but his resentment is part of a growing rift between clubs and countries and not just in Scotland.

Moore is suspended for tomorrow's match, the captain Lorenzo Amoruso is still not fit and though Rangers have Turkey's Kerimoglu Tugay, the disaffected Italian Marco Negri and Chile's Sebastian Rozental to call on, even their resources are looking stretched for a notoriously awkward fixture.

Dundee for their part cannot win on their own ground and are fast slipping into the relegation mire, with Kilmarnock and Aberdeen beginning to show some form. Their mood will hardly be lightened by the remarks of their director Peter Marr about the future of their manager Jocky Scott, whose contract expires this summer.

"Jocky's got to work with what he's got, but he has been aware of that for some time," Marr said. At least it makes a change from the usual club endorsements that tend to lead to the handing over of a P45.

fields.headline: Man for all seasons
fields.trailText: The legend of Matthews was born through a combination of mystique and longevity. For the majority of fans he was merely an image in the mind's eye... a personal first impression was disappointing.
fields.body:
News of the death of Sir Stanley Matthews filtered through on Wednesday night just as Wembley was debating the wisdom of England using David Beckham, one of the most gifted crossers of a ball from the right flank in the modern game, in a central role.

English football could never make up its mind about the worth of the winger purely as a provider. Even when Matthews was in his post-war prime he was apt to be left out of the national team on the ground that his dribbling skills held up the play.

Perhaps it should be explained that in those days the England team was selected by a committee of Football Association councillors. Imagine the present side being picked by the likes of Ken Bates and Doug Ellis and you get the picture.

Matthews or Tom Finney: the argument split saloon bars and playgrounds alike, although the statistics suggest that England often did better when both were included, one for his service, the other for that plus a greater inclination to cut in and score from wide positions. Nowadays anyone in charge of the national squad would be grateful for such a choice.

When Alf Ramsey won the 1966 World Cup after moving Bobby Charlton, a fast but fitful outside-left, into the middle to play behind the front runners, the romantic age of the winger seemed to be over.

Yet spectators will always thrill to the sight of the sort of wing play which takes opponents on for speed or skill; witness Ryan Giggs's dash through the Arsenal defence in last season's FA Cup semi-finals, or David Ginola's frequent teasing of opposing full-backs at Tottenham.

The legend of Matthews was born through a combination of mystique and longevity. The bulk of his playing career was recorded by newpapers, radio commentaries and cinema newsreels. Television discovered him in the FA Cup finals of 1948, 1951 and, famously, 1953 but without action replays.

For the majority of fans Matthews was merely an image in the mind's eye. Only those living near a First Division ground had a chance of seeing him in the flesh on a regular basis, and that was only once a season unless Blackpool made another visit in the FA Cup. Much of his fame, then, was based on fleeting glimpses. No wonder the Blackpool team of that era could command average away gates of 46,000.

A personal first impression of Matthews was disappointing. The Cup final of 1953 has become synonymous with his name but until the second half he was largely a peripheral figure and had to drift towards the middle to get into the game.

It was only when Ernie Taylor began fully to exploit the effect of the early injury to Eric Bell, which had forced the Bolton Wanderers left-half to hobble through the rest of the match as a token left-winger (despite which he managed to head his team into a 3-1 lead), that Matthews came into his own.

Supplied by Taylor's passes, he destroyed a tiring Bolton defence, Stan Mortensen completed a hat-trick, Bill Perry turned a last, low cross from Matthews into the net and Blackpool's 4-3 victory became part of football history.

In truth it had been a scrappy match with comically bad goalkeeping and frequent stoppages for injuries. But Matthews was chaired off the pitch after the final whistle to receive his long-delayed cup-winner's medal and had certainly played a significant part in turning the game around.

Yet the greater heroes that afternoon were Mortensen and Harold Hassall, Bolton's inside-left, who had played superbly in trying to cover for Bell as well as attending to his normal duties.

But when the legend becomes fact, print the legend. Nobody begrudged Matthews the crowning moment of his career.

Yes, he was a role model before anyone began to talk seriously about role models. Modern football attitudes could be said to have started at the moment when, during a Blackpool training session, Matthews ordered a teenaged Alan Ball to pass to his feet and was told in no uncertain terms that he had to run after it.

Matthews was never booked but his career did have its down side. One of three transfer requests he made during his first spell with Stoke City followed a refusal to play in the reserves after an injury.

When he did move to Blackpool it was after a row with the Stoke manager Bob McGrory, who had dropped him.

In this respect, then, Matthews was little different from most other leading footballers of his time. It was just that his time seemed likely to go on for ever, and it was only after he retired that his life took a sudden and bizarre turn.

The story of how Matthews, as manager of Port Vale, travelled to Prague to discuss a boot sponsorship, fell in love with an attractive Czechoslovak whom he later married, became caught up in the Soviet invasion and fled to Malta to avoid the paparazzi makes a slightly more compelling read than the dressing habits of the Beckhams.

The bow-legged, baggy-shorted figure hovering over the ball may belong to a distant age but Stan the man would not be out of place now, although he would have to go a little further afield than Malta to escape the media mob.

It was only when Ernie Taylor began fully to exploit the effect of the early injury to Eric Bell, which had forced the Bolton Wanderers left-half to hobble through the rest of the match as a token left-winger (despite which he managed to head his team into a 3-1 lead), that Matthews came into his own. Supplied by Taylor's passes, he destroyed a tiring Bolton defence, Stan Mortensen completed a hat-trick, Bill Perry turned a last, low cross from Matthews into the net and Blackpool's 4-3 victory became part of football history. In truth it had been a scrappy match with comically bad goalkeeping and frequent stoppages for injuries. But Matthews was chaired off the pitch after the final whistle to receive his long-delayed cup-winner's medal and had certainly played a significant part in turning the game around. Yet the greater heroes that afternoon were Mortensen and Harold Hassall, Bolton's inside-left, who had played superbly in trying to cover for Bell as well as attending to his normal duties. But when the legend becomes fact, print the legend. Nobody begrudged Matthews the crowning moment of his career. Yes, he was a role model before anyone began to talk seriously about role models. Modern football attitudes could be said to have started at the moment when, during a Blackpool training session, Matthews ordered a teenaged Alan Ball to pass to his feet and was told in no uncertain terms that he had to run after it. Matthews was never booked but his career did have its down side. One of three transfer requests he made during his first spell with Stoke City followed a refusal to play in the reserves after an injury. When he did move to Blackpool it was after a row with the Stoke manager Bob McGrory, who had dropped him. In this respect, then, Matthews was little different from most other leading footballers of his time. It was just that his time seemed likely to go on for ever, and it was only after he retired that his life took a sudden and bizarre turn. The story of how Matthews, as manager of Port Vale, travelled to Prague to discuss a boot sponsorship, fell in love with an attractive Czechoslovak whom he later married, became caught up in the Soviet invasion and fled to Malta to avoid the paparazzi makes a slightly more compelling read than the dressing habits of the Beckhams. The bow-legged, baggy-shorted figure hovering over the ball may belong to a distant age but Stan the man would not be out of place now, although he would have to go a little further afield than Malta to escape the media mob.

webTitle: Supremo Edmonds denies rift with MCC

fields.headline: Supremo Edmonds denies rift with MCC
fields.standfirst: Middlesex chairman insists his county's position is safe
fields.trailText: Frank Keating meets poacher turned gamekeeper Phil Edmonds, the vibrant chairman of Middlesex CCC.
fields.body:
Phil Edmonds is the most unlikely poacher turned gamekeeper, but he has had little time to argue with that tag as the vibrant chairman of Middlesex CCC.

He has not had an easy baptism in the post. There have been no end of planted leaks and rumours around London's St John's Wood that the MCC, cash-strapped and needing more big-money attractions, would like to be rid of its county tenants.

"Totally malicious twaddle," says Edmonds. "Don't believe a word of such balderdash. MCC and Middlesex continue to have a perfectly harmonious relationship. We have had one for 137 years and it is going to continue into the distant future."

He agrees that the two clubs with the shared home have had recent strains and that various matters "might seem to be coming to a head this spring". That is because of Lord's busier-than-usual international schedule, with Tests against West Indies and Zimbabwe plus the triangular tournament of one-day games - "on top of which four pitches are being dug up and relaid.

"If big cup finals and international matches are going to represent increasingly lucrative life-blood for Lord's and the MCC, then Middlesex fully understand that. But our tenancy agreement has been on their table for months and we really need to know where we stand.

"All we are very keen on now is a firm guarantee of the minimum of first-class matches we will be playing at HQ: say six out of eight. Not too much to ask, is it? Meanwhile, if you see any headline, 'MCC to throw Middlesex out of Lord's', it's complete balls."

It is hard to believe that the handsome, upright fellow will be 50 this time next year. Edmonds retains the companionable edge and agreeable belligerence he always had when he was England's finest - if unfulfilled - left-arm spin bowler in ages. In conversation he can still pounce on a point as killingly as he would a close-in catch.

He rejects the poacher-gamekeeper cliche, but his defence is speckled with regular and humorous chortles as if the "singular man" - the title of his cricketing biography - himself still can't quite believe this conversion to orthodoxy.

"It's rubbish. I've always been an establishment boy, haven't I? Only when you balk at the establishment when it might be behaving stupidly does it turn round and say, 'Oh, take no notice of him, he's always been a rebel'."

He took 125 Test and 1,242 first-class wickets but his combative colonial nature - he was brought up in Zambia - and appealingly laconic swagger made too many blue blazers wary, else he would surely have captained both England and Middlesex.

Expensively suited City high-flyers, however, relish such qualities and he has fashioned a highly successful business career. His writer-wife Frances sighs: "He's in the City all day and, can you believe, now it's Middlesex all night."

He admits: "I might not have before, but I must say I now have the highest admiration for anybody involved in sports committee work. It takes up such an extraordinary amount of time. The only reward is to know a crucial job is being done with all reasonable competence. And in my case - and I know this is going to sound frightfully naff to you or anyone who thought they knew me - I had such a rich enjoyment out of cricket that I felt really committed about trying to put something back."

He had little time to watch England's South African series, but he is quick to the defence of his county's players. "It seemed a foolhardy expedition from the start when they didn't even take such a star-quality batsman as Mark [Ramprakash] - my God, in, out, in, out, the fellow has been treated abominably since his very first Test series... and as for Philip Tufnell, well, was someone out there telling Tuffers just to doddle them down solely for containment? He's an attacking bowler." Only for the new committeeman to rein himself back: "Mind you, I hesitate to criticise selectors, it's a mighty difficult job."

For both Middlesex and England, his spats with his captain Mike Brearley amused the cricket world. "Dear old Brears... do you know, as soon as you stop playing and step into the real world you realise how petty and small-minded we all were about our dressing-room snubs and grievances and rivalries."

Again a pause, the smile thins and the bright-eyed gaze narrows in recall: "Mind you, it does still bug me when I'd be going to the wicket at No7 or 8 and this guy Brears, who'd fannied around and blocked for just 70 in 70 overs, meets you at the crease and orders, 'Quick runs, Phil, we need quick runs and a few bonus points'; ie give my wicket away pronto. What a nerve. And sometimes I still wake up and think, 'That wasn't effing fair.' OK, I suppose it's always been a fundamental flaw in my character, this belief in fairness and justice all round."

He is laughing again. "Certainly as a committeeman, fairness and justice is going to be the absolute basic tenet."

fields.headline: Captaincy chaos as Lara abdicates
fields.standfirst: West Indies left in limbo as their talisman bows to his team's failures
fields.trailText: The man who would be king of the Caribbean has abdicated his throne. Brian Lara's resignation yesterday, after 18 matches as captain, has thrown West Indies further into turmoil three weeks before they begin an intensive period of Test cricket that sees home series against Zimbabwe and Pakistan followed by a five-match series in England this summer.
fields.body:
The man who would be king of the Caribbean has abdicated his throne. Brian Lara's resignation yesterday, after 18 matches as captain, has thrown West Indies further into turmoil three weeks before they begin an intensive period of Test cricket that sees home series against Zimbabwe and Pakistan followed by a five-match series in England this summer.

Captaincy, even for the game's geniuses, is clearly a precarious business: on Wed-nesday Sachin Tendulkar stood down from leading the Indian side.

Although the West Indies Cricket Board will want to be quick to appoint a successor when they meet on March 7, in order to try to rekindle some spark in a team that has suffered arguably the worst run in its history, there is no obvious, let alone outstanding, candidate.

It is not even clear whether Lara, ranked as one of the top three batsmen in the world, still has the desire to continue his international career or whether he will retire to Lara Towers, the pink palace in the centre of Port of Spain given to him by a grateful and ecstatic Trinidad and Tobago nation following his Test record 375 against England, to ponder his future. Carnival time it may be in Trinidad but this will give no cause for celebration.

Lara tendered his resignation in a letter to the WICB, a document that appears to have been drawn up by a government quango. "After two years," he says, "the moderate success and devastating failure that has engulfed West Indies cricket have brought me to the realisation that there is a need for me to withdraw from my present leadership position." In other words, "we're useless and I quit."

In response the board president Pat Rousseau thanked Lara for his efforts during a difficult time for West Indies cricket. "I know he has made a very hard decision," Rousseau said yesterday "and I appeal to the public to give him the total support that the WICB will be giving him as he continues his career."

In truth, Lara had given himself little option but to stand down. Ever since he first came to prominence as a batsman, with his debut at 21 in Lahore's Gaddafi Stadium in December 1990, and his first century, the fantastic 277 in Sydney two years later, he had been regarded as heir apparent to the captaincy, and he led Trinidad, if unsuccessfully, at an early age.

He might have slotted seamlessly into the position in any case had he not pursued the role so relentlessly, conducting an almost presidential campaign and undermining, so it was said at the time, both Richie Richardson and his successor Courtney Walsh.

In 1996-97 he took over the captaincy for one match with Walsh injured but was given the role permanently for the home series against England in 1998, a move seen in many quarters as a snub to Walsh and pandering to Lara's ego. But, having won his first match, he took the series against England 3-1.

Since then, however, West Indies cricket has had some awful times. The following winter the tour to South Africa was preceded by acrimonious arguments between players and board over pay and conditions, with Lara first sacked then reinstated and the team subsequently losing all of the five Tests and six of the seven one-day internationals.

Then, after an uplifting drawn series at home to Australia, which saw Lara play two of the greatest innings the game has seen to win matches against the odds in Jamaica and Barbados, came the nadir at the end of last year when they lost both Tests to New Zealand as well as all five one- day internationals. After one such defeat Lara was observed close to tears as he talked about "trying to salvage a legacy".

No one could point a finger at Lara's personal performance as captain - in his 18 matches in charge he has averaged 50.13 against a career average of 51.6 and against Australia produced innings of 213, 153 not out and 100 in successive matches. But, despite a lack of quality cricketers and in particular, the inevitable ageing of Walsh and Curtly Ambrose, something had to give - and it has been the captain.

To replace him now will be difficult: there really is no one else. Current captains in the region include Shivnarine Chanderpaul (Guyana), Stuart Williams (Leewards) and Philo Wallace (Barbados) but none is assured of his place in the team.

Jimmy Adams, the stalwart Jamaican, might do a job but his form is patchy, and the one person who might have taken on the role, Lara's great friend Carl Hooper, suddenly retired from international cricket after the Australia series, and has not yet been persuaded to return. Maybe the time is right to make him an offer. If not, Walsh, who is approaching a world record number of Test wickets, might find himself back in the hot seat.

England must beware of the complacency that can arise in seeing a side on its uppers, not least because they are not so far from that position themselves. Yesterday, the England coach Duncan Fletcher reinforced the idea that his charges will still have their work cut out this summer if they are to beat West Indies.

"Whoever their captain is," he said, "it would be a big, big mistake to think they are a weak side. Their recent form is obviously not as good as we have come to expect but they are still a strong cricketing side and we are in for another demanding series."

Bangladesh are likely to be granted Test match status at the annual meeting of the International Cricket Council in London in June. It would make Bangladesh the 10th Test-playing nation.

webTitle: Donald and Pollock turn tables on India

fields.headline: Donald and Pollock turn tables on India
fields.standfirst: Second day
fields.trailText: Allan Donald and Shaun Pollock got South Africa out of trouble in the first Test in Bombay yesterday after India, who had allowed the tourists' bats men to reach 90 without loss in their first innings, took all 10 of their wickets for only 86 more runs.
fields.body:
Allan Donald and Shaun Pollock got South Africa out of trouble in the first Test in Bombay yesterday after India, who had allowed the tourists' bats men to reach 90 without loss in their first innings, took all 10 of their wickets for only 86 more runs.

At stumps on the second day India were 75 for five in their second innings, an overall lead of 124, with Pollock and Donald taking two wickets apiece. Donald now has 294 Test wickets. But yesterday's crucial one, that of Sachin Tendulkar, was taken by Hansie Cronje.

At one stage in their second innings India were 24 for three but Rahul Dravid and Sourav Ganguly put on 49 for the fourth wicket. The latter fell for 31 but Dravid, who blocked the last 5 overs with Anil Kumble, finished undefeated on 27.

In South Africa's innings it was Tendulkar who made the breakthrough, having Herschelle Gibbs taken for 47. Gary Kirsten, with 50, and Lance Klusener, 33, were their only other significant contributors.

webTitle: Shearer to quit internationals after Euro 2000

fields.headline: Shearer to quit internationals after Euro 2000
fields.trailText: England captain Alan Shearer announced tonight that he plans to end his international career after Euro 2000.
fields.body:
England captain Alan Shearer announced tonight that he plans to end his international career after Euro 2000.

The 29-year-old striker, who has scored 28 goals in 57 games for his country, is planning to concentrate his efforts on giving Newcastle "full value for money".

Shearer announced his decision to England manager Kevin Keegan decision before England's goalless draw against Argentina at Wembley on Wednesday night, and said this evening: "I would like to play, if selected, in Euro 2000 and then bow out so that the manager has time to plan effectively for the 2002 World Cup."

Shearer, explaining his decision: "I want everyone to understand that I am not walking away from a challenge - I am hugely patriotic and my time as England captain has made me incredibly proud.

"However, I realise that if I want to give Newcastle value for money in the remaining four years of my contract with them, I will need to pace myself a bit more than I am able to do at the moment.

Keegan revealed that he had attempted to persuade Shearer to change his mind but insisted that "everyone should respect his decision - I certainly do.

"Of course I was very sad and I tried to persuade him to change his mind," said the England coach.

"But I know that what makes Alan Shearer special is that he is his own man. I'm happy for him because it's what he wants.

Newcastle boss Robson added: "This is a decision made entirely by Alan and he had made that decision in the best interests of himself. We support him in whatever decision he makes."

Football Association executive director David Davies admitted that Shearer's decision had come as a "surprise" and declared: "Alan Shearer is already in the record books as one of England's great goalscorers.

"For a top professional with such a high profile, knowing the right moment to step back has to be immensely difficult. He will want to end his England career with a flourish and that has to be good news for our prospects at Euro 2000."

I'm happy for him because it's what he wants. Newcastle boss Robson added: "This is a decision made entirely by Alan and he had made that decision in the best interests of himself. We support him in whatever decision he makes." Football Association executive director David Davies admitted that Shearer's decision had come as a "surprise" and declared: "Alan Shearer is already in the record books as one of England's great goalscorers. "For a top professional with such a high profile, knowing the right moment to step back has to be immensely difficult. He will want to end his England career with a flourish and that has to be good news for our prospects at Euro 2000."

webTitle: Mark Foster: Credit card | Pillow | Good-luck stone

fields.headline: Mark Foster never travels without...
fields.trailText: Credit card | Pillow | Good-luck stone
fields.body:
A necessity: My credit card. Then no matter what I forget - from goggles to a ticket home - I can replace it, plus do whatever I want while I'm away.

A luxury: My pillow. I need to have a good night's sleep the night before a race and some hotels have terribly uncomfortable pillows.

A good-luck charm: I used to have a teddy bear, but I don't travel with that any more! I have a good-luck stone with a whale carved into it to signify power. I always keep it in my ruck- sack along with a shark's tooth - both of which were given to me by friends.

If only: I wish swimming received more funding. In Australia, swimming is like football here in the UK - an extremely high-profile sport attracting a great deal of sponsorship. I would like to find a sponsor to make training and competing abroad far easier.

 Mark Foster is the fastest swimmer in the world and holds the world record in the 50 metres freestyle (shortcourse). His next major competitions include the World Championships in Athens, March 16-19, followed by the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games in September. He intends to come back with a gold medal around his neck.

fields.headline: Restricted view
fields.standfirst: The London Eye is open to all, but what does the city look like like from the top of Centrepoint or Canary Wharf?  Nigel Fountain fails to find out
fields.trailText: The London Eye is open to all, but what does the city look like like from the top of Centrepoint or Canary Wharf? Nigel Fountain fails to find out.
fields.body:
There is security in going round and round. You do at least know where you will end up. Thus with Millennium Wheels, so too with new ages and alibis.

The London Evening Standard had a spectacular front page on the British Airways London Eye, taken from 450ft as it finally began to turn, offering the "greatest view in London". The experience, the Standard and other papers - this one included - proclaimed, was spectacular. Even "hardened Fleet Street journalists burst into spontaneous applause". But such behaviour among such people is unsettling: one should watch out for applauding journalists. And then there was something else, a realisation that I had been an onlooker at this media circus before.

Last time, October 1965, the star of the show that went round and round - or at least part of it did - was even higher above London, 620ft. While Big Ben had represented "the fussy grandeur of the Gothic revival that epitomised the Victorian imperial affluence, built on the foundation of the first industrial revolution", as the postmaster-general, a Mr Anthony Wedgwood Benn, had pithily proclaimed at the opening, "the Post Office tower, lean, practical and futuristic, symbolises the technical and architectural skill of this new age."

Good old new ages, where would we be without them? At the time, Tony Benn - as he became when he, too, opted to be lean, practical and futuristic - reckoned a new definition of a Cockney would be someone born within sight of the tower.

In May 1965, its viewing gallery and revolving restaurant opened to the public. Sixteen months later, the tower had entertained 500,000 visitors. Five years after that, someone planted a bomb on the 31st floor. The gallery closed. In 1980, 1.6 million diners later, the revolving restaurant closed. The lifts were in need of renewal, said the Post Office.

As for public access, key words were spun round instead: studies to be conducted, security needs, not ruling things out. Soon after, British Telecom was flogged off, and that was that.

Go along to the BT Tower as it now is and you will be told that admission to its heights is by invitation only. Go a few rounds with BT's redoubtable PRs and security will be mentioned; you will be told how it is an operational building, a vital part of the network, and that things have changed over 30 years.

How true. A virtue of the London Eye is, whether one enthuses or rages about its effect on the skyline, the wheel was built specifically for public access. A vice of the capital's tall buildings - the Shell, NatWest, Millbank towers, Centrepoint, Canary Wharf - I decided, was the assumption by conglomerates that having stuck up, purchased or bailed out bloody great towers around the metropolis, the public's sole right is to stand in their shad ows and stare, cor blimeying, muttering "that's a good 'un and no mistake", and expressing gratitude to the great and good who cast the shadow upon them.

Brooding on this, I considered New York's public-access glories: the World Trade Center, the Empire State and the RCA Building at the Rockefeller Center. The bum's rush has set in there too, with the top of the RCA now closed, leaving the World Trade - controlled by the Port Authority - and the world's greatest skyscraper, the Empire State, as surviving stairways, or elevators to the stars. "These days, most public buildings in New York are security guarded," pointed out a British Land spokesperson whom I had contacted about Euston Tower.

Like many representatives of the villainous conglomerates, he was happy to explain the situation, sometimes, somewhat irritatingly, with cogent arguments. Euston Tower was too small for access, he said, and over at Liverpool Street's Broadgate Centre - not a high rise - British Land had provided public space.

The NatWest Tower, meanwhile, is no more. Now renamed Tower 42, its current owner, Greycoat, says it has introduced a "hotel concept", together with an upmarket café on the ground floor and a Roux restaurant on the 24th. There are publics, and publics. Dire from a distance, Tower 42 looks spectacular once one is kneeling underneath in proper cor-blimeying mode.

Canary Wharf's chief executive, George Iacobescu, waxed lyrical about public access: the top of the tower had been open for organised groups, and of course, he went on meaningfully, the newspapers based in the tower were very hot on security.

Early on a glittering Saturday morning in the City, I stood by London's greatest, albeit shortest, high rise: Sir Christopher Wren's Monument to the 1666 Great Fire (public access for three centuries). "Merciless to the wealth and estates of the citizens," its inscription proclaims, the fire "was harmless to their lives, so as to remind us of the final destruction of the world by fire".

Good old God, she knew about priorities. Perhaps she will mercilessly ensure that if wealthy citizens are to be allowed to erect great vertical estates, the great unwashed will have a right to access.

Meanwhile, await news that the London Eye is to be turned into an air-traffic control installation and closed to the public. For security reasons of course.

fields.headline: Droving licence
fields.standfirst: Continuing our series of celebrity walks, chairman of the Countryside Agency  Ewen Cameron  gets back on track in the Quantocks
fields.trailText: Continuing our series of celebrity walks, chairman of the Countryside Agency Ewen Cameron gets back on track in the Quantocks.
fields.body:
When you climb the track past the disused quarry at Tiscombe and reach the ridge of the Quantocks, you suddenly find yourself on an ancient drove road between an avenue of twisted beech trees. Parts of the track are cut into the soil among shoulder-high roots.

"It's a sensational place," says Ewen Cameron. "Sometimes there's mist swirling below in the valley, and you're up there above it, looking down on a white cloud. It's not hard to imagine the herds of animals being driven along the top to market in Taunton.

"I come from the north of Scotland and, when I first saw these hills in the mid-1970s, I was quite surprised. I thought, wow, Somerset's got it, too. And I knew that Wordsworth and Coleridge lived nearby and would have walked these hills, and that adds to the sense of history."

From this southern starting point, Cameron's favourite walk takes him six miles along the ridge before he turns off and into Bicknoller, a place dear to his heart as chairman of the Countryside Agency: it's got a community-owned post office and shop, the kind of sustainable rural enterprise he's trying to encourage.

"You pass out of the beech trees through various gates into a rougher moorland area, with gorse and broom. Suddenly it seems much wilder and, on a clear day, the views are fantastic, right over the islands of the Bristol Channel and up into Wales. There's also Hinkley Point power station sitting there, very imposing, but not attractive.

"Behind, you look south to the Blackdown Hills and the Wellington Monument 15 or 20 miles away. It's when you get towards the northern end that you're likely to see the red deer that live here, near a place called Bicknoller Post and the woodland that runs down on the western side of the hills."

Cameron owns the Dillington Estate, near Ilminster, 10 miles to the south of the Quantocks, and is a former president of the Country Landowners Association. He's married with four children and two labrador dogs, and some of them come with him on walks. "I think what I get out of it is relaxation and spiritual uplift and just plain exercise - filling the lungs with air. If it contributes to problem-solving, it's by taking the mind off the problem for a few hours so you come back to it fresh."

The Quantocks - from the earlier cantuc, believed to come from the Welsh word canto, meaning circle or rim - are one of the few places in Britain where the landscape looks much the same as it did 6,000 years ago. Neolithic settlers cleared the 1,000ft tops for grazing and they've stayed like that ever since, apart from a brief attempt to plough them in medieval times. Ten years ago, Somerset County Council fought off a proposal to put signs on the M5, and it's still official policy to avoid national publicity for the Quantocks. But they're well known for one of Britain's three remaining stag hunts, which takes to the hills on Mondays and Thursdays, eight months a year.

The National Trust and the local councils have banned hunting from their land, but that still leaves 70% of the Quantocks where the hunt can pursue the 800 red deer. The controversy colours most local debates, including the new Quantock Strategy proposing a more sustainable local economy and new footpaths to take pressure off the ridge.

Romantic associations

Samuel Taylor Coleridge moved in 1796 into a small cottage in Nether Stowey, under the eastern rim of the Quantocks, determined to live a simple and spiritual life. He only stayed for two years, but some of his best poetry was written there and the landscape had a deep influence on him.

When some friends visited in June 1797, he was unable to go walking with them, and wrote This Lime-Tree Bower My Prison, which laments staying at home in the garden while the others climb the 600ft to the ridge of the Quantocks. It was a poem that helped fix him as a pioneer of "outdoor" literature:

Now my Friends emerge
Beneath the wide wide Heaven
and view again,
The many-steepled tract magnificent
Of hilly fields and meadows, and the sea,
With some fair bark, perhaps, whose sails light up
The slip of smooth clear blue betwixt two Isles
Of purple shadow!

Among his friends was William Wordsworth, who lived for a time with his sister Dorothy at nearby Alfoxton House. But the poets' sympathy for the French Revolution, 10 years earlier, meant local people suspected them of sending signals to French ships when they walked on the hills at night.

The Home Office sent an agent to spy on them, who took evidence from waiters about their uninhibited dinnertime conversations. The agent concluded that Coleridge and Wordsworth were as bad as the French themselves - "a mischievous gang of disaffected Englishmen, a sett of violent Democrats."

At Stowey, Coleridge began his most famous poem, The Ancient Mariner (now the name of the village pub).

He finally left Stowey to study in Germany, later becoming a helpless opium addict. But he went back often, and was never much impressed with life in and around London: "The little toe of Quantock," he wrote, "is better than the head and shoulders of Surrey and Middlesex."

The practicals

The Quantocks are 150 miles from London by road. Convenient railway stations are at Bridgwater and Taunton. For information about Somerset visit www.somerset.gov.uk or phone 01934 750 834 to request a colour brochure.

fields.headline: Georgia on my mind
fields.standfirst: In the 1990s, the city was torn by civil war, but  Mark Espiner finds it magical, infectious and seriously intoxicating
fields.trailText: In the 1990s, the city was torn by civil war, but Mark Espiner finds it magical, infectious and seriously intoxicating.
fields.body:
The Georgians have a saying that if you throw a match into the ground in their country, it will grow back a tree. And the strange thing is, it's believable. Not just because the land is so rich that it effortlessly bears the most delicious produce, but because it is just as fertile in fairytales and legend.

After a few hours in Georgia's capital, with its strange curly writing, its 20ft statues of its celebrated poets, its neither eastern nor western sense of place where cars roll up the hills due to magnetic forces and where people generally live to over 100, anything seems possible.

The Tbilisi wonderland was waiting for me as I fell out of the café Dukani on to Rustaveli Avenue, scene of running battles and sniper fire in the 1992-94 civil war. The buildings showed a few signs of the conflict - pock- marked or in states of disrepair - otherwise, it was hard to believe this place could be anything other than the bustling, exciting European-style town that it is.

I stopped in a church and was mesmerised by outbursts of achingly-beautiful close harmonies sung by what seemed to be a spontaneous choir. Then, sidetracked by the shop windows, I ducked into a delicatessen to discover tubs of caviar for only 10 Lari (£3.10). Tbilisi had got its claws into me, and I made for the flea market on the bank of the Mtkvari river, ready to part with more cash.

There were strange objects and bargains: old Russian movie cameras, cooking implements, marvellous little treasures. Someone I mistook for a beggar offered me the sights from a sniper's rifle for 30 Lari (£9.35). "You can use it at the football to see better," he said.

There is a memory of war here. But there is something much stronger and as ancient as the conflicts this country has felt: its culture - and its performance culture in particular. I was told that every third Georgian is an actor, if not every one, and their lust for life is evident and infectious, as is their desire to tell a story over a drink - or drinks.

Their theatrical culture is impossible to ignore. There is almost every kind of theatre space imaginable, including the One Person Theatre, which has room for an audience of 20, and the puppet theatre, which seats more than 100 and has a beautiful wooden interior - it was staging the story of the Battle of Stalingrad with puppets (if you can picture it).

Even though I didn't understand a single word of Georgian, I decided to take in a show at the magnificent Rustaveli theatre. This proved to be a good move: it was true spectacle and showed how vibrant Georgia's live performance world is. The theatre was filled with a cross-section of society - the young, the fashion conscious, the old, families, young couples - all as a community laughing and cheering at a Commedia Dell'Arte show.

Stuffed with culture but starving hungry, I wandered through the old quarter of town to find a place to eat. Seeing I was lost, a passer-by took me to a restaurant, sat me down, had a word with the patron and said he would join me later for a drink. Food arrived at my table. Drink as well. The music being played in the corner of the bar on a duduk - an ancient Armenian instrument, a bit like an oboe - was plaintive and mesmerising.

My friend returned and told me the tune being played had been dedicated to me as the bar's guest. As we drank, he told me a bit about himself in broken English. He was a jeweller and, later, he insisted on taking me to his studio over the road - a tiny workshop where he turned out cameo jewellery. I asked him what material he used to make the delicate thumbnail-sized pieces. "Marmot", he replied. What? "Mar-mot," he re-emphasised with more volume and stress on the second syllable. Seeing I was still puzzled, he produced a huge tusk from under his work bench and showed me a picture of a woolly mammoth.

He was making cameo jewellery out of woolly mammoth tusks from Siberia. I guess they are not endangered species any more, but that had to be illegal, and when I asked him where he got it from, he said he bought it over the internet from a dealer in Moscow.

The next day I met my Georgian friend, Mamuka, at the baths. He told me that these hot sulphur springs gave the city its name. "Tbili" means warm, he said and then related the story of how the fifth-century Georgian king Vakhtang Gorgasali had been hunting in the forest and speared a pheasant. On recovering his quarry, he found the bird in a pool of hot water, cooked and ready to eat, or was it that the bird fell in the water was healed and flew away. Anyway, he was so impressed, that he moved his palace to the spot and made it the centre of his kingdom.

'P ushkin also came to these baths and so did Dumas," said Mamuka. "You've got to try it." Pushkin's personal bathroom had a huge stone pool brimming with hot spring water. I immersed myself, relaxed and drank tea. It was the best way to prepare for Mamuka's vodka onslaught.

Over a bottle of Eduard Shevardnadze peace vodka (yes, politician-branded booze), Mamuka explained to me the complexities of Geor gian toasting. First you drink to peace, he said, then the reason for gathering. To the host, to parents and ancestors, to friends, to those who are no longer with us, to the people here - individually and combined. The list seemed to go on and on, and with each toast a shot of vodka.

After such toasts and then a few more, gathering friends on the way, Mamuka led us through the falling snow and narrow winding streets crammed with houses with carved wooden verandas to a cellar restaurant. Snug inside, we sat and ate and drank still more. The people at the next table, who looked as if they had left their Kalashnikovs at the door, toasted us, our families and our friends and pulled up their chairs.

It was infectious and intoxicating, but I really couldn't drink any more. I couldn't eat any more, either. And the table was creaking under the weight of food to be dreamed about. Spinach chopped and crushed with walnuts sprinkled with fleshy pomegranate seeds, lobio - a dish of beans cooked in an earthenware pot - stewed pork, mushrooms seasoned with garlic, oil and dill, khachapuri - a bready pastry folded over and stuffed with melted cheese - and much more besides.

The vodka tasted like wine and the Georgian wine tasted like honey. But it only took a piece of tomato and a slice of cucumber to betray why this country was called the breadbasket of the Soviet Union. With no need for fertilisers, all the food is organic and even a staple salad tasted better than anything sun-ripened in the Mediterranean.

Mamuka, with full Georgian hospitality, insisted on paying the bill. No argument. But I sneaked a look at it and was shocked. It was only 15 Lari (£4.70) a head.

5 best cafés

1 Dukani Next to the Kashveti Church, off Rustaveli Avenue. Eat yourself silly at little cost.

2 Le Sans Souci Near the Anchiskati church on Shavteli Street. A good meeting place, run by renowned puppeteer Rezo Gabriadze, who says: "Georgia is part of the Mediterranean, which starts in Gibraltar and ends in my café."

3 Alani Just off Gorgasali Square. Serves all kinds of vodka and pickled flowers.

4 Racha On Lermontov and Dadiani. A great eaterie, often with live music. Eat and drink until you can eat and drink no more.

5 Argo Irakli II 17. Tblisi's most trendy bar, with bizarre interior design.

The practicals

Journeys Through Georgia (020 7431 5428) organises city breaks to Tblisi as well as longer excursions to the country. British Mediterranean Airways (0345 222111) operates direct flights to Tblisi at £319. Mark ESpiner stayed at the Sheraton Metechi Palace Hotel (+995 32 94 64 44) single rooms £150, double £185.
