The buildings showed a few signs of the conflict - pock- marked or in states of disrepair - otherwise, it was hard to believe this place could be anything other than the bustling, exciting European-style town that it is. I stopped in a church and was mesmerised by outbursts of achingly-beautiful close harmonies sung by what seemed to be a spontaneous choir. Then, sidetracked by the shop windows, I ducked into a delicatessen to discover tubs of caviar for only 10 Lari (£3.10). Tbilisi had got its claws into me, and I made for the flea market on the bank of the Mtkvari river, ready to part with more cash. There were strange objects and bargains: old Russian movie cameras, cooking implements, marvellous little treasures. Someone I mistook for a beggar offered me the sights from a sniper's rifle for 30 Lari (£9.35). "You can use it at the football to see better," he said. There is a memory of war here. But there is something much stronger and as ancient as the conflicts this country has felt: its culture - and its performance culture in particular. I was told that every third Georgian is an actor, if not every one, and their lust for life is evident and infectious, as is their desire to tell a story over a drink - or drinks. Their theatrical culture is impossible to ignore. There is almost every kind of theatre space imaginable, including the One Person Theatre, which has room for an audience of 20, and the puppet theatre, which seats more than 100 and has a beautiful wooden interior - it was staging the story of the Battle of Stalingrad with puppets (if you can picture it). Even though I didn't understand a single word of Georgian, I decided to take in a show at the magnificent Rustaveli theatre. This proved to be a good move: it was true spectacle and showed how vibrant Georgia's live performance world is. The theatre was filled with a cross-section of society - the young, the fashion conscious, the old, families, young couples - all as a community laughing and cheering at a Commedia Dell'Arte show. Stuffed with culture but starving hungry, I wandered through the old quarter of town to find a place to eat. Seeing I was lost, a passer-by took me to a restaurant, sat me down, had a word with the patron and said he would join me later for a drink. Food arrived at my table. Drink as well. The music being played in the corner of the bar on a duduk - an ancient Armenian instrument, a bit like an oboe - was plaintive and mesmerising. My friend returned and told me the tune being played had been dedicated to me as the bar's guest. As we drank, he told me a bit about himself in broken English. He was a jeweller and, later, he insisted on taking me to his studio over the road - a tiny workshop where he turned out cameo jewellery. I asked him what material he used to make the delicate thumbnail-sized pieces. "Marmot", he replied. What? "Mar-mot," he re-emphasised with more volume and stress on the second syllable. Seeing I was still puzzled, he produced a huge tusk from under his work bench and showed me a picture of a woolly mammoth. He was making cameo jewellery out of woolly mammoth tusks from Siberia. I guess they are not endangered species any more, but that had to be illegal, and when I asked him where he got it from, he said he bought it over the internet from a dealer in Moscow. The next day I met my Georgian friend, Mamuka, at the baths. He told me that these hot sulphur springs gave the city its name. "Tbili" means warm, he said and then related the story of how the fifth-century Georgian king Vakhtang Gorgasali had been hunting in the forest and speared a pheasant. On recovering his quarry, he found the bird in a pool of hot water, cooked and ready to eat, or was it that the bird fell in the water was healed and flew away. Anyway, he was so impressed, that he moved his palace to the spot and made it the centre of his kingdom. 'P ushkin also came to these baths and so did Dumas," said Mamuka. "You've got to try it." Pushkin's personal bathroom had a huge stone pool brimming with hot spring water. I immersed myself, relaxed and drank tea. It was the best way to prepare for Mamuka's vodka onslaught. Over a bottle of Eduard Shevardnadze peace vodka (yes, politician-branded booze), Mamuka explained to me the complexities of Geor gian toasting. First you drink to peace, he said, then the reason for gathering. To the host, to parents and ancestors, to friends, to those who are no longer with us, to the people here - individually and combined. The list seemed to go on and on, and with each toast a shot of vodka. After such toasts and then a few more, gathering friends on the way, Mamuka led us through the falling snow and narrow winding streets crammed with houses with carved wooden verandas to a cellar restaurant. Snug inside, we sat and ate and drank still more. The people at the next table, who looked as if they had left their Kalashnikovs at the door, toasted us, our families and our friends and pulled up their chairs. It was infectious and intoxicating, but I really couldn't drink any more. I couldn't eat any more, either. And the table was creaking under the weight of food to be dreamed about. Spinach chopped and crushed with walnuts sprinkled with fleshy pomegranate seeds, lobio - a dish of beans cooked in an earthenware pot - stewed pork, mushrooms seasoned with garlic, oil and dill, khachapuri - a bready pastry folded over and stuffed with melted cheese - and much more besides. The vodka tasted like wine and the Georgian wine tasted like honey. But it only took a piece of tomato and a slice of cucumber to betray why this country was called the breadbasket of the Soviet Union. With no need for fertilisers, all the food is organic and even a staple salad tasted better than anything sun-ripened in the Mediterranean. Mamuka, with full Georgian hospitality, insisted on paying the bill. No argument. But I sneaked a look at it and was shocked. It was only 15 Lari (£4.70) a head. 5 best cafés 1 Dukani Next to the Kashveti Church, off Rustaveli Avenue. Eat yourself silly at little cost. 2 Le Sans Souci Near the Anchiskati church on Shavteli Street. A good meeting place, run by renowned puppeteer Rezo Gabriadze, who says: "Georgia is part of the Mediterranean, which starts in Gibraltar and ends in my café." 3 Alani Just off Gorgasali Square. Serves all kinds of vodka and pickled flowers. 4 Racha On Lermontov and Dadiani. A great eaterie, often with live music. Eat and drink until you can eat and drink no more. 5 Argo Irakli II 17. Tblisi's most trendy bar, with bizarre interior design. The practicals Journeys Through Georgia (020 7431 5428) organises city breaks to Tblisi as well as longer excursions to the country. British Mediterranean Airways (0345 222111) operates direct flights to Tblisi at £319. Mark ESpiner stayed at the Sheraton Metechi Palace Hotel (+995 32 94 64 44) single rooms £150, double £185.

fields.headline: Millennium mile
fields.trailText: New Father Thames?
fields.body:
New Father Thames?

London's river, particularly between Westminster and Tower Bridge, is undergoing a radical renaissance.

Urban meadows?

Sprouting waterside museums, engineering triumphs, new hotels, remodelled performance venues, riverside restaurants and a host of other pleasure zones.

So the Dome, bless it . . .

. . . is simply the first of a host of grand millennium projects.

The seismic eye of the transformation?

Is the London Eye. A funride with a glorious view, perhaps, but also a masterwork of engineering.

Looking down on the new London mayor?

Too late. County Hall now contains two hotels, Britain's best aquarium, a Namco Station games centre and a "Hall of Fame" devoted to the story of FA Premier League.

That'll get the children going.

So will the BFI Imax on Waterloo's roundabout. This glass drum of a structure houses the tallest - 60ft - screen in Britain.

A regular South Bank Show.

Drink to it at Vinopolis, an audio-visual "world of wine" attraction, with tastings and two restaurants.

For culture, not viticulture?

Get ye to the Globe, that faithful reconstruction of an Elizabethan theatre, for the largest exhibition on the Bard ever staged, scheduled to open this month.

What's your favourite?

On May 18 the cultural shrine will be unveiled.

Eye, eye . . .

No, a £134-million, glass-lidded conversion of the old Bankside Power Station, destined to be a model of born-again creativity.

Apart from the name.

As the Tate Modern, it will house Picasso, Monet, Matisse, Mondrian, Rothko, Dali, Bacon, Giacometti, Pollock, Warhol et al.

Has there been a new wave of investment in boats?

City Cruises' four 500-passenger, £1.25-million "riverliners" are all called Millennium something.

The South Bank complex is still a mess.

Plan B is to transform the entire area into a single set piece of design.

Who's paying for all this?

The Lottery has provided much of the seed money, but the row of crops now has a momentum that will sustain life on the Thames way beyond the year 2000.

fields.headline: Running on empty
fields.standfirst: The motor car made Detroit, but when recession hit the industry, the city stalled.  Decca Aitkenhead  searches for the ignition key
fields.trailText: The motor car made Detroit, but when recession hit the industry, the city stalled. Decca Aitkenhead searches for the ignition key
fields.body:
The woman behind the counter in the city-centre bookstore looked politely amazed to see us. Most of the lights in the shop were switched off, a calculation, presumably, that the electricity bill would be hard to justify in the absence of any customers. We smiled brightly, and asked if she had anything on Detroit, and she peered at us as if we were mad.

Then she disappeared down an aisle and into a cloud of dust that rose from the shelves marked Local Interest. When it cleared, she was standing there, looking doubtful, and holding out a couple of books. One was called Ghost Towns of Michigan, and the other was called Great Escapes; Detroit. This turned out to be not a guide to great escapes in Detroit but rather to great escapes from it.

If you had never been to America before, and landed in Detroit, you would wonder what everyone had been talking about all your life.

America may be a large country, but there are certain things you can confidently expect to find no matter where you go. You expect great big plates of food, and big people with great teeth telling you how fabulous everything is. You expect action and energy and that bewildering can-do enthusiasm, and you expect to look at all the fancy things they have, and think, bloody hell.

And you are not normally disappointed - but if you go to Detroit you will find nothing of the sort. The city is famous for creating cars, and cars have played a large part in making America, but Detroit today is the most un-American creation imaginable. I would guess you could find bits of Bulgaria that are more American than Detroit City.

"Welcome to Dee-troit," the pilot announced as we landed, and there was something of the ringmaster in the heavy emphasis on the first syllable, a kind of verbal drumroll, to hint that this was a city in need of some help with its entrance.

For the first 10 minutes in town, this seemed unnecessary, as the taxi sped us past rather beautiful, vaguely art-deco skyscrapers, the kind that ticker tape would snow from in old American movies. We drew up at a tight knot of shiny, mirrored towers beside the river downtown, which constitute the Renaissance Centre, known as the RenCen.

The words renaissance and regeneration crop up a lot in the recent history of the city, with - you soon discover - an increasingly hollow ring. Our hotel in the RenCen was in the process of being regenerated when we arrived - General Motors is relocating its global HQ there - but, being new to the city, we took the PR promises of imminent architectural urban glory at face value, and scampered out in high spirits to explore downtown.

It took a little time to realise what was wrong. We kept checking the map, and it kept assuring us that we were indeed in the heart of the city, but this became increasingly implausible, because it was quite clear that we were the only people there.

On a sunny Saturday afternoon, in the centre of America's ninth largest city, we were the only two human beings in downtown Detroit. We walked up and down past boarded-up shops, disused parking lots, steaming manhole covers, and businesses that didn't look as if they'd closed down so much as simply given up, and grew more and more spooked, until eventually we found a bar that was open.

We were the only customers, and when the barman had got over his surprise at seeing us, he told us that Greektown, a few blocks away, was where it was "at". Greektown transpired to be a short strip of modest restaurants serving moussaka, but there were some other people on it - not many, but some, and even a little traffic - and that, it turned out, was as good as downtown Detroit got.

Elsewhere, the streets are eight lanes wide, but often there is little traffic, and often no buildings on either side either, just blanks of empty wastelands. The only enterprises apparently able to stay in business are loan shops ("Need a loan? Ask Sam"), tyre and transmission repair shops, and strip clubs; one, Venus, was advertising a Golden Oldies night on Wednesdays, which gave us something to puzzle over.

The only other buildings in good repair are the churches, and there is no mystery as to why people might feel the need for God in a place like this. Inner-city Detroit looks like an artist's impression of alienation.

But Motor City is currently trying to reinvent itself. It has acquired a licence for gambling, and three vast casinos are in the process of being built; temporary casinos are in operation already, and the campaign is underway to re-launch Detroit as a river side resort of high rollers and good times. This is a bold challenge.

But the campaign is underway, nonetheless, and high on the list of official tourist attractions is the Henry Ford Museum; Henry Ford's name is attached to practically everything in Detroit - hospitals, libraries, schools and so on - and so the Henry Ford Museum enjoys the must-see tourist status of something like Buckingham Palace.

Like everything in Detroit, it is a million miles away from where you are. When you finally get there, it looks from the outside like an English public school, and the foyer - all marble and chandeliers - is suggestive of a vaguely aristocratic philanthropist, which is how Detroit generally likes to think of Henry Ford. Inside, the museum is more like an Ikea warehouse, full of mock-up roadside diners and ex-Presidents' limos.

No one blinks when you tell them you're going to visit the basically very dull Henry Ford Museum, but almost everyone winces and frowns if you say you're off to see the Motown museum. "But it's in the badlands!" they shudder. How you distinguish the badlands from the goodlands in Detroit is beyond me, but the Motown museum is a world away from the Henry Ford "experience", not least because nobody else is there.

We drove past three times before we realised that was it - a modest, old-fashioned wooden house next door to a funeral parlour on a semi-derelict boulevard, it is the house where Berry Gordy, creator of the Motown label, lived and recorded most of the Motown classics.

Inside, the rooms have been restored to their period simplicity, and the walls are crammed with photos of Smokey Robinson, Marvin Gaye, the Supremes and others. It is a dreamily poignant archive, unaffected but affecting, and we emerged into the derelict tatter outside in a daze.

If you drive around Detroit for long enough, you realise that it does have pockets of beauty. The African American museum is one, as is the Institute of Arts, and a new development of warehouse apartments and breweries and bars called Rivertown is another. The trouble is that you have to drive so far to get from one to another. The car still dominates every inch of Motor City, simply because you can't even pop out for a paper without getting into one, and everyone tells you their car is their saviour, but in fact it is more like their ruin.

The irony of Motor City is that life there would be vastly improved if the car were abolished, so that things would be built nearer to each other, and people might fill in the gaps. The brighter irony is that Detroit's citizens, having failed to live the American dream, are in many ways far more likeable than their fellow Americans. Engagingly unafflicted with gormless optimism, Detroit's citizens also lack the common American addiction to self-promotion.

A bartender announced to the assembled clientele: "These two are here from England to write a travel piece about Detroit!" The bar raised its head and stared in blank disbelief. "You must be out of your mind," someone said.

The practicals

STA (0870 160 6070) has return flights from London to Detroit with BA from £236 (student/under 26) and £281 open to all. Manchester, Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Newcastle £62/5 extra. Hoteldesk (0845 6021532) has 17 hotels in the Detroit area inc Days Inn, Howard Johnson, Ramada and Travelodge from £41 per night

fields.headline: Ski briefs
fields.trailText: • Avalanche deaths in the Alps this week served as a reminder that nobody should even think about venturing off piste without a transceiver, which can help rescuers find a victim under the snow. After last winter's tragedies, equipment shops report increased sales to British skiers. But they are selling hundreds rather than thousands and only to those who know they are likely to head off into risky areas.
fields.body:
 Avalanche deaths in the Alps this week served as a reminder that nobody should even think about venturing off piste without a transceiver, which can help rescuers find a victim under the snow. After last winter's tragedies, equipment shops report increased sales to British skiers. But they are selling hundreds rather than thousands and only to those who know they are likely to head off into risky areas.

For most once-a-season skiers, who rarely go off piste, the price - £180 upwards - can be a deterrent. The latest digital types cost even more. Nor can you rely on being able to rent them in resorts.

A cheaper alternative is the Recco system of reflectors, which send out a locator beam. The equipment needed to lock on to them has become much lighter and has been acquired by a wide range of resorts, listed at www.recco.com. If the reflectors do not come with your clothes or boots, they can be bought for around £13 a pair.

 Contemplating a late ski holiday? Compare tour operator prices carefully with what a strong pound will buy in resorts. A six-day adult lift pass in the French resort of Les Arcs, for example, can cost up to £127 from a tour operator. At the current exchange rate, you could save nearly £30 by buying it when you get there. Much the same goes for Austria's St Anton , where the saving could be up to £25. Tour operators justify this with the not unreasonable argument that they guarantee not to charge customers extra if sterling plunges. But if the gap becomes very wide, some operators, including Thomson, Crystal and First Choice, say they will offer refunds in the shape of après-ski extras.

 A wind-powered ski lift has helped Aspen win a top environmental prize. The Colorado resort was this week named long-haul specialist winner in the British Airways Tourism for Tomorrow awards scheme, which aims to encourage working compromises between the travel industry and environmental interests. The Aspen Skiing Company's Cirque drag lift is powered by electricity generated at a wind farm north of town. Serving a fragile area of tundra, it was built by hand between animal mating and nesting periods. The judges, chaired by Professor David Bellamy, praised Aspen for other green initiatives, including the beefing up of its free shuttle bus service to cut traffic pollution.

 The final result of an internet poll, set up to discover whether Aspen Mountain should end its snowboard ban, was a close run thing. Just under half of all voters (48%) said yes. A slender majority of 51% said no, with a few don't cares.

fields.headline: Italy - the director's cut
fields.standfirst: Films often inspire travel, and yet the Italy that director  Anthony Minghella explored while shooting the Oscar-nominated The Talented Mr Ripley is only available through the 'distorted frames of a movie'
fields.trailText: Films often inspire travel, and yet the Italy that director Anthony Minghella explored while shooting the Oscar-nominated The Talented Mr Ripley is only available through the 'distorted frames of a movie'
fields.body:
Last year I spent a great deal more time in Italy than anywhere else, but on reflection it's clear to me that I wasn't really in Italy, but in a country of my own imagination. Film directors are thieves; magpies. They resemble barbarians bringing home the spoils, ransacking each city for its treasures. They plunder landscapes, corrupt geography, redraw maps, and invent villages. Screenplays, too, are notoriously hieroglyphic. They resemble architects' blueprints and collide with many of the same practical obstacles when translating ideas into reality.

In my screenplay of The Talented Mr Ripley, adapted from Patricia Highsmith's mordant 1950s novel of the same name, Tom Ripley (played by Matt Damon), a young American misfit, is sent to Italy to persuade Dickie Greenleaf (Jude Law), the errant son of a wealthy industrialist, to return home to New York. Instead, he becomes obsessed with the glamorous life Dickie is leading in Mongibello and stays on, first befriended and then rejected by Dickie and his fiancée, Marge Sherwood (Gwyneth Paltrow). Eventually, Ripley assumes Dickie's identity and takes himself to Rome and Venice where, as is often the case with holidays, he samples the life he's always wanted.

His catastrophic adventure begins innocuously enough with a blue Fiat bus, 1940s vintage, puttering along a coast road, Ripley inside, having hauled itself up from the harbour at Naples where the Queen Mary has just delivered him from New York.

Collecting the half-dozen shots that create this sequence was less straightforward. The Queen Mary is long becalmed, the New York skyline irreparably altered by 50 years of vertical aspira tion. The once-majestic Arrivals Building in Naples is derelict and - most exercising to the film-makers - Mongibello, Ripley's destination, notionally situated on the Amalfi coast, is a figment of Highsmith's imagination. But there it all is on film. A departure from Manhattan, an arrival in a teeming hall of passengers, a short bus journey, a picturesque fishing village complete with villagers, fishermen, fish. And none of it, except perhaps for the fish, is real.

So the Italy I explored for the past year is available to the traveller only through the distorted frames of a movie. I lived in the land of Ripley, and that mosaic of dream images, half-remembered moments from Italian movies, photographic references, travel diaries, documentaries and anecdotes, was my guidebook as I explored modern Italy and re-imagined it in the service of the film.

The shooting of The Talented Mr Ripley, set in the Italy of 1958-9, was continuously confounded by progress: buildings mentioned in the adaptation were no longer there, or were hemmed in by modern neighbours or decorated with the ubiquitous green canvas of Rome's makeover for the millennial celebrations. In the 1950s, travel was largely the privilege of the moneyed class, and this had particular significance when it came to shooting in Italy's landmark locations: there were simply fewer peo ple then. We were faced with the problem of clearing piazzas swarming with tourists.

By locating the movie a year or two later than the novel, there was an opportunity to explore a significant moment in Italian history, Il Boom, where a thin veneer of the modern, the sophistication of La Dolce Vita, had glossed but could not entirely hide the more primitive mores of the country. Italy is a place I love above all other places, but it's always possible to detect a darker note sounding under its breezy melodies. And this dissonance seemed to speak of the film itself: apparently sybaritic, but lounging on a volcano. Mongibello, as it happens, is a local name for Mount Etna.

As Dickie, Ripley takes a suite in The Grand Hotel. This hotel has one of Rome's few genuinely impressive hotel exteriors and lobbies and so, for once, we were able to shoot an only semi-modified reality. But for Ripley's hotel suite we used the breathtaking interiors, frescoed and ornate, of the Palazzo Tiburna. The same building has a staircase of grim beauty, austere and colossal, like Escher's Möbius etchings. Here we filmed the halls and stairs of Ripley's Roman apartment, where bad things happen; while its evocative courtyard served as the exterior of an apartment belonging to Meredith Logue (played by Cate Blanchett), a young heiress with whom Ripley has become improba bly involved. It was possible, then, to walk out of a door, down some stairs and go outside, and have passed through three of the film's most significant locations, separated in the movie by weeks and miles. And so it went on. We filmed Roman locations in Naples, Neapolitan locations in Rome, Venetian locations in Sicily, sometimes by choice, mostly by force majeure .

A key scene in Ripley's stay in Venice is a visit to his conductor friend Peter's rehearsal of Vivaldi's Stabat Mater in the composer's own church, La Pieta, a scene I wrote specifically because of the location. In fact, an earlier visit to a concert there actually gave me the idea for Peter Smith-Kingsley's occupation. Naturally, then, when it came to filming, the church became mysteriously unavailable.

With the schedule tightening on us, we were faced with the prospect of having to shoot the scene in Palermo, Sicily, the next stop on our own journey. I couldn't scout a replacement church myself, and had to rely on a hastily-assembled selection of photographs. My eye was taken by images of the astonishing Byzantine gilt mosaic work in one of them, the 14th-century Chiesa Martorana. Its dazzling iconography of golden saints and angels seemed to offer a perfect backdrop to one of the film's few genuinely romantic moments.

We arrived in Palermo the evening before we were due to film, only to discover that the mosaic work was confined to the rafters above the brooding monochrome of its walls. The church rehearsal would have photographed as if it took place in a large garage. The only solution I could think of, to the dismay of the production design team, was to take the performers to the mosaics. We built a terrifyingly rudimentary platform, and musicians and instruments were hoisted up. The camera has one eye; geography is only what the film establishes. Ripley enters the church, looks up to see Peter rehearsing Stabat Mater in what appears to be an organ loft. The audience can't see the glue and bits of string creating this illusion.

Sometimes, of course, there is no simple line between fiction and fact. An elegantly-dressed woman approached us as we were preparing a café exterior in Rome's Piazza di Spagna. There has never actually been an outdoor café there, but I'd had an idea about Ripley observing his connivances from a high vantage point, and the architecture of the Spanish Steps, with its view stretching past the piazza, lent itself perfectly to the mechanics of the scene.

The woman ducked under our work ropes and sat at one of the prop tables, indifferent to the fact that there was no café, that the facade concealed a dress shop, and insisted she had arranged to meet her friend at Dinelli's. As I attempted to explain that the café was in reality a film set, that Dinelli's had been the name of my aunt's café at Ryde Esplanade, on the Isle of Wight, her friend arrived and they sat down and had their meeting, a little irascible at our failure to serve them coffee but otherwise perfectly content.

This seems to be the contract that Romans have made with Rome generally. They have made accommodation with a city bristling with facades and gestures from Nero to Mussolini. They perch on the statues, argue at the fountains, slouch against antiquity, and eat lunch on steps that might have been carved by Michelangelo.

As Italy reconciled itself to our foibles, we tried to reconcile ourselves to Italy's. Filming was often fraught. You can't shoot in this street on Monday morning unless you restrict the field of view to 180 degree. The building is undergoing sewerage repairs from 7am-10am and the owner has a birthday party in the afternoon. That pneumatic drill can't be silenced until after 6pm. A key location in Venice is suddenly not available when the clergy discover there's a murder in the film (hard to imagine how they view the Bible). Every day, to quote our wonderful Italian crew's shrugging words of explanation, is a casino.

And yet I would rather spend an afternoon with an Italian than anybody else. They know certain things about the world. They know how to lean. They most certainly know how to eat. They stare particularly well. They mostly know how to dress.

The search for Mongibello took me and Roy Walker, the film's production designer, on a loop around the perimeter of Italy, tracing its coastline with increasing frustration for the necessary constituents: a house with a terrace giving directly on to a harbour; a pungent sense of life unchanged for centuries; good beaches - in short, an undiscovered Italy. Starting at Portofino (too self-consciously glamorous), then taking the train that winds through the Cinque Terre, that rosary of vertical medieval towns on the country's outer thigh, exquisitely coloured like so many Klee landscapes, we eventually strayed as far south as Sicily. Italy has not cherished its past and has been cavalier, particularly on its coastline, with post-war building. The Amalfi coast, the obvious choice for Mongibello, was not suitable. The whole region is scarred by development, some of it excruciatingly misjudged, and many beautiful medieval towns, flanked by a single clogged road - Positano, Amalfi, Ravello - are suffocating under the accretions of garish holiday homes clustered round them like cheap baubles on an elegant neck.

I was excited by the neighbouring volcanic islands of Lipari and Salina, off Sicily's northern coastline, but their inaccessibility, and the lack of a house or terrace sufficiently ostentatious for Dickie or of a real focus to their harbours, led us to surrender their austere charms for two other islands off the Gulf of Naples, Ischia and Procida, less admired sisters of glamorous Capri. From their complex geographies, we created a map of a small village, with Dickie's and Marge's respective houses at either end of a harbour, a beach, a church, a small piazza. The houses themselves were on Ischia, but the funnelled alleys and cobbled streets which connected them were shot on Procida.

The process of witnessing, which I think of as a particular duty of the director, extends beyond observing the work of the actors in the film. A choreographer once told me that he began each day in the studio by writing down everything in his head and tossing the results into the bin, a kind of mental spring-cleaning. I try to observe the same exercise when arriving on set, abandoning the meticulous planning that pre-production has until that moment demanded, and telling myself that any obstacle is useful, every curse contains a blessing. This happened on several occasions in Ripley, not least in the circumstances surrounding an important scene in the movie, where a local girl, Silvana, secretly pregnant with Dickie's child, drowns herself for shame during a religious ceremony.

While working on the screenplay in a monastery in Cetona, Tuscany, I had had a dream in which I had seen a statue of the Madonna surfacing in the sea, followed by the body of young woman. From this image a whole strand of the screenplay had developed, a calm surface broken by a death in the water, prefiguring what would happen later with Dickie. Now we were in Ischia, there seemed no appropriate place to stage the festival in a way that the American characters could have vantage of the event while remaining appropriately isolated from the rest of the community, whom I wanted present in the scene.

During our location-scouting, Roy Walker and I stood on Dickie's terrace and decided to make the best of an eroded slipway that poked into a narrow cove next to the house but was altogether too small. On the back of an envelope we devised a plan to enlarge the scale of the celebra tion by surrounding the cove with fishing boats, imagining a festival in which the Madonna was blessing the harvest of fish, as if this Christian event had been written over a pagan one, an idea consonant with the notion that the American interlopers were reading only the surface of the world they had found themselves in and not its darker currents. The location seemed a necessary but unhappy compromise.

A few weeks later, our art director arrived back in Rome with photographs and a painting. which corresponded almost exactly to the sketch on our envelope. When I asked where he'd found these references, he told me they'd come from Ischia, that the slipway was the very same we'd felt obliged to select.

But I also examine the equivalent of the choreographer's trash. A year before filming, I had been invited to Capri to receive an award for what seemed no better reason than being in possession of an Italian surname. I went on the basis that it would be a good opportunity to visit the Amalfi coast and do some exploring. Afterwards, I was cajoled by the producer to go to a club on the island where he assured me there would be a terrific party. He introduced me to a young friend, darkly handsome and effervescent, who had turned up during the evening and together we drove to an extremely unprepossessing building.

Inside we found a cave, throbbing with people, who burst into applause as the producer's friend appeared, chanting his name - Fiorello! Fiorello! - and practically carrying him on to the stage. It transpired that Fiorello is a national star. Struggling through the crowd, he jumped on to the stage, began a writhing impression of Michael Jackson, sang and danced. "And now," he shouted, "all the way from America [sic] to sing for you tonight, Anthony Minghella!"

I would love to report that this social wallflower declined, but I didn't. The atmosphere was contagious, and I found myself sharing a microphone, singing my heart out to a medley of songs. Somewhere during my intoxicating stint in the club I had found myself talking to a coven of Italy's celebrated singers, listened carefully to their advocacy of a famous 1950s song whose composer was also present, Tu Vuoi Fa l'Americano.

It had long occurred to me as I struggled with the screenplay that at the heart of Tom Ripley's unease is the fear of not being chosen. It's one of the things that makes him human. I think everyone knows this feeling or its correlative, knows too that for each of us as we pass from child to adult is the essential recognition that we are alone, the essential desire that we yearn not to be alone.

Music was to play a huge role in the film of Ripley, and here - in the incident at the Capri club - I had found a way for Ripley to make the first significant claim for Dickie's affection, through music, through being chosen to come up on stage in a jazz club in Naples. And so my own experience, barely mediated, literal even to the extent of casting Fiorello in the movie, having him use the same form of words for inviting Tom Ripley up on stage, found its way into the film in a moment of unadulterated pleasure, as he and Dickie and Fiorello jump and jive their way through Tu Vuoi Fa l'Americano, a song about Italians wanting to be American, in a film about Americans wanting to be Italian.

In a sense, the blatantly fictional landscape of Italy created to serve Ripley's story provides only a more noisy broadcast of what each traveller experiences. Just as a reader projects an internal and unique film of the novel he or she is reading - imagining rooms, faces, gestures - so the traveller brings home from each journey a landscape that is selective and personal, influenced by expectation, mood, the weather, a romantic encounter, a great meal, a terrible one.

As tourists, we pay attention with a rigour that would paralyse us at home. The man who passes Trafalgar Square every day without looking at it is the same man who carefully photographs the Bernini sculpture in Piazza Navona. And what is it about, this endless snapping and videoing, if not to prove we were there, to say that this is what we thought beautiful or significant, this is what we want to remember? Similarly, if the adapter of a novel aims to be the ideal reader, a passionate advocate of the source material, then the film director must attempt the same function as a witness to the world he finds himself in, collecting and marvelling, abandoned to subjectivity, the ideal tourist.

The practicals

Follow in the footsteps of The Talented Mr Ripley with a Magic of Italy Holiday (020 8748 7575) to Ischia. Seven nights' half board at the 4 star Hotel Grand Mezzatorre, converted from a 16th century watchtower and set on a rocky headland with steps down to the sea, costs from £689 inc flights with BA and transfers. A day trip by hydrofoil to Naples costs around £10 or add on a few nights to sample the Naples nightlife from £32 per night at the Hotel Brittanique. A three night package with flights costs from £315. you cxanrent your own apartment in Rome or Venice from £485 a week inc scheduled flights, or stay in a hotel from £290 for two nights on a B&B basis.

fields.headline: Land of the free
fields.standfirst: Martin Bell reports from the revolutionary US Free-skiing Open at Vail. Winter sports may never be the same again
fields.trailText: Martin Bell reports from the revolutionary US Free-skiing Open at Vail. Winter sports may never be the same again.
fields.body:
Last week's 2000 US Free-skiing Open in Vail, Colorado, was billed as "the future of skiing", and the event's promoter, Freeze magazine, professes to be the bible of "the new skiing culture".

There is no doubt that skiing has undergone a revolution in recent years. Several developments have been sparked off by the new shapes of ski design: funcarving, where skiers incline their bodies inwards at crazy angles; and adventurous off-piste techniques, where imposing Alaskan powder faces are conquered using just a handful of huge, high-speed turns. And ski-racing styles have become ever more intense and aggressive (as exemplified by Hermann "The Herminator" Maier).

The energetic young sport of snowboarding has occasionally rebelled against skiing, but has also influenced it in recent years. The "new school" of free-stylers (also known as "trick skiers" or by their 1970s moniker "hotdoggers") are creating asymetric flips with "grab" moves modelled on snowboarding tricks.

As the cult of "new school free-skiing" has spread via ski magazines and resort word-of-mouth, a haphazard circuit of new events has sprung up. The most lucrative of these take place in North America. ESPN, the sports cable channel, has just organised its third Winter X-Games. This year, rival network NBC felt compelled to put on its own version, the Gravity Games.

The pool of potential sponsors for these Generation X events is so rich, that Jonny Moseley, 1998 Olympic mogul champion and a golden boy of the "new school", decided to forgo mainstream mogul competitions completely for two years and run his own free-skiing event, The Jonny Moseley Invitational.

The US Free-skiing Open was open to any would-be hotshot free-skiers who wanted to measure themselves against some of the legends of the genre. The three days of competition included slopestyle (where competitors descend over a course of "rails" and jumps), big air (one large jump), and a skiercross (where racers compete five abreast through a racecourse of banked turns and jumps). In addition, there was an unofficial "halfpipe jam session".

In the slopestyle, competitors had to slide sideways down a couple of metal rails, including one with a downward kink halfway along - the infamous "sex-change rail". Then, they had the choice of a "table-top jump" or a sideways "quarterpipe hit". The course finished with two "booters" - huge jumps with an upwards kick. Over two days, the field was whittled down to 10 finalists. On the decisive run, it was inevitably Moseley who best impressed the judges, with some "above the tree-tops air" on the quarterpipe, and a "switch rodeo roll 720".

One of the most impressive moves was by Shane McConkey, who took off backwards, did a back flip, and landed backwards. But his sketchy landings did not impress the judges and he failed to make the final.

'Compared to traditional aerials competition, which has become a bit of a formula with everyone doing the same type of tricks, this is more skiing-oriented," said Moseley. "Each competitor is doing different moves, being creative, thinking out of the box. But it's impossible for things to continue like this - eventually free-skiing will become increasingly technical, with more rules. And then something else new will pop up." Next season, Moseley plans a return to mainstream mogul competition in order to prepare for the defence of his title at the 2002 Olympics.

The skiercross is modelled on snowboarding's "boardercross", which in turn was derived from motorcross. In each heat, five competitors thrust out of the start simultaneously, and jostle for position going into the first bend.

So, did I witness the "future of skiing"? Undoubtedly, the gladiatorial skiercross has the potential to become an attractive TV alternative to traditional World Cup ski-racing, where the ever-tinier time differences make all the racers now look identical. In skiercross, the public can clearly see who is winning, and the ever-present wipeouts, as in the knockabout sport of short-track speed-skating, simply add to the uncertainty and excitement.

But the event is presently contested by middle-ranking ex-racers. Until skiercross organisers can guarantee enough press coverage and prize money to attract the best skiers in the world, such as Hermann Maier and Kjetil Aamodt, it will lack ultimate credibility.

As for the new school of freestyle, it will probably become assimilated into mainstream freestyle, as Moseley predicts. But there will always be rebellious youths out there on the slopes, riding skis, snowboards and who knows what else, ready to challenge the pre-conceptions of their elders.

fields.headline: Late bookings
fields.trailText: Paris express
fields.body:
Paris express

Spend the night in Paris for £59. The price includes return Eurostar tickets and one night's B&B in the two-star Hotel Veronese. One slight drawback: the outward journey must be on the 5.15am or 6.19am from Waterloo. Available until March 31 through Magic Cities (020-8563 8959).

Lille break

Two nights at the three-star Grand Hotel Bellevue in Lille costs £179pp and includes return Eurostar tickets, accommodation and buffet breakfast. Time Off (0870 5846363).

Basquing it

Two nights in Bilbao until the end of March cost £255pp with British Airways. This includes B&B in a choice of four-star hotels, and free entry to the Guggenheim Museum. Mundi Color Holidays (020-7828 6021).

Miles of Nile

A seven-night Nile cruise that takes in the East and West banks of Egypt. Ten free excursions are included and a qualified Egyptologist is on hand to answer your questions. The trip costs £399, departing March 6, and includes return flights from Gatwick, transfers, full board on the cruise and excursions. Discover Egypt (0171-407 2111).

Sheikh your money

Seven nights' B&B in Sharm el Sheikh, at the tip of the Sinai peninsular, costs from £325pp, including return flights (departing March 2 or 5), transfers and B&B at the Tropicana Tivoli hotel. Sharm el Sheikh is a divers' haven and well-placed for excursions to Luxor and St Catherine's Monastery. Longwood Holidays (0181-551 4494).

Bermudan shorts

Spend seven nights in Bermuda for the price of six, saving £64 (or 14 nights for the price of 12, saving £128) at the four-star Southampton Princess Hotel. Seven nights now costs £877pp, based on twin share, and 14 nights £1,261 including return BA flights from Gatwick, accommodation with breakfast and free unlimited golf. Cresta Holidays (0870 1610930).

Life's a beach

If one beach is not enough, take a 14-night all-inclusive holiday in Antigua, where there are 365 beaches to choose from. Until April 15, the price is £899pp, which includes return flights from Gatwick, accommodation in the adults-only Jolly Beach Resort, all meals, drinks and sports. Tropical Places (0800 0185256)

Coasting France

Have two weeks self-catering in France for the price of one. A villa, sleeping seven, on the Languedoc coast costs £169 over Easter. Cross-Channel travel costs £95 per car and four passengers with a free upgrade to first class on Hoverspeed. Crystal Premier France (0870 8880023).

fields.headline: Oz and them
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey achieves his own state of Dreamtime beating about the bush with the Aborigines of the Northern Territory
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glancey achieves his own state of Dreamtime beating about the bush with the Aborigines of the Northern Territory
fields.body:
I feel bad about myself for feeling bad about Sydney. I was only there for a weekend, and this was my first visit. First time to Australia, in fact.

Unsure what to do, I found myself handing over a tuckerbag full of dollars to make the vertiginous climb across the very top of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. I rode the characterful green-and-cream ferries that ply beneath it. I gawped at the alien spaceship underbellies of giant rays in the dreamlike new harbourside aquarium. I trekked listlessly around fashionable Paddington and King's Cross feeling that I ought to see something of hot and happening Sydney. Yet, I felt as out of place as a wombat would clinging to an oak tree in the New Forest.

Trouble is, I'd been spoiled rotten by the experience of being in the Northern Territory. There, I met people I never thought I'd meet, encountered animals, nose to snout, I'd only seen before in books. I trekked through landscapes where the colour of the soil, the fronds of plants (where there is plantlife), the profile of trees, the texture of clouds, the insects I tried to keep away from my trouser legs, the food I ate and the croc-infested waters I bathed in were all like nothing I'd experienced before.

Strangely, I felt quite at home in the Aboriginal lands of the northern outback. I could have stayed for months. Sydney - a stop-off on the way home via New Zealand and the Cook Islands - held no appeal after my journey through trackless lands alongside the Roper River. I'm sure it would have in other circumstances.

Mike Keighley, a real-life Crocodile Dundee with a practical sensitivity to the people, wildlife and places of his native patch of Australia, was the man who ensured I felt at home. Mike runs a travel outfit that specialises in setting up one-off, custom-made holidays and adventures for visitors to the Australian outback who wish to experience the "real thing", but, like me, have no real idea of what the "real thing" is.

But, like so many people who come this way, I hoped to meet some of the Aborigines who live in the Northern Territory on their own terms, although I imagined that they would probably prefer not to meet yet another "white fellah" in search of gratuitous adventure among the "black fellahs".

My first attempts to experience Aboriginal culture met, in my own terms, with failure. From Darwin, I flew to Bathhurst Island on a day trip to meet the Tiwi people. They couldn't have been more friendly, yet I felt like some dumb visiting dignatory. I was shown how to make "damper" (bush bread) and billy tea, watched a dance or two, was driven out to an ancestral burial ground, saw the sea and came back again.

I felt like asking my patient guides "with their permanent smiles" how long had they been here (40,000 years probably), where they came from (Papua New Guinea?) and what exactly they did (hunt, dance, play football, surf the net, get on with their lives when the tourists go back to their air-conditioned hotels on the mainland).

My dream would have been to trek across these all but virgin islands, to sleep out on the deserted white beaches under the stars as the Tiwi people do themselves. Who wouldn't want to on an underpopulated island as beautiful as Bathurst? Yet, why would the Tiwi people want me hanging around?

Back to Darwin, where the local art museum tells you more about Aboriginal ways of life, art and culture in a few superbly-arranged galleries than a day here or there on flying visits to the people themselves ever could. I fell completely under the spell of Aboriginal art, a living tradition in the Northern Territory.

Two hundred miles south at Katherine airport, enter Mike Keighley in a Mitsubishi 4WD pick-up, unpainted aluminium boat with outboard motor bobbing behind on a trailer and a gang of young Aborigines who he dropped off in out of the way places on our drive through the 32F heat along the Stuart Highway.

This is the one metalled road that connects the north and south coast through central Australia via Alice Springs. Left and right, there appears to be nothing, or at least not on the map. Out of the shimmering heat haze, at five-minute intervals, one road-train after another blasts past, klaxons blaring. These are the vast International and Mack trucks that rock'n'roll across the outback, leaving a trail of squished wildlife in their wake. We were off to see Mike's friends some way south and east of Mataranka and well off the Stuart Highway. Mike, a bit of a school drop-out, was "adopted" a long while back by the indigenous tribes of the Aboriginal homelands that stretch for days along the banks of the Roper River and up into Arnhem Land.

As a tourist, you need permits to head off the highway into these prohibited areas, which comprise half the land mass of the vast Northern Territory. Applications are sent via the territorial government in Darwin to the tribes themselves who may or may not give their assent. And why should they? Outsiders haven't exactly done much to endear themselves to Aboriginal Australians over the past 200 years. Although the majority of Aborigines in the Northern Territory live in towns, many have gone back out into the bush where they can pursue their own way of life undisturbed.

Mike drives straight past signs warning visitors that they're entering prohibited lands and on into the ultimately roadless, trackless wilderness that forms most of the all-but-uninhabited Northern Territory. He tells me as we wind through a magical landscape dominated by giant termite's nests, that the 35,000 or so Aborigines in the Territory speak about 40 languages between them. These can be as different as Italian is from Cantonese. Most people speak five or six. The languages are infiltrated with pidgin English and you'll find young men with names like Petrol, Dieselmotor and Applemac along with women named, after the influence of Christian missionaries, Erica, Christine and Sheila, which we do.

Down we plunged to a dusty village, past piles of beer cans ("the men come out to booze on Friday nights," says Mike; "they've prohibited alcohol in the village itself." The village is Jilminghan, a former cattle ranch near Elsey Station where Jeannie Gunn, the pioneer and novelist, lived and wrote her famous outback novel, We of the Never Never. It's a book as endearing to the Northern Territorians as The Virginian is to cowboys in Wyoming, the least populated of the US states. It was made into a feature film, with a little help from Jilminghan people in 1981.

The Mangarrayi men, whose village Jilminghan is, are away hunting. The children are at morning school. They're learning their own language when Erica, Christine and Sheila take me to say hello. "Jirr ka-nga jaykin" ("I'm standing"), they chant. "Ka-nga kurlaj ma" ("I'm shaking from side to side"). "Ka-mga ngorrony ma" ("I'm wriggling"). Two naked teenagers are sitting at computer screens, solar-powered, in a trailer alongside. They're studying for the equivalent of their A-levels via a link-up with the University of Darwin. While the men stick and shoot pigs, lizards and kangaroos out in the bush, their children are wired into the latest technology.

Jilminghan is a very long way from the tourist, day-trip stuff I'd seen. I like the fact that the corrugated houses built with grants from Darwin are barely lived in. The kitchens are unused; most of the rooms are used as storage and shelter when the rains eventually come.

We push Mike's boat out, waist deep in snakey ooze, into the Roper River near the village, and set off upstream to bathe naked in the natural jacuzzis that line the river banks. Kingfishers, red- tailed kites, black cockatoos and untold wings of budgerigars fly overhead and into the tropical treescape. Crocodiles lurk. "These are freshwater crocs," says Mike, "so, no worries. But, you do get salties [saltwater crocs] up here some days. That's when we need our steel bathing trunks."

This is a magical world, way off the tourist track. It gets much better when we return to pick up the village women and some of the teenagers after school to go off in search of bush-tucker (berries, roots, lizards, witchety grubs, whatever) and to link up with the men. We drive for a long, long way, bouncing through endless vistas of man-high termite nests. All I have to do to be accepted is be there, quietly, and then go shooting "piggies" with Mike. We kill two feral pigs and tie them on top of the boat bumping along behind us. "Good tucker," says Erica. Now we're all firm friends. The new "white fellah" is okay because he's with Mike and because he doesn't keep taking pictures.

Eventually, we run out of reliable ground to drive on. There is much consternation as to whether "piggies still there". They are. The vehicle is abandoned and we just walk, and walk, as the women collect food. And this, aside from cooking the piggies whole on an earth oven, singing, staring on my back at the infinite southern stars, is more or less how we spend our time.

How long, I don't know. Who cares what day it is? I learn about dances and Dreamtime and whose spiritual ancestor is a barking owl, whose a magpie, snake or caterpillar. I can't play the didgeridoo. In tourist shops and markets this is a beautiful, crafted instrument made, as it's meant to be, of a eucalyptus tree branch hollowed out by termites and with a honeybee wax mouthpiece. The local boys make do with plastic drainpipes they've bought in Woolworths on a rare trip hitch-hiking north to Katherine. The smart ones, are "for tourist fellahs".

Joining the men dragging whole Brahmin cows behind their 4WD pick-ups - really good bush-tucker: organic and free from BSE - I realised how much I'd changed in a just a few days before Mike drove me back to Katherine. As we walked into the local motel bar and restaurant looking like extras from The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith, a smart young Sydney woman (said so on her bag) sniffed "cowboys" as her boyfriend toyed with a green salad. Not that we stank, the climate's too dry for that, but we did look as if we'd just come back from walkabout. Which we had.

I'd go back to the Northern Territories, sports, at the drop of an Akubra hat. Still feel crook about Sydney though. Well, not that crook.

The practicals

Air New Zealand (020 8741 2299) flies daily from Heathrow to Sydney, via LA. Stopovers in LA permitted for free, or a choice of Pacific Islands for £30 each. Ansett Australia's G'Day Airpass (020 8741 2299) offers discounted domestic flights throughout Australia if pre-purchased in the UK. Mike Keighley can be contacted at Far Out Adventures, Katharine, NT. 0061 (0) 889 722552 or www.farout.com.au.

We push Mike's boat out, waist deep in snakey ooze, into the Roper River near the village, and set off upstream to bathe naked in the natural jacuzzis that line the river banks. Kingfishers, red- tailed kites, black cockatoos and untold wings of budgerigars fly overhead and into the tropical treescape. Crocodiles lurk. "These are freshwater crocs," says Mike, "so, no worries. But, you do get salties [saltwater crocs] up here some days. That's when we need our steel bathing trunks." This is a magical world, way off the tourist track. It gets much better when we return to pick up the village women and some of the teenagers after school to go off in search of bush-tucker (berries, roots, lizards, witchety grubs, whatever) and to link up with the men. We drive for a long, long way, bouncing through endless vistas of man-high termite nests. All I have to do to be accepted is be there, quietly, and then go shooting "piggies" with Mike. We kill two feral pigs and tie them on top of the boat bumping along behind us. "Good tucker," says Erica. Now we're all firm friends. The new "white fellah" is okay because he's with Mike and because he doesn't keep taking pictures. Eventually, we run out of reliable ground to drive on. There is much consternation as to whether "piggies still there". They are. The vehicle is abandoned and we just walk, and walk, as the women collect food. And this, aside from cooking the piggies whole on an earth oven, singing, staring on my back at the infinite southern stars, is more or less how we spend our time. How long, I don't know. Who cares what day it is? I learn about dances and Dreamtime and whose spiritual ancestor is a barking owl, whose a magpie, snake or caterpillar. I can't play the didgeridoo. In tourist shops and markets this is a beautiful, crafted instrument made, as it's meant to be, of a eucalyptus tree branch hollowed out by termites and with a honeybee wax mouthpiece. The local boys make do with plastic drainpipes they've bought in Woolworths on a rare trip hitch-hiking north to Katherine. The smart ones, are "for tourist fellahs". Joining the men dragging whole Brahmin cows behind their 4WD pick-ups - really good bush-tucker: organic and free from BSE - I realised how much I'd changed in a just a few days before Mike drove me back to Katherine. As we walked into the local motel bar and restaurant looking like extras from The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith, a smart young Sydney woman (said so on her bag) sniffed "cowboys" as her boyfriend toyed with a green salad. Not that we stank, the climate's too dry for that, but we did look as if we'd just come back from walkabout. Which we had. I'd go back to the Northern Territories, sports, at the drop of an Akubra hat. Still feel crook about Sydney though. Well, not that crook. fields.headline: Name dropping
fields.standfirst: The Readers' Editor on...  the dangers of a culture of anonymity
fields.trailText: The Readers' Editor on... the dangers of a culture of anonymity
fields.body:
There is a dilemma in writing about unattributed pejorative quotes. Do you repeat them for the purpose of discussing them, thereby adding to their circulation? I repeated one that was at the centre of a complaint dealt with in this column last week and decided that its use in the context complained of was justified, a conclusion with which several readers strongly disagreed. We have to differ. That particular remark will, however, slip quietly into oblivion. It does not resonate in the journalistic mind.

The same cannot be said, unfortunately, about a grossly offensive remark made by someone from whom, in May last year, we sought a comment upon the appointment of Andrew Motion as poet laureate. That the remark was intended to apply, as our story said, to the decision and not to Andrew Motion personally, was a distinction too fine perhaps for any of us to grasp.

It was immediately regretted by almost everyone concerned, including the poet who made the remark. If you are going to write about it, he said, you might point out that the source of the quote, appalled at how the remark was being both misapplied and misattributed, fairly swiftly identified himself and apologised to Andrew Motion, that it was made by a vociferous advocate of Carol Ann Duffy's candidature who heard the news at 11.30pm as he emerged from the pub somewhat the worse for drink, and was staggered to hear that the government had failed yet again to appoint a woman to the post, and that he regrets having come up with such an unfortunately resonant phrase.

Let me add the reminder that it was the Guardian that started the controversy in the first place. Andrew Motion says, yes, he did have a very long and apologetic letter from the person who made the remark, but by then the damage was done. It is easy to see what he means. In the nine months since it was printed in the Guardian the remark has been run in at least seven other newspapers and, more to the point, it has been repeated at least six times in the Guardian.

Andrew Motion said he could understand the need to use phrases such as "Downing Street sources" in the context of political reporting but the use of anonymous pejorative quotes apparently aimed at an individual was a cowardly practice and "just deeply irresponsible". Perhaps our regret that we ever used the remark would carry greater force if we desisted from any further repetition of the remark.

We have to ask ourselves whether there is an anomaly in our demanding greater openness and accountability from others, on the one hand, and the prevalence throughout the paper of unattributed material on the other. It seems to me that there is. It is not a question of whether the device is useful or not. It is sometimes an essential tool, most obviously, perhaps, in political reporting. The question is, are we, through allowing its proliferation, creating a culture of anonymity?

That is overstating the situation. However, the deputy editor (news) made the general point, "It is quite objectionable that we are allowing so many people to voice their opinions under the cloak of anonymity." We had been speaking earlier about our front page lead on Tuesday (February 22) headed "Secret plan to ditch Dobson", which claimed that Tony Blair had drawn up a contingency plan to back Mo Mowlam, rather than Frank Dobson, as Labour's London mayoral candidate if Ken Livingstone stood as an independent. There was no specific attribution anywhere in the story, even though remarks which Mr Blair was said to have made at a meeting with Mr Livingstone were placed within quotation marks.

The deputy editor (news) said that in these circumstances he always asked reporters and specialists three questions: Did they know the person or persons giving them the story? Had they dealt with the source before? And was the source in a position to know what he or she was telling us?

Our political editor said, "I have what I call the jury test. If you were forced to divulge your source would a jury think you were justified in what you had written?"

The editor of the paper acknowledges that the use of unattributed quotes can sometimes be a device for getting at the truth. In the case of a pejorative remark he suggested the journalist had to ask whether it provided so valuable an insight that it justified the shield of anonymity.

He said that if a story was being built around unattributable sources it should always be discussed with a senior editor, and the printed story should be as specific about the sources as possible, both the nature and number of them.

One final thought. If you do not already know what remark was made when Andrew Motion was made laureate, is that knowledge that you can manage to live without? Or do you have a feeling that I have let you down?

fields.headline: Universities review fee options
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Vice-chancellors at top universities yesterday reopened the debate on "top up" tuition fees by asking a group of leading economists to carry out an appraisal of different funding options for higher education.
fields.body:
Vice-chancellors at top universities yesterday reopened the debate on "top up" tuition fees by asking a group of leading economists to carry out an appraisal of different funding options for higher education.

The influential Russell group of 20 universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, is fighting for the right to charge higher fees in order to maintain standards in the face of international competition.

English universities are currently prevented from charging fees higher than the standard £1,025 a year payable by full-time undergraduates, although they can charge overseas students much higher "market-based" fees of between £6,000 and £7,000.

Last week the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, acknowledged that another strategic review on funding for higher education was needed, and refused to rule out the possibility that "top up" or differential fees might be introduced in the next parliament.

Yesterday the Russell group discussed different options at a special meeting at Warwick university. These included larger grant allocations by the government, deregulation of fees and core funding made available via student vouchers. The group has asked the economists, who include Nick Barr of the London School of Economics, to examine the practical implications of these options.

A key priority will be to ensure that students unable to afford fees could still enter higher education, through bursary or other schemes. In a statement yesterday the vice-chancellors said: "The challenge Britain's top universities face is finding a system which both brings in additional resources to help Britain's top universities compete with the best in the world, and ensures better social representation from under-represented groups".

webTitle: Dow dives as boom goes on

fields.headline: Dow dives as boom goes on
fields.trailText: US financial markets were last night bracing themselves for higher interest rates after figures showing the economy is continuing to power ahead.
fields.body:
US financial markets were last night bracing themselves for higher interest rates after figures showing the economy is continuing to power ahead.

On Wall Street fears of dearer borrowing costs sent the Dow Jones industrial average tumbling through the 10,000 mark. It ended 230 down on the day at 9,862, its lowest point in 10 months. However, the prospect that the federal reserve - which has raised interest rates four times since last June - will again increase borrowing costs next month boosted US bond prices and the dollar

Meanwhile, the Nasdaq composite index, which had seesawed all day, slipped 27.16 points, to 4,590. Earlier, the technology-stacked index touched an intra-day high of 4,662.93.

Yesterday's economic figures showed the US economy growing at an annualised rate of 6.9% in the final quarter of last year - well ahead of market expectations.

Analysts had accounted for a 6.4% rate of growth. "It definitely reveals unexpected vigour for the US economy in the final quarter and only enhances the likelihood of a rate hike at the March 21 meeting of the federal open market committee," according to John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investor Services in New York.

"The US economy is rocking", was the reaction from Merrill Lynch economist Gerald Cohen.

The continuing strength of the American economy is adding to fears that it will eventually feed through into inflation, forcing the fed to push rates higher.

"The stock market more and more is waking up to the realisation that two more interest rate hikes and perhaps three are being factored in," according to one market strategist.

The boom in the American economy is being powered by consumer spending, which accounts for two thirds of all economic activity, higher government expenditure and higher business inventories as companies stock up in the belief that the spending spree will continue.

The fed may not be too concerned by the fall in the Dow Jones. High share prices have helped Americans to feel wealthier and made them prepared to spend more and save less, keeping the consumer boom going.

Lower share prices may help to check the heady growth rate bringing economic expansion back to levels the US central bank would view as more sustainable.

But it will be concerned that the sell-off - which has seen the Dow Jones fall back 15% from the 11,700-point level in the middle of last month - does not turn into a rout.

Financial markets are likely to remain jittery in the coming week with various economic data due to be released in the coming days.

fields.headline: Flood relief
fields.trailText: The world watches as cyclone Eline destroys the homes and livelihoods of the people of Mozambique, among the poorest in the world (Cyclone hits battered Mozambique, February 23). The British government has announced a welcome $1.2m in emergency aid. Yet, Mozambique pays $1.4m a week in debt service to western creditors.
fields.body:
The world watches as cyclone Eline destroys the homes and livelihoods of the people of Mozambique, among the poorest in the world (Cyclone hits battered Mozambique, February 23). The British government has announced a welcome $1.2m in emergency aid. Yet, Mozambique pays $1.4m a week in debt service to western creditors. Despite receiving some debt relief, it continues to spend more on debt servicing than on primary healthcare. Much of the country's foreign debt was built up during the apartheid-sponsored war which cost 1m lives.

More than ever, Mozambique needs to keep the dollars it currently pays out on debt servicing. It would be economically irresponsible and morally reprehensible for western creditors to insist on any further payments. The debt needs to be cancelled outright. Mozambique has suffered enough.
Ben Jackson
Action for Southern Africa
Julian Filoschowski
Cafod
Dalip Mukherjee
Christian Aid
Ann Pettifor
Jubilee 2000 UK
Justin Forsyth
Oxfam

 I hope that the government and the people of Britain will be generous; but, so far, I have neither heard nor seen any reference in the media to the fact that Mozambique has been a member of the Commonwealth since 1995.
Martyn Berry
Sevenoaks, Kent

webTitle: Introduction: should we extend pub opening hours?

fields.headline: Introduction: should we extend pub opening hours?
fields.body: This week an NOP poll for the Institute for Alcohol Studies found a significant majority of the British public opposed to reform of the licensing laws. But polls by the Campaign for Real Ale suggest the exact opposite, and government is moving towards liberalising the laws on pub opening hours. Are our current licensing laws a vital safeguard against alcohol-related violence and binge drinking? Or are they contributing to it? In this week's Saturday Review debate, Andrew McNeill of the Institute for Alcohol Studies and Mike Benner of Camra debate the question. Read the debate then tell us what you think.
