webTitle: Should we extend pub opening hours?

fields.headline: Should we extend pub opening hours?
fields.trailText: The alcohol industry has been campaigning for years for the relaxation, if not the removal, of what it claims are our antiquated and unpopular licensing laws - and appears to have persuaded the government and media that much-needed reform has been blocked only by a minority of cranks and  fanatics determined to prevent  people from enjoying themselves.
fields.body:
Dear Mike,
The alcohol industry has been campaigning for years for the relaxation, if not the removal, of what it claims are our antiquated and unpopular licensing laws - and appears to have persuaded the government and media that much-needed reform has been blocked only by a minority of cranks and fanatics determined to prevent people from enjoying themselves.

The truth is otherwise. A culture of binge drinking largely explains our present licensing laws. And reform of those laws will not be a response to popular demand. A survey we commissioned from National Opinion Polls this week shows there is not a single region in which there is a majority for extending drinking hours at night; the greater the increase in hours being proposed, the smaller is the minority in favour.

There is some support for a limited extension of drinking hours in town centres, rather than in residential areas. Most people regard our present laws as useful social safeguards. They are right. Experience shows that deregulation of closing times serves the interests of the licensed trade and a minority of drinkers at the expense of the community. This is not to deny the need for any reform. But licensing controls cannot be dismantled without adverse effects.

Yours sincerely,
Andrew McNeill,
Co-director,
Institute for Alcohol Studies

Dear Andrew,
The industry has been campaigning for the modernisation of licensing to enable the licensed trade to better meet the needs of consumers. The current laws are based on legislation introduced by Lloyd George to ensure that first world war ammunition workers remained sober. This hardly meets the needs of today's consumers.

The results of our surveys show an entirely different result from yours. Every six months over the last two years we have been tracking public views and the results have been consistent. The latest (January) show that 61% of adults agree that a pub should be able to open when the landlord pleases, subject to no major objections from the community. Only 23% disagreed. Camra is in favour of a flexible approach to opening hours, but we believe (as, it would appear, does the government) that local residents need to be protected from nuisance. That can be achieved via a set of guidelines implemented at local level.

Previous liberalisation in 1988 and 1995 did not lead to significant increases in consumption or alcohol related disorder. Nor did the decision to let pubs open for a 36- hour period over the last New Year. Just the opposite. Experiments in relaxation of hours in Scotland and the Netherlands refute your claim.

Yours sincerely,
Mike Benner,
Head of Campaigns,
The Campaign for Real Ale

Dear Mike,
To my knowledge, our NOP survey is the most comprehensive and reliable survey of public attitudes to alcohol in recent years. Questions were included about whether pubs should be able to stay open with no set closing times. The results were 16% in favour for residential areas, and 27% in favour for city centres. You have every right to your views, but it would be better to accept that they are the views of a minority.

Is what you want sensible? The millennium celebrations were such a one-off that I don't believe they provide a guide to other New Years' Eves, let alone the rest of the year. Our information is that, in the Netherlands, less than 10% of municipalities experimented with deregulated closing times and in half of these the experiment failed. In Scotland, the government urged licensing boards to control late night opening better because "the proliferation of late night extensions is causing distress to local residents and to police out of all proportion to any benefit the community may derive from such extensions".

We accept that the laws need modernisation. But the evidence is clear that the changes you want would be socially harmful and unpopular.

Yours sincerely,
Andrew

Dear Andrew,
I think it is unreasonable to suggest that the results of a survey of 1,800 people (less than 0.004 % of the adult population) should be treated as a reality. Our research does not support your findings. Recent research by the all-party parliamentary beer group (some 300 MPs) included a detailed study of systems in Scotland. It found that the current, more flexible, system is better than the previous strict early closing times, because there was a reduced tendency to binge drink.

Surely it is not unreasonable to allow adults to make a choice. Is it fair that people are forced to "sup up and get out" at 11.20 each evening? They are left with the option, not of continuing to enjoy the company of friends in their local, but going home or on to a night club.

Inflexible drinking hours cause unnecessary stresses on public services and lead to increased alcohol-related crime. Chucking thousands of people out at the same time, all battling for the same taxi and kebab, leads to trouble. Our licensing laws have helped label Brits as the lager louts of Europe. The liberalisation of opening hours will, over time, lead to a society which does not rely on binge drinking to have a good time. You acknowledge that there is a need for modernisation of the law. What would you like to see?

Yours sincerely,
Mike

Dear Mike,
If our poll fails to show anything of significance, then so do yours - in which case public opinion must remain forever unknown. I am aware of the report of the all-party parliamentary beer group. I think you will accept that this is not exactly an impartial body. Nor does it represent the views of the public. It is a lobby group which promotes the interests of the breweries, the main beneficiaries of the reforms you want to see.

We can throw the Scottish experience to and fro all day. We do not claim that Scotland proves beyond all doubt that any extensions of drinking hours are a wholly bad thing. We do not claim that, at least in city centres, 11pm closing should be totally unalterable in England. What we do say is that radical change should not be imposed on an unwilling public and that the onus is on those who want it to show that it is in the public interest. We do not think they have succeeded in doing so. The available evidence suggests that deregulation is more likely to reduce the quality of life of the majority than improve it.

The main reform we would like to see is in the direction of greater involvement of the public in licensing decisions that directly or indirectly affect their lives, whether they drink in pubs or not. That could well result in variable closing times. I hope you will agree with us on this even though the majority of the public have different interests from your own.

Yours sincerely,
Andrew

Dear Andrew,
My understanding of opinion polls is that they are simply useful indicators of the public view. Surely legislation on an issue as important as this should not be based on a one-off survey of 1,800 people, the full details of which have not to my knowledge been made publicly available. Far better to consider equally the views of all interested parties including the trade, the better regulation task force, the association of chief police officers and the like?

You appear to doubt the impartiality of the MPs who make up the parliamentary beer group. They receive no payment for this work and they are not a "lobby group". They do care about the future of an industry which supports 900,000 British jobs. They also represent some 26m constituents.

It is not a question of deregulation and it never has been. All parties agree that there is a clear need for a legislative regime to protect people from alcohol abuse. It's just that the current system makes the problem worse. You accept the need for modernisation and you do not claim that 11pm closing should be unalterable. Your main point is that there should be greater involvement of the public in licensing decisions. I agree. Every individual will have a right to make their views on this issue known to the home office when consultation begins in the spring.

I trust that the government will listen to those views and to those of the many organisations that have taken an interest in this issue. It would be a black day if policy was based on the results of a one-off survey from an organisation sponsored by the UK temperance alliance. Perhaps we can meet up over a pint or two. Preferably in a pub and at a time of our choice.

Yours sincerely,
Mike

fields.bodyText: Dear Mike, The alcohol industry has been campaigning for years for the relaxation, if not the removal, of what it claims are our antiquated and unpopular licensing laws - and appears to have persuaded the government and media that much-needed reform has been blocked only by a minority of cranks and fanatics determined to prevent people from enjoying themselves. The truth is otherwise. A culture of binge drinking largely explains our present licensing laws. And reform of those laws will not be a response to popular demand. A survey we commissioned from National Opinion Polls this week shows there is not a single region in which there is a majority for extending drinking hours at night; the greater the increase in hours being proposed, the smaller is the minority in favour. There is some support for a limited extension of drinking hours in town centres, rather than in residential areas. Most people regard our present laws as useful social safeguards. They are right. Experience shows that deregulation of closing times serves the interests of the licensed trade and a minority of drinkers at the expense of the community. This is not to deny the need for any reform. But licensing controls cannot be dismantled without adverse effects. Yours sincerely, Andrew McNeill, Co-director, Institute for Alcohol Studies Dear Andrew, The industry has been campaigning for the modernisation of licensing to enable the licensed trade to better meet the needs of consumers. The current laws are based on legislation introduced by Lloyd George to ensure that first world war ammunition workers remained sober. This hardly meets the needs of today's consumers. The results of our surveys show an entirely different result from yours. Every six months over the last two years we have been tracking public views and the results have been consistent. The latest (January) show that 61% of adults agree that a pub should be able to open when the landlord pleases, subject to no major objections from the community. Only 23% disagreed. Camra is in favour of a flexible approach to opening hours, but we believe (as, it would appear, does the government) that local residents need to be protected from nuisance. That can be achieved via a set of guidelines implemented at local level. Previous liberalisation in 1988 and 1995 did not lead to significant increases in consumption or alcohol related disorder. Nor did the decision to let pubs open for a 36- hour period over the last New Year. Just the opposite. Experiments in relaxation of hours in Scotland and the Netherlands refute your claim. Yours sincerely, Mike Benner, Head of Campaigns, The Campaign for Real Ale Dear Mike, To my knowledge, our NOP survey is the most comprehensive and reliable survey of public attitudes to alcohol in recent years. Questions were included about whether pubs should be able to stay open with no set closing times. The results were 16% in favour for residential areas, and 27% in favour for city centres. You have every right to your views, but it would be better to accept that they are the views of a minority. Is what you want sensible? The millennium celebrations were such a one-off that I don't believe they provide a guide to other New Years' Eves, let alone the rest of the year. Our information is that, in the Netherlands, less than 10% of municipalities experimented with deregulated closing times and in half of these the experiment failed. In Scotland, the government urged licensing boards to control late night opening better because "the proliferation of late night extensions is causing distress to local residents and to police out of all proportion to any benefit the community may derive from such extensions". We accept that the laws need modernisation. But the evidence is clear that the changes you want would be socially harmful and unpopular. Yours sincerely, Andrew Dear Andrew, I think it is unreasonable to suggest that the results of a survey of 1,800 people (less than 0.004 % of the adult population) should be treated as a reality. Our research does not support your findings. Recent research by the all-party parliamentary beer group (some 300 MPs) included a detailed study of systems in Scotland. It found that the current, more flexible, system is better than the previous strict early closing times, because there was a reduced tendency to binge drink. Surely it is not unreasonable to allow adults to make a choice. Is it fair that people are forced to "sup up and get out" at 11.20 each evening? They are left with the option, not of continuing to enjoy the company of friends in their local, but going home or on to a night club. Inflexible drinking hours cause unnecessary stresses on public services and lead to increased alcohol-related crime. Chucking thousands of people out at the same time, all battling for the same taxi and kebab, leads to trouble. Our licensing laws have helped label Brits as the lager louts of Europe. The liberalisation of opening hours will, over time, lead to a society which does not rely on binge drinking to have a good time. You acknowledge that there is a need for modernisation of the law. What would you like to see? Yours sincerely, Mike Dear Mike, If our poll fails to show anything of significance, then so do yours - in which case public opinion must remain forever unknown. I am aware of the report of the all-party parliamentary beer group. I think you will accept that this is not exactly an impartial body. Nor does it represent the views of the public. It is a lobby group which promotes the interests of the breweries, the main beneficiaries of the reforms you want to see. We can throw the Scottish experience to and fro all day. We do not claim that Scotland proves beyond all doubt that any extensions of drinking hours are a wholly bad thing. We do not claim that, at least in city centres, 11pm closing should be totally unalterable in England. What we do say is that radical change should not be imposed on an unwilling public and that the onus is on those who want it to show that it is in the public interest. We do not think they have succeeded in doing so. The available evidence suggests that deregulation is more likely to reduce the quality of life of the majority than improve it. The main reform we would like to see is in the direction of greater involvement of the public in licensing decisions that directly or indirectly affect their lives, whether they drink in pubs or not. That could well result in variable closing times. I hope you will agree with us on this even though the majority of the public have different interests from your own. Yours sincerely, Andrew Dear Andrew, My understanding of opinion polls is that they are simply useful indicators of the public view. Surely legislation on an issue as important as this should not be based on a one-off survey of 1,800 people, the full details of which have not to my knowledge been made publicly available. Far better to consider equally the views of all interested parties including the trade, the better regulation task force, the association of chief police officers and the like? You appear to doubt the impartiality of the MPs who make up the parliamentary beer group. They receive no payment for this work and they are not a "lobby group". They do care about the future of an industry which supports 900,000 British jobs. They also represent some 26m constituents. It is not a question of deregulation and it never has been. All parties agree that there is a clear need for a legislative regime to protect people from alcohol abuse. It's just that the current system makes the problem worse. You accept the need for modernisation and you do not claim that 11pm closing should be unalterable. Your main point is that there should be greater involvement of the public in licensing decisions. I agree. Every individual will have a right to make their views on this issue known to the home office when consultation begins in the spring. I trust that the government will listen to those views and to those of the many organisations that have taken an interest in this issue. It would be a black day if policy was based on the results of a one-off survey from an organisation sponsored by the UK temperance alliance. Perhaps we can meet up over a pint or two. Preferably in a pub and at a time of our choice. Yours sincerely, Mike Join the debate

webTitle: Join the crowds going online to go on holiday

fields.headline: Join the crowds going online to go on holiday
fields.standfirst: Websites are an increasingly popular first stop for tourists as more and more firms sell their packages on the net. Jill Papworth reports
fields.trailText: Websites are an increasingly popular first stop for tourists as more and more firms sell their packages on the net.
fields.body:
Holidaymakers and other travellers who book their flights and accommodation via the internet might consider adding travel insurance to their web-based purchases given the growing number of providers now selling their policies online.

If you want to explore this route, you can save yourself time surfing between competitors looking for the best deals by checking out the latest findings from independent financial product analysts The Research Department (TRD).

The results of an investigation into purchasing travel insurance in the UK through various distribution channels, including the internet, can be found on its website www.trd.co.uk together with useful "best buy" tables on single trip and annual cover policies and direct links into the websites of more than 30 online providers.

Brian Brown, associate director of research at TRD, says: "There is a bewildering range of travel insurance products available online and purchasers need to be careful about selecting the right product for their needs. Not all policies offer the same levels of cover and prices can vary significantly."

Through analysing single trip and annual travel policies from from more than 150 providers TRD found that the price differential in travel insurance can be staggering. Holidaymakers buying their insurance from one source can pay almost eight times as much for the same cover through other sources.

Cover levels also vary tremendously with some policies offering considerably more extras than others, sometimes for little extra premium, and often for lower premiums.

The price you pay and the level of cover you get will also differ depending on the distribution channel you use. TRD says that, for example: "while some tour operators' products provide excellent levels of cover, in many cases this is at the most expensive prices. (And) in some cases tour operator insurance actually offers poorer levels of cover than elsewhere".

While buyers should ideally get quotes and compare cover from a variety of distribution channels, TRD points out that policies sold direct or via the internet can be purchased easily, often for significant discounts to those purchased from tour operators or travel agents.

Before buying travel insurance on the Net you should:

Make sure you know what you want before you start. Products tend to group into basic, standard and super levels of cover and are priced accordingly.

Remember insurance is not just about price. Make sure you know what level of cover you are getting for your money. While it's vital to make sure you are not underinsured, there's little point in paying extra for unnecessary cover or bells and whistles you don't need.

Check out a few websites. Don't be tempted to buy on the first site you see just because the price looks cheap.

Don't buy from a site that does not tell you full details of your cover until after you buy the policy.

It is preferable to select a UK-based website with a "real world" address, not a PO Box.

As with all internet purchases only give your credit card details if using a secure site which uses encrypted connections.

When the policy arrives, read the smallprint carefully. If it is not what you expected, you will be able to return it and get a refund, but usually only within 7-14 days.

As an example of the net deals available, TRD analysed more than 40 products available for purchase online from 31 providers and compared premium prices for a 17 day single European trip (excluding winter sports cover) for both a single person and a family of four comprising two adults and two children aged 10 and 12.

Checking out the top three best price policies alone highlights the variation in price and cover. I found that all three providers offer clear, navigable websites with straightforward online purchase forms.

The best priced policy at £11.36 for a single person and £22.72 for the family is Protect Travel insurance from insurance intermediary Under The Sun (www.underthesun.co.uk) based in Sidcup, Kent. Protect is the provider's budget policy costing some 40% less than its super level 'Premium' policy with a £40 excess on most claims. While Protect provides many of the same benefits as Premium, such as £5m medical, £2m personal liability, £25,000 personal accident and £500 money, the premium saving is made by excluding cancellation and baggage cover. This would suit holidaymakers who make a last minute booking which they are unlikely to cancel and those with low value baggage or baggage cover provided in their household policy.

Next cheapest is the single trip policy from Policy Partners (www.policypartners.co.uk), a division of Leicestershire-based James Hampden Insurance Brokers, which costs £12.56 for a single person and £26.17 for a family with a £35 excess on claims. The cover on this policy is comfortingly comprehensive including £3m medical, £2,500 cancellation or curtailment and £1,500 baggage with a relatively high single article limit of £500. The only irritating thing about the Policy Partners site is that, unlike many other providers' sites, it does not provide a clear table of premium quotes for different policies and trips. You only get a premium quote once you have filled out an application form outlining your details.

Finally, I checked out the Standard Level single trip policy from Worldwide Travel Insurance (www.wwtis.co.uk) which costs £13.50 for a single adult and £27 for our example family. This again provides comprehensive cover, perfectly adequate for most holidaymakers, but charges excesses of £50 on medical claims and £100 on personal liability or legal expense claims.

Worldwide Travel Insurance is also the provider of the Single Trip Elite policy, which scores one of TRD's highest star ratings, assigned on the basis of premium levels and cover compared with other internet travel products. Costing £22 for a single adult and £44 per family, again for a 17 day sin gle European trip, Elite provides high levels of cover in all categories, has no excess and includes extras like "new for old" baggage cover compared with the "wear and tear" cover provided by most travel policies.

Other policies which scored a top star rating for single European trip cover are Gold TravelCover from Bupa (www.bupa.co.uk); Single Trip Travel Insurance from Travelstore.com (www.travelstore.com); Travel Protector from NatWest (www.natwest.co.uk) and Travel Insurance from the Halifax (www.halifax.co.uk).

fields.headline: Dogged determination
fields.standfirst: Cats and dogs no longer have to suffer in quarantine, but  Nicky Holford learns that taking pets on holiday is not plain sailing
fields.trailText: Cats and dogs no longer have to suffer in quarantine, but Nicky Holford learns that taking pets on holiday is not plain sailing.
fields.body:
On Monday, for the first time in 100 years, pet owners will be allowed to take their animals abroad and bring them home without having to leave them in quarantine for six months.

At first, the idea that Pickle, our Norfolk Terrier, could join the family holiday to France filled us with enthusiasm. There would no longer be the worry or expense of putting him in kennels or finding family or friends to look after him.

And as France is very dog friendly, we thought we would take Pickle along. Tour operators such as Thomson list hotels that will accept pets.

But the reality has proved to be so complicated - filling out forms, visiting the vet and trying to decipher the requirement by the Ministry of Agriculture - that it hardly seems worth it. Each country you visit has its own requirements and some are stricter than others.

The bureaucratic nightmare is enough to put off most owners, certainly those travelling on short breaks. The process can take up to six months, and there is always the nagging worry that you might have forgotten some vital document so that when it comes to the crunch, you have to leave your pet on the quay.

Hoops to jump through

1 Microchip

The vet shaves a small patch of the animal's skin and injects the chip, which is the size of a grain of rice. Microchips have been around for several years but some of the older ones cannot be read by the European scanners that will be used at ports of entry. This is your responsibility and may mean you have to buy a scanner (£150) so your pet's identity can be checked. Microchips cost £20-£30.

2 Rabies shot

Some vets recommend two shots two weeks apart - £38 for the first £28 for the second.

3 Blood sample

Thirty days after the rabies shot, a sample of blood must be taken to an approved Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAFF) laboratory to make sure your pet has the required antibody. There is only one laboratory in the UK that performs this complicated test, so most samples are shipped to laboratories in Europe. Currently labs are receiving 45-50 samples a day. When the Ministry of Agriculture started offering the test it cost £58 and was reduced to £46.50. Some vets add a handling charge. My vet charged £70.50. Takes 4-6 weeks.

4 Declaration of residence

You will also need this to declare that you have not taken your pet to any country not listed in the pets pilot scheme. It can be obtained from MAFF or the transport company you will be using. Amazingly, no cost.

5 Export health certificate

The country you are taking your pet to will require you to have one of these. Requirements vary from country to country. Germany, for example, requires a bilingual certificate. The form obtained from MAFF has to be filled in by you and issued by a government-authorised Local Vetinary Inspector - in my case this was my local vet. MAFF has a list of all LVIs. Takes 2-6 weeks. £30-£40.

6 Overseas inspection

Before returning to Britain, your pet has to be inspected by a government-authorised vet to check it has not picked up any ticks or tapeworm. The inspection must take place not less than 24 hours and not more than 48 hours before you are due to travel. Even if you are going abroad for a day, pets still have to see a vet before returning. £20 upwards.

7 Insurance

Check your pet insurance will cover animals abroad. Most do not.

 The pilot Pet Travel Scheme will run until early next year. If it is a success, it may be extended to include other types of pets, air carriers and more countries. The countries taking part in the pilot scheme are France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Greece, Austria, Germany, Andorra, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Gibraltar, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Sweden, Luxembourg, Monaco, Holland, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and Vatican City.

 The MAFF pet travel helpline is on 0870 2411710, www.maff.gov.uk For information on Thomson hotels that will accept pets, phone 0870 6061470

The practicals

Expect to pay around £30 to cover costs of scanning the microchip and checking the documents.

fields.headline: Desktop publishing
fields.standfirst: Jane Austen's portable writing box goes on show for the first time next month.  Sally Varlow tracks down the desks on which the classics came to life
fields.trailText: Jane Austen's portable writing box goes on show for the first time next month.  Sally Varlow tracks down the desks on which the classics came to life
fields.body:
The writing desk Jane Austen used to write Pride and Prejudice, Emma and Sense and Sensibility, will be shown for the first time next month when the British Library opens a new exhibition, Chapter and Verse: 1,000 years of English literature.

If it steals the show from Charlotte Brontë's Jane Eyre manuscript or the Beatles' lyrics, it won't be due to size and splendour. It is a plain, hinged wooden box with a drawer that still holds her tiny, wire-framed "granny specs". Its fascination lies purely in its link with her books, and in what it says about the way she wrote - perched at a table in a parlour, her papers easily hidden away.

 The British Library (020-7412 7332), 96 Euston Road NW1, March 10 to October 15. Entry: adults £3, concessions £2, under 18s free.

Like Jane Austen, the Brontë Sisters used portable wooden writing desks, propped on a table wherever there was time and space to write. Their home at Haworth still contains the three boxes Charlotte, Emily and Anne filled with little hoards of personal possessions.

Charlotte's was polished rosewood with silver trim, held pens (quill and steel nibbed), seals and sealing wax, an invitation to a reception and a tiny book of devotions. Anne's was inlaid mahogany, lined in velvet, with brass fittings. Emily's, well-used and ink stained, held some Belgian bills, letters and coins, five newspaper reviews of Wuthering Heights and, most poignant of all, a letter from her publisher urging her not to send her second - now lost - novel till she was "well satisfied with it".

 Brontë Parsonage (01535 642323), Haworth, Keighley, West Yorkshire BD22 8DR. Open daily, Oct 1 - March 31, 11am - 5pm; April 1 - Sep 30, 10am - 5pm. Adults £4.50, concessions £3.30, children (5-16) £1.40.

George Bernard Shaw, ever the rationalist, had a desk to write at, one to read at and another, possibly favourite, at the bottom of the garden. Fixed into a corner of his revolving summerhouse, it is a curiously flimsy little desk for such a heavyweight (but witty) dramatist, critic and writer. Alongside are his cane chair, wastepaper bin, fire and fold-away bed, where G (don't "George" me) BS would stretch out and think, or nap.

What he was thinking during his 44 years at Shaw's Corner was nothing less than a political revolution (Brecht called him a terrorist who made humour his weapon) spelt out in thousands of articles, lectures and letters, as well as all the plays: Heartbreak House, Pygmalion (an Oscar-winning film even before it became My Fair Lady), Saint Joan, The Apple Cart and much more. When he died, 50 years ago this year, aged 94, he was still writing for the theatre.

 Shaw's Corner (01438 820307), Ayot St Lawrence, Hertfordshire AL6 9BX. Open April 1 -Oct 29, Wed -Sun. Adults £3.50, children £1.75, family £8.75. The National Trust and RADA plan anniversary events in London and Shaw's Corner.

Arthur Ransome claimed Swallows and Amazons "almost wrote itself". He'd fallen out with the family of children who inspired Swallow's crew and wanted to reclaim the book as his own childhood memories of the Lake District: "No matter where I was, wandering about the world - in my mind's eye [I] could see the beloved skyline of great hills."

His wanderings (war correspondent in Russia during the Revolution) and restless life mean there isn't a Ransome house to visit. But his widow, Evgenia (Trotsky's secretary when they met) gave his desk and prized possessions to the Museum of Lakeland Life in Kendal. It is kept on show in a special room surrounded by his fishing rods and pipes, sketchbooks and, photos, a Jolly Roger flag, and the chess set he used in Russia (to beat Lenin, once, he said).

 Museum of Lakeland Life and Industry (01539 722464), Abbot Hall, Kendal, Cumbria LA9 5AL. Open daily Feb 10 - Dec 22. Entry: adults £3, seniors £2.80, children £1.50, family £7.50.

Hugh MacDiarmid, Scotland's modern-day national poet, died 21 years ago. His home in the Borders, a basic, two-room labourer's cottage, looks as though he left it yesterday. The table he wrote at (always in foolscap, covering every inch of space) and most of the well-worn furniture came from second-hand sales at nearby Biggar; but it was better than the fruit-boxes the family used during their penniless stay in Shetland.

 Brownsbank (01899 221050), Candy Mill, Biggar, Strathclyde. Open strictly by appointment. No charge, but donations welcome.

Charles Dickens is too big a writer and character to have left just one desk. There seem to be half a dozen dotted around. One of the most famous is in the Dickens Centre at Rochester, the city Dickens knew from childhood, returned to once he'd made his fortune, and used as the backdrop for Great Expectations and Edwin Drood. The desk is part of a large-scale recreation of the portrait known as The Dream, in which Dickens sits daydreaming while his characters reappear around him.

 The Charles Dickens Centre (01634 844176), Eastgate House, High Street, Rochester, Kent ME1 1EW. Open daily year round (except Christmas). Adults £3.50, seniors and children £2.50.

Dylan Thomas called his bright-blue workshed at Laugharne "The Shack", a "water and tree room on the cliff". Seated at the simple red table, he could see the "heron priested" Taf Estuary spread out below, while he wrote - and re-wrote - Under Milk Wood and the lines to his dying father, Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night.

His other desk, inherited from his father, stands in the parlour of the nearby Boat House, where he lived with Caitlin and their children.

 Dylan Thomas Boat House (01994 427420), Laugharne, Carmarthenshire SA33 4SD. Open all year (except Christmas). Adults £2.75, seniors £1.75, children (7-14) £1.

Thomas Hardy's study in his last home, Max Gate (the singularly charmless house he designed himself), was moved lock, stock and desk to Dorset County Museum after his widow died in 1935. Now the museum, in Dorchester (Hardy's Casterbridge), has moved it upstairs to a first-rate new Thomas Hardy gallery. In the book-lined study, his desk is laid out with his blotter and "dipping" pens, each inscribed, by him, with the name of the books they had written: Tess of the d'Urbervilles, Jude The Obscure and The Woodlanders.

 Dorset County Museum (01305 262735), High West Street, Dorchester, Dorset DT2 7LG. Open Mon - Sat all year; Sunday in July and August. Adults £3.30, seniors and students £2.20, children £1.60.

Rudyard Kipling's desk at Bateman's in Sussex is solidly "establishment", preserved pen for pen as he left it. "I always kept certain gadgets on my work table," he wrote, "a long lacquered canoe-shaped pen tray, full of brushes and dead 'fountains', a wooden box held clips and bands, another, a tin one, pins; all manner of unneeded essentials from emery paper to small screw drivers - an inky foot rule - left and right of the table were two big globes."

It sits in serene peace, overlooking classic English countryside where Bombay-born Kipling finally felt at home. The Jungle Book and Just So Stories were already in print when he came here, but once he'd set out his writing table he dreamed up Puck of Pook's Hill and his eternally popular If...

 Bateman's (01435 882302), Burwash, Etchingham, East Sussex TN19 7DS. Open April 1 - Nov 1, Sat - Wed, open Good Friday. adults £5, children £2.50, family £12.50.

Lucy Boston always wrote in pencil at the dining-room table, facing the French windows where she fed the birds, and with her back to the huge hearth of her mysterious 12th-century home in the Fens.

As everyone knows who grew up on The Children of Green Knowe, (or heard it broadcast last Christmas) this is where young Tolly finds himself inside - the ground floor of a castle - furnished with "comfortable polished old-fashioned things as though living in castles was quite ordinary". Except that great-grandma Oldknow and her ancient house turn out to be anything but ordinary.

The polished old-fashioned table and chair where Lucy wrote, the attic filled with ghostly children's toys and the lovely moated gardens are kept exactly as she restored - and Tolly found - them.

 The Manor (01480 463134), Hemingford Grey, Huntingdon PE18 9BN. Open year round by appointment. Adults £4, seniors £3.50, children £1.50.

Agatha Christie's typewriter, a 1937 Remington portable, takes pride of place among family photos, portraits, bits of porcelain, theatre programmes and early editions in the Agatha Christie Memorial Room in Torquay.

Her desk isn't there, so this one is a cheat (so what: critics claimed The Murder of Roger Ackroyd had a "rotten cheat ending"), but the typewriter was more important. Most of her 80-odd books and 19 plays were typed straight on to it, she said, using three fingers not two.

There is something deliciously sinister about the quiet, panelled room in Torre Abbey, Torquay's oldest building. Poirot or Miss Marple could appear any second.

 Torre Abbey (01803 293593), King's Drive, Torquay, Devon TQ2 5JE. Open daily Apr 1 - Nov 1. Adults £3, seniors £2.50, children (8-15) £1.50.

 Sally Varlow's Traveller's Guide to Writers' Britain will be reissued in May by Prion Books at £15.
fields.bodyText: The writing desk Jane Austen used to write Pride and Prejudice, Emma and Sense and Sensibility, will be shown for the first time next month when the British Library opens a new exhibition, Chapter and Verse: 1,000 years of English literature. If it steals the show from Charlotte Brontë's Jane Eyre manuscript or the Beatles' lyrics, it won't be due to size and splendour. It is a plain, hinged wooden box with a drawer that still holds her tiny, wire-framed "granny specs". Its fascination lies purely in its link with her books, and in what it says about the way she wrote - perched at a table in a parlour, her papers easily hidden away.  The British Library (020-7412 7332), 96 Euston Road NW1, March 10 to October 15. Entry: adults £3, concessions £2, under 18s free. Like Jane Austen, the Brontë Sisters used portable wooden writing desks, propped on a table wherever there was time and space to write. Their home at Haworth still contains the three boxes Charlotte, Emily and Anne filled with little hoards of personal possessions. Charlotte's was polished rosewood with silver trim, held pens (quill and steel nibbed), seals and sealing wax, an invitation to a reception and a tiny book of devotions. Anne's was inlaid mahogany, lined in velvet, with brass fittings. Emily's, well-used and ink stained, held some Belgian bills, letters and coins, five newspaper reviews of Wuthering Heights and, most poignant of all, a letter from her publisher urging her not to send her second - now lost - novel till she was "well satisfied with it".  Brontë Parsonage (01535 642323), Haworth, Keighley, West Yorkshire BD22 8DR. Open daily, Oct 1 - March 31, 11am - 5pm; April 1 - Sep 30, 10am - 5pm. Adults £4.50, concessions £3.30, children (5-16) £1.40. George Bernard Shaw, ever the rationalist, had a desk to write at, one to read at and another, possibly favourite, at the bottom of the garden. Fixed into a corner of his revolving summerhouse, it is a curiously flimsy little desk for such a heavyweight (but witty) dramatist, critic and writer. Alongside are his cane chair, wastepaper bin, fire and fold-away bed, where G (don't "George" me) BS would stretch out and think, or nap. What he was thinking during his 44 years at Shaw's Corner was nothing less than a political revolution (Brecht called him a terrorist who made humour his weapon) spelt out in thousands of articles, lectures and letters, as well as all the plays: Heartbreak House, Pygmalion (an Oscar-winning film even before it became My Fair Lady), Saint Joan, The Apple Cart and much more. When he died, 50 years ago this year, aged 94, he was still writing for the theatre.  Shaw's Corner (01438 820307), Ayot St Lawrence, Hertfordshire AL6 9BX. Open April 1 -Oct 29, Wed -Sun. Adults £3.50, children £1.75, family £8.75. The National Trust and RADA plan anniversary events in London and Shaw's Corner. Arthur Ransome claimed Swallows and Amazons "almost wrote itself". He'd fallen out with the family of children who inspired Swallow's crew and wanted to reclaim the book as his own childhood memories of the Lake District: "No matter where I was, wandering about the world - in my mind's eye [I] could see the beloved skyline of great hills." His wanderings (war correspondent in Russia during the Revolution) and restless life mean there isn't a Ransome house to visit. But his widow, Evgenia (Trotsky's secretary when they met) gave his desk and prized possessions to the Museum of Lakeland Life in Kendal. It is kept on show in a special room surrounded by his fishing rods and pipes, sketchbooks and, photos, a Jolly Roger flag, and the chess set he used in Russia (to beat Lenin, once, he said).  Museum of Lakeland Life and Industry (01539 722464), Abbot Hall, Kendal, Cumbria LA9 5AL. Open daily Feb 10 - Dec 22. Entry: adults £3, seniors £2.80, children £1.50, family £7.50. Hugh MacDiarmid, Scotland's modern-day national poet, died 21 years ago. His home in the Borders, a basic, two-room labourer's cottage, looks as though he left it yesterday. The table he wrote at (always in foolscap, covering every inch of space) and most of the well-worn furniture came from second-hand sales at nearby Biggar; but it was better than the fruit-boxes the family used during their penniless stay in Shetland.  Brownsbank (01899 221050), Candy Mill, Biggar, Strathclyde. Open strictly by appointment. No charge, but donations welcome. Charles Dickens is too big a writer and character to have left just one desk. There seem to be half a dozen dotted around. One of the most famous is in the Dickens Centre at Rochester, the city Dickens knew from childhood, returned to once he'd made his fortune, and used as the backdrop for Great Expectations and Edwin Drood. The desk is part of a large-scale recreation of the portrait known as The Dream, in which Dickens sits daydreaming while his characters reappear around him.  The Charles Dickens Centre (01634 844176), Eastgate House, High Street, Rochester, Kent ME1 1EW. webTitle: Egyptian Christians and Muslims urged to strive for harmony

fields.headline: Egyptian Christians and Muslims urged to strive for harmony
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II urged Egyptian Christians and Muslims to strive for harmony in a historic mass in a Cairo stadium yesterday. It was his second call for inter-faith understanding since his arrival in the country on Thursday for a three-day visit.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II urged Egyptian Christians and Muslims to strive for harmony in a historic mass in a Cairo stadium yesterday. It was his second call for inter-faith understanding since his arrival in the country on Thursday for a three-day visit.

The calls followed the death of 19 Christians and two Muslims in the southern Egyptian town of Kosheh over the new year, in the worst sectarian clashes in decades.

"All citizens have a duty to play an active part in a spirit of solidarity, in the building of society and consolidating peace between communities, and in managing the common good in an honest way," the Pope said at the mass attended by some 20,000 people, about a tenth of Egypt's Catholic community.

There are about 6m Christians in Egypt's 64m population, but most belong to the Coptic church.

"To do this common work, which should bring together all members of the same nation, everyone, Christians and Muslims, while respecting different religious views, should place their skills at the service of the nation at every level," the pontiff said.

His visit is the start of a millennium pilgrimage aimed at retracing the foot steps of Jesus and Moses. The climax of his Egyptian tour is a visit today to Mount Sinai, where tradition holds that God revealed the Ten Commandments to Moses.

The Pope also said he was deeply pained by communal violence in Nigeria, where hundreds of people were killed this week in the northern city of Kaduna in riots between Christians and Muslims who are demanding Islamic law.

"In deploring all forms of violence, I pray to the Lord so that all citizens of this country choose to live in brotherhood, based on respect for persons and religious freedom," he said. "Only these values can open the way to a future for the Nigerian nation."

His audience chanted "John Paul two, we love you" as he entered the stadium. The pontiff, 79, appeared tired. His words were slurred and his hands trembled.

"This is a great blessing for Egypt," said Lydia Youssef, who had travelled all night with her family from Assiut in the south.

Muslims also attended the ceremony, which was in French and Arabic and was broadcast live on national television. "We're all brothers and we came here to support each other," said Youssra, a Muslim who is one of the country's best-known actresses.

fields.headline: Nazi loot challenge to ministers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Nazi war criminals in Britain
fields.trailText: The Labour peer Lord Janner last night challenged the government to give an unequivocal commitment that works of art in British collections, which were looted by the Nazis from Jewish owners, will be returned to their rightful owners or their heirs.
fields.body:
The Labour peer Lord Janner last night challenged the government to give an unequivocal commitment that works of art in British collections, which were looted by the Nazis from Jewish owners, will be returned to their rightful owners or their heirs.

"There must be an absolute commitment that the objects will be returned," he said. "It is a principle in common and international law that the rightful owner of stolen property is entitled to the return of that property."

Both Lord Janner and Anne Webber, chair of the commission for looted art in Europe, expressed deep disappointment that the draft terms of reference for the advisory group which will make recommendations to the government on claims over Nazi loot, gives no specific commitment that the works will be returned.

On Tuesday, the first audit of the collections of the national galleries and museums will be published, and is expected to raise questions over the provenance of hundreds of works from 1933 to 1945.

One which will certainly be included is a painting by Jan Griffier, the subject of the only formal claim made to a British national gallery. It is currently on display at the Tate in London.

The history of the painting, A View of Hampton Court Palace, is typical of the complications the government will have to address. The claim says it was originally owned by a banker, shot by the Nazis, whose children emigrated to England. The Griffier is said to have been in a private collection in southern Germany until 1955, when it was sold at auction. In 1961 it was bought in Cologne, in good faith, for £400 by the Friends of the Tate.

Last night a spokeswoman for the department for culture, media and sport stressed that the terms of reference for the advisory panel were still the subject of consultation.

fields.headline: Hit man, myth maker
fields.standfirst: Bill Drummond the pop star deleted the LPs and burnt the cash; but the artist lives on
fields.trailText: The pop star deleted the LPs and burnt the cash; the artist lives on. Now Bill Drummond has written a book, 45
fields.body:
45
Bill Drummond
Little, Brown, £12.99, 361pp
Buy it at BOL

Bill Drummond is a conceptual artist; in fact, he and collaborator Jimmy Cauty are the only true conceptual artists of the last decade. And for all the eldritch beauty of their art, their most successful creation is the myth they have built around themselves.

It was a myth assiduously cultivated. In the early 90s, as the KLF and The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu, Drummond and Cauty sampled the fearful alarums of industrialised society and forged with them epic pop masterpieces such as "What Time Is Love?" and "3am Eternal". They went disguised in futuristic dayglo boilersuits and gasmasks, or as robed necromancers with rhino horns poking from their cowls. The songs were drenched in arcane numerology. Honoured at the 1992 Brit Awards, they busked a live thrash-metal version of their biggest hit and then sprayed the aghast audience with machine-gun blanks.

Pop had been too easy to conquer: their rivals were imaginative pygmies in the face of this situationist onslaught. So Drummond and Cauty deleted their entire back catalogue and reinvented themselves as the K Foundation. When Rachel Whiteread won the Turner Prize with her monstrous "House", the K men nailed £40,000 in cash to a wooden board and presented it to her for the worst body of work over the previous 12 months.

On the remote Scottish island of Jura, they carefully set fire to £1m and toured the country with the camcorder evidence, Watch the K Foundation Burn a Million Quid . It was an ideologically charged crime in a society where the hope of having £1m in the first place is the officially sanctioned mental opiate, mercilessly pushed every Saturday night on the lottery. Drummond likes to say he did it "to keep warm".

So why, after all this, does he want to write a book? Presumably printed literature still secretes a tang of seriousness: after gambolling around in the foothills of other forms, you scale the peaks of prose. (Even Tracey Emin, for pity's sake, is contracted to write a book.) But Drummond has long considered himself a writer, and has already co-written two volumes. First there was The Manual: How to Have a Number One The Easy Way (witness his and Cauty's huge smash as The Timelords with "Doctorin' the Tardis"). And in 1996, Drummond and Z (aka ex-pop star Zodiac Mindwarp) published Bad Wisdom, the almost unintelligible hallucinogenic fable of their (real) quest to plant a statue of Elvis Presley at the North Pole.

45 (begun on Drummond's 45th birthday, and alluding to the 45 rpm of a pop single) is a collection of short essays. Drummond goes to Iceland to record songs by an imaginary band called The Fuckers (including "Teenage Virgin Supermodels Eat Shit" and one "in celebration of the recent and untimely death of Princess Diana, 'One Less Slag' "). He reminisces about his early career managing Echo and the Bunnymen and Julian Cope; analyses his Scottishness; argues with a sinister rickshaw driver in Calcutta; and meets Tammy Wynette (she cooks him breakfast).

The book really sizzles, however, with the plans he and his cohorts draw up for artworks. One, at the height of the BSE crisis, involves hanging two dead cows from an electricity pylon: "For the previous few years," Drummond deadpans, "I had relished the idea of stringing up a beast like this, with no further explanation than a plain cardboard label with the two words, 'FUCKING COW'... Of course, the reason for wanting to have just two cows... was not just to have one each but to proclaim, as loudly and as silently as we could, 'Mu Mu'."

At the last moment he bottles out of this, but with his friend Gimpo he does manage to drive around the M25 for 25 hours ("I am hoping to uncover some psychogeographical facts about both the ancient and modern roads and routes that radiate out of the unseen metropolis") and hand out most of a truckload of Tennent's Super to the homeless on Christmas Eve.

Drummond's theories of art are always provocative and deceptively erudite. But his disarming, self-doubting persona ("I want you the reader to realise that I can stand outside myself and think, 'What an arsehole you are, Drummond' ") implies a more interesting, almost desperate motive for the book.

The last public appearance of the K Foundation was in 1997: renamed 2K, they took to the stage at the Barbican for a 23-minute performance involving ear-splitting techno, a male voice choir and a colliery brass band. Drummond and Cauty were dribbling old men in pyjamas, buzzing around the stage on electric wheelchairs with pathetically flaccid rhino horns taped to their heads while the PA blasted out the tune's message, "Fuck the Millennium". As Drummond explains here, the gig was an attempted suicide: "The show was about the crapness of the comeback, of blowing one's own myth."

45 is a further attempt to bury the myth. Throughout, Drummond poses as an ordinary middle-aged man who lives in the country, drinks lots of tea and spends his mornings in the nearest library, with coffee breaks in the shopping centre. Yet the myth motors on, pitilessly. When he goes to Serbia to appear on an underground music station, he brings a recording of an unreleased KLF song called "The Magnificent". Soon it "had not only become the theme tune of the station, but the anthem of the democracy movement... A track we recorded in a day, never released as a single, thought was crap and had forgotten about had taken on a meaning, an importance in a 'far-off land'."

As Drummond surely knows, a myth like the KLF's is peculiarly omnivorous. Just as there can never be any evidence to disprove a conspiracy theory because the fabrication of such evidence - don't you see? - is itself part of the conspiracy, so the pop myth of the KLF can never be blown apart by anything they do, no matter how dumb or embarrassing. The myth will suck it up, like a black hole.

And so with 45. At its best it has flashes of twisted brilliance reminiscent of Iain Sinclair or Will Self, but the majority is most interesting because the author was one half of the KLF. Of course, that is more than enough glory for one lifetime. Yet the fact remains that this book will forever labour under the shadow of those horned men and their gleefully apocalyptic music.

But his disarming, self-doubting persona ("I want you the reader to realise that I can stand outside myself and think, 'What an arsehole you are, Drummond' ") implies a more interesting, almost desperate motive for the book. The last public appearance of the K Foundation was in 1997: renamed 2K, they took to the stage at the Barbican for a 23-minute performance involving ear-splitting techno, a male voice choir and a colliery brass band. Drummond and Cauty were dribbling old men in pyjamas, buzzing around the stage on electric wheelchairs with pathetically flaccid rhino horns taped to their heads while the PA blasted out the tune's message, "Fuck the Millennium". As Drummond explains here, the gig was an attempted suicide: "The show was about the crapness of the comeback, of blowing one's own myth." 45 is a further attempt to bury the myth. Throughout, Drummond poses as an ordinary middle-aged man who lives in the country, drinks lots of tea and spends his mornings in the nearest library, with coffee breaks in the shopping centre. Yet the myth motors on, pitilessly. When he goes to Serbia to appear on an underground music station, he brings a recording of an unreleased KLF song called "The Magnificent". Soon it "had not only become the theme tune of the station, but the anthem of the democracy movement... A track we recorded in a day, never released as a single, thought was crap and had forgotten about had taken on a meaning, an importance in a 'far-off land'." As Drummond surely knows, a myth like the KLF's is peculiarly omnivorous. Just as there can never be any evidence to disprove a conspiracy theory because the fabrication of such evidence - don't you see? - is itself part of the conspiracy, so the pop myth of the KLF can never be blown apart by anything they do, no matter how dumb or embarrassing. The myth will suck it up, like a black hole. And so with 45. At its best it has flashes of twisted brilliance reminiscent of Iain Sinclair or Will Self, but the majority is most interesting because the author was one half of the KLF. Of course, that is more than enough glory for one lifetime. Yet the fact remains that this book will forever labour under the shadow of those horned men and their gleefully apocalyptic music.

fields.headline: The codfather
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit  on Michael Schumacher's life of Francis Ford Coppola
fields.trailText: Chris Petit on Michael Schumacher's life of Francis Ford Coppola
fields.body:
Francis Ford Coppola: A Filmmaker's Life
Michael Schumacher
Bloomsbury, £25, 544pp
Buy it at BOL

Coppola was the first of a generation who at the end of the 60s gatecrashed Hollywood "via the shortcuts of film school and producer Roger Corman's low-budget mill", where previously a slow pecking order had meant aspiring directors had to wait their turn, sometimes for years.

According to this biography, in 1972, Coppola, having lucked out on The Godfather 's success, was on Sunset Boulevard in his chauffeured limousine with William Friedkin, director of The French Connection, another big hit. Peter Bogdanovich, the newly successful director of The Last Picture Show, drew alongside. While waiting for the lights to change the three men, "all young and in demand, crowed over their respective successes, with Coppola the winner on account of the size of his box office".

This cock-of-the-walk scene was forgivable because all three looked to have licked the system and joined the Hollywood pantheon (which Bogdanovich had been instrumental in creating as a critic). But they all blew it; they all turned out to be chumps.

As with several other contemporaries, a sickly, cosseted childhood had contributed to Coppola's imagination, and like them he hid his wunderkind reputation behind an early beard. He was also content at first to work with the system. When young European filmmakers were indulging in social revolution, he was making his first studio movie with Petula Clark, Tommy Steele and Fred Astaire.

He got the job of The Godfather, so the story goes, because of his Italian name. What Schumacher doesn't ask is to what extent The Godfather created the myths with which Coppola subsequently surrounded himself. Nor is the transformation from self-confessed nerd to self-invented movie mogul adequately explained. With success, Coppola quickly emerged as a potentate, buying property like Monopoly, acting as a cultural fixer, issuing press statements like Charles Foster Kane.

Shards of Kane, Welles, Hearst and San Simeon were evident in Coppola's public face; he was always the showman, whether creating an anti-Hollywood principality in San Francisco, courting European auteurs or pursuing the messy dream of Zoetrope Studios. Distraction probably accounts for the surrogate nature of too many Coppola movies. For all his vaunted skills as a screenwriter, the films often lacked a final draft. Apocalypse Now added up to less than the brouhaha surrounding its production. Schumacher ignores the willed recklessness at the heart of the project, with Coppola perhaps desperate to make up for a lack of personal experience; nor does he question the usual "they-all-went-mad" story.

Too much dreary synopsis and too many old reviews contribute to a book stronger on the ephemerality of film criticism than on Coppola, who is presented in terms of standard press-release jargon - risk-taker, visionary, maverick (the genius of Hollywood is that it lets everyone believe they are a maverick: controlled deviancy is a part of the system).

Coppola's visionary schemes were pretty half-baked. For all his cultural philanthropy, he was an erratic employer, firing regularly, and he indulged in too many follies, the exception being his career as a vintner (no quarrel there, his wine is excellent). The films came bedevilled by sloppiness - his own admission - and too many press releases supposed to be taken at face value.

Overall, what emerges as Coppola's most impressive achievement is his ability to spend money. For all the history of fiscal mess, mountains of debts, legal wrangles and extravagant investments, in the long run he proved canny at looking after number one. With the exception of The Godfather (in its extended television cut), the movies pale beside a magnificent talent for financial irresponsibility in the face of disaster.

fields.headline: Fury at police shooting verdict
fields.trailText: Anger spilled on to the streets of New York last night after a jury cleared four white policemen of murdering an unarmed black street trader by firing 41 shots at him from a range of no more than 7ft.
fields.body:
Anger spilled on to the streets of New York last night after a jury cleared four white policemen of murdering an unarmed black street trader by firing 41 shots at him from a range of no more than 7ft.

People were arguing in the street where the victim lived and died, screaming out of the windows of their apartments and howling at police helicopters flying overhead.

"They shot the brother down in the street, they murdered him," said Steve Taylor, one of those milling around on Wheeler Avenue in the Bronx. "I'm hurting right now."

Another man dashed from a building carrying a child and shouting: "Shoot my baby now, shoot my baby now. He's a black boy, look at him, look at his skin. He's a negro in America."

A racially mixed jury at the New York state supreme court in Albany cleared the four white officers of the top charge of second-degree murder and five lesser charges, including first-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide.

The four plainclothes officers of the elite street crime unit all testified that they thought Diallo, 22, was pulling a gun when they saw him standing in his apartment building vestibule in the early hours of February 4 1999. They told the jury that they had acted in self-defence.

Sean Carroll, 37, Kenneth Boss, 28, Edward McMellon and Richard Murphy, both 27, said they realised too late Diallo had been reaching for his wallet, not a weapon. Diallo died after being shot 19 times.

The trial went to the heart of the dispute over law enforcement in a racially diverse city. It was moved to the state capital of Albany, 150 miles north of New York City, because it was ruled that the officers could not be sure of a fair trial in the Bronx because of protests and publicity.

The Rev Al Sharpton, the black activist who orchestrated demonstrations against the police after Diallo was killed a year ago, said last night: "We had no chance here of real justice. This is not the end. This is the beginning.

"We said from the beginning that we would pursue this in the federal courts. We will not rest until we get justice."

Diallo's mother, Kadiatou, said: "The killing of Amadou was wrong. I want to be able to pursue that."

Mr Sharpton called on protesters to make their way to the Bronx but said: "Let not one brick be thrown. Let not one bottle be thrown. Let not the violence come from us."

The mayor of New York, Rudy Giuliani, who was criticised at the time of the shooting for maintaining his normal policy of supporting the police at all times, said: "The death of Amadou Diallo was a great tragedy and once again we express our profound sympathy, condolences and support to the Diallo family.

"We also express our sympathy in the strongest terms to the four police officers in this case who have also gone though a nightmare.

"Any fair-minded observer of the trial would have to say that it was an eminently fair trial under very difficult circumstances."

But some lawyers believed that the prosecution did not press its case hard enough, in particular failing to cross-examine the final witness, an expert on police procedure who said that the officers had acted correctly.

The trial was looked upon as a test of the zero tolerance policing that has driven down crime in New York - but at the price of perceived discrimination. Murders have fallen sharply, from 2,245 in 1990 to 667 last year. The policy of frisking people in high crime areas - which usually have a high proportion of ethnic minorities - has led to persis tent accusations of racial bias.

Brian O'Dwyer, a legal expert, said he was not surprised at the verdict: "I think there was no chance of a murder conviction as it came down." The turning point, he said, was when Carroll, the oldest of the officers and one of two who fired all 16 bullets from his 9mm handgun, broke down while giving evidence.

"I think the jury felt with this officer and decided that no punishment was appropriate. He was not swaggering as some policemen are on the stand," he added.

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.trailText: Blow your own trumpet
fields.body:
Blow your own trumpet

Suppose you're happy at your job and, out of the blue, you get an excellent job offer from another company. But for whatever reason, you don't take it. Should you use the opportunity to toot your horn? Or should you just pat yourself on your back and forget about the whole thing? Depends on your feeling of job security. Presenting another offer could trigger a review of your salary, especially if you have researched the market and found that you are underpaid. Alternatively, you could save the big announcement for when you're offered a promotion and see what you can negotiate from there. Remember, though that you always run the risk that your boss may suggest it would be a good idea to take the job offer after all.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.standfirst: We sample life at either end of the scale at Vauxhall Motors
fields.trailText: Two employees at either end of the scale share their experiences of working at Vauxhall Motors
fields.body:
Bruce Warman
Aged 51
Director of personnel
Vauxhall Motors

The motor industry offers a wide range of prospects for graduates, according to Vauxhall's Bruce Warman. "The motor industry is very exciting. For example, while the manufacturing side is vitally important, we are the second biggest advertiser in the UK. It's also an international career."

Bruce read biochemistry at Bristol ("but I didn't want to be a scientist") and did an MBA at London Business School. After a spell in insurance he joined General Motors and took on a series of senior roles culminating in his present appointment.

Current role: Responsible for all Vauxhall's personnel policy and industrial relations among its10,000 staff who last year produced 300,000 cars in the UK. He also links up with GM centres in the US and Switzerland.

"Industrial relations is evolving with the greater and greater impact of employment law."

The buzz? "I enjoy the development of people, seeing them grow and move on."

Must-have qualities: "We look for graduates with the ability to get results, to be flexible and be able to work constructively with others."

Route map? "Be flexible and recognise the need for change and seize all opportunities presented."

Gavin Horner
Aged 25
Sales district manager
Vauxhall Motors

Vauxhall's careers team gained a lot of mileage with Gavin Horner when he was doing geography at Birmingham University. "Their presentation included contributions from recent graduates which greatly impressed me," he recalls.

Before completing his degree in 1996 he applied to 30 companies, but became one of the 20 or so graduates recruited by Vauxhall each year.

Road test: He has been a network anaylst and part of the Novano van and Vectra brand teams. Currently, he is in charge of a sales district from Wolverhampton to Crewe ensuring that the retailers hit targets and maintain standards.

Servicing and parts? Gavin had a three-month induction programme followed by weekly training leading to a Chartered Institute of Marketing qualification. His progress has also been monitored by appraisals.

Graduate culture: "It's very accommodating and there's a pleasant working environment. Colleagues are happy to help and ideas are encouraged."

Next stop? "In the short term, I would like to move into product management and in the longer term I hope that I might rise through the ranks to executive level."

For more career details visit www.vauxhall.co.uk

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: • What did we tell you? Hot on the heels of last week's advice on how to tackle the old "Don't you think you're overqualified for this post" poser, the Centre for Economic Performance has published research showing that almost a third of the UK's workers are overeducated for their jobs. The overskilled are more likely to have studied subjects like arts and humanities.
fields.body:
 What did we tell you? Hot on the heels of last week's advice on how to tackle the old "Don't you think you're overqualified for this post" poser, the Centre for Economic Performance has published research showing that almost a third of the UK's workers are overeducated for their jobs. The overskilled are more likely to have studied subjects like arts and humanities.

 Book of the week: Your first management position can be as terrifying as it is exciting, but author Julie-Ann Amos offers to hold your hand until you find your feet. Published by How To Books, Moving into Management is available at the special price of £7.99 plus 99p p&p from our Cultureshop. Place your order by ringing 0800 316 6102.

 Lapdog computer: The campaign for a Bring Your Mongrel to Work Day starts here. Man's best friend won't just keep you company, he'll also boost your chances of finding love in the office say psychologists at Warwick University where tests have shown that irrespective of your sex or appearance, having a dog will encourage people to interact with you.

 Surf's up: We are spending more time surfing the internet at work because our home modem speeds pale in comparison to the faster connections we have in the office. During January, at-work internet users spent an average of 21 hours on the web, more than double the amount of time at-home users were online, according to Nielsen Media Research.

 Total recall: Drugs in the workplace needn't be such a no-no, particularly if you have a habit of forgetting important meetings. Cell biologists in El Cerrito, California say that people who take extra phosphatidyl serine - a fat-soluble nutrient found naturally in our bodies - have better recall of names, faces and written information.

 Appliance of science: Graduates from the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology earn the highest salaries in Britain, according to a new survey. Six months after graduation in 1998, the top earner was being paid £63,000 while the median salary was £18,300.

fields.headline: The libel lord
fields.trailText: Ian Caplin, Solicitor advocate with Peter Carter-Ruck
fields.body:
Name: Ian Caplin

Status: Solicitor-advocate with Peter Carter-Ruck and Partners.

Past: Read law at Oxford University; after obtaining bar exams, did advocacy work for a local council and moved on to Allen & Overy, where he qualified as a solicitor. Became one of the country's youngest solicitor-advocates at the age of 25, after challenging the Law Society which initially refused his application.

Present: Has a mixed practice of defamation and employment law cases, some involving high profile clients. When required he also appears in court as an advocate.

Future: "I'd like to develop as both a solicitor and barrister by conducting more cases before they go to court and appearing as an advocate when they get there."

Strengths: "Tenacity and a desire to get results."

Weaknesses: "When my computer crashes, I tend to let rip with the English language."

Wisdom: "Be prepared to be flexible and seize opportunities because they come and go very quickly."

References: www.carter-ruck.com

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to successful negotiation

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to successful negotiation
fields.trailText: Getting what you want, whether that means securing the desk by the window or a promotion, may not be as hard as you think
fields.body:
A. Compromising positions

You may never use it for anything more significant than getting leave when you want, or securing the desk by the window, but being able to recognise when there's scope for negotiation, then using it to get what you want, is an art worth mastering. The basis of successful negotiation is never even hinting you intend to have your own way but rather appearing to accept compromise. If the other side think they've got the better of a deal when you know you did, that's success.

B. Starting points

Everyone who enters into negotiation does so because they hope to gain some advantage for themselves. The rituals accompanying this are well understood. Each side starts the bidding high and tries to hide just how low they're prepared to go. Offers are met with counter offers, incredulity is feigned and heads are shaken. Decide beforehand what you're willing to give up and which aspects are non-negotiable. Then ask for much more. Create the impression of being confident enough not to have to make concessions.

C. Happy endings

Keep a cool, non-committal exterior and be watchful for your opponent's weak points without revealing your own. Avoid threats and never lose your temper. Ploys to show you're getting to the end of being reasonable include putting a time limit on the discussion. Negotiations are only ever successful if the agreement reached is then acted upon.

Decide beforehand what you're willing to give up and which aspects are non-negotiable. Then ask for much more. Create the impression of being confident enough not to have to make concessions. C. Happy endings Keep a cool, non-committal exterior and be watchful for your opponent's weak points without revealing your own. Avoid threats and never lose your temper. Ploys to show you're getting to the end of being reasonable include putting a time limit on the discussion. Negotiations are only ever successful if the agreement reached is then acted upon.

fields.headline: Love is in the air
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 32¾
fields.trailText: Vincent Ludlow, my next-door neighbour, knocked on my door at 11.30 tonight and asked if I could "let him 'ave a few fags until the mornin'"
fields.body:
Tuesday, February 15, 2000, 12 Arthur Askey Way

Vincent Ludlow, my next-door neighbour, knocked on my door at 11.30 tonight and asked if I could "let him 'ave a few fags until the mornin'."

I told him that I was a life-long non-smoker. He looked back at me with an expression of disbelief.

"You don't smoke?" he checked.

"No," I said, and gave him a brief talk about the dangers of smoking, citing the Royal College of Physicians' latest report. I was interrupted by his wife, Peggy, shouting, "'urry up, Vince, I'm bleedin' gaspin' 'ere", from their doorstep.

Two of their three big dogs escaped from the house and preceded to fight in my front garden. "Satan! Devil!" roared Ludlow. "Get back in the 'ouse!"

The ill-trained animals ignored their master and carried on with their fight. Eventually, they were joined by the third dog, Kane, who entered the fray with evident enjoyment. Mrs Ludlow ran from the house with a sweeping brush and set about the dogs with the wooden handle. They were quickly subdued, and slunk back into the house with their tails between their powerful legs. "Bleeders," said Ludlow, fondly, as he watched them go. I couldn't take my eyes off Peggy Ludlow: she was panting from her exertions, causing her magnificent bosom to rise and fall beneath her food-stained dressing gown. She looked like a beautiful, long-haired version of Ann Widdicombe. I felt my manhood stir for the first time in many months. Wednesday, February 16

This morning, I saw Peggy Ludlow in her back garden, hanging washing on the line. I splashed a little Ralph Lauren's Polo on to my cheeks and hurried down to my own garden, where I pretended to examine the tree. I glanced over the fence. Peggy was wearing full make-up, her raven hair was blowing in the wind. She held a clothes peg tantalisingly between her carmine lips. She nodded to me.

"Just looking at my tree," I croaked.

"The last bloke what lived in your 'ouse murdered his brother-in-law then 'ung himself from that tree," she said with obvious relish. I went back inside and phoned the homeless unit. I left a message on Pamela Pigg's voicemail, demanding an immediate transfer.

Friday, February 18

Nigel came round tonight and brought me a bunch of Stargazer lilies. As he handed them to me, he said, "Congratulations on finally coming out, Moley."

After I had vehemently protested my heterosexuality, Nigel said, "Well, I was told by a council worker that you had claimed on an official form that you were a gay single father. You're obviously in denial."

He and his partner, Cliff, have planned a "coming out" dinner party for me. "It'll just be a few close friends," he said. "Cliff's doing the Naked Chef's aubergine-and-pasta bake." I told him that I loathed aubergines, and he snatched the lilies back and left. A pity. He is my best, indeed only, friend and I need to confess to somebody about my growing passion for Mrs Peggy Ludlow.

Saturday, February 19

Glenn's maths homework project is to draw a graph illustrating the result of the Livingstone, Dobson, Jackson mayoral race. Clorette Ludlow, the eldest daughter, is pregnant! I heard the row through the party-wall. Peggy screamed, "Why din't you take precautions, you stupid mare?" Clorette screamed back "Tony an' Cherie slipped up, an' they're both brain-boxes, so shurrup, our mam". I fear that the PM and his wife are not setting a good example to the nation's young, contraception wise.

Sunday, February 20

Glenn is in despair over his maths homework: "It's no good, dad," he said after putting the Electoral College results into his calculator. "It don't matter how I do the percentages, I still can't work out how Mr Dobson won." I wrote a note to the school saying that the boy had tried his best.
