fields.headline: The List
fields.trailText: Bryan Bunch on the hunt for some exotic numerical game, plus How We Believe and The Quest For Reality
fields.body:
The Kingdom of Infinite Number
Bryan Bunch
Freeman, £13.95

Buy it at BOL

Such has been the success of pop-maths books recently, it seems you need a new gimmick; only so many warm human stories can be wrapped around another exegesis of Fermat or probability. So Bunch has the fun idea of organising his book like a wildlife guide, describing numbers "in their natural habitat" as though we were leaf-decked twitchers in the Platonic realm. Each has "field marks" and, sweetly, a "personality" (some numbers, like 1 and 25, are "friendly").

Exploring numbers 1 to 20 explains many useful geometric and arithmetical ideas, before Bunch yomps on into more exotic fauna. Rotman's Even Bigger Biggest Number (10 to the power of 10 to the power of 98) is the highest number you could count to if you built a computer as big as the universe (so don't bother), and then we spot pi, the Imaginary Unit and various flavours of infinity, whereof Bunch likeably remarks: "When I get to the infinity represented by the ordinal numbers, I always find that I go weak in the head." Uh, me too.

How We Believe
Michael Shermer
Freeman, £14.95

Buy it at BOL

Fifty years ago, it appeared to many onlookers that religion was on the wane and science was driving out superstition. Yet today 72% of Americans believe in angels. What went wrong? Shermer's excellent book takes on spiritualists ("Talking Twaddle with the Dead") and creationists; he has no hysterical Dawkinsian axe to grind, but he does rather diagnose theism as a weakness of the head. He finds, for example, that the single most popular justification of theism is an appeal to beauty or "design" in the wonderful complexity of the universe, but gently points out that such people are actually adducing empirical reasons - relying on senses rather than on faith. The "evidence", of course, is far better explained by evolution.

Shermer, once a born-again Christian himself, understands God's warm, fuzzy comfort, and acknowledges that religion has been a very useful social institution. But now it's time to dump it in favour of a liberating wonder at cosmology and contingency.

The Quest for Reality: Subjectivism & the Metaphysics of Colour
Barry Stroud
Oxford, £19.99
Buy it at BOL

Does red look the same to you as it does to me? How could we ever decide? For Democritus, colour and taste were mere conventions: "In truth," he summed up, "atoms and the void." Which may be trivially true, but doesn't get us anywhere. Stroud's highly readable and drily witty investigation of this hoary philosophical problem is both wide-ranging and amiably modest; indeed, he thinks there is probably no satisfying philosophical theory of "reality" to be had, ever. But that should not stop us worrying about it, going for a bracing swim in the cranial soup.

fields.headline: Stormy weather
fields.standfirst: Roger Allam's reading of Joseph Conrad's Typhoon leaves the gale ringing in your ears
fields.trailText: Roger Allam's reading of Joseph Conrad's Typhoon leaves the gale ringing in your ears
fields.body:
Typhoon
Joseph Conrad
Cover to Cover, £12.99, 195 mn unabridged
Buy it at BOL

A typhoon is a violent hurricane, says the OED. But it's all just "dirty weather" to Captain MacWhirr, skipper of the steamer Nan-Shan, who has "just enough imagination to carry him through each successive day, and no more". As the barometer plummets, MacWhirr pooh-poohs textbook advice on how to dodge storms, declaring to his deputy's horror that to head on is the only way.

When it is all over, MacWhirr proves the only man able to avert the feared mutiny by the massed Chinese coolies, who've been locked below throughout in terrible conditions. Roger Allam puts a fine brush of sympathy on the skipper's gruff Belfast voice and nicely catches the suppressed hysteria of the second in command, Jukes. You hear the gale shrieking long after his admirably taut reading of Conrad's classic sea-storm portrait is over.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Albert French has written a novel that demands to be read aloud, plus Warriors Of The Rainbow and Thin Air
fields.body:
I Can't Wait On God
Albert French
Vintage, £6.99

Buy it at BOL

There are novels which demand to be read aloud, and this is one of them. French has created a kaleidoscope of voices with a narrative style which, although it has clear antecedents, is uniquely his own. Jeremiah Henderson and his girl, Willet, want to escape from Pittsburgh and a life spent sitting on back porches waiting for the world to happen. Their goal is New York, but to get there Willet must agree to sell her body to the local loan shark. Part thriller, I Can't Wait On God could easily be descibed as a Joycean take on Elmore Leonard, but that would be an injustice to the originality of French and the characters he has created.

Warriors Of The Rainbow
AD Harvey
Bloomsbury, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

It's not nuclear war or pollution that plunges Britain into perpetual winter in this neat twist on apocalypse, but whales fighting a rearguard action against us. A man, newly released from prison, treads the frozen streets of north London to his girlfriend's house only to find that she is dead. Her body, however, lives on as host to an artificial brain. The man and his strange companion suddenly find themselves as emissaries for the human race. Harvey, more at home with the scholarly past than the imagined future, creates a credible nightmare and turns what at first seems a simple eco-sermon into something more weirdly compelling.

Thin Air
Kate Thompson
Sceptre, £6.99

Buy it at BOL

Slight but poignant, Thin Air revolves around a very ordinary family coming to terms with the disappearance of their elder daughter. When Martina Keane's horse returns home without her, the everyday worries of her parents, grandfather and siblings take a back seat as they search for an explanation of her disappearance. Thompson's canvas is small and her tragedy commonplace, but her eye adeptly fixes on the tiny instances which make up family life. She has a refreshing clarity of style, and is careful to evoke a sense of Ireland as a place of strangeness and myth without being swept away on bogs and blarney.

fields.headline: The inside story
fields.trailText: Orgies, naked bathing, sado-masochistic gatherings of the great and good... read all about in Lord Denning's superbly written report.
fields.body:
Uncovered Editions: John Profumo and Christine Keeler, 1963
Stationery Office, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Orgies, naked bathing, sado-masochistic gatherings of the great and good... read all about in Lord Denning's superbly written report. The book is part of the excellent Uncovered Editions series of released government papers which the privatised Stationary Office has cunningly made available for all to enjoy. Other books in the series include: The Loss of the Titanic, 1912 ; The Judgement at Nuremberg, 1946 ; The Boer War: Ladysmith and Mafeking, 1900; War 1914: Punishing the Serbs; R101: Airship Disaster; War 1939: Dealing with Adolf Hitler; and the serial-killer papers, Rillington Place.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Harry Evans is a newspaperman. That's not necessarily an insult... plus Gramercy Park, Plain Tales from the Raj and Wrought Iron
fields.body:
The American Century
Harry Evans
Pimlico, £20
Buy it at BOL

A history of the US and indeed the whole world from 1890 onwards, as viewed from the very parochial parish of Washington DC, with fine pix of presidents and generals and other mega-equivalents of town council and beadles. Sombre layout, like bundles of old mags found in basements of antique malls in urban unrenewal zones across the mid-West. The writing is at its strongest narrating single incidents, say, FDR's funeral trainride. Evans is a newspaperman. That's not necessarily an insult - not a caption or mini-pic is wasted.

Gramercy Park
Carole Klein
Johns Hopkins, £14.50
Buy it at BOL

A proper local history - that is, inept and over-genteel in tone - of the brownstone Manhattan estate built through the 19th century and now reverently preserved. Wont to generalise and quote from biogs of the rich and famous who dwelt there, when you would have liked to know about the groundplans of its houses - did they have bathrooms? - or the lives and duties of the servants. Please, no lit crit, just tell us where they parked their early automobiles. It's as if Klein hasn't walked the ground. Pity, because it's a fab NY district.

Plain Tales from the Raj
Charles Allen
Abacus, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

At last reprinted, this best of oral histories - of British India, which was all at once a small village, a sub-continent and a state of mind; and is now quite vanished away (almost: we know a few bungalows). Allen understands just which minutiae aggregate to create an epic - the Army & Navy pukka wardrobe trunk in flax canvas, £13 14s 6d, the new bride of 1914 who felt on parade like "Queen Alexandra, don't you know", the smell of woodsmoke and dust when the first rain falls after the long drought. Glorious.

Wrought Iron
Richard Hayman
Shire Publications, £3.50
Buy it at BOL

Shire albums aren't craft-designed literature like the 40s Batsford English studies. But they are sound, cheap introductions to history's details, fervently specific to locale - here college gates, cope-chests and spa balconies across the land. The tone has the briskness of those chapboards with pasted-on lists of features that used to await visitors in the porches of rural churches, explaining that the iron grilles topped with spikes were medieval security installations to stop pilgrims climbing the tombs.

fields.headline: The other dome of discovery
fields.standfirst: Novelist Jane Rogers pleads for the future of the 'great free school' in the north of England
fields.trailText: Novelist Jane Rogers pleads for the future of the 'great free school' in the north of England
fields.body:
Manchester Central Library, the biggest free reference library in the north of England, is in grave danger. Its glorious dome-shaped building has been cleaned and gleams as pristine as that dumber dome down south. It is a great landmark - the most easily recognisable building in Manchester - a Portland-stone cathedral to learning and a haven of research. When built, it was the biggest public library in the country.

The outside is not under threat; that white shell fits too beautifully with post-bomb Manchester. It is the inside that is at risk; the untidy mass of books, documents, scripts, scores, tapes, files, archives and stuff (and librarians). To maintain them is expensive, and cuts must be made - £130,000 this year, £500,000 over the coming three years. The founding principle, of providing the widest possible range of resources for learning for ordinary people, will be overturned.

The library has 2.6m books on 30 miles of shelving; seven specialist libraries, including a Chinese library and the Henry Watson music library; a theatre in its basement and a glorious reading room; manuscript pages by Elizabeth Gaskell and scores by Handel and Vivaldi. The Manchester city council wants to rationalise it, close the specialist libraries and reorganise the stock. (The future of the music library is still under discussion.)

They want to "weed and reduce" stock and to reduce specialist staff by a third, which will reduce access. And they want to do this to provide "best value" for ratepayers, not - as cynics would have you think - to save money.

The library was opened in 1852, the first rate-supported, free public library in the country, with 18,000 books purchased and 3,300 received as gifts. Over £12,000 (enough to buy the building and the books) was raised by appeals, and not all from the moneyed classes. The Working Men's Committee, from the mills and workshops, collected £800.

The opening was a blaze of idealism and self-congratulation. Prince Albert donated 18 volumes, which he desired to be "freely accessible to persons of all classes, without distinction". The guest of honour, Charles Dickens, acknowledged that he was "a zealous advocate for the diffusion of knowledge amongst all classes and conditions of men" and described the library as "this great free school, inviting the humblest workman to come in and be a student". He hoped other towns would follow the example.

William Thackeray, in flowery support, added: "If books do soothe, and cheer, and console - if books do enlighten; and enliven, and fortify - if they do make sorrow bearable to us (etc, etc)... surely, we will not grudge these inestimable blessings to the poorest of our friends." Edward Bulwer Lytton, rejoicing to see "intelligent young faces bending over books" in preference to the gin palace, beat Tony Blair by 148 years to announce: "Education does not cease when we leave school. Education is the work of a life, and libraries are the school-rooms of grown-up men."

The library grew all the while; the first branch libraries, for those who lived far from the centre, were opened in 1857. In 1862, principal librarian Robert Smiles reported on the difficulties created by the American civil war; the cotton famine meant that mills stood empty, the unemployed crowded into the library. "The accommodation in the reference library was found inadequate for the number of readers, every table being completely surrounded, and every chair occupied, a number of youths accommodating them selves on the warming pipes, where they were to be seen in rows on each side of the room every evening." He resolved the problem by opening a specially designated room for them.

The library developed specialisms, all of which are peculiar to it, and most of which still exist (but are under threat) today. There is the technical library and the local history library (both dating back to 1852); the arts library (with theatre and gardening collections, Victorian fashion plates and samples books); the language and literature library (unique Gaskell and Broadside ballad collections); and, in the great glass-domed reading room, the social sciences library.

I first ventured in when I was researching my novel, Mr Wroe's Virgins, set in 1830s Lancashire. From the social sciences stock I called up 19th-century pamphlets by local preachers announcing the imminent apocalypse, furious indictments of Prophet Wroe by local worthies, and records of night schools and the first spinners' strike.

Some of it hadn't been called up for decades. I didn't expect to have so much luck with my next novel, but Australia 1788 was no problem for central ref, and the index led me to books I didn't know existed, helping to define the subject of Promised Lands.

Anthony Burgess probably got the best story out of research there. As a schoolboy he had trouble understanding the index and was helped by "a charming woman running acceptably to fat" who was reading about Engels. And that is, sadly, true. You cannot use Manchester's university libraries unless you are a student or graduate; you cannot go anywhere else in the whole north of England for this range of materials and expertise. Sheffield and Liverpool libraries have already had their guts removed by "best value".

There is London's splendid new British Library, only two and a half hours away by train - and £150 standard return if you want to arrive early enough for a seat in the reading room. (I do think Bulwer Lytton put it better.)

fields.bodyText: Manchester Central Library, the biggest free reference library in the north of England, is in grave danger. Its glorious dome-shaped building has been cleaned and gleams as pristine as that dumber dome down south. When built, it was the biggest public library in the country. The outside is not under threat; that white shell fits too beautifully with post-bomb Manchester. It is the inside that is at risk; the untidy mass of books, documents, scripts, scores, tapes, files, archives and stuff (and librarians). To maintain them is expensive, and cuts must be made - £130,000 this year, £500,000 over the coming three years. The founding principle, of providing the widest possible range of resources for learning for ordinary people, will be overturned. fields.headline: Humanity among the horrors
fields.standfirst: Tzvetan Todorov tells Desmond Christy about moral life in the death camps
fields.trailText: Tzvetan Todorov tells Desmond Christy about moral life in the death camps
fields.body:
I go to meet Mr Structuralism, who is visiting London, and find that his interest in literary theory has faded with the years. Tzvetan Todorov is the Bulgarian-born Director of Research at the Centre National de Recherches in Paris and has written a shelf a of influential books, including Littérature et Signification, and Les genres de discours. He has not come to talk about literary theory, however, but about a book he first published in Paris in 1991, Facing The Extreme: Moral Life In The Concentration Camps (Phoenix, £7.99).

Professor Todorov does not mind that, controversially, the "concentration camps" of his title means both the Nazi variety and those of Stalin's Gulag. Wasn't the human suffering much the same? But he understands why I find it odd that he looks for morality in such immoral places.

"Many of the witnesses - and my material is the narrative of the witnesses - start their narratives by claiming that there was no such thing as moral life in the concentration camps, that it was a place where every man was for himself, a wolf to other men, in a war of all against all, a Hobbesian world. Yet if you read the narratives themselves, in detail, you discover that this is not true and that, as one of them says, none of them would have survived without a helping hand. Of course moral life was not easy, but there was a moral life."

He categorises moral life in the German and Soviet camps under the headings of caring, dignity, and the life of the mind. "Not that they are universal categories, but they come out of the texts themselves. Of dignity: that is preserving one's self-respect, of remaining clean, or holding oneself straight, so that one wouldn't despise oneself. Of caring, which is of course the major moral act, and of which there are numberless examples, next to others in which a person takes the bread from the hand of an inmate and by this act kills him, because without bread there is no survival. This exists, but next to it there is the sharing of bread between people who hardly knew each other.

"Then of what I call the life of the mind, that is the simple interest for an abstract idea, for beauty, for something that was beyond the necessity for survival." He reminds me of the incident in Ravensbrück, involving Milena Jesenska - Kafka's Milena - and Margarete Buber-Neumann. They found a Brueghel reproduction in a magazine, tore it out and tacked it to the wall; they saw this as "a protest against our condition as prisoners". "Each time they had a free moment they would get together and look at the picture," Todorov says. "And I think this is a moral act of affirming the dignity of human beings, who need not just food but something beyond it."

Todorov's book will not be easy reading for those who want a simple message to come out of the suffering and death in German and Russian camps. "I know that many people, the general reader perhaps, prefer clear-cut situations and black-and-white images. The black must remain black and the white must remain white. The victim should be an absolute victim and the executioner nothing but an executioner. I don't mean that the victims shouldn't be cherished, or that one shouldn't condemn the executioner. But to me that is not enough.

"My interest begins once that has been said. But they were not simply victims - it is only in the most extreme situations where the victim can do nothing but be killed or be tortured. Most of the time the victim has a a limited but certain range of possibly of action. That is why there is a moral life in the camps.

"And on the other side, since this is a book about ordinary evil as well as ordinary goodness, I think we must avoid this initial reaction, which is very common and very understandable, that the killers were monsters, totally different from us, that we have nothing to do with all that, they were demonic, or at least the incarnation of pure evil. In a way this thesis of [Daniel] Goldhagen, of 'exterminatory anti-Semitism', is another example of this. It is creating an essence that which would explain everything. And because of that essence, the people outside the essence feel they don't need to feel concerned at all."

Todorov, who grew up in totaliatarian Bulgaria and came to Paris in 1963, cannot look at history without making judgments. His "post-structuralist" writing has challenged those who over-simplify history or who refuse to see the good and the bad in it. "In the Middle Ages one spoke of exempla. History was a collection of stories which make you think about values. I don't think that even when we are writing history in the most objective way we are really refraining from judgment, but I think that judgment is buried in the way the material is organised and selected. There is always a thesis. Otherwise it is just a chronicle.

"History necessarily has a view of the good. But we feel ashamed to name it because our whole idea of the humanities has been to think we should eliminate everything subjective, every value judgment. I don't think we really manage that well. Because of this we frequently produce unreadable books. It is a strange genre. Maybe that is why we listen so much to novelists and poets - because they have remained full human beings rather than eliminating a large part of their sensibility."

fields.headline: Incident in Exeter Station
fields.trailText:
He came in the door, staring at me,
like he'd known me in another life.
'I've chased everywhere after you,' he said.
fields.body:
for Eddie Linden

He came in the door, staring at me,
like he'd known me in another life.
'I've chased everywhere after you,' he said.
'Years and years, I've been on the road,
too many to count. The train-fares,
the bus-fares, the plane-fares...
The least you can do is buy me a pint.'
He plonked his duffle-bag on the floor
and sat on the stool next to mine.
He looked in my eyes like a holy man,
said 'You're looking well, you've lost weight.'
His face could have done with flesh.
His hair needed a cut and a wash.
'I don't know you', I said, 'I've never,
ever seen you before.' He smiled,
the same smile Jesus must have flashed
at Judas, then his face changed
into a voodoo mask, as he shouted
'After all I've done for you!',
turning to face the roomful of eaters
and drinkers, all of whom ignored him
but I knew they classed us together,
so, seeing a train pull up at the platform,
I grabbed my hat, bags and ran,
getting in just as the train was leaving,
not knowing where it was headed,
hearing his roars follow me out
into the green Devon countryside
that I'd never risk visiting again.

 Matthew Sweeney's collection, A Smell Of Fish, is published by Cape on March 2.

fields.headline: Wilde boy
fields.standfirst: Jad Adams  on the decadent poet Ernest Dowson who died 100 years ago, 'a human sacrifice to art'
fields.trailText: Jad Adams on the decadent poet Ernest Dowson who died 100 years ago, 'a human sacrifice to art'
fields.body:
Alongside other sensual and macabre authors - Poe, Baudelaire, Swinburne - sits one of the most curious figures of English decadence, Ernest Dowson, whose centenary falls this week.

One imagines him a century ago disconsolately surveying the wreckage of his life. Yet the poems still captivate, winning him a loyal following with their emotional directness. They conjure up a world of plaintive distress, concentrating it in powerful bursts of lyrical verse: "They are not long, the weeping and the laughter"; "Beyond the need of weeping, beyond the reach of hand"; "I would not alter thy cold eyes"; "You would have understood me, had you waited"; "I have been faithful to thee, Cynara, in my fashion".

This was the real thing, a man steeped to the soul in poetry. Some of his lines were, as his friend WB Yeats said, destined for immortality, "bound to outlive famous novels and plays and learned histories and other discursive things". He was right. Dowson went into the language, giving us "Days of wine and roses" and "Wine and woman and song", plus - in "Gone with the wind" - the title of a classic film.

Dowson wrote 120 poems, some of which he refused to have published in his lifetime, as if they contained truths too painful to reveal. His companions of the 1890s - Wilde, Yeats, Symons, Beardsley, Gray, Johnson, Rothstein, Smithers - described his life as a human sacrifice to art, propelled by the "swift, disastrous and suicidal impetus of genius". He was "a desperate gamester who had risked all on one throw and lost". To critics, though, he represented "the sentiment, the sentimentality, the nerveless effeminacy... among the wreck of all that is mouldy and unwholesome".

Some people, such as Aubrey Beardsley, who illustrated Dowson's books, found the poet intolerable - dirty, diseased and drunken. Dowson was certainly a man easier to love than to like. When drunk he was, according to his friend Arthur Symons, "almost literally insane, certainly quite irresponsible... a vocabulary unknown to him sprang up like a whirlwind; he seemed always about to commit some absurd act of violence". Oscar Wilde, when asked why he spent his time with such a drunk, replied that it was unfortunate not that this poet should be drunk but that more drunks were not poets.

Dowson was a man of febrile sexual energy: when he could afford it he would have a woman (mainly prostitutes) each night. Yet he was also always described as gentle and drifting, with "the air of being submerged in a dream... the charm of an uncommon simplicity and sincerity". He had the power to attract and keep friends who never doubted his remarkable qualities, for all his faults.

Dowson had more qualification than most for finding himself listed among what Yeats called the "tragic generation". His family was not poor when he was born, but became increasingly impoverished throughout his childhood as they travelled around continental resorts in an attempt to cure his parents' tuberculosis. He had scant education, and was at last forced to work in the near-bankrupt family dry-dock business in Limehouse, pursuing literature as a sideline.

First his father and then his mother committed suicide; Dowson himself developed tuberculosis to add to his depression and his alcoholism. When Wilde was disgraced and imprisoned with hard labour, the best hopes of the decadent movement of which Dowson was a major figure were destroyed.

Dowson never had a relationship with a woman who could be considered his equal in intellect or age; he fell in love with Adelaide, the daughter of a Soho restaurant proprietor, when she was 12 and he was 22. Most of his best work was dedicated to her - "you, who are my verses" - but the over-sensitive poet was no kind of partner. Eventually, after six years of courtship and despite an offer of marriage, she married the family lodger who sometimes worked as a waiter in the restaurant.

Dowson, "suffering the torture of the damned", took to wandering, in Brittany, Paris and London. In 1900, at the age of 32, he died - of years of neglect as much as of tuberculosis - in a friend's house, owning nothing but his tattered manuscript book of verse. He was the last of the romantics.

 Jad Adams's biography of Ernest Dowson, Madder Music, Stronger Wine , is published by IB Tauris at £19.95.

fields.headline: In love with nothingness
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  on Glen Duncan's tale of doomed romance, Love Remains
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on Glen Duncan's tale of doomed romance, Love Remains
fields.body:
Love Remains
Glen Duncan
Granta, £15.99, 288pp
Buy it at BOL

We know that Nicholas and Chloe's affair isn't going to run smoothly when, on their first day together, they visit a bookshop. She goes to the loo and thinks miserably about the scar running from her breast to her arm, the result of a childhood tumble into an open fire. When she returns, her new boyfriend is sitting on a stool reading The French Lieutenant's Woman . "Walking towards him," we are told by the unknown narrator who flits between the two characters' points of view and fills in the gaps in between, "was like forcing herself into a cold sea." Bad auguries indeed.

Love, for Glen Duncan's pair, is not particularly consoling or secure; rather, it is a folie à deux urging them towards an inseparability that threatens their ability to survive apart. For several years Nick and Chloe live almost literally in a world of their own; most of their waking lives are taken up by ceaseless forays of examination into what their attachment to one another has cost them.

These moments of reflection yield somewhat depressing results: Nicholas, hating his wife "for having finished the shape of him so early in life", allows himself the revenge of considering whether she is pretty enough for him. He concludes not. Chloe, in an act of greater revenge, announces that she wants a child; that betrayal of their self-sufficiency is the beginning of their journey apart.

All this hints at a fairly conventional, if over-dramatised, story; boy meets girl, they fall in love and then out of it. Yet Love Remains has far bigger fish to fry. As the novel opens, this narrative is in the past; some catastrophic event has occurred. We meet only Nicholas, exiled in New York, chainsmoking and knocking back Bloody Marys, about to be seduced by a rich sadist with a Fifth Avenue apartment and befriended by an alcoholic ex-pat. (Would that we all had such luck on our holidays.)

This kind of improbability, combined with some desperate overwriting, makes for a seriously flawed novel. It takes a major suspension of disbelief to follow Nicholas and Chloe on their journey into co-dependency: because neither of them has especially well-developed or likeable personalities, it's difficult to appreciate why they should love one another so much, or at least why they should so painstakingly construct an edifice of impenetrable togetherness. It's even harder to go along for the ride when the relationship begins to unravel.

As if sensing this problem, Duncan introduces one of the most outrageous plot developments I've ever encountered in order to get himself out of narrative hot water. As it occurs halfway through the novel and entirely disrupts proceedings, it seems churlish to reveal the exact nature of the twist.

It's enough to say that something absolutely hideous and extremely unlikely happens, which suddenly reconnects Nicholas and Chloe to the material world and splits them apart, sending Nick scurrying towards the airport. But it's not just the couple's relationship that cracks under pressure: this selfconsciously portentous and delicate love story was never built to withstand such a sudden change of pace, nor a metamorphosis into a wholly different kind of novel.

Love Remains has evidently been conceived and executed with tremendous care and effort; like a relationship that leaves both parties scratching their heads, it smacks of something that nearly worked and then went awry. It would be extremely hard to accuse Glen Duncan of a lack of ambition, as his central theme - the solipsism and inscrutability of lovers - famously resists description and interpretation.

There is evidence of real talent here, if Duncan can keep the purple prose in check and resist the temptation to lard straightforward, truthful thoughts with linguistic obfuscation. Somewhere inside this stilted, disjointed novel, there was a much simpler tale trying to be told, instead of which we get two unfinished novels oddly conflated - a bold attempt to tell it like it is, but curiously wide of the mark.

fields.headline: Greer uncut
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on the sequel that Germaine Greer said would never happen, The Whole Woman
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on the sequel that Germaine Greer said would never happen, The Whole Woman
fields.body:
The Whole Woman
Germaine Greer
Anchor, £7.99
Buy it at BOL

This is the sequel that she said would never happen - but we shouldn't hold this against her, as not only are all writers' vows written on water, but a lot has changed since The Female Eunuch came out. Besides, it isn't exactly as if she has been away. People have not had much opportunity to wonder "wouldn't it be nice if she wrote another book?" in the way that they used to yearn for Beatles reunions.

So here we are again, Greer's rage and wit being launched against all that irks her. Feminism, for her, is not a matter of equality; it's a matter of not having your womanhood traduced, compromised, or threatened. This is the first principle from which all else follows: for all that Greer is accused of wild inconsistency, she is also, among other things, an academic, with an academic's capacity to pursue an argument rigorously and without deviation, ad absurdum, if necessary.

So when she rails against transsexuals ("pantomime dames" is the chapter heading - Greer's lower case - in which she discusses them), she does so in order to present us not with individuals tormented by the feeling that they have been born into the wrong gender, but with an example of men trying to argue themselves into the last sacrosanct female places, ie the women's loos.

"When a man decides to spend his life impersonating his mother (like Norman Bates in Psycho ) it is as if he murders her and gets away with it, proving at a stroke that there was nothing to her." This is what really gets her goat: women not being noticed, not being treated as people.

To complain about the insensitivity and cold-heartedness of many of her arguments is, perhaps, to miss the point. In the chapter headed "daughters", she visits the notorious part of Blake Morrison's As If where he describes his infant daughter's body, pretty much all of it, in terms which caused something of a fuss, and points out that to look at a young girl in this way is another way of refusing to see a person: "scrumptious, sensual and irrational while denying their present reality... I am grateful to the artfulness of Morrison's writing for the insight into how the distant father and the sexualising father can be one and the same."

Of the famous sentence of Morrison's, "A child in my lap, being read to, and I find myself erect," she says: "Not so long ago finding oneself erect would have meant springing involuntarily to one's feet." The point is not just a good fogeyish gag but the dismay that Morrison identifies himself with his penis. The other point is that this is not, I feel, a fair reading of Morrison. It has to be said: Greer is not fair; and this isn't a quality we should seek from her. I have a few friends and colleagues - most of them women - who have been publicly vilified or even sued by Greer, and, if it were not so obviously fighting talk, I would be tempted to say that she is one of those people who can dish it out - boy, does she dish it out - but can't take it.

But that's not a good enough reason to dismiss her. She is sui generis, seemingly unstoppable, very often right, and an extraordinarily talented self-publicist: who else could have been so constantly in the public eye, making so many (how shall we put it?) unexpected pronouncements, not to mention publishing more photographs of her pudenda than we normally ask of our intellectuals, without exhausting our appetite for her?

fields.headline: Camera crimes
fields.standfirst: Michael Ignatieff's Virtual War offers a defence of Nato's remote-control zapper war against the war criminal in Belgrade, but is alert to the heavy moral questions it raised.
fields.trailText: Michael Ignatieff's Virtual War offers a defence of Nato's remote-control zapper war against the war criminal in Belgrade, but is alert to the heavy moral questions it raised.
fields.body:
Virtual War: Kosovo and Beyond
Michael Ignatieff
Chatto and Windus, £12.99, 249pp
Buy it at BOL

Long before the Nato bombs, when Kosovo's ethnic Albanians were only being killed in their low thousands, a tractor came down a lane carrying three adults and two children. The MUP policemen lay in wait, then opened fire. The five corpses were, literally, shredded. Detectives and pathologists from the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe turned up to count the cartridges: the family on the tractor had been shot with more than 300 bullets. That night Belgrade TV reported that the five had died in a serious road accident.

It was true enough for Belgrade TV. The tractor family had been on a road. They had been involved in an accident, because the Serb policemen had hoped to ambush the "terrorists" of the KLA, and someone had shot up the family before realising that they were unarmed and defenceless civilians. And 300 bullets is pretty serious. Ergo, a serious road accident.

All right, there is no font for irony. In plain language, then, Belgrade TV was - and is - a lie machine. Because the five dead were ethnic Albanians and the killers were Serb cops, their murder was reinvented as a car crash. When the TV studios were blasted by Nato bombs, Harold Pinter, Jon Pilger, Tariq Ali, the BBC's John Simpson and the Iraqi Minister of Information said it was an atrocity; Pinter called the killing of the make-up lady a war crime. If so, what was Srebrenica?

You can understand it, really: Pinter and the others have met lots of make-up ladies, but probably never had their cheeks rouged by 7,000 blokes from a small town in eastern Bosnia. (The reason Nato bombed the TV studios was not because of its journalistic output. Milosevic's generals were using the transmitter to talk to their colonels in Kosovo, colonels who held the ring while Arkan's boys did the machine-gunning. Got it?)

To his great credit, Michael Ignatieff saw the difference between what Slobodan Milosevic had been doing to Yugoslavia and what Nato was trying to do to him and his supporters. Unlike some members of what you might call the British intelligentsia, Ignatieff recognised the subtle fascist in Milosevic. This book offers a defence of Nato's remote-control zapper war against the war criminal in Belgrade, but is alert to the heavy moral questions it raised.

He is struck by the unreality of the war in Kosovo - how the western public saw it as a succession of videogame images, targets coming into focus through a nose-cone camera and then fading to fuzz. He sees a shallow war, in which the western public can watch its servicemen fight with impunity. The central question is simple. Does the wholesale abuse of human rights in one state permit other states to fight a war to stop that abuse?

You might think that the doctrine of non-interference went out with the Holocaust, but Ignatieff has a dialogue with Robert Skidelsky where the two knock this one around. Skidelsky writes: "Blair takes direct issue with the prudential tradition of diplomacy. 'Bismarck,' he remarked, 'famously said that the Balkans were not worth the bones of a single Pomeranian grenadier.' He added smugly: 'Bismarck was wrong.' "

Ignatieff sees off Skidelsky, and sets out the case for committed internationalism. He misses the best, single argument for Nato's involvement: that Nato telescoped the civil war between the Serb one-tenth minority and the Albanian nine-tenths majority and shortened a conflict that could have ground on for years to three months. Nato saved lives. Had the west acted sooner and more forcefully - say, back in 1991, when Milosevic sent the tanks in against the Belgrade students - then perhaps 100,000 Yugoslavs might still be alive.

It's an easy read, with deft touches, but a bit thin. As a child, Ignatieff spent a couple of years in Belgrade; this gives him an emotional link to the city and its agonies, but it reads a little superficially. There are nice vignettes with some of the big players - Wesley Clark, Richard Holbrooke, Louise Arbour - but not enough reporting from the ground. One has the uneasy feel of too many pieces to camera and TV clips stuck back-to-back, and not enough wandering around in the mud with a pen and a notebook. And finally, Ignatieff is a handsome man, but two photographs of the author in war mode? Too few for Hello! magazine, maybe, but too many in a book about the mass murder of innocent people.

 John Sweeney will talk on related topics tomorrow at the Bath Literary Festival.

fields.headline: DNA and destruction
fields.standfirst: John Emsley's 'biography' of phosphorous, The Shocking History of Phosphorus, is eminently skimmable...
fields.trailText: John Emsley's 'biography' of phosphorous, The Shocking History of Phosphorus, is eminently skimmable...
fields.body:
The Shocking History of Phosphorus: A Biography of the Devil's Element
John Emsley
Macmillan, £12.99, 326pp

If God had any consideration, he would have delivered phosphorus with a health warning. Its abundance in brains and bones made the first chemists believe the elemental stuff must be good for you. They had no inkling that the eerily glowing solid they distilled laboriously from vats of stinking urine would one day destroy cities in firestorms, yield poisons potent enough to quicken the heart of any tyrant, or underpin an industry which killed hundreds of workers.

Yet all this came to pass because a German alchemist trapped a strange liquid with a smell like garlic. Solidified, a pale light came from the flames playing continually over its surface. Hennig Brandt of Hamburg was probably the first person to see pure phosphorus. A little less than 300 years later, his city was reduced to ash by relentless allied fire bombing.

In between, the fiery element was responsible for innumerable misguided medical treatments. It plagued workers in match factories with "phossy jaw"; victims' rotting bones and sores stank so vilely that doctors could hardly bear to examine them. And it was the key ingredient in the nerve gas already being manufactured by the Nazis when Hamburg was cremated, but which Hitler kept to himself for fear of retaliation in kind.

All very dramatic - and if a biography of an element is a feasible idea, then phosphorus is an obvious one to choose. But John Emsley's volume, more potted history than biography, also shows the limits of the conceit.

The fact that all these triumphs and tragedies, great and small, are linked by one elemental signature has no particular significance. Humans exploit the properties of natural materials for whatever ends they see fit. Those properties may expedite particular ends, but they do nothing to shape them. If matchsticks, incendiaries, nerve gas - or detergents, insecticides, fertilisers and food additives - all incorporated different chemicals instead of the same one, there is no reason to think that the great sweep of history would have changed much. Many small histories would have been affected, and these Emsley relates efficiently. But on a larger scale mere chronology does not make a narrative.

With that constraint in mind, he mostly does a good job. The sources are impressively wide, and there is no obvious competition. Primo Levi has a chapter headed "Phosphorus" in The Periodic Table but, of course, it is not really about phosphorus at all.

The vogue for recovering tales from the history of science, such as the stories Dava Sobel tells in Longitude or Galileo's Daughter, demands episodes which unfold during a single lifetime. Emsley, meanwhile, needs to take a wider canvas. But his pointillistic method occasionally makes dreary reading, even though he tries to keep everything brisk and accessible.

Some chapters do tell self-contained stories, like the Victorian industrial struggles of the Bryant and May match girls. Others, like those on murders which might or might not have involved phosphorus or on alleged cases of spontaneous human combustion, appear to come straight off the card index. Read one case summary of a marriage ended by rat poison rather than divorce, and several more of the same become less compelling. Seen one set of human remains consumed in flames fuelled by body fat? Seen them all.

On the other hand, the absence of an overarching narrative means that the book is eminently skimmable, and most browsers will find something of interest in Emsley's blend of social, industrial, military and economic history, mixed in with a fair bit of chemistry. His conclusion, in spite of phosphorus's past misdeeds, is upbeat: now that we really understand this dangerously alluring element, we can exploit the benefits and avoid the hazards.

As it turns out to be essential to everything from energy transfer in our cells to building the molecular backbone of DNA, this is good news, if it is true. But the optimism of some of Emsley's historical verdicts makes one wonder. After describing the hellish night of destruction in Hamburg, he declares that "dropping phosphorus bombs on the homes of innocent civilians is never likely to happen again".

Sure, but now we have napalm and nuclear weapons; again, this shows the limits of a history focused on a non-human actor. But if you want to explore how the chemical peculiarities of one element have aided and abetted humans, well-intentioned and otherwise, then take a look at this wide-ranging book.

 Jon Turney is a member of the Department of Science and Technology Studies, University College London

fields.headline: Inadmissible evidence
fields.standfirst: Nigel Rees's  Dictionary of Anecdotes contains 'over 1,000' anecdotes. Ian Sansom doesn't care
fields.trailText: The faceless, frothing phantasms conjured up in Nigel Rees's Dictionary of Anecdotes are merely the freaks and mooncalves born of Wishful Thinking and Misremembrance.
fields.body:
The Cassell Dictionary of Anecdotes
ed Nigel Rees
Cassell, £12.99, 384pp
Buy it at BOL

You start out life as a query and end up as an anecdote - if you're lucky. If you're really lucky - if you've managed to kill lots of people, say, in a new and exciting way, or you've spent your time constructing some great wobbly paradigm shift or composing unreadable works of literary fiction - then all the anecdotes about you might one day be sourced, collected and published. This will be called your biography and sold in Waterstone's on the shelves marked "People".

Right this moment, all over the world, all sorts of People are being plucked and jointed and elaborately sauced, ready for a retelling over dinner tonight. Did you make a mistake at work yesterday? Were you funny? Did you trip and fall? Excellent! For what are colleagues and friends and family but anecdotes in the making? Grandparents are old wives' tales. Parents are reminiscences. Former lovers, moral fables; children, sayings and stories. And your boss is a second-hand B-format horror.

Your afterlife is an anecdote, and vice versa. Indeed, most people, post-Vatican II, seem to imagine heaven as This Is Your Life: you enter a celestial TV studio to discover the great serried ranks of your past waiting to tell their anecdotes which prove what a great person you always were, despite all the evidence to the contrary. Then a slab-faced St Peter hands you the big red book and you all shuffle out back to an eternity of canapés, sparkling white and the swapping of amusing stories. (Hell is similar, but without the canapés and with sweet sherry instead of Cava.)

Not surprisingly, most of the "over 1,000" anecdotes in Nigel Rees's Dictionary of Anecdotes are told by, or of, actors and politicians, with the occasional churchman thrown in for good measure. This is because they already inhabit that deathly world called public life, where image means more than substance. Here, the carefully polished bon mot and high-glossed sally of wit are important signs of social status. It may also be that they are the only professions with enough gall to try and fob off their ramblings on the public, although football managers and newspaper columnists have also started getting in on the act. The anecdote thrives among those professionals for whom personality means performance: it makes a fetish of "character".

The faceless, frothing phantasms conjured up in Rees's collection - the likes of Winston "And you, madam, are ugly" Churchill and Oscar "This wallpaper will be the death of me" Wilde - presumably bear no relation to the living, breathing individuals who once inhabited their names, but are merely the freaks and mooncalves born of Wishful Thinking and Misremembrance.

Anecdotes are made and not given, as Rees's habitual means of attribution confirms. Most entries find themselves "According to" or "Related by" (often to and by the likes of Peter Ustinov and Ned Sherrin and not infrequently on Quote... Unquote, a radio show devised by Rees as a meeting place for plummy-voiced old-stagers and silly storytellers). The resulting recycled concoctions are not the kind of evidence that would stand up in a court of law or work of history (except perhaps one by a future Simon Schama).

To bulk up his selection Rees includes as anecdotes what the rest of us might regard merely as remarks, witticisms, sayings, catchphrases or malapropisms. Is the phrase "the wrong kind of snow" really an anecdote? Or Auden's saying of his face that it looked like a wedding cake left out in the rain? As Peter Ustinov once remarked to me, Ned Sherrin and Simon Callow over an excellent roast beef and claret dinner at his club in Pall Mall, recalling his great friend, that wonderful comic actor Ricky Tomlinson in The Royle Family - commissioned by a friend of mine at the Beeb, actually, wife left him for a studio manager, awfully sad - "My arse".

fields.headline: Bathetic fallacies
fields.standfirst: With his new collection, Laureate's Block, anti-Laureate Tony Harrison has lost his laurels
fields.trailText: With his new collection, Laureate's Block, anti-Laureate Tony Harrison has lost his laurels
fields.body:
Laureate's Block and Other Occasional Poems
Tony Harrison
Penguin, £7.99, 112pp
Buy it at BOL

When John Betjeman died in 1984, it was widely assumed that Philip Larkin would be offered the Laureateship - not least by Larkin himself. "That's in my lap," he told Kingsley Amis as far back as 1976. "I've no hope of getting out of that bugger." In the end he was indeed offered the post, gave it careful consideration, and turned it down.

When Ted Hughes died in 1998, press speculation threw up a number of names, some more plausible than others. Nobel Laureate Seamus Heaney had long before carefully warned everyone to "Be advised my passport's green / No glass of ours was ever raised / To toast the Queen", making his Irish republicanism clear.

Tony Harrison, roused at even the mention of his name in the papers, faxed the Guardian with "Laureate's Block", a hubristic poem outlining not merely his English republicanism but his adulterous relationship with a younger woman, his dislike of Andrew Motion and his need to be free to "blast and bollock Blairite Britain". He was not offered the job, but these two events were not necessarily related.

"Laureate's Block" has been reprinted as the title poem of Harrison's new volume. Also included are an earlier poem he wrote fantasising the abdication of King Charles III, some poems about Bosnia, a couple more on his adultery, a suite of poems for his sick son and another to a friend who died. There are also occasional poems for birthdays and suchlike.

There is much to dislike in the volume, but the worst thing about it is that the verse is bad. Harrison has been lauded so often for his technical skill, his facility with metre as a classicist and his ability to use the demotic alongside the elevated, that fewer and fewer people notice how cloth-eared he has become.

Within six lines of the book's opening we encounter the couplet: "and hymn the crown's demise I will / with this black goose-feather quill". Leaving aside the archaic sentence construction, dictated by rhyme and metre, there is no way of scanning the second line in a satisfactory manner.

Now, metrical variation - exchanging an iamb for a trochee, for instance, or allowing in the odd dactyl - is a legitimate and necessary technique in verse: it breaks the monotony of line upon line of iambics and, at its best, the varied metre will in some way echo a change of pace, tone, direction or content in the line.

There is no evidence in this book that Harrison's divergence from his predominant iambic, nor his addition or subtraction of a foot every so often, is deliberate in this way; it looks, instead, very much like a bad accident. "His restlessness fed into mine / though I've always come back to the Tyne". There are countless examples of this: blandly worded banalities that don't quite scan. After a while, they become unintentionally hilarious. Even Homer nods, but this is more like narcolepsy.

The most grotesque result of this poor technique is to render bathetic his more serious material: about Bosnia, for instance, or the illness of dying friends and acquaintances. One problem is that Harrison cannot see beyond the rhyming couplet to what he is trying to say. The couplet becomes an end in itself, and content is repeated for as long as Harrison can find rhymes and enough padding to fill the lines. "Figs on the Tyne", a birthday poem for his girlfriend, takes as its point of departure the idea that global warming has allowed Harrison to grow figs in Newcastle.

The point is made over and over again, in a style not dissimilar to Marvell's in "To His Coy Mistress", a poem that gets a couple of name-checks earlier in the book. But where Marvell's apparent repetition of one point in a variety of phrases is a device aimed at steadily accumulating spurious arguments as to why his loved one should yield to him ("the grave's a fine and private place, / but none, I think, do there embrace"), Harrison's look threadbare rather than wittily epigrammatic: "This vision of Yorkshire by the Med / no doubt won't come until I'm dead. / Torridity in Tyne and Wear / won't come till I'm no longer here." And so on, and on, and on.

In "Deathwatch Danceathon" Harrison more obviously travesties Marvell's poem: "Put less ornately, 'we're soon dead, / my sweetest darling, come to bed!' " This might well be the problem: Harrison doesn't seem to understand why poems are written in certain ways - that the ornateness is central to the wit of Marvell's poem, for instance.

In this collection, Harrison's no-nonsense debunking of the classics and his now tiresome employment of once-rude words is not far off the spraying of obscenities on forebears' gravestones that he treated with more sophistication in his controversial long poem V. Harrison was wrongly criticised for his use of obscenities in that book: they were crucial to his subject, and to the language of the text. Here one gets the uneasy feeling that Harrison's relish for the word "fuck" is that of the schoolboy rather than of the poet.

The intimations of mortality that give Marvell's poem its grim vigour are clearly preying on Harrison. "Laureate's Block", in considering the death of Ted Hughes, offers the confession that "I heard / Ted died, and needed my lover... to help me not to brood I'm near Ted's age".

"Figs on the Tyne" returns to that consolation: "and with the first of my Tyne figs / celebrate you're 46!"; "I've seen it, like our love, survive / from when you were only 35"; "And now today you're 46 / and far from the first of our sweet figs"; "46 / leaves life enough for future figs, / and I still hope to suck a few / though this year I turn 62!"

This is a stab in the dark, but I think what Tony Harrison is saying is that his girlfriend is 46 (or forty-sigs, perhaps), and that he is 62, and that they've been dating for about a decade. I think this cheers him up, whatever his wife might make of it ("My semen in your body's not yet dried. / My wife sleeps warm and naked by my side"). But I do not feel that reading about any of this has improved my life.

To be honest, this book reads like a cruel parody of Tony Harrison, and marks a terrible falling off from his earlier work. The man who wrote the admirable poem "On Not Being Milton" has come up with work that should be filed under "On Not Being Marvell" or, indeed, "On Not Being Motion". On the evidence of this collection, it isn't just his politics that would have made Harrison unsuitable for the Laureateship.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.trailText: Ian Rankin charts a new map of the psyche of modern Scotland, plus Arms And The Women
fields.body:
The British sleuths are back in force, with the investigative pack in brilliant form. Ian Rankin's Set in Darkness (Orion, £16.99) is his eleventh Inspector John Rebus novel in a series whose time has come, with a television adaptation featuring John Hannah on the way.

Rebus is deeply flawed and invariably pig-headed, but harbours a strong moral centre often at awkward odds with the cases he is called to examine. Edinburgh is his patch, and few authors have dug as deep as Rankin beneath the city streets. The new Scottish parliament is the setting for a bizarre series of murders, and Rebus's intervention soon charts a new map of the psyche of modern Scotland, a country torn between past and present in the wake of devolution. Complex, humane and gripping, this is a perfect introduction to the art of Ian Rankin, head capo of the Scots mystery MacMafia.

Reginald Hill's northern cops Andy Dalziel and Peter Pascoe take a back seat in their latest adventure, Arms and the Women (HarperCollins, £16.99). This 17th novel in a series combining traditional sleuthing, wit and exquisite characterisation pushes Ellie, Pascoe's wife, to the fore. Threatened by poison-pen letters, she assumes they are due to her husband's work, but soon discovers strange and sometimes comic connections with the novel she is writing about ancient Greece. Part parody, part breathless thriller, this is Reginald Hill lite, but he's always worthwhile.

Martyn Waites's Candleland (Allison & Busby, £16.99) bears witness to the flowering of a major new talent. A cynical journalist is asked by a policeman from his native Newcastle to hunt down his lost HIV-positive daughter among the murky London underworld: warring drug dealers, child prostitutes and born-again Christian gangsters all feature. If Philip Marlowe had been born later, British and Geordie, these are the mean streets he would be cleaning up.

Buy Set In Darkness at BOL

fields.headline: The beast inside
fields.standfirst: Lisa Darnell  is captured by Jula Leigh's stunning first novel, The Hunter
fields.trailText: Lisa Darnell is captured by Jula Leigh's stunning first novel, The Hunter
fields.body:
The Hunter
Julia Leigh
Faber, £9.99, 124pp
Buy it at BOL

Australians know something about wilderness. They understand the dangers that lurk there, the balance between survival and extinction. In Julia Leigh's The Hunter, the inscrutable naturalist "M" has been sent to track down the Tasmanian tiger, the thylacine, a mythical, wolf-like creature last seen in 1936. It is believed that one female still exists. Following in the footsteps of a previous hunter who has failed to return from an expedition, M lodges at the foot of the mountains with the missing man's wife, now somnambulant with grief, and her two anarchic children.

Every week M prepares his pack, climbs the mountains, camouflages himself with animal excrement, sets intricate traps and tries to stay awake long enough to catch a glimpse of his prey. When he returns to his lodgings it is merely to take a shower, accept bizarre meals from the children and set off again.

During the long weeks he dreams of being hunted, inhabiting the body of the beast he pursues. It soon becomes clear that M's mission is not necessarily the one he has been sent on by the mysterious "company", and that he is compelled by a quest of his own.

Both M and the tiger of which he dreams are survivors, united in their isolation and by their resolute ability to wait. Like the tiger, M has no mate, no friends. He is capable of amputating his own foot if necessary to survive. He smears himself with wallaby droppings "until he is not quite human, a strange but not entirely unfamiliar beast". He believes himself to be joining his ancestors. "It will take time to get a fix on his prey, to think like a fine and worthy predator. Yet he knows it will come easily, this skill learnt in the schoolyard, rough-hewn at fumbling teenage parties, and finely honed during hand-to-dollar transactions."

Leigh is careful to leave M's character unformed: he is as dispassionate as the animals he hunts. It is only in the introduction of two hippie landrangers who are also searching for the tiger - in order to protect it - that Leigh allows us a glimpse of an alternative moral framework.

Over time, M is affected by regular contact with the dead man's wife and children. He falls prey to human emotions - the wife's longing for a mate, the boy's jealousy of M's access to the plateau, the girl's suspicion and desperate hope that M will somehow return with their lost father. He finds it in himself to care about their future. But, as time reveals, this isn't necessarily a route to redemption.

It is rare to find a first-time novelist who can so confidently avoid the confessional - albeit by reinventing Hemingway. Leigh has completely mastered the craft of storytelling, and her evocation of place and time is stunning. A more than commonly gifted writer, she has made a startling debut.

webTitle: Fact vies with fiction in pursuit of the classic English poisoner

fields.headline: Fact vies with fiction in pursuit of the classic English poisoner
fields.standfirst: Truth not enough for biography, says poet laureate
fields.trailText: The poet laureate, Andrew Motion, spent two years partly inventing a "fictional" biography and imaginary confession of the 19th-century poisoner Thomas Wainewright, with the defence that most of the key facts about the murderer's life had been destroyed.
fields.body:
The poet laureate, Andrew Motion, spent two years partly inventing a "fictional" biography and imaginary confession of the 19th-century poisoner Thomas Wainewright, with the defence that most of the key facts about the murderer's life had been destroyed.

"If the material simply isn't there, what can be done?" Motion asked. "I'm going to have to make it up." Well - another scholar replied yesterday - he could have looked more thoroughly at some 300 documents on the Regency artist and dandy in the public record office, London, and other libraries.

Much of the key material has not been destroyed and was waiting on the shelves to be unearthed, according to research by Marc Vaubert de Chantilly. And it includes a real-life virtual confession by Wainewright to the most celebrated of the three murders of which he was suspected.

The new documents go far towards clearing up a notorious 170-year mystery. They prove that Wainewright - writing in desperation from a convict ship as he awaited deportation to Tasmania for another offence - made a series of last-ditch offers to the authorities to reveal details of the murders in exchange for a free pardon and guarantees about his safety.

After Wainewright's death in Tasmania in 1847 at the age of 53, Oscar Wilde grew fascinated with him, and Charles Dickens used him as model for a poisoner in his novel Martin Chuzzlewit and in other stories.

Disappeared

Dickens was told in 1867 that these statements of Wainewright's "so-called confession" had "all disappeared". Motion's book, Wainewright the Poisoner, published by Faber and Faber last Monday, finds that the evidence for the man's guilt is "flimsy". But de Chantilly said the new papers he has found on file are "as close to a confession as we are going to get".

He said the files also contained a wealth of "massively important" biographical facts that the laureate had missed.

Last night, after seeing two of the new papers, Motion confessed that certain documents had "eluded" him. "I'm delighted they have been found," he said. "I would love to have seen them. I did as much research as I was able. Every scholar knows you miss things. Life's like that."

But he confidently defended the rest of his research and his choice of an imaginative approach. "Even if all this material had been available, I would still have done what I did."

The book has received qualified critical praise. In its foreword, Motion argues that "orthodox biographical methods" would be formidably difficult because of the scarcity of facts. Wainewright's voice is "lost". Yet "our responsibility to history includes a duty to reflect on forgotten lives".

His solution is a "confection" of imagination and long factual notes, an attempt to "ventriloquise" the killer's voice. His method has already triggered a literary debate on whether biographers should be expected to rely on facts alone.

One interviewer wrote: "Making it up is not generally accepted as a weapon in the biographer's arsenal. Motion is well aware that purists may be dismayed - and may already have their guns trained on him."

A former antiquarian bookseller in Charing Cross Road, London, he has spent 18 months in libraries including the Bodleian, Royal Academy and Victoria & Albert researching his own life of Wainewright and editing an anthology of the painter's writings.

Dedicated

Giles Mandelbrote, curator of early printed books at the British Library, said: "From what I have read of his other work, he is a very dedicated, scrupulously accurate and painstaking researcher who is finding out some very interesting things.

"I have been very impressed by his dilgence. I would be very surprised if he is wrong about these records."

De Chantilly sees Wainewright as "a forerunner of the classic English murderer - the middle classes poisoning for money". He was an indigent, self-obsessed artist and writer who was friendly with leading contemporaries including Blake, Hazlitt, De Quincy, Clare and Keats.

In 1830, when he was short of money, he got his young sister-in-law Helen Abercrombie to take out insurance policies worth £16,000 (a high six-figure sum today) and to make a will in his favour.

Within days of this deal, Helen started vomiting, grew weak, went blind and died slowly. Wainewright was also suspected of poisoning two other relatives for money. He was never charged because forensic knowledge of poisons was then too primitive. But he was convicted of an insurance forgery and deported for life, an unusually harsh sentence implicitly meant to reflect suspicions of murder. The papers, in a home office file of criminal petitions at the record office, are from Eagle Insurance, which held one of Helen's policies.

The first was sent to the department, in view of the "strange mystery" of the three deaths, on July 17 1837 by Henry Smith, company actuary, while Wainewright was about to be deported.

Smith wrote: "He has offered that if his safety be guaranteed, and a free pardon be granted to him, to enable him to give Evidence, he will make a full disclosure of all the facts connected with the concoction of this Fraud, and the Death of Miss Abercrombie."

Only five days later a company clerk sent the home secretary a frantic letter received that morning from Wainewright. It asked: "Am I to hear farther from Mr Smith, on the subject of my giving a full account and revelation of the circumstances connected with the sudden or somewhat sudden end of [Helen]? I am ready & can point out the places where Medicines were procured &c &c. It will - you must see - complete your affair...

"My evidence will touch two Persons and the Warrants should be got at once to stop farther Proceedings in Equity... Now all cause of concealment is done away and you may inform the secretary of state that I am ready to make such depositions."

According to one view of the letter, he was offering to incriminate two other relatives who were still pursuing claims against the company on Helen's policy. By confessing knowledge of the poisons, he risked incriminating himself. But, with the pardon and guarantee he had earlier asked for, he could not have been prosecuted or hanged for the murders. However, his bait for a pardon was refused. His convict ship sailed to Tasmania - which proved to be a punishment as fatal as the gallows and even more drawn-out than a poison.

The papers throw new light on a later claim by Smith that "Wainewright confessed that he used strychnine and morphine", though no documented confirmation of this has yet been found. Mentioning the claim in his book, Motion declares dismissively: "It is impossible to tell what confession - if any - Wainewright made in his papers."

Last night Motion congratulated de Chantilly on, "like all biographers and scholars, adding to an existing store of knowledge. At the same time, it is not true to say that I neglected to do vital primary research. I spent several years working in, among other places, all the libraries he mentions."

The made-up parts of his book were not expedient. They were mainly "the result of my wish to experiment with biographical form, and to employ various imaginative ways of bringing my subject back to life... Truth can be slippery and many-faceted and certainly was in the case of Wainewright."

De Chantilly - the purist - insisted: "Our duty to history is to find out the truth, not to resort to making it up. I don't think he has done his work properly."

webTitle: Christina Foyle library expected to fetch £10m

fields.headline: Christina Foyle library expected to fetch £10m
fields.trailText: The private library of the notoriously eccentric bookshop heiress, Christina Foyle, is expected to raise more than £10m when it goes under the hammer later this year.
fields.body:
The private library of the notoriously eccentric bookshop heiress, Christina Foyle, is expected to raise more than £10m when it goes under the hammer later this year.

The 7,000 leather-bound volumes, including a first folio of Shakespeare's works and signed copies of other literary masterpieces, are to be sold by her family to raise money for the charitable trust set up in her name.

The multi-million pound collection was started by her father, William, who founded London's most celebrated bookshop on Charing Cross Road in 1904. The first tranche of books was removed from Ms Foyle's former home, Beeleigh Abbey, near Maldon, Essex, last week by experts from the rare books department at Christie's.

Christie's yesterday declined to give details of the books in the sale, saying only that it would be an "historic" auction.

Her nephew, Christopher Foyle, who now runs the bookshop, said: "It is a quite remarkable collection, the like of which only comes on to the market every 10 years or so.

"The entire collection is leather-bound and includes extremely rare first, second, third and fourth folios of Shakespeare's works.

"There are also a number of Books of Hours handwritten on vellum, which are extremely beautiful."

John Sprague, who works for Sotheran, the rare book dealer in Piccadilly, London, estimated that a first folio of Shakespeare could fetch £1m. "They are very rare and there are very few in the hands of private collectors."

Nigel Traylen, who was employed by the Foyle family as their expert in antiquarian books, said: "It is a very large collection, although a bit of a hotchpotch.

"But they are all very good books."

Mr Traylen, who now works for Ventnor Rare Books on the Isle of Wight, said that the library contained a large number of illuminated manu scripts, in addition to rare first editions by Dr Johnson, James Boswell and Charles Dickens.

One of the most sought after pieces is likely to be a signed letter by Samuel Pepys.

Ms Foyle joined the family business at the age of 17.

She was devoted to her father and his shop, and was regularly introduced to writers such as Shaw, Kipling and Wells when they talked with her father while book buying.

A renowned hostess of literary luncheons for almost 70 years, she left just a few thousand pounds to her family when she died last June.

She reserved her biggest bequest to her handyman to look after her pets - a dog and six tortoises.

webTitle: If you can't take the heat...

fields.headline: If you can't take the heat...
fields.trailText: Guests at the packed TS Eliot lecture this week, given by man of the moment David Mamet, got more than they bargained for when they sat down to dinner afterwards in the grand hall of Eliot College in Canterbury.
fields.body:
 Guests at the packed TS Eliot lecture this week, given by man of the moment David Mamet, got more than they bargained for when they sat down to dinner afterwards in the grand hall of Eliot College in Canterbury. As they picked their way delicately through the monkfish and guinea fowl and wondered what the hell Mamet had been talking about (fairytale, Freud and ice hockey), a fire alarm sounded, distantly but insistently.

The assembled company duly trooped out into the bitter Kentish night, oohed and aahed as burly firemen hurled themselves out of fire engines and into danger, and then wondered where the guest of honour was. But the shy and retiring Mamet was nowhere to be seen, having taken the opportunity to slip discreetly away and straight into a fast car back to London.

 Booker Prize devotees will recall that one source of discontent for the judges is the sheer volume of material they have to read - for, as one of them put it last year (albeit slightly more politely), bugger all. Well, it's just got worse. Currently, publishers are allowed to submit two titles for consideration, causing much jockeying among authors. Under new rules, however, they can be joined by any authors who have previously won or been shortlisted. In other words, if your name's Barnes, McEwan or Bainbridge, you're in - although not necessarily, as in 1998, all at once.

 Meanwhile, one of last year's controversial omissions, Salman Rushdie, is up against the winner. The Ground Beneath Her Feet, having won the Eurasian heat of the Commonwealth Writer's Prize for best book, now meets JM Coetzee's Disgrace, winner of the African section, in the grand final, along with Shauna Singh Baldwin (the Caribbean and Canada) and Lily Brett (southeast Asia and the south Pacific). The final victor will emerge in April and claim their £10,000.

fields.headline: Top 10 hardback novels
fields.trailText: A straightforward list of hardback novels that contains a few surprises: that John Grisham and Joanna Trollope top the chart may be taken as read, but look at Scottish crimester Ian Rankin, well on his way to superstar status at number 3: he has a loyal and rapidly growing following. Perhaps the most impressive display in this list, however, is by newcomer Zadie Smith with her lively tale of urban racial identity, White Teeth. It is no mean feat, as a first novelist, to get within snapping distance of the likes of Grisham and Trollope. Certainly there will still be a great difference in the volume of sales between her and those doughty titans, but Hamish Hamilton's large advance to Ms Smith is beginning to look like a shrewd commercial decision.
