fields.headline: She said too much
fields.standfirst:
A woman soldier, trained in brutality in Northern Ireland, has her book suppressed
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A woman soldier, trained in brutality in Northern Ireland, has her book suppressed.
fields.body:
"Dear Sir. . . She Who Dared ISBN No 085052 696-8. . . We must ask you immediately to return your copy of this book to us. . . We will send you a replacement copy as soon as possible. "

As a book promotion, this letter to literary editors earlier this month, from the respected military publisher Leo Cooper, obviously had hidden depths; an opacity in keeping with its subject matter: the undercover war in Northern Ireland. That an injunction had been obtained by the ministry of defence to suppress the book, two months after publication and long after the ministry itself had "cleared" (ie, censored) the work, was not mentioned.

Nor, for that matter, has HarperCollins explained to retailers why the paperback of my own book about the Troubles - The Irish War - remains unpublished following an advisory letter from MoD saying "Don't !" This deterrent was one that succeeded without even the formality of a court order to back it up.

Is this a new trend in book marketing? A negative buoyancy test to affirm the true importance of a book about Britain's last colonial war? Should publishers collude in the process? Or is the inconsistent behaviour of MoD - first allowing a book to be published, and then having a paroxysm of post-publication regret - the military equivalent of coitus interruptus , left, as so often with this technique, too late to avert disaster?

For there are, to my personal knowledge, at least three uncoordinated (and apparently competing) censorship teams setting out to hunt down wayward authors and publishers from their separate lairs within the same ministry. In view of the singular attention attached to She Who Dared, what is special about this book ?

It is one of three recent memoirs derived from the experience of the undercover, armed, plainclothes team commonly known as 14 Intelligence Company. The company comprises three detachments ("the Dets"). Their surveillance techniques include armed, illegal entry into private premises. The three authors, writing under pen-names - "Jackie George" (a woman soldier, now a freelance bodyguard), "James Rennie" (an infantry officer, now a stockbroker), and "Sarah Ford" (a woman sailor, now also a freelance bodyguard), cover the years 1983-91. All publish identically-worded health warnings at the front, a mantra apparently prescribed by Whitehall: "Owing to the sensitivity of the contents of this book, the manuscript was submitted to the ministry of defence prior to publication. At their request some changes were made to the text - including altering the names of individuals and places - in order to protect the work of the unit in their fight against terrorism."

One would think that this set all three authors on the same footing. But Jackie George's book is the one that has been blasted with an injunction. (None the less, it continues to sell well, particularly in Hereford, home of the Special Air Service.) Among many marvels attached to this decision is the fact that although recently published, it covers the most remote time-frame of the collection, 1983-88.

The censorship of Jackie George's story displayed Whitehall's characteristic incompetence even before the injunction. For example, the names and places changed include that of an SAS soldier, Al Slater, shot dead by the IRA in Fermanagh in December 1984. Why now conceal Slater's identity when it has been in the public domain - including two of my own books - for most of the preceding six years? Why cut out any reference to the deaths of two IRA men, Tony MacBride and Keiran Fleming, in the same contact? It would seem that the censor does not know what has been published already and what has not.

Yet from such ignorance is asserted the right to suppress information which, since it does not damage security, the public has a right to know.

Jackie George's book shares common features with the other two, including an account of the brutalising nature of the selection process. "Resistance-to- interrogation" licenses the selectors to deprive their masked, female subjects of the right to go to the loo. If they have the "bottle" to wet themselves before the prurient gaze of their male interrogators, that wins brownie points.

Both of the women authors, as it happens, came from dysfunctional working-class homes where violence had already marked them. Service with Britain's secret army in the war against terrorism left them psychologically more damaged than before. No help was offered to stabilise them after the trauma of blood, booze and brutality across the water.

Where Jackie George breaks the mould is in her attitude to the Royal Ulster Constabulary. (Ford, by contrast, decorated her bleak quarters with a King Billy tea-towel.) George describes the successful surveillance of a loyalist arms transfer, an operation which greatly displeased the RUC special branch. Her partner, Joe, "thought we had all done a good job in locating these terrorists, regardless of their political persuasion. However, it seemed that the RUC was only concerned with apprehending republican terrorists. We were told in no uncertain terms that we were never to work that area again. Under no circumstances were any records to be kept."

Or: "The police, who had jurisdiction over the army, seemed to believe that they could do whatever they wanted and get away with it. The sad truth was that they probably could. . . They could even arrange for you to die if it suited their purpose." Or, again: "The bitterness I felt towards the special branch of the RUC will remain with me always. Those police officers played with our lives with total indifference and many of them were no better than the terrorists they were supposed to be fighting."

To publish such sentiments at a time when the Patten report was about to recommend drastic reform - a virtual demolition - of the RUC was to invite some sort of reaction. Did anyone invite Jackie George to give evidence to Patten? It seems unlikely.

The chosen option was to shoot the messenger; or in this case at least to suppress the message. In the Irish war, truth is not just the first casualty. It promises to be the last and most permanent one also.

 Tony Geraghty's The Irish War is published by Johns Hopkins University Press. He was charged under the official secrets act, which led to widespread public protests; the charges were later dropped, but secrets charges are still pending against a decorated bomb-disposal officer, Colonel Nigel Wylde

The company comprises three detachments ("the Dets"). Their surveillance techniques include armed, illegal entry into private premises. The three authors, writing under pen-names - "Jackie George" (a woman soldier, now a freelance bodyguard), "James Rennie" (an infantry officer, now a stockbroker), and "Sarah Ford" (a woman sailor, now also a freelance bodyguard), cover the years 1983-91. All publish identically-worded health warnings at the front, a mantra apparently prescribed by Whitehall: "Owing to the sensitivity of the contents of this book, the manuscript was submitted to the ministry of defence prior to publication. At their request some changes were made to the text - including altering the names of individuals and places - in order to protect the work of the unit in their fight against terrorism." One would think that this set all three authors on the same footing. But Jackie George's book is the one that has been blasted with an injunction. (None the less, it continues to sell well, particularly in Hereford, home of the Special Air Service.) Among many marvels attached to this decision is the fact that although recently published, it covers the most remote time-frame of the collection, 1983-88. The censorship of Jackie George's story displayed Whitehall's characteristic incompetence even before the injunction. For example, the names and places changed include that of an SAS soldier, Al Slater, shot dead by the IRA in Fermanagh in December 1984. Why now conceal Slater's identity when it has been in the public domain - including two of my own books - for most of the preceding six years? Why cut out any reference to the deaths of two IRA men, Tony MacBride and Keiran Fleming, in the same contact? It would seem that the censor does not know what has been published already and what has not. Yet from such ignorance is asserted the right to suppress information which, since it does not damage security, the public has a right to know. Jackie George's book shares common features with the other two, including an account of the brutalising nature of the selection process. "Resistance-to- interrogation" licenses the selectors to deprive their masked, female subjects of the right to go to the loo. If they have the "bottle" to wet themselves before the prurient gaze of their male interrogators, that wins brownie points. Both of the women authors, as it happens, came from dysfunctional working-class homes where violence had already marked them. Service with Britain's secret army in the war against terrorism left them psychologically more damaged than before. No help was offered to stabilise them after the trauma of blood, booze and brutality across the water. Where Jackie George breaks the mould is in her attitude to the Royal Ulster Constabulary. (Ford, by contrast, decorated her bleak quarters with a King Billy tea-towel.) George describes the successful surveillance of a loyalist arms transfer, an operation which greatly displeased the RUC special branch. Her partner, Joe, "thought we had all done a good job in locating these terrorists, regardless of their political persuasion. However, it seemed that the RUC was only concerned with apprehending republican terrorists. We were told in no uncertain terms that we were never to work that area again. Under no circumstances were any records to be kept." Or: "The police, who had jurisdiction over the army, seemed to believe that they could do whatever they wanted and get away with it. The sad truth was that they probably could. . . They could even arrange for you to die if it suited their purpose." Or, again: "The bitterness I felt towards the special branch of the RUC will remain with me always. Those police officers played with our lives with total indifference and many of them were no better than the terrorists they were supposed to be fighting." To publish such sentiments at a time when the Patten report was about to recommend drastic reform - a virtual demolition - of the RUC was to invite some sort of reaction. Did anyone invite Jackie George to give evidence to Patten? It seems unlikely. The chosen option was to shoot the messenger; or in this case at least to suppress the message. In the Irish war, truth is not just the first casualty. It promises to be the last and most permanent one also.  Tony Geraghty's The Irish War is published by Johns Hopkins University Press. He was charged under the official secrets act, which led to widespread public protests; the charges were later dropped, but secrets charges are still pending against a decorated bomb-disposal officer, Colonel Nigel Wylde

fields.headline: Box of delights
fields.standfirst: Elaine Showalter  on television as nostalgic memoir in Stuart Jeffries' Mrs Slocombe's Pussy
fields.trailText: Elaine Showalter on television as nostalgic memoir in Stuart Jeffries' Mrs Slocombe's Pussy
fields.body:
Mrs Slocombe's Pussy: Growing Up in Front of the Telly
Stuart Jeffries
Flamingo, £12.99, 378pp
Buy it at BOL

Mrs Slocombe, the hyper-refined, sex-starved and elaborately coiffed matron of Grace Brothers department store in the 70s sitcom Are You Being Served?, had a running joke about her troublesome pussy. Every week she referred to her pet's difficulties, while the audience enjoyed the double-entendre, reinforced, Stuart Jeffries suggests, by the one in her name. For Jeffries, Grace Brothers was a cruelly funny metaphor for Britain's declining service economy, a self-mocking description of a country in which people hated serving others.

But there's no irony in the subtitle of his apologia for TV. The British term "telly", as opposed to the American "box", is anthropomorphically affectionate, domesticised and coy. Calling television "telly" makes it quasi-familial (the BBC as "Auntie"). Indeed, for Jeffries, memories and emotions about television are connected to the weekly lunch with his nan: telly is almost someone (rather than something) that has given him his sense of being British.

Thus, while Jeffries deplores the nostalgia industry of Dad's Army and detests Brideshead Revisited, he seems unaware of how much he belongs to it. His nostalgia, however, is not for the Blitz or the dreaming spires, but for the good old days when we all sat around watching Coronation Street. Only in his 30s, Jeffries already looks back to his youth as an era in which television reflected the cherished "guilt and shame, denial and occasional bombast, fiercely guarded privacy and social awkwardness" of British identity. However comic his descriptions of dire sitcoms, cheesy soap operas, The Eurovision Song Contest or Mastermind, Jeffries is serious in his elegy for the passing of British TV as the "chief cultural national unifier".

The book is organised in a rough chronology, beginning with children's programmes and connecting key phases of Jeffries's growing up with memories of TV culture. He is brilliant on the childhood fantasies generated by Sooty and other hand puppets - who seemed to him frightening aliens - and on the upsetting hidings of Bill and Ben the Flowerpot Men, which he compares to the Fort-Da game of Freudian child psychology.

As he gets older, Jeffries's love-hate relationship with the telly becomes more acute. He wants to see his own Birmingham suburban childhood reflected on the screen, but when he does - in Crossroads, or Brookside - he hates the lack of glamour. He admires British comedy, especially Fawlty Towers, but also sees it as conservative, self-hating and on the side of the loser.

He feels a thrill of patriotism watching football, but at a real match is disgusted by his yobbish companions: "National football for me has always had to be a television event because I can't bear to share a stadium with my compatriots." Indeed, he believes, the "English national character in the late 20th century could only be defined through absurdity and negativity".

With this state of mind, Jeffries is both attracted and enraged by the confidence, prosperity and braggadocio of American television as it begins to infiltrate his family, beginning with the children's cartoon Top Cat and ending with his favourite, The Simpsons. Homer Simpson is both an eternal child and a subversive rebel - indeed, almost British. On the other hand, Jeffries painfully recalls watching thirtysomething when he was living with his girlfriend in a nasty little flat, wearing a horrible suit and driving a broken-down car. He quickly came to resent the program for its feel-good liberalism: "Nice apartment, shame about the political message."

Jeffries is worried about the digitalisation of television, the access to 200 channels that will destroy the comforting sense of "common experience and shared memories" he considers the finest legacy of British television. But as an American addicted to British television, I am much less convinced that more television choice will mean less emotional involvement.

Jeffries's lament for British TV seems more like part of the national psychological transition from the security blanket of nostalgia and onedownmanship to a different, more naked kind of ambition, competition and desire. The latest news on this side of the Atlantic, however, is that TV producers are frantically looking to Britain for fresh ideas and real-life formats. Of course it's easier to be the straight man than the top cat. But I think even telly can get used to it.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe floods leave 250,000 homeless
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe special report
fields.trailText: Twelve people have died and 250,000 have been made homeless in Zimbabwe by the rains and floods which have swept southern Africa this week, officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
Twelve people have died and 250,000 have been made homeless in Zimbabwe by the rains and floods which have swept southern Africa this week, officials said yesterday.

Road traffic between Zimbabwe and South Africa came to a standstill yesterday when the main bridge between the two was flooded.

Witnesses said hundreds of trucks were stranded either side of Beitbridge, Africa's busiest border post and the main gateway from South Africa to central Africa, after the Limpopo burst its banks on Thursday night.

"The situation is desperate," a reporter with the government's Zimbabwe Information Services (ZIS) said by telephone.

"The civil protection authorities have been trying to help people but their operations are being hampered by the wet weather. It's raining, flooded and difficult to move around even by helicopter. People are desperate for food and warm clothing," he said.

The floods and cyclone Eline have worsened Zimbabwe's fuel shortage by disrupting rail and road links with Mozambican ports. The few fuel stations operating in the capital, Harare, had to call in riot police to control angry motorists forced to queue.

President Robert Mugabe's government on Thursday declared a state of emergency in Manicaland, Matebeleland South and Masvingo provinces. Officials said the country could need around $50m (£30m) in foreign aid. Reuters

fields.headline: Evangelists of the technology temple
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Enterprising New Labour MPs who wish to make their mark may consider asking Clare Short, the international development secretary, about the investments of a treasury investment arm, CDC. Take this hypothetical Commons exchange.
fields.body:
Enterprising New Labour MPs who wish to make their mark may consider asking Clare Short, the international development secretary, about the investments of a treasury investment arm, CDC. Take this hypothetical Commons exchange.

Young wannabe Blairite MP: "Can my right honourable friend explain what has happened to the £7.5m of taxpayers' money paid to Satyam Infoway of Chennai, India, from the CDC fund?"

Clare Short: "We felt that the internet stock chosen was an appropriate vehicle for stimulating a technological revolution in a developing country. I am pleased to announce that the taxpayers' stake is now worth more than £900m."

Cue headlines and glory for the MP. The exchange maybe fictional, but the story is true.

Described as India's answer to America Online, Satyam - 16% of which is owned by CDC - has been around for less than 18 months. A slither of equity was offered to investors in October last year on the Nasdaq. Satyam Infoway, which receives 37m page views a month, is now worth $9bn (£5.6bn).

Foreign economies have benefited too. By 1996 nearly half of the 55,000 temporary visas issued by the US government to hi-tech workers went to Indians.

The EU is now rushing to catch up with the US. There are already 500,000 vacancies in the hi-tech sector. German chancellor Gerhard Schröder said last week that he planned to give residence permits to computer programmers from India as Germany needs more computer specialists.

Britain, where the term "economic migrant" is used only in a pejorative sense, is now considering lowering the drawbridge to let in talented programmers.

What does this mean for India? New economy gurus claim the temples of technology that have sprung up in India will transform it. Take Professor Michael Dertouzos, head of computer science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who told a conference recently that about 50m Indians are in line for a $1 trillion windfall from software work.

Yet there are only are 3.8m personal computers in India. New York has twice that number. The internet has reached only 0.1% of the population and cable television can be received in 30m homes.

This is a country of 900m souls. The yawning digital divide is there for all to see. Visitors to India view the country's new economy through a lens smeared by poverty. Billboards for mobile phone companies are obscured by shanty towns. The World Bank estimates more than 80% of Indians live on $2 a day. The new economy may be throwing up skyscrapers in Delhi but it is the real economy that houses millions of poor.

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst:
Labels, labels everywhere - but not so much as a tomato 'made in Russia'

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Dasha and I treated ourselves to a new photocopier the other day, one that does all sorts of tricks and makes the Guardian's Moscow office an immeasurably happier place.
fields.body:
Dasha and I treated ourselves to a new photocopier the other day, one that does all sorts of tricks and makes the Guardian's Moscow office an immeasurably happier place.

We popped along to Partiya, Moscow's main chain of stores flogging all manner of electronic goodies, a kind of Russian Comet. It's a very Russian experience, bewildering to those uninitiated in the arcane rituals of buying and selling here.

Moscow is a dollarised economy and there's barely an adult in the sprawling metropolis who can't instantly quote you that days's rouble rate to the greenback. Partiya's cornucopia of consumer items is priced in bucks. The customer wanders round the store with a pocket calculator or does a swift bit of mental arithmetic to work out the rouble price.

The complexities deepen. The prices may be in dollars, but you have to pay in roubles. That is, if you're a foreigner. There's a curious kind of logic to it. A Russian can pay in American currency, a foreigner has to pay in Russian currency. Either way, the local economy gets the bucks.

The salesman (always a male) fills out a chit for your goods, sends you off to the other end of the store to a girl clerk (always a female) who declares she can't accept dollars unless you're a Russian, demands passports, driving licences, visas, etc before relenting and exchanging a few dollar bills for a fat pile of roubles. Then you carry these to another cashier girl who takes your money and gives you another handful of papers, copiously stamped. Got that?

You are not yet the proud owner of the Xerox you've come for. Armed with a fistful of papers you now have to join the queue to fetch the elusive gadget. Every item bought - from a deluxe multi-part stereo system to an electric kettle - is unpacked before your eyes and tested to make sure it's working. Patient Russian resignation suddenly makes sense.

But such rites are where Partiya's Russianness ends. There are Japanese TVs, American laptops, German fridges, Taiwanese CD players. But not so much as a cable or a plug bearing the proud label "made in Russia".

The emporium's surfeit of western and far eastern consumer goods coupled with the utter absence of home-grown products might be a metaphor for Russia's post-communist economy, a third world pattern of exporting natural resources and raw materials and importing everything the consumer wants, but can barely afford.

It's a bonanza for the big western brands, a huge market long denied the forbidden fruits of capitalism and gorging itself on Cadbury's chocolate, Heineken beer, Marlboro cigarettes. For every wizened babushka standing outside a metro station hawking dried mushrooms or home-made pickles, there's another granny standing freezing incongruously trying to peddle a bottle of Paris perfume or a packet of soap powder from Germany.

True, imports shrank last year by a third, doubling Russia's trade surplus, because the rouble's collapse in August 1998 sent import prices through the roof. And domestic production has picked up a bit as advertising hoardings exhort people to buy Russian and fill the gap.

But absurdly, the gaps remain. Within a decade Moscow has become one huge street bazaar. Yet the absence of the tradition of the family corner shop means there's no such thing as a butcher's, a greengrocer's, or a fishmonger's.

At food markets, the stall-holders wink and try to charm you into believing their tomatoes are real, "from the south, Georgia". They're Dutch, of course.

And there's six varieties of milk on offer from fat-free to full fat - all long-life, with a bitter aftertaste. It is possible to buy fresh milk in Moscow. But it's not Russian. Another import, from Finland.

fields.headline: Boom time in Electronic City
fields.standfirst:
At Infosys, even the canteen manager is a rupee millionaire. Welcome to India's e-revolution

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Drive along the dusty four-lane highway towards Chennai from India's computer capital, Bangalore, and about 10 miles out you will be struck by the sight of gleaming towers and concrete curves of Electronic City.
fields.body:
Drive along the dusty four-lane highway towards Chennai from India's computer capital, Bangalore, and about 10 miles out you will be struck by the sight of gleaming towers and concrete curves of Electronic City.

Home to some 80 companies, Electronic City is the centre of India's silicon plateau. This patch of land - most of it encased in walls and littered with banners for commercial giants such as Oracle and NTT - is the epicentre of an economic earthquake that is shaking the subcontinent.

Polite conversation revolves around how to make, when to make and who is making money from the internet. The big banks, like ICICI, have plans for online customer services. All the advertising in the pages of mid-market Delhi tabloids have been bought up by a financial website, sharekhan.com. The upstarts and corporates target the new, moneyed, consuming class of some 200m - more buyers than live in any one European country. And a sizeable number of them are becoming rich on the back of India's new economy.

Software is modern India's spice. The industry will be worth £2.5bn in exports this year - and in three years should top £12.5bn, making up nearly a quarter of the subcontinent's output.

The country's most precious resource is its people. The pool of highly educated, English speaking IT professionals so impressed Microsoft's Bill Gates in 1997 he proclaimed that India would be a software superpower and promptly awarded the first Microsoft professorship outside the US to Delhi's Indian Institute of Technology. The stock market values each employee of Wipro Technology, one of India's computing darlings, at £1.9m.

Foreign companies have rushed into silicon plateau: Novell opened their R&D centre at Bangalore nearly four years ago; the operating system for Oracle' s NC was written in Bangalore; European software company Baan has headquartered its R&D operations at Hyderabad.

The tide of colonisation of the Indian computer industry is now over and a generation of home-grown talent is emerging. Most have taken their cue from California's silicon valley - where a quarter of start-ups are run by Indians. Others have read of the exploits of Pavan Nigam, rated by Netscape's Jim Clark as the "best programmer he had ever met".

And none have forgotten the entrepreneurial buzz created by software engineer Gururaj Deshpande, the data communications expert who offered shares in his third start up, Sycamore, last year for $38m (£23.9m). They closed on the first day of trading at $184.75 and Mr Deshpande is now worth $3.7bn.

But Sycamore is a US-based company. The hottest stocks at the moment are those with roots in Indian soil but have imported the lifestyle and entrepreneurial get-up-and-go of American capitalism.

Take Infosys. This software services company has its own 25-strong fleet of buses, runs generators to avoid the power cuts that plague Bangalore and built basketball courts and a Domino's Pizza to re-create the relaxed, campus feel of an e-venture in silicon valley.

Formed in 1981 on about £200 by seven software engineers and run from their homes, it offered software services around the globe. The first 10 years of the company saw revenues grow to about 90m rupees (£1.3m).

The company's big break came when the it developed a computerised distribution package for Reebok France, which then referred clients to Infosys. Last year, the it became the first Indian software firm to list on a US stock market. Big customers now include Sainsbury's, Visa, Lucent and Nortel networks. About 3% of the company was floated, rais ing £44m. The current US valuation tops £8bn - on nine month earnings of £87m.

"The stock has performed well in the investor market," said Narayana Murthy, the chief executive and brother-in-law of Mr Deshpande.

The 46-year-old Mr Murthy is himself something of a legend. He won a place at the best university in the country, IIT Kharagpur, in 1962 but could not take it up because his father, then an education official in the state government with eight children to support, could not afford the hundred rupees a month in accommodation fees. A man of great modesty, Mr Murthy lives in a small three-bedroom bungalow in downtown Bangalore.

The original seven founders are now worth nearly £2.5bn - on paper. Out of the company's 5,000-strong workforce, some 200 are dollar millionaires and a further 1,800 are rupee millionaires - including the canteen manager and company chauffeurs.

"We see wealth creation as essential to spanning the divide [between rich and poor]. "It is a very competitive market for talented software engineers," says Mr Murthy. "But these wages in India, which are increasing at 30% a year, are containable. webTitle: Western visitors a PR dream for Putin

fields.headline: Western visitors a PR dream for Putin
fields.standfirst:
Russia: special report
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Like a tsar-in-waiting, Mr Putin has been sitting amid the refurbished splendour of the Kremlin for the past month courteously receiving one western visitor after another while his troops simultaneously smash a city the size of Edinburgh to pieces, beyond the point of reconstruction and recovery.
fields.body:
Like a tsar-in-waiting, Mr Putin has been sitting amid the refurbished splendour of the Kremlin for the past month courteously receiving one western visitor after another while his troops simultaneously smash a city the size of Edinburgh to pieces, beyond the point of reconstruction and recovery.

Madeleine Albright from the US, Hubert Védrine from France, Joschka Fischer from Berlin, Lord Robertson from Nato and, finally, Robin Cook - the first British cabinet member to meet the new leader - have been charmed by the ex-KGB man who is a month from being crowned Russia's new democratic leader , even though he has never contested a democratic vote in his life.

Mr Cook and Mr Putin laughed at one another's jokes.

"It's all gone surprisingly successfully for the acting president," said the Moscow paper Kommersant. "Cook was clearly against putting pressure on Russia because of Chechnya. The west has done its bit to ensure Putin's election as president."

It is hard to escape that conclusion in Moscow. If Ms Albright reckons that Mr Putin is "a liberal reformer" and President Bill Clinton writes that Mr Putin is "liberating" Chechnya, British officials confided that their first encounter with Mr Putin could not have gone better.

For the Chechens, last Wednesday was neither pleasant nor encouraging. It was the anniversary of the day in 1944 when Stalin's henchman, Lavrenty Beria, started rounding up more than half a million Chechens, putting them in cattle wagons and sealed lorries, and deporting them to central Asia and Siberia to almost certain death.

There is not a Chechen family untouched by the atrocities of 56 years ago. Amid further reports of Russian atrocities against Chechen civilians this week, Mr Cook's first words to Mr Putin on Wednesday morning referred to the two countries' alliance in the second world war. That past alliance should be transformed into a future "strategic partnership", with Russia a "top priority of British foreign policy".

Chechnya, Moscow assumes, will not get in the way of realpolitik. Of the recent western visitors, only Hubert Védrine, the French foreign minister, had "a tense and difficult" session with Mr Putin, although the Germans are also less effusive than the Anglo-Americans.

But while Mr Cook claimed that western protests about Chechnya "have not fallen on deaf ears", David Scheffer, the US state department's human rights and war crimes official, said: "It's clearly been distressful to us that so much of the concern expressed about Chechnya appears to have fallen on either deaf ears or ears that wish to focus on other issues."

Mr Putin is not yet confirmed in office. His intentions and policies remain a mystery. Western governments say they will judge him by his actions, not his words. His most salient acts as prime minister and acting president have been to deploy an army of 92,000 to vanquish an area about the size of Wales, uproot 300,000 civilians, and utterly destroy a city once home to 400,000.

webTitle: Virgin train halted by fuel leak

fields.headline: Virgin train halted by fuel leak
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Scores of passengers had to abandon Virgin Trains' service from Edinburgh to Brighton yesterday when it ran out of fuel.
fields.body:
Scores of passengers had to abandon Virgin Trains' service from Edinburgh to Brighton yesterday when it ran out of fuel.

Virgin blamed the incident on a tiny fuel leak. The engines stopped close enough to a local station for the train to eventually "drift in" to a platform. A spokesman said: "The train didn't run out of fuel because we didn't fill it up enough.

"The problem occurred becase the engines lost a quantity of fuel due to a leak.

"There was no danger involved - it was not a case of all the fuel suddenly leaking out in a few yards.

"It is quite an unusual occurrence but the locomotives are more than 30 years old - unfortunately that is what we inherited from British Rail.

"It happened between Reading and Three Bridges station. It was sod's law that such a long-distance service failed so near to its destination. Fortunately there are regular services from Three Bridges to Brighton and a service left only 10 minutes after our train arrived."

webTitle: Call dealing has them hanging on

fields.headline: Call dealing has them hanging on
fields.standfirst:
Soaring demand means gridlock for internet and phone share trading. Patrick Collinson reports
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: On-line and telephone share traders are hastily taking on staff and adding new computers after the recent trading boom caught them off guard - and left furious small investors hanging on the phone for up to an hour to place, buy or sell orders.
fields.body:
On-line and telephone share traders are hastily taking on staff and adding new computers after the recent trading boom caught them off guard - and left furious small investors hanging on the phone for up to an hour to place, buy or sell orders.

Since last November the number of trades on the London Stock Exchange has ballooned from around 50,000 a day to an average of 100,000 and on some days it has hit 140,000. Almost every one of the new share traders - whose cheap dealing fees have fuelled the boom - buckled under the phenomenal rise.

Many internet dealing sys tems slowed to a crawl, which was a disaster for "day trading" investors in hi-tech stocks such as Pacific Media or Baltimore Technologies, where prices have yo-yoed dramatically in the space of a few hours. Many small investors abandoned internet trading sites for telephone services instead, hoping for a faster response, but found that they were held in call queues lasting 30-60 minutes.

Anger among investors has spilled over into the chat rooms and bulletin boards at net sites such as iii and hemscott. At times the boards have been jammed with investors messaging each other with complaints about which internet or phone dealer is currently worst. All the big stockbroking names have suffered, with Charles Schwab and Barclays Stockbrokers in particular taking a roasting.

The problems are still not fully ironed out. The Financial Services Authority stepped in before Christmas to monitor the situation and this week said service was improving, with 75-80% of calls now being answered first time. Yet a check by Jobs & Money this week found that many brokers are coping only by closing their doors to new customers and, even for existing customers, severe problems can still arise on Monday mornings and Friday afternoons when trading volumes are at their most intense.

Callers to Halifax's Share Xpress service are greeted by a message that the company will not accept new registrations. Halifax jolted the market by offering trades at just £5 a go when it opened for business - but was then overwhelmed by the volumes. It says now that it is monitoring the situation daily. This week, for example, it allowed new registrations on Tuesday and Thursday.

Charles Schwab refuses to take new "certificated" business, where the investor wants to trade using paper certificates, but will open accounts for 'nominee' business, where certificates are 'dematerialised' and held by Schwab in a nominee account instead. Barclays Stockbrokers also admits to continuing delays with certificated telephone dealing. NatWest Stockbrokers has avoided the worst of the problems by a slow roll-out of its internet service.

The brokers have also tried to stem volumes by blacklisting certain shares, predominantly small hi-tech stocks, which have created huge back-office problems because they are not tradable over Crest, the electronic settlement system. The list includes popular stocks such as Geo Interactive Media and BATM Advanced Technology.

Schwab and Barclays, who with NatWest are the biggest brokers for small traders in the UK, both say they are racing to build up capability to deal with the trading surge. Schwab spokeswoman Jane Drew says: "We have opened a new customer service centre with 100 people and increased by 60% the number of people answering phones to 170. We are also doubling the capacity of our net service."

Barclays, which says that it is now transacting more than 10% of all share trades in London every day, says it is looking at increasing its internet capability to handle 40,000 trades a day. Spokesman Justin Urquhart Stewart says: "In the worst case, telephone delays were up to 45 minutes, but now the queues are about 4-5 minutes."

Other on-line stockbrokers are hoping to take advantage of the big brokers' embarrassment. A recent favourite among the chat room investors is Stocktrade, part of the Brewin Dolphin group. "It's been very busy, and volumes are extraordinarily high, but our response times have been good," says director Robert O'Riordan. Call queues are in the seconds rather than the minutes, he claims. NatWest, although admitting to some "growing pains", also says that its call answering is now "pretty much instant."

The real test will be if the systems are able to cope with a crash in internet stocks, when everybody wants to get on the phone or on-line simultaneously to sell. "There will inevitably be some big delays" warns Barclay's Urquhart Stewart.

He admits to being astonished by the stocks which currently top the trading volume lists and which have displaced the privatisation and demutualisation favourites.

 Investor 2000, the UK's largest private investor conference, is taking place at the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Centre, Westminster, London, on March 3 and 4. There is a special Jobs & Money readers' offer- the first 50 people to call 0845 605 2001 will receive a one-day ticket for £25 instead of £75, a two-day ticket for £39.50 instead of £110, or an exhibition-only ticket for £5 instead of £30. Quote reference number 166.

fields.headline: Net policy to change
fields.standfirst:
Soon you'll be able to turn to the web to provide for your retirement, says Rupert Jones
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Retirement saving is being brought into the 21st century with the announcement that from next year, you will be able to buy a pension entirely online.
fields.body:
Retirement saving is being brought into the 21st century with the announcement that from next year, you will be able to buy a pension entirely online.

This will cut out a lot of the paperwork and should mean lower charges, as there will be no need for documents to be sent off in the post. And some experts say it won't be long before people are able to use the net to track their pension's performance.

The "e-pension" is just one of a package of measures announced by the government this week which slots the final pieces into the stakeholder pension jigsaw.

Stakeholder pensions have been described as a much more user-friendly version of personal pensions and will be available from April next year. The government is promising they will be simple to understand, good value and flexible.

Millions of people now excluded from taking out a personal pension - such as those taking career breaks, mature students and carers - will be able to buy a stakeholder plan and benefit from the tax relief they will attract. You will be able to start one up for as little as £20 and the maximum a company will be able to charge for managing the funds is 1% a year.

Labour has been talking about stakeholder pensions since it was in opposition but the details and rules have been confirmed only this week.

The announcement came hot on the heels of a MORI survey that will make depressing reading for the government: it found that 75% of people said they had either not heard of stakeholder pensions, or knew nothing about them. More worryingly, almost as many (74%) believe they will be financially secure in retirement, even though almost half are relying on the state pension alone, says benefits consultancy Towers Perrin, which commissioned the research.

On Wednesday a report will be published calling for an end to people who retire being forced to buy an annuity with their pension fund. The Retirement Income Working Party, made up of representatives from insurance and investment companies, and academics, will recommend that people should have a lot more choice about how they take their retirement income.

Allowing electronic applications for stakeholder pensions is definitely a step forward. At the moment, the information needed to open a personal pension has to be provided in paper form, and companies have to send back written confirmation.

Some of the websites up and running have cut out some of the paperwork, allowing people to fill in their details on screen. However, they still have to print the form off, sign it and post it to the company. But from April next year, information can be provided over the phone, by email or via the net, says the department of social security. The firm will still have to send out confirmation of the details to the customer, but this could be via email.

This will bring pensions in line with individual savings accounts, which can already be bought entirely online from some companies.

But experts are warning that a number of the other details that emerged this week are not so positive.

There has been a lot of debate about whether the millions of people in company pension schemes should be allowed to pay into a stakeholder pension too. Ministers have decided that higher earners in "final salary" company schemes definitely won't be able to boost their retirement savings in this way, and lower and middle earners may be barred too.

Another blow is the scrapping of the "carry forward" rule which lets people make additional pension contributions to make up for low contributions in previous years. The self-employed will be hardest-hit by this because their incomes often fluctuate and they tend to want to catch up on pension contributions when their earnings permit it, says John Glendinning at Scottish Amicable.

Thomas McPhail at independent financial adviser Torquil Clark, says what we are seeing on stakeholder pensions suggests it is only a matter of time before the government abolishes higher rate tax relief on pension contributions - a move that would prove hugely controversial.

But from April next year, information can be provided over the phone, by email or via the net, says the department of social security. The firm will still have to send out confirmation of the details to the customer, but this could be via email. This will bring pensions in line with individual savings accounts, which can already be bought entirely online from some companies. But experts are warning that a number of the other details that emerged this week are not so positive. There has been a lot of debate about whether the millions of people in company pension schemes should be allowed to pay into a stakeholder pension too. Ministers have decided that higher earners in "final salary" company schemes definitely won't be able to boost their retirement savings in this way, and lower and middle earners may be barred too. Another blow is the scrapping of the "carry forward" rule which lets people make additional pension contributions to make up for low contributions in previous years. The self-employed will be hardest-hit by this because their incomes often fluctuate and they tend to want to catch up on pension contributions when their earnings permit it, says John Glendinning at Scottish Amicable. Thomas McPhail at independent financial adviser Torquil Clark, says what we are seeing on stakeholder pensions suggests it is only a matter of time before the government abolishes higher rate tax relief on pension contributions - a move that would prove hugely controversial.

webTitle: Big three car makers unite to buy parts online

fields.headline: Big three car makers unite to buy parts online
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Three of the world's biggest car companies announced the creation of an online exchange yesterday, which is expected to cut industry costs drastically. Overturning decades of competition, Ford, General Motors and DaimlerChrysler are to set up a new company to work together to buy and sell automotive parts.
fields.body:
Three of the world's biggest car companies announced the creation of an online exchange yesterday, which is expected to cut industry costs drastically. Overturning decades of competition, Ford, General Motors and DaimlerChrysler are to set up a new company to work together to buy and sell automotive parts.

The new exchange, which will be jointly owned by all three companies, could be spun off as early as later this year. Although details of the new company were still sketchy yesterday, the exchange is expected to be used by hundreds of suppliers to make the buying and selling of parts cheaper and more efficient.

The deal marks a significant development in the business-to-business arena which many analysts expect to dominate e-commerce over the next year.

A GM executive said yesterday that the new company would create "the world's largest exchange for transacting business that the internet, or probably any other business, has ever seen". Ford and GM had combined sales of $340bn (£214bn) last year.

Richard Wagoner, GM's president and chief operating officer, explained the motivation for working together: "As we continued to build our separate exchange sites, we quickly realised traditional, individual stand-alone models weren't the winning strategy for us, our industry, our suppliers and, ultimately, our customers."

Shares in all three car groups rose by more than $1 each after the announcement yesterday. Until now the groups have been competing in the race to exploit the internet. The two rival exchanges run by Ford and GM - AutoXhange and TradeXchange - will be folded into the new company.

Senior executives at the three groups indicated that other car companies could join the new venture at a later date. Shares in Commerce One rose more than 14% after yesterday's announcement as it will work in new venture along with Oracle, the technology company.

Ford and GM have taken a particularly aggressive stance in moving parts of their business online. Yet their share prices have continued to suffer from the disaffection with traditional offline groups. Ford was trading near a 52-week low immediately prior to yesterday's announcement.

fields.headline: Generals accused of war crimes
fields.standfirst:
Human rights watchdog blames Russian army leaders for Chechnya atrocities and the west for failing to act
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russian generals in Chechnya have presided over frequent executions, torture and rape, according to Human Rights Watch, a United States-based pressure group which blames the west for doing nothing to stop the slaughter.
fields.body:
Russian generals in Chechnya have presided over frequent executions, torture and rape, according to Human Rights Watch, a United States-based pressure group which blames the west for doing nothing to stop the slaughter.

Peter Bouckaert, an HRW researcher who has interviewed hundreds of Chechen refugees during the last three months, said there was enough evidence to bring a war crimes case to an international court.

In the last few days, the watchdog group has presented evidence of a "killing spree" by Russian troops in the Aldi district of the Chechen capital, Grozny, in which it said at least 62 civilians were murdered. It also reported systematic torture and occasional rape of civilians at detention centres known as "filtration camps".

Mr Bouckaert singled out Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, for criticism. During a visit to Moscow on Wednesday Mr Cook expressed "frank concern" about the Russian campaign in Chechnya but praised the acting president Vladimir Putin's "refreshing and open" style. "I found his priorities ones we would share," Mr Cook said.

Mr Bouckaert told the Guardian yesterday that the foreign secretary was an "emperor with no clothes".

"During Kosovo, Mr Cook said Europe could not stand by and watch atrocities being committed or it would be com plicit. But that is exactly what he is doing with Chechnya."

A German television report this week showed Russian soldiers dumping dozens of male corpses into a mass grave. Some of the bodies were in military uniform, but others were in civilian clothes and a number appeared to had been bound and mutilated. One of the corpses had an ear chopped off. In other footage, a lorry was shown dragging a body behind it.

The German report did not make it clear when or where the film was made, and a Russian spokesman, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, said last night he had information proving it was a "fabrication".

But the European Union's foreign policy commissioner, Javier Solana, yesterday urged an independent investigation into the reports, after seeing the German film. Representatives of the United Nations, the Council of Europe and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe also said they were deeply concerned about reports of human rights violations.

Russian forces have prevented human rights groups from visiting Chechnya, but Mr Bouckaert said yesterday: "The evidence of mass graves, massacres and other abuses has been emerging at an alarming rate. The evidence is too large to ignore. Blanket denials by Russian authorities are not credible."

The US state department accused Moscow of "the indis criminate use of force" in Chechnya in a report published yesterday. It said air and artillery attacks on civilian areas suggested that "government forces are relying mainly on unguided rockets and other low precision weapons".

However, the state department report made no mention of war crimes, saying only that Moscow's human rights record "remained uneven".

Mr Bouckaert said that to the best of HRW's knowledge, no US official had travelled to the region since the fighting started last year. Monitors from the OSCE have been prevented from visiting Chechnya or neighbouring Ingushetia, a constraint he said the OSCE and its member states had "meekly accepted".

The west's response to the tragedy had been "all talk and no action". In a column in yesterday's Washington Post he wrote: "In the wake of the noble principles announced during the Kosovo and East Timor crises, the silence on Chechnya is deafening."

fields.headline: Missing Russian reporter resurfaces
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian-American war correspondent, Andrei Babitsky, feared dead 40 days after disappearing in Chechnya, resurfaced last night in mysterious circumstances in neighbouring Dagestan.
fields.body:
The Russian-American war correspondent, Andrei Babitsky, feared dead 40 days after disappearing in Chechnya, resurfaced last night in mysterious circumstances in neighbouring Dagestan.

Mr Babitsky, a fearless reporter who enraged the Russian authorities with his detailed dispatches on civilian suffering in war-ravaged Chechnya, spoke to his wife, Lyudmila, yesterday by telephone for the first time since his disappearance last month.

He had been shown last month, on film shot by Russian intelligence, being swapped to alleged Chechen guerrillas in exchange for two captured Russian soldiers in Chechnya. Amid a series of contradictory statements from Russian officials on the journalist's fate, his family, friends, and employers - the US government-funded Radio Liberty - feared he had been killed.

His disappearance was taken in Moscow and abroad as a harbinger of the type of administration being groomed by Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president and a former intelligence chief.

The circumstances of Mr Babitsky's re-emergence were unclear last night.

Ms Babitsky had travelled to Prague, Radio Liberty's headquarters, yesterday where she received a phone call from her husband from Makhachkala, the capital of Dagestan to the east of Chechnya. "He told me he was at the interior ministry press centre in Makhachkala. I don't know if anyone brought him there," she told Russian television last night. "The conversation was very brief. I asked about his health and he told me everything was all right and he hoped to be home soon. He said he had been in Chechnya all this time."

He was said to have been released from captivity in Chechnya and to have walked across the border where he was taken into custody by Russian police, suspected of passport violations.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, said in Moscow on Wednesday that Mr Putin had assured him that Mr Babitsky was alive in the mountains of southern Chechnya, living with Chechen civilians.

Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister, blaming Mr Cook's remarks on a linguistic misunderstanding, said yesterday that Mr Babitsky was not with civilians, but with the Chechen military.

webTitle: Councils told to halt 'export' of refugees

fields.headline: Councils told to halt 'export' of refugees
fields.standfirst:
Protests as asylum seekers are bussed to hostels in the north
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Southern councils which are exporting asylum seekers hundreds of miles to private landlords in the north have been officially warned to abandon their freelance dispersal arrangements.
fields.body:
Southern councils which are exporting asylum seekers hundreds of miles to private landlords in the north have been officially warned to abandon their freelance dispersal arrangements.

The attempt by some councils, such as Westminster and Slough, to solve their asylum problems by bussing refugees across the country has sparked protests from the receiving authorities.

The northern authorities, including Newcastle and Hull, are faced with providing essential services to the asylum seekers without any warning.

The official caution was sent out as the latest home office figures showed that the number of new asylum applications had fallen from 7,180 in December to 6,110 in January.

The number of decisions leapt from 2, 320 in December to 4,040 in January, but despite this improvement the backlog of cases continued to grow, reaching a new record of 104,890.

The recovery in the system for making decisions was welcomed by refugee welfare groups but it is still a long way from delivering an average of 8,000 decisions each month promised by the spring by Tony Blair in the Commons last week.

The extent to which the Conservative party intends to use the issue of asylum in this May's local government elections became clear yesterday.

Two Conservative-led local authorities, Kent county council and the London borough of Hillingdon, said that their voters would face council tax increases in order to pay for the costs of supporting increased numbers of asylum seekers waiting for decisions. Kent county council claimed that the department of health's failure to reimburse the full costs of looking after unaccompanied refugee children would add about £3 extra to household council tax bills.

Unlike adult asylum seekers, children who arrive in Britain on their own and claim asylum cannot be sent to other parts of the country.

Some of the money in dispute between Whitehall and Kent is to pay for places in private foster care to supplement council care.

London councils believe there is a £10m shortfall between the cost of providing services to the 55,000 asylum seekers living in the capital and the funds being made available by Whitehall.

The Local Government Association yesterday warned councils in the south-east against bussing asylum seekers to private landlords in the north without warning the local council in the area.

John Ransford, the association's head of social affairs, said: "These private arrangements are against Local Government Association guidelines and should not be required now that we have the organised dispersal scheme which can deal with the situation in a properly co-ordinated way."

But the current scheme for shifting the burden away from London and the south-east has seen only about 4,000 places offered in the north and the midlands instead of the 40,000 needed.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, is to give details soon of exactly how a new statutory dispersal scheme will operate from April 1. It is expected to be phased in because of the shortage of accommodation.

fields.headline: Blair faced cheek
fields.standfirst: Haider wants us to believe that Blair, just like him, has the enviable qualities of an autocrat who can bend his party to his will
fields.trailText: Haider wants us to believe that Blair, just like him, has the enviable qualities of an autocrat who can bend his party to his will
fields.body:
It is a marvellous tease by Jörg Haider, the Austrian pariah of Europe, to keep saying that there is almost no difference between him and Tony Blair. He made the point in greater detail than ever this week in the Daily Telegraph, in which he described the similarities between them as "amazing". The main difference, he said with breathtaking cheek, was that he was "arguably" less extreme than Blair on the issue of immigration. This left Downing Street speechless with rage: "The idea that there are genuine similarities between the two is so risible that I do not think it is worth wasting our breath," a spokesman said.

But Haider is a clever devil. Leave aside his claim that their political goals are much the same - social justice in a free market, "a new sense of community", opportunities for young people, and so on. Leave aside, especially, the unacceptable argument that his Freedom Party and New Labour are mirror images of each other, extremist parties of right and left whose leaders have both "freed them from old ideological ballast". The plausibility, such as it is, of Haider's case lies in the unspoken. He wants us to believe that Tony Blair, just like him, has the enviable qualities of an autocrat who can bend his party to his will.

Haider is always extolling leadership, which is an admirable thing in a politician when understood as the ability to inspire and persuade. But what leadership means, in Haider's case, is effectively personal rule. One difficulty with this slippery fellow is that he hasn't actually said a lot to pin him down as a neo-Nazi, and what little he has said he has subsequently explained away. He signed a declaration of support for the EU and human rights before joining the Austrian coalition government, and it is very hard to justify his ostracism by the rest of Europe on the basis of his words alone.

It is hard enough, in any event, to justify rejecting the democratic choice of an independent country; but if there were any case for doing so in this instance, it would be the wholly undemocratic nature of the Freedom Party itself. It is a one-man show. The officers and members of the party, who come from different social and ideological backgrounds, are united around just one article of faith: "Jörg is right." Policy is not determined by internal party debates, but by whatever Haider thinks at the time.

Le Monde found in an exhaustive study of the Freedom Party last weekend that it is ruled by unconditional Haiderites, "a handful of young people who owe their entire careers to their mentor and on whom Haider knows he can rely". They imitate his clothes and his sporting look, and "they have often been recruited by him intuitively at chance encounters, without any attention to their curricula vitae". In fact, the party is incredibly bereft of experienced politicians. Its finance minister in the new government, Karl Heinz Grasser, is hardly Gordon Brown. He is 31 years old, and seems to have done nothing much except serve as a loyal deputy leader of the party in Haider's province of Carinthia.

In claiming Blair as his clone, Haider is doing the prime minister no favours. He implicitly depicts him as a populist like himself, with the same contempt for democracy within his party. That is grossly unfair, but it is cunning. It plays on the charges of cronyism and control-freakery, which are always being made against Blair in Britain. And the timing is excellent, coming in a week in which Frank Dobson has been elected as Labour's candidate for mayor of London without rank-and-file support and under a voting system supposedly fixed to ensure Ken Livingstone's defeat.

The fury and bitterness with which the Labour Party has responded to this shambles, and its unpredictable political consequences, are evidence, if any were needed, that Blair cannot control his party in the way that Haider can. Nor, one assumes, would he want to. He is a democrat, after all. But Haider would have us regard our prime minister as no more principled than he is, saying one thing and meaning another, subordinating every other consideration to the pursuit of power.

I don't know where Haider thinks this is going to get him. It certainly won't win him any friends in the British government, while William Hague must be delighted that Haider doesn't like him: in one interview recently, Haider described Blair, not Hague, as the true heir to Margaret Thatcher. But this frightful Austrian with the ski-instructor looks may be doing us all a favour. Blair will be at greater pains than ever from now on to demonstrate what a true democrat he is.

fields.headline: I've been Norrised
fields.standfirst:
It is galling to have to admit that a Tory has the best lines

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: I should begin by addressing an error in a report of Thursday's London mayoral debate. I was sitting in the audience, minding my own business, when Ken Livingstone came in and sat in front of me. Hence, I was reported in this paper as being part of his "entourage".
fields.body:
I should begin by addressing an error in a report of Thursday's London mayoral debate. I was sitting in the audience, minding my own business, when Ken Livingstone came in and sat in front of me. Hence, I was reported in this paper as being part of his "entourage". This suggests I'm the sort of person who follows people around. Moreover, if we are defined by the person sitting in front, we could be accused of anything.

It might be said that I am part of a taxi-driver's coterie, the inner circle of friends and hangers-on who broadly share his views on other drivers and immigration. What if I were sitting in the Streatham Odeon and Jörg Haider breezed in? I would at least move seats, if not lead the audience in a rousing chorus of Edelweiss. But what if I were slow to act, and a photographer caught me? It might be reported that I'm a member of the Countryside Alliance.

This is all by the by. You probably want to know what were the least boring and depressing moments of the debate, and might have guessed that they were the bits when Frank Dobson wasn't speaking. His speech consisted of: "I want to live in a London where. . ." and you can fill in the rest. The Liberal, Susan Kramer, was nice, but kept saying: "I'm a banker," as though it were a good thing. I'm glad there are kindly sorts working in finance but I could never lay down my life for the kind of person who says: "You should really be making your money work for you."

Annoyingly, the best speaker was Steven Norris, who might have stormed the gig were it not for the fact that his body language is all to cock. He pulls weird faces, and nods vigorously when someone is saying something like: "We've got time for a few more questions." But the content of his speech and his answers were the most radical of the three. He probably did not mean any of it - I'm just saying.

A week earlier he was condemning "politically correct policing" - you know the kind of thing, suspects sustaining head injuries falling down the wheelchair ramp as well as the stairs. But, if we view Norris in the light of the fact that he was part of a racist government, it is only fair to say that Dobson was part of one more recently. It's a shame that a question about asylum seekers was disallowed. No one who has been a member of this government can claim to be anti-racist with any credibility. The Tories have an abysmal record of playing the race card and clobbering migrants but one wonders whether the idea of the Asian bond, visitors having to stump up a ten grand deposit, would even have reached discussion level if Blair and Straw were not the men policing our border. What an inclusive message to non-white Britain: "We embrace your milder dishes but don't even think about your auntie coming over for a holiday." And I suppose Afghanis are just rotten cooks.

With true liberal zeal, he referred immediately to the contribu tion made to "cuisine". I'm not dismissing this at all; indeed I don't think the ethnic communities can ever really know how much the rest of us value what they have done for our diet. No longer living in a land in which the highest compliment one could pay to a chef was "moist", means a great deal to us.

And I guess progress has been made when a leading Tory feels he should announce that he will make appointments in proportion to the ethnic mix of London. Tokenism undoubtedly, but not more so than Dobson wanting his sidekick to be the black chair of the police authority, or Kramer saying she wants "senior" black people seconded to the overseeing of policing, to "change the way it looks at the top".

The attitude of people with power, mostly white but with a sprinkling of co-opted success stories to set an ex ample to their peoples, is that justice is a top-down process. One of the yawning gaps in the implementation of Macpherson is the failure to support local monitoring groups. These community- based projects, that support families and tackle racism on the ground, are routinely derided as "the race relations industry". If they are an industry, it is one of the only industries in this country still producing something useful.

Those that are here can stay, and are appreciated if they do well. White society will adjust to them, if not pushed too hard. In time, we shall try to answer all their questions, but we will decide what questions can be asked.

fields.headline: We're acting over race
fields.trailText: It might be fine for you to lump all police forces - excluding the Metropolitan police - together to make a story (Police race failures exposed, February 24), but the impact on my staff, who are working hard to implement the Macpherson report recommendations, is considerable.
fields.body:
It might be fine for you to lump all police forces - excluding the Metropolitan police - together to make a story (Police race failures exposed, February 24), but the impact on my staff, who are working hard to implement the Macpherson report recommendations, is considerable.

The West Midlands police has the highest proportion of ethnic minority officers in the country and, with the help of our Black Police Association and a range of schemes, our average six-weekly intake has for some months had around 20% of recruits coming from ethnic minority communities. Ethnic minority officers are also doing well in career progression.

The implication that not having commenced the training recommended by Macpherson is tardiness or worse, is disingenuous. Poor quality, inappropriately targeted training would be positively harmful. We are working with Dianna Yach's Ionann to design high-quality training for our 11,000 staff, including me. That training cannot be delivered overnight. The police service is not paying lip service to Macpherson and my staff needs encouragement, not disillusionment, from reading responsible journals.
Edward Crew
Chief constable, West Midlands police

fields.headline: Buffy's stake in the Indians
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
This week Buffy the Vampire Slayer (Sky 1) was about cultural imperialism. It was Thanksgiving and Buffy, though properly conflicted about celebrating a frankly white triumphalist historical moment, wanted a nice turkey dinner to remind herself of her lost youth. Willow (the dopey, cutesy one who during this episode was wearing a sweater with a CND logo as if to underscore her radical credentials) felt differently. She didn't want to kill the native American avenging spirit who had risen from the dead at this topical time to slash the throats of white America, but preferred to return his people's land to this solitary remnant of a once-great tribe and generally be nice and gooily guilt-ridden. Bleeding-heart liberals! God save us from them! This, one suspects, isn't the way to win the hearts of Guardian readers.

But back to the story. A long-dead native American, with a full set of brooding brows, chiselled jaw and sensual lips, had come back to life to avenge the extermination of his tribe. He slashed the throat of the cultural centre's curator and then smashed into its display cases in order steal their contents - a clutch of rather unpleasant-looking tomahawks with which he intended to express himself freely. Mind where you're waving those sharp items, sunshine.

He tried to get forbiddingly butch on Buffy's nocturnal booty. "I am vengeance," he told her as he dodged a flying kick. "My people have called on Hoos, their avenging spirit, to carve out justice." Avenging spirits who talk about themselves in the third person and have little in the way of a sense of humour can become tiresome, don't you find?

Intriguingly, there was another level to this cultural analysis. Giles, Buffy's bookish English sidekick, brought the whiff of the British empire to southern California. As Buffy prepared Thanksgiving dinner, she complained that the peas were frozen and so would be mushy. "But I like mushy peas," said Giles, alluding to his country's rich, erm, culinary heritage. That, replied Buffy, is probably why the first pilgrims left Plymouth for the new world. In search of a new life of fresh peas. Probably, though, their motivation was rather more complex.

Spike, the English vampire with a bleach-blond hairdo, contested Willow's view that one should talk to this avenging spirit and perhaps smoke a pipe of peace with him. He did so in an accent that veered uneasily from Ruislip to Redondo Beach (Americans, those reverse cultural imperialists, never do their old oppressors the favour of getting details about Britain or anywhere east of Maine right. Insular clowns.)

"You exterminated his race," Spike told Willow. "What could you possibly say to him that would make him feel better? It's kill or be killed here. Take your bloody pick." They read a lot of Nietzsche down Ruislip way these days, you know.

Unfortunately for this subversive text, Buffy ended with a mass brawl in which a lot of anonymous native American avenging spirits were bumped off by the slayer and her all-white chums, in the manner of an old western. Which kind of served to deconstruct the show's radical critique. Bummer.

Talking of reverse cultural imperialism (we were, you know), in the first show of the third series of Goodness Gracious Me (BBC2), the NDPD were on the hunt for a murderer. The NDPD are like the New York Police Department except that they are, in a very real sense, responsible for law enforcement in Delhi. Now perhaps you understand what I'm on about.

The deceased was a member of the "English community". "But let's not forget," said the captain to hoots of derision from his Indian officers, "we are supposed to police the whole community. Not just the Indians, but the white minority, too." This was a very funny critique of racist policing, of the kind for which the Metropolitan Police has been repeatedly criticised. Goodness Gracious Me is at its best with such reverse racist sketches.

The murder victim had been found in a gutter with a 12in knife in his back and a note that read: "Die whitey scum." The token white police officer suggested that this, just possibly, might have been a racially motivated killing. The Indian officers rolled their eyes sarcastically. That's the trouble with these white English people. Touchy buggers. Always thinking that everything comes down to race. Will they ever learn?

fields.headline: Travels with my armchair
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
It is a truth universally acknowledged that the whole point of travel documentaries is to make us want to stay at home. The presenters' multiple humiliations lead us to a Wizard of Oz conclusion: there's no place like chez nous. They travel so that we don't have to.

So we approach a documentary about a journey to Timbuktu: Drowning in Sand (Radio 4) pretty sure we'll never make the trip ourselves. If, that is, the idea ever crossed our minds. The town has become such a synonym for "far away" that few of us realise that it actually exists.

Writer Graeme Fife and two friends set out in 1998 by bicycle and boat to reach the real Timbuktu in west Africa, and the first half of this feature followed their desperate journey. It was almost all commentary, apart from the trio's mutterings about the lacerating sun and how different it all is from Accrington.

Fife makes an astute guide. His vignettes of Malian poverty are unflinching, never romantically embellished. He identifies the fatalist local catchphrase - "Ça va?" - and is driven mad by it. His bargaining with a charmingly dishonest canoe-owner is recounted with resigned acceptance.

And yet his response to what he sees has a poetry that's never precious. When the fishermen on the Niger drop their fine mesh nets to the water, he compares it to "a broadcast of seed". The desert sky at night is a "stellar switchboard".

By the time he reaches Timbuktu, you completely trust his judgment. The place itself has a certain iconic familiarity - not glamour, but seediness. Sand gets everywhere, even in the food. But Fife gets beyond the dilapidation, the sense of what isn't, into what is, finding a residual pride, solidarity and energy beyond the ubiquitous plastic detritus. Producers John Partington and Richard Bannerman, master braiders of sound both, plaited actuality and narrative beautifully, showing that words can be the best means of transport.

Radio 4's disability sketch show Yes Sir, I Can Boogie is back for a second series, but the opening programme demonstrated yet again the pitfalls of trying to be universally appealing. The first few sketches played on able-bodied people's prejudices about disability, but jokes about stereotyping themselves reveal their limitations before long.

So Boogie has to move beyond gags about benefits and a truly original sketch about disability campaigners, dropping in a piece about a man with low self-esteem who attempts a chat-up. Fresh though it sounded, what was this doing here? Is Boogie about disability, or about anyone beyond the mythical norm? Is it so integrationalist that it has diluted its distinctiveness ? And is it funny?
