fields.headline: The rise of the ManBoy
fields.standfirst: Where are the  real men in public life, the ones who do not sulk or resort to violence when the big bad world gets too much for them
fields.trailText: Where are the real men in public life, the ones who do not sulk or resort to violence when the big bad world gets too much for them
fields.body:
There are lots of men I would never go out with - ones between the ages of nought and 15, and ones over 30, basically. But top of that list, just under the finger-sniffers but above those who say "enjoy!" before tucking into a nice nosh, would be men who liked the Peanuts cartoon strip. For they are, without fail, one of the most loathsome male types in the world today. They are - sssss! - the ManBoy.

Don't get me wrong, I like real boys just fine, and I have been known to give the time of day to men. But, like chalk and cheese, love and marriage, or rough anal sex with a stranger at a wedding reception, some things just do not sit well together. Are you a Man or are you a Boy? Boys can't be over 28, for a start. I know a woman who's engaged to a man in his 50s (loaded, natch), and she still calls him a "boy" - well, it makes me literally want to cry.

ManBoys are creepy as hell, and the Daddy of them all is, of course, Bill Clinton, who got his frillies in a real twist recently when Peanuts creator Charles Schulz kicked it. The Times pretty much got it right, for good or ill, when it said that Peanuts "has played as big a part as Coca-Cola or Levi's in making much of the world dream the American dream". God help us. Clinton is the archetypal ManBoy; someone who demands all the rights of an alpha male, but will only admit to the responsibilities of a pre-teen boy - "Aw, shucks, ma'am, ah didn't know ah done wrong!" From Michael Douglas and Woody Allen starting families at 80 to the ghetto gangstas who display a teenage disgust for girls but who live in fear of their mommas, US culture is drowning in a sea of soggy self-discovery.

And, like herpes and Aids, we've caught it from them. Those footballers who just can't seem to stop themselves from brawling with each other, screaming at referees and beating up girls who won't do what they're told? ManBoys. Even the sweetest of them: I know several people who've been in the company of David and Victoria Beckham, and apparently he's so dependent on her that anything he wants to say he whispers into her ear, then she translates to the assembled company. Beckham is obviously not a thug, like so many of his colleagues, but he is horribly Peter Pannish in his petulance. The one thing sportsmen always had over the rest of us was the myth of their self- discipline; they hadn't read Huysmans and they thought Verdi was a type of pasta, but goddamn they could control themselves! Now they seem like sad little boys, fighting themselves and each other within the playpen of their pitch.

It's not, as the family fetishists of the mezzobrow press ceaselessly insist, because of feminism that these footballers don't know how to be men - I cannot recall one feminist leader exhorting men to become inarticulate, violent morons. But if feminism did not exist, then extreme capitalism would surely have had to invent it, because it is feminism that currently does scapegoat duty for all the social evils that the free market has inflicted upon us. Unemployment, the underclass, the unmarried mother who has nothing to gain from marrying a ManBoy on the dole - capitalism did all this, but feminism carries the can. Yes, I admit it - it was me, Andrea Dworkin and Geri Spice who closed down the mines, shut down the steelworks and threw a generation of young urban men on the scrapheap!

Like the song said, it's the rich what gets the pleasure and the poor what gets the blame - and while being a perennial ManBoy may be fun for Michael Douglas, it is likely to leave any man who can't act, kick or sing in an extremely vulnerable position, probably behind bars. As if this was not bitter harvest enough, there is also the fact that while the all-pervasiveness of the free market frees up the rich to live in a permanent Never-Never Land, the same market contributes to the fact that some citizens have no childhoods whatsoever. What must it be like to be a child of nine who is raped on a daily basis in state "care" and seeing in the papers the endless soft parade of expensive infantilism for those who can afford it?

It really is cheap and easy to make London's new Millennium Dome a metaphor for waste and anomie (so, please, don't expect me to resist), but, for sheer savage irony, it takes some beating when the unveiling of the woeful puppets "Coggsley and Sprinx" as the public faces of a project that is meant to celebrate 1,000 years of British culture takes place in the same week as the sexual holocaust that has been taking place in this country's children's homes for the past 20 years was finally exposed.

While we waste millions on a fool's paradise designed to appeal to the child in all of us rich, soft southerners, real children in their tens of thousands are learning to deal with the hard facts about sex and power at an age when they should be watching puppet shows. Youth may be wasted on the young, but it is squandered, pathetically, when clung to by the adult; just look at any office on "Dress Down Friday" to see what I mean.

You out there, on the football pitch and in Parliament, in the White House and in jail: stop beating up women because you can't get your way, stop wearing trainers at 40, stop sobbing over Peanuts. No one is suggesting for one minute that you join the Territorial Army or wear a hat in the streets at all times, but isn't it possible that you might consider passing through maturity on the way from infancy to senility? Where are the real men in public life, the ones who do not squeak or squawk or sulk or resort to violence when the big bad world of spoken communication gets too much for them? (Apart from David Attenborough.)

Interestingly, one meets so many of them in real life; perhaps the famous are just naturally infantile. It's a shame, though, for all of us. I have never met a real man who was opposed to feminism, but I have known of a million petulant little ManBoy creeps who were. Everyone blames women for everything these days, so I'm going to blame Kate Bush for that song. Because, nine times out of 10, The Man With The Child In His Eyes is probably a paedophile scoping out his next victim. The other times, he's just a tosser.

But if feminism did not exist, then extreme capitalism would surely have had to invent it, because it is feminism that currently does scapegoat duty for all the social evils that the free market has inflicted upon us. Unemployment, the underclass, the unmarried mother who has nothing to gain from marrying a ManBoy on the dole - capitalism did all this, but feminism carries the can. Yes, I admit it - it was me, Andrea Dworkin and Geri Spice who closed down the mines, shut down the steelworks and threw a generation of young urban men on the scrapheap! Like the song said, it's the rich what gets the pleasure and the poor what gets the blame - and while being a perennial ManBoy may be fun for Michael Douglas, it is likely to leave any man who can't act, kick or sing in an extremely vulnerable position, probably behind bars. As if this was not bitter harvest enough, there is also the fact that while the all-pervasiveness of the free market frees up the rich to live in a permanent Never-Never Land, the same market contributes to the fact that some citizens have no childhoods whatsoever. What must it be like to be a child of nine who is raped on a daily basis in state "care" and seeing in the papers the endless soft parade of expensive infantilism for those who can afford it? It really is cheap and easy to make London's new Millennium Dome a metaphor for waste and anomie (so, please, don't expect me to resist), but, for sheer savage irony, it takes some beating when the unveiling of the woeful puppets "Coggsley and Sprinx" as the public faces of a project that is meant to celebrate 1,000 years of British culture takes place in the same week as the sexual holocaust that has been taking place in this country's children's homes for the past 20 years was finally exposed. While we waste millions on a fool's paradise designed to appeal to the child in all of us rich, soft southerners, real children in their tens of thousands are learning to deal with the hard facts about sex and power at an age when they should be watching puppet shows. Youth may be wasted on the young, but it is squandered, pathetically, when clung to by the adult; just look at any office on "Dress Down Friday" to see what I mean. You out there, on the football pitch and in Parliament, in the White House and in jail: stop beating up women because you can't get your way, stop wearing trainers at 40, stop sobbing over Peanuts. No one is suggesting for one minute that you join the Territorial Army or wear a hat in the streets at all times, but isn't it possible that you might consider passing through maturity on the way from infancy to senility? Where are the real men in public life, the ones who do not squeak or squawk or sulk or resort to violence when the big bad world of spoken communication gets too much for them? (Apart from David Attenborough.) Interestingly, one meets so many of them in real life; perhaps the famous are just naturally infantile. It's a shame, though, for all of us. I have never met a real man who was opposed to feminism, but I have known of a million petulant little ManBoy creeps who were. Everyone blames women for everything these days, so I'm going to blame Kate Bush for that song. Because, nine times out of 10, The Man With The Child In His Eyes is probably a paedophile scoping out his next victim. The other times, he's just a tosser.

fields.headline: Nihil riggente votandum
fields.trailText: We Smallweeds make it a rule never to vote for people who try to rig an election.
fields.body:
We Smallweeds make it a rule never to vote for people who try to rig an election. Where others have inscribed on their coats of arms slogans like "nemo me impune lacessit" or "quod est demonstrandum", our own bears the words (though in Latin, of course), "A Smallweed shall never vote for a rigger". No true Smallweed would have voted Labour in Wales after the nomination was squared for Alun Michael; nor can we now vote for Dobbo because of the way the London nomination was fixed for him.

People tend to forget another electoral outrage: the use in the last Euro-elections of a closed list PR system, designed to ensure that only those candidates in with the party boss class got high enough up the list to be elected. Calling down vengeance on Rigger Blair, this Smallweed shunned Labour then too. What will the Rigger rig next? Or will he now learn his lesson?

Multum in parvo (Byfleet) writes : Does any of this have anything to do with the well- known condition rigger mortis?

Smallweed acerbically snaps: No, but it could lead to it before long if they go on like this.

Goliath lost to David, according to new academic research, not because some proto-Blair was rigging the contest, but because he had rotten eyesight, and slang (the biblical term) his missiles off target. Nowadays people in universities come up with new reasons for victory or defeat while you wait.

Take the battle of Agincourt (1415). The French took up their positions on a boggy terrain, into which their heavily armoured men at arms and cavalry sank, thus allowing the English, though outnumbered five to one, to rout them. One source has already noted that this was the very opposite of what happened at Bannockburn (1314), where the English were on the squishy ground and the Scotsmen wiped the floor with them.

This is surely the key to the whole proceeding. Work in progress at the university of Aix-en-Provence is said to reveal the connection. The French, it seems, went into Agincourt with a map of the line-up at Bannockburn, but got the dispositions the wrong way round, thus emulating the bogbound English instead of the dry-footed Scots. This was blamed at the time back in Paris on perfidious Albion having worn their change strip at Bannockburn.

Next week, exclusively in Smallweed: how Napoleon lost Waterloo by wearing the wrong kind of trousers.

Brian Glanville, who wrote the Guardian obituary, can be excepted, but as one who saw the great man play, I'm astonished by the assumption that Stanley Matthews was universally recognised as the greatest footballer of his day. In those days, the England team had selectors who sometimes de-selected him, inspiring the traditional cry that was heard on football grounds until at least the mid-70s: "bring back Stanley Matthews." But even non-selectors would tell you, especially in the north, that Stan was not as good - by which they meant, not as complete - as Tom Finney.

This was not to dispute his gifts: his ability to tease and torment a left-back and leave the poor fellow sprawling before planting the perfect cross on the forehead of what was then known as a centre-forward was unmatched in my experience. But Finney, also a right-winger by inclination, could play on the left too, as he often had to since Matthews was picked on the right for England; he was also when pressed into service a formidable centre-forward.

It isn't true to say that Matthews never headed the ball: I have seen him nodding it down so that he could play it with his feet. But Finney could do just about everything. It was perhaps indicative of where the two players stood in public opinion generally that where Stan was known as the wizard of dribble, Tom was the Preston plumber. He got his knighthood years after Stan, as an afterthought. He is still around, and paid gracious tribute this week to his dead friend. I hope we will treasure him while he is still with us.

An objection has been raised with this column's ombudsman to my reference last week to myself as snarling with tooth-bearing menace. This, it has been suggested, was one of those dreaded homophones which one keeps reading about in the corrections and clarifications column. What Smallweed meant to say, my critics contend, was "teeth-baring" - that is to say, baring his teeth in a snarl.

In conversations with the columnar ombudsman (myself) Smallweed has argued as follows. No man can show his teeth unless he has teeth. In other words, he cannot be tooth-baring unless he is tooth-bearing first. As proof of this point I cite the existence of the word "dentigerous", which sure enough is defined as "bearing teeth." As my paragraph was clearly designed to evoke a dentigerous posture, I leave the court without a stain on my character, or even on my escutcheon.

Wednesday night in the Unibond Premier League: Leek Town 1, Winsford United 2. Need I say more? Our first away win of the season. In 18 games before Smallweed espoused the Winsfordian cause United collected two points. In 13 since, they've accrued a sizzling nine. We are steadily closing the gap on the side above us, Bamber Bridge: now there are only 22 points in it, though we have played rather more games. I hope some of the triumph at Leek may have been attributable to readers of Smallweed who made the journey. I would have been there myself, but I had to rig an election.

fields.headline: Post-mortem on Panorama
fields.trailText: In her article (Alder Hey has distracted us from real cases of tragedy, February 23) Polly Toynbee accuses Panorama of "tabloid television", and of encouraging grief-stricken parents to focus on their children's missing organs. In her opinion this is a "frivolous" and "inappropriate" cause but the parents certainly do not agree. We have not "stirred up" emotions in the case.
fields.body:
In her article (Alder Hey has distracted us from real cases of tragedy, February 23) Polly Toynbee accuses Panorama of "tabloid television", and of encouraging grief-stricken parents to focus on their children's missing organs. In her opinion this is a "frivolous" and "inappropriate" cause but the parents certainly do not agree. We have not "stirred up" emotions in the case.

More than 200 families belong to the main Liverpool parents action group, and they have been very critical of Alder Hey's practice of keeping organs without consent and the way the hospital dealt with their inquiries subsequently.

There are serious worries about the state of pathology and post-mortems, but far from ignoring them, Panorama addressed those concerns in detail. The pathologists spoke frankly about the unclear wording of consent forms, how practice had diverged from the strict letter of the law and the need for consent and transparency in the future.

At a time when there is widespread concern and debate about the arrogance of the medical profession, it is surely Panorama's job to investigate such a systematic abuse of the rights of the bereaved.
Jane Corbin
Panorama

fields.headline: E-ostriches
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting, in dismissing the internet (We've been here before, February 24), misses the point by focusing on consumer sales and the inconvenience of picking up parcel deliveries for goods ordered online.
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting, in dismissing the internet (We've been here before, February 24), misses the point by focusing on consumer sales and the inconvenience of picking up parcel deliveries for goods ordered online. Sales to business represent more than 80% of e-commerce and businesses have no problem being in during the day for deliveries. With insurance companies, banks and many others experiencing cost reductions of between 80-98% from online automation, the internet isn't going to go away.

It may result in more creative, empowered new jobs - or in boring new production lines. Madeleine is right to point out the unequal social effects of the web. And that is why socialists and trade unionists need to be involved in defining the new world of work that is being created. This is no time to bury your head in the sand and pretend nothing is changing.
Henry Stewart
Happy Computers
stewarthenry@hotmail.com

 e-commerce, e-finance, e-mail, e-media, e-venture, e-banking, e-gaming, e-citizen, e-government, e-envoy, e-shopping. When will it end?
e-ludlow
Leicester

fields.headline: Bad review for Reagan
fields.trailText: Reagan's promotion to the ludicrous position of 11th best of the 41 US presidents (White House winners and losers, February 22) is a sad reflection of America's migration to the extreme right.
fields.body:
Reagan's promotion to the ludicrous position of 11th best of the 41 US presidents (White House winners and losers, February 22) is a sad reflection of America's migration to the extreme right.

As president he killed at least 40,000 Nicaraguans, subverted the constitution over Irangate, created the biggest budget deficit in history and believed in a final (nuclear) armageddon against the forces of evil (communism). Luckily Gorbachev exercised his overwhelming intellectual and moral superiority to manoeuvre a bemused Reagan into a u-turn towards disarmament. It was not because of, but in spite of Reagan that the cold war ended. Reagan had no understanding of the world outside America and very little inside. He has to be number 41 as he is the only one on the list who makes Buchanan look positively competent and wise.

As for the rest, Jefferson (7th) is ridiculously underrated. He should certainly be in the top three and has a strong case to be accepted as number one and the true architect of his country. The terminal dry rot which has set in since is not his fault. Jackson (13th) is also rather low and Eisenhower (9th) and Truman (5th) too high, although not ridiculously so. Monroe (14th) seems unduly favoured, and I think the long view of history will judge Clinton (21st) a bit higher. Say a straight swap with Monroe, at least.

One does feel a certain sympathy for Zachary Taylor (dead after less than a year and a half in office, 28th) and William Harrison (dead after a month, 37th). What if the playing field were levelled and they were all judged just on their first four weeks? Reagan would still be 41st.
Steve Edwards
Wivelsfield Green, E Sussex

fields.headline: No dividend for the Co-op
fields.trailText: In common with many other members of the co-operative movement, I was amazed at your report announcing the creation of a Co-operative Commission (Blair sets up Co-op review board, February 25).
fields.body:
In common with many other members of the co-operative movement, I was amazed at your report announcing the creation of a Co-operative Commission (Blair sets up Co-op review board, February 25).

I'm sure John Monks and the other Labour party and union representatives nominated to this body are unaware of the fact that this move - which the Co-operative Wholesale Society's chief executive, Graham Melmoth, seems to have got Tony Blair to sponsor - completely bypasses the democratic structures of the independent societies and the Co-operative Union (which is supposed to represent them).

The co-operative movement is in danger of becoming a members' movement in name only. Yes, we need professional managers like Melmoth to fight the business battles with our competitors. But no we don't need them to take over the co-operative movement, a key element in the labour movement and, incidentally, an important and loyal supporter of the Labour party. What is happening now is half-way to demutualisation, in the form of what could be best described as a mangers' movement. Among other things, this would withdraw political and financial support from Labour and the allied Co-operative party - as CWS has already been doing.

I resigned last month from the board of the Co-operative Retail Society over the "merger" with Melmoth's CWS. In reality this is a takeover by CWS, a hybrid body which is effectively controlled by its senior managers, of the largest and most independent society. The proposed transfer of engagements is being sold to CRS members on the basis of an exaggeration of our financial difficulties, with no guarantees to members of the democratic rights they take for granted.

A memorandum of understanding, laboriously agreed between the two boards as the basis for a transitional period and establishment of a review board to outline a new structure, is being kept secret from the members. Those who have asked for it at members' meetings round the country have been told it will not be released to them since it is confidential to the two boards. Yet these same members will be asked at a meeting on March 4 to effectively close down CRS and hand over hundreds of millions of pounds' worth of assets to Melmoth and co.

I have asked the Registrar of Friendly Societies, who is charged with ensuring member control of the co-operative societies, to look urgently at the way in which CRS management has conducted its campaign for a Yes vote on transferring members' assets to CWS. It may be too late: although there are many dissenting voices within the society and the movement, the deal seems to have been steamrollered through. Is this the end of co-operation as an expression of member control? And if so, what is the point of a Co-operative Commission surveying the wreckage?
Barbara Rogers
London

fields.headline: Deathblow
fields.trailText: I don't know why Philip Knightley persists in claiming there is still some question over the "moment of death" picture taken by Robert Capa in the Spanish Civil War (Now for the moment of truth, Media, February 21). The suggestion that the picture is bogus has smeared the reputation of a great photographer.
fields.body:
I don't know why Philip Knightley persists in claiming there is still some question over the "moment of death" picture taken by Robert Capa in the Spanish Civil War (Now for the moment of truth, Media, February 21). The suggestion that the picture is bogus has smeared the reputation of a great photographer.

Knightley researched this more than 20 years ago. Since then it has been proved beyond doubt that the man who died was a 24-year-old mill worker called Federico Borrell Garcia, the only man to die on that front on September 5 1936. He was identified by a researcher who was fighting that day, who checked the story with Borrell's surviving sister-in-law. All of this was reported in 1996 for the Observer.
David Loyn
London

fields.headline: Labour's monument
fields.standfirst: The pioneers of 1900 enriched our politicsNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: We cannot help but take pleasure in the Labour party's 100th birthday this weekend - and not only because the party was founded just around the corner from our current headquarters, at the Methodist Memorial Hall in Farringdon Street, central London. Our pleasure also springs from the fact that throughout Labour's century we have stood as a candid, often awkward, friend, endorsing the party directly or indirectly in almost every election it has fought. Its history is part of our own.
fields.body:
We cannot help but take pleasure in the Labour party's 100th birthday this weekend - and not only because the party was founded just around the corner from our current headquarters, at the Methodist Memorial Hall in Farringdon Street, central London. Our pleasure also springs from the fact that throughout Labour's century we have stood as a candid, often awkward, friend, endorsing the party directly or indirectly in almost every election it has fought. Its history is part of our own. Tomorrow's anniversary of that very first meeting of trade unionists, activists and socialist societies - eventually producing the Labour Representation Committee - provides an apt moment to reflect on Labour's past and to wonder about its future.

A view that was once merely fashionable, but which has now graduated into conventional wisdom, declares that this birthday might not be a cause for celebration at all. Roy Jenkins, once a deputy leader of the party, has led the way in arguing that the tragedy of 20th century British politics was the division of the liberal left into two parties, one Labour, the other Liberal. If these progressive forces had only been united, runs the argument, then we might not have had to live through seven decades of Conservative or Conservative-dominated rule. Thanks to that division, Labour has governed for no more than 24 of the last 100 years. Tony Blair himself is an advocate of this view of history: indeed, it forms the rationale behind his beloved "project" of ever-closer cooperation with the Liberal Democrats. Mr Blair urges a reunion of the liberal left, to ensure that if the 20th century belonged to the Conservatives, then the 21st ought to be in the hands of the progressives.

There is some appeal in this argument, not least the compelling evidence of the numbers. Still, despite our century-long advocacy of accommodation between the Labour and Liberal parties, we cannot agree with it completely. Lest we forget, it was Labour which built the modern welfare state - including a national health service and pensions system - oversaw the peaceful end of the British empire, constructed the open university and presided over a decade of social progress, with liberalising legislation in the 1960s on abortion, sexuality, the death penalty and equal pay. No party with a proud record like that should be asked to regard its own existence as a mistake. On the contrary, if the brute reality of our first past the post electoral system means there was only room for one progressive party, it would surely have been the Liberals who had to leave the stage - not Labour. Liberals cannot, with any conviction, claim they would have notched up that same catalogue of achievement. It took the Labour party.

A tougher argument is the one about the present and future. The party of Tony Blair faces problems that would have baffled its predecessors. For one thing, devolution has moulded an unfamiliar landscape. There are now at least three distinct political battlefields in Britain: Scotland, Wales and the UK-wide parliament in Westminster. Labour is the only party which is a lead player on all three grounds - taking on the nationalists on the first two, and the Conservatives on the third. Labour's dominance in all these different arenas leaves a problem: how can a party tailor different messages for these increasingly distinct political entities yet still remain a single, coherent UK-wide party? Can Labour continue to speak a language that appeals to Edinburgh and Cardiff while simultaneously reaching the voters of middle England, the people who decide general elections at Westminster? Can it have one transport policy for the country and another for London, if that's what it takes to win a London-wide election? This is an existential challenge to Labour far more than to the Conservatives - who have all but given up on being a UK-wide party. It is Labour which needs to crack this riddle.

The party's second problem is related. Labour's great modern achievement is to have transcended its original status as a sectional vehicle for one class. The Blairite Labour party is a home fit for millionaires and business leaders now; no longer the ragged-trousered comrades who gathered on Farringdon Street. This counts, in part, as a testament to Labour's own achievement: its expansion of higher education led to the creation of a vast, new middle class and the eventual blurring of the old class hierarchies. But it also leaves Labour with a conundrum. How can Labour be the party of David Sainsbury and Bob Ayling - and simultaneously keep hold of its loyalists in the heartlands, the men and women typified by the former minister, Peter Kilfoyle, who resigned over what he regards as the excessive attention lavished on affluent middle England? The prime minister says he's "not interested" in the tired old language of class. But that is too easy. Labour needs to find a way to stay true to its roots, even as it stretches and grows, touching areas that were once deemed out of reach. These concerns need not be sources of angst. On the contrary, they are problems that come from success, rather than failure. After 100 years there is much to celebrate. Labour can wish itself a very happy birthday.

fields.headline: A pointless prosecution
fields.standfirst: The attorney general should halt it now
fields.trailText: Politics is a difficult art. Unpredictable events would alone be enough to make that inevitable. But some public embarrassments are perfectly predictable, and there is one staring the attorney general starkly in the face at this moment. Lord Williams of Mostyn wants to go down as a reformer, as befits a former Rhyl grammar school boy who rose to be chairman of the bar council. He has spoken of the need for law reform and his determination to improve the beleaguered crown prosecution service. But before he turns to these bigger pictures, he needs to review again an individual prosecution now heading towards the courts.
fields.body:
Politics is a difficult art. Unpredictable events would alone be enough to make that inevitable. But some public embarrassments are perfectly predictable, and there is one staring the attorney general starkly in the face at this moment. Lord Williams of Mostyn wants to go down as a reformer, as befits a former Rhyl grammar school boy who rose to be chairman of the bar council. He has spoken of the need for law reform and his determination to improve the beleaguered crown prosecution service. But before he turns to these bigger pictures, he needs to review again an individual prosecution now heading towards the courts.

The attorney general has already made one sound ruling - the decision in late December to drop the prosecution against Tony Geraghty, the first journalist to face charges under the secrecy laws for 20 years, which he made because he was not content with the case against the writer. But the prosecution of Mr Geraghty's co-defendant, Nigel Wylde, a former army colonel who won the Queen's gallantry medal in a Northern Ireland tour in which he defused 96 terrorist bombs, is - absurdly - still proceeding. He is alleged to have helped Mr Geraghty with his book, The Irish War, an account of 300 years of fighting in Ireland in which he sets out the current extent of computer-assisted surveillance of the civilian population.

From the moment the heavy ministry of defence police feet marched into Mr Geraghty's Herefordshire home, the writer insisted that he had done no damage to the national interest. As a former squadron leader in the RAF military reserve, who served with General Sir Peter de la Billiere's staff in the Gulf war, Mr Geraghty's patriotism was not in question. What he revealed was already known. It was embarrassing, but not damaging. Embarrassing the government is still, even in this authoritarian time, not a crime. The authorities seemingly concurred. There was no attempt to injunct the book either at the time of publication or even after the two men had been arrested and charged. Then, shortly after the New York Times had taken up the case, the charges against Mr Geraghty were dropped.

But this still leaves Nigel Wylde facing his prosecutors. There are several reasons why they will fail. First, because the law under which he is being prosecuted, section two of the 1989 official secrets act, is in breach of the fair trial provisions of the European convention on human rights. The section tramples over a key pillar of natural justice by reversing the onus on the burden of proof. Instead of the prosecution having to prove that the book damaged the national interest, the burden will rest with Mr Wylde to demonstrate that it did not. This invidious provision was also included in the prevention of terrorism act, which was condemned by the attorney general when in opposition. And it was while Labour was in opposition that Labour opposed the 1989 official secrets bill for failing to provide a public interest defence. Surely the attorney general has not forgotten this commitment.

All this in any case presupposes that the prosecution can prove that Mr Wylde assisted Mr Geraghty. It is time the attorney general took another urgent look at this case. He cannot seriously believe a jury would find Mr Wylde guilty when the charges against Mr Geraghty have already been dropped and the prosecution is in breach of the European convention. Lord Williams must surely see the logic of that. He should act on it.

fields.headline: Cheep shot
fields.trailText: Dr Luis Baptista is correct to argue that "the music of nature had a way of affecting the nature of music" (Bird songs affect nature of music, February 21). But his proposition is undermined by some glaring inaccuracies.
fields.body:
Dr Luis Baptista is correct to argue that "the music of nature had a way of affecting the nature of music" (Bird songs affect nature of music, February 21). But his proposition is undermined by some glaring inaccuracies. Mozart's Divertimento (K522) was written in 1787, three years after his starling died. It lampoons poor performers and bad composers, not ingenious pets.

Mozart did teach the bird to whistle a theme from his Piano Concerto in G (K453); though, as the composer noted, it could not quite get the tune right.
Timothy Rhys Jones
University of Exeter
T.R.Jones@exeter.ac.uk

webTitle: A chance to see what they say about you

fields.headline: A chance to see what they say about you
fields.standfirst: From next week strengthened data protection laws are set to give the public greater access to information held on them by organisations from banks to credit agencies and direct marketing to staff records. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: New rules come into force next Wednesday to give greater rights to private individuals faced with leviathan organisations and their filing systems. And that will give consumers and others who want to know what information is held on them a cause to cheer.
fields.body:
New rules come into force next Wednesday to give greater rights to private individuals faced with leviathan organisations and their filing systems. And that will give consumers and others who want to know what information is held on them a cause to cheer.

The subtantially strengthened Data Protection Act - enacted in 1998 - goes live on Wednesday. Besides reinforcing the individual against the corporate machine, it throws a fresh light on data collection which could see many individuals exercising rights to opt out and others insisting organisations turn out their filing cabinets afresh. It could also lead to many employees asking bosses, for the first time, to reveal what is in personnel department files.

But there could well be another sound coming from offices up and down the country - the whirr of shredding machines as firms try to frustrate individuals exercising some of their new rights.

Information on every individual is probably held on average in 50 places - for those who frequently buy over the internet or by mail order, and for those with complicated financial arrangements, the number can easily top 100.

Some of it is essential. If you have an account with NatWest Bank, then the bank must keep some details about you. Shareholders in British Telecom need the comfort of knowing that a registrar has their personal details - otherwise they would not get their dividends or annual reports as this country has no tradition of anonymous bearer bonds and shares. And if you buy a fridge from John Lewis, the store needs to know your address in case there is a safety recall or you have a guarantee quibble and cannot find the receipt.

But information creates more information. Putting lots of individual facts together - someone banks with NatWest, has BT shares and has recently bought a fridge from John Lewis - creates a marketing profile. This person is likely to have different tastes and aspirations to someone with no bank account or shares and who buys domestic goods from the local second hand store. Many organisations exist to buy and sell this information.

The resulting material can be used to select prospects for marketing purposes; it is also routinely used in decision making. Most of us are only dimly aware of all this. We treat it as an irritant of life - until something goes wrong.

We might be turned down for credit because of an error at a reference agency such as Experian or Equifax, we might want to complain about being mis-sold a financial product or we might just want to know why we have been selected for the latest round of telephone torture sales.

One huge advance - and the reason for those shredding machines - is that the new act includes "manual data" rather than just the computer records in the original 1984 legislation.

Mike Bradford, the recently appointed data protection director at Experian, says the act gives "data" a very broad definition. He says: "It now includes manual data in any form that is "structured and accessible". That could include filing cabinets, card index boxes and piles of lifestyle questionnaires provided they are in some order such as being sorted by name or by postcode. It could even include a contacts list in a Filofax. But the act will exclude personal lists however they are kept. Nor would information kept in a random order count.

The exclusion of manual data from the old law allowed "blacklisting agencies" such as the old Economic League to keep records in a paper form rather than on computer files so the subject could not demand to inspect them.

Back in the early 70s, actor Ricky Tomlinson was a politically active building worker who became involved in a construction site strike in Shrewsbury. The police alleged he had taken part in violence; the court concurred and Tomlinson - one of the Shrewsbury three - was sentenced to prison.

Since then, he has become a successful actor, first in the Channel 4 soap Brookside, and most recently as Jim, the largely armchair-bound father of the television watching kin in BBC 1's The Royle Family.

But between construction site activism and television fame, Tomlinson found himself blacklisted by an employers' organisation. He was not alone: thousands of others were similarly on warning lists circulated to employers, unable to find work due to union or political activities.

None of these could use the old Data Protection Act. They could use the new version - provided they can discover who is keeping records on them. Most employee records from the original application to the latest disciplinary action have usually been kept as manual data.

It is often easier to file away handwritten notes, while locking them away in a physical filing cabinet can ensure more confidentiality than a computer system.

But up to now, these files have escaped data protection provisions. With some exceptions, employers will now have to be honest with their staff. Some will react by filing less - many lawyers believe material kept by date order in a notebook does not count for the "structured and accessible" rule.

Once the act is up and running - and companies which were registered under the previous data laws by October 1998 have until October 2001 for full compliance - Data Protection Registrar Elizabeth France will bring in a code of practice governing the uses of personal data by employers.

The code will introduce tighter control over the use of employee records in three key areas:

1. Employee surveillance involving collection of data to monitor performance or detect problems

2. Automated processing such as aptitude and psychometric testing and the extent to which employment decisions might be taken by computers analysing results

3. Sensitive information including genetic tests or results of alcohol or drug testing.

Once the new code is fully in place, failure to comply could lead to enforcement action by the Registrar, or a claim for compensation by any individual who has suffered as a result.

Mrs France says: "The development of new technology is threatening personal privacy in the workplace. Employers want to know more and more about their staff who are often not in a position to resist. This code will set out clear ground rules to ensure fairness to employees."

Another group who might be able to use the "manual data" provisions are those who were mis-sold pensions and endowments. While financial and investment companies have had to hand over formal factfinds for a decade, many unscrupulous sellers made separate records on paper which could reveal the real reasons they sold the products.

Companies and other organisations which fear that their manual files will have to be revealed and which could then expose them to potential legal action will be keeping their shredding machines working overtime.

Andersen Legal have already warned clients to "clean up" old files so that only essential and relevant information is retained.

The new law contains other new rights. Individuals can object to their personal data being used for direct marketing - existing opt-outs are toughened with new penalties for non-compliance.

But there will be some areas where personal records will be subject to secrecy - for example, national security and crime prevention and apprehension.

Companies will be able to claim exclusions for price sensitive information while files kept for "journalism and other literary purposes" are not included.

Main changes

Records kept on paper to be revealed in addition to computer data

New rights to know who holds information on you

Being told the identity of the person in a business nominated as responsible for data protection issues

Rights to have a photocopy of personal information held

Greater rights to object to anyone holding personal data

New rules to prevent data being sent to a foreign country outside the European Economic Area to escape the legislation

A new range of non-compliance rules which can lead to individuals being held personally responsible for breaches.

webTitle: Nato looks to boost Kosovo forces but 'crisis is over'

fields.headline: Nato looks to boost Kosovo forces but 'crisis is over'
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Nato rushed to calm fears about Kosovo last night, pledging to keep its forces up to strength, but claiming that the immediate crisis in the ethnically divided town of Mitrovice was now over.
fields.body:
Nato rushed to calm fears about Kosovo last night, pledging to keep its forces up to strength, but claiming that the immediate crisis in the ethnically divided town of Mitrovice was now over.

Speaking after an emergency meeting of the north Atlantic council, the alliance's governing body, the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, insisted that the situation was under control.

"Mitrovice is a potential flashpoint. It flared up but we dealt with the unrest quickly and decisively," he told reporters in Brussels. "K-For has dealt with the situation firmly and even-handedly.

"We are determined to keep K-For at the right strength to allow it to carry out all its security tasks in Kosovo."

Reinforcements could be announced next week, after Britain, Italy and Spain reportedly expressed willingness to provide more peacekeeping troops for the troubled Serbian province. France has already offered to send another 600-700 men.

Officials at Nato headquarters said another option was to deploy forces from outside the 37,000 under K-For command but which are being held in a "strategic reserve" in the region.

There was an attempt to play down the dimensions of the crisis, which has erupted uncomfortably close to next month's first anniversary of Nato's war against Yugoslavia. But troubling questions about ambiguous policies and inadequate means remain.

"It was never a question of going round the table and pointing a finger and saying 'you're not doing the job'," one senior diplomat said last night. "This wasn't about numbers and who was going to cough up."

Concern has focused on the fact that some K-For participants have allowed their contributions to slip - limiting the ability of commanders to redeploy quickly within Kosovo.

Others, privately accused of not pulling their weight, have not been willing to have their troops deployed away from their agreed command areas, in trouble spots like Mitrovice.

General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander in Europe, appeared before the council for the second time this week while Gen Klaus Reinhardt of Germany, the K-For commander, addressed ambassadors by video link from Pristina. Gen Clark has formally requested three new battalions - 1,800 to 2,000 troops.

No decision was made on Gen Clark's request, but the alliance's military committee was ordered to examine troop needs and report back to the council next week.

The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, under pressure because resources are already stretched, said that Britain - the largest contributor to K-For - would see what others had to offer.

Tensions have been high in Mitrovice since a grenade attack on a United Nations bus in early February killed two elderly Serbs. Revenge attacks followed, leading K-For troops to carry out extensive searches to seize weapons.

Nato claims that the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, is orchestrating a destabilisation campaign in the city, which contains the most significant Serb community remaining in Kosovo, and that ethnic Albanians are also trying to foment trouble.

Bernard Kouchner, the French head of the UN civilian operation in Kosovo, yesterday demanded that more police be sent to the province. "I need a lot more policemen, a lot more. I need about 2,500 more. Even the slightest bit more would be a gift for us," he said in a radio interview.

Officials at Nato headquarters said another option was to deploy forces from outside the 37,000 under K-For command but which are being held in a "strategic reserve" in the region. There was an attempt to play down the dimensions of the crisis, which has erupted uncomfortably close to next month's first anniversary of Nato's war against Yugoslavia. But troubling questions about ambiguous policies and inadequate means remain. "It was never a question of going round the table and pointing a finger and saying 'you're not doing the job'," one senior diplomat said last night. "This wasn't about numbers and who was going to cough up." Concern has focused on the fact that some K-For participants have allowed their contributions to slip - limiting the ability of commanders to redeploy quickly within Kosovo. Others, privately accused of not pulling their weight, have not been willing to have their troops deployed away from their agreed command areas, in trouble spots like Mitrovice. General Wesley Clark, Nato's supreme commander in Europe, appeared before the council for the second time this week while Gen Klaus Reinhardt of Germany, the K-For commander, addressed ambassadors by video link from Pristina. Gen Clark has formally requested three new battalions - 1,800 to 2,000 troops. No decision was made on Gen Clark's request, but the alliance's military committee was ordered to examine troop needs and report back to the council next week. The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, under pressure because resources are already stretched, said that Britain - the largest contributor to K-For - would see what others had to offer. Tensions have been high in Mitrovice since a grenade attack on a United Nations bus in early February killed two elderly Serbs. Revenge attacks followed, leading K-For troops to carry out extensive searches to seize weapons. Nato claims that the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, is orchestrating a destabilisation campaign in the city, which contains the most significant Serb community remaining in Kosovo, and that ethnic Albanians are also trying to foment trouble. Bernard Kouchner, the French head of the UN civilian operation in Kosovo, yesterday demanded that more police be sent to the province. "I need a lot more policemen, a lot more. I need about 2,500 more. Even the slightest bit more would be a gift for us," he said in a radio interview.

webTitle: Serbs vow to stand their ground

fields.headline: Serbs vow to stand their ground
fields.standfirst:
Mitrovice has become a symbol of resistance for town's minority

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Close to 4,000 Serbs gathered in a tense and angry Mitrovice yesterday to hear their leaders proudly proclaim "we do not support violence" and "we are not anti-Albanian, only pro-Serb".
fields.body:
Close to 4,000 Serbs gathered in a tense and angry Mitrovice yesterday to hear their leaders proudly proclaim "we do not support violence" and "we are not anti-Albanian, only pro-Serb".

But as the patriotic songs and defiant speeches rang out from a platform erected at the main crossroads of the Kosovan town, the lone Albanian left in one of the tallest blocks of flats in the Serb-dominated northern part of Mitrovice felt a different reality.

The 23-year-old woman was showing a newly arrived United Nations policeman around her building. Two weeks ago, 46 Albanian families lived there. Now they have gone.

A curtain hangs across the space where the front door used to be in the first flat on the ground floor. The door was torn from its hinges and the flat was looted. Cupboard doors swing open and clothes are strewn around where strangers apparently searched in haste for money or jewellery.

The flat upstairs, where the metal door has been twisted open, has half-packed suitcases lying on the bed. The occupants presumably fled in a hurry.

"The Serbs came in like vultures and the Albanians ran for their lives," said a Canadian police officer working for the UN. His American colleague used a different metaphor. "This place was unguarded for just three hours. They took it over like ants and removed everything," he said.

The assault happened after K-For, the international peacekeeping force, had already increased its troop strength in northern Mitrovice and, ironically, in the middle of a search for weapons.

"There were Greek troops on guard here, but they were called away to duties on the bridge. It wasn't their fault," continued the American policeman, who is renting a flat in the building himself. "French troops were doing a search a few streets away and didn't see this."

Two blocks on either side suffered a similar frenzy of looting. Now the three buildings have become the focus of UN efforts to get at least some Albanians back into northern Mitrovice.

A committee started registering the latest refugees yesterday with a view to helping them back. There is also a plan to build a footbridge across the river Ibar to give the three blocks - which flank the embankment on the northern side of the river - direct access to the south.

It seems a strange waste since they are little more than a hundred yards from the main road bridge, which K-For troops have been guarding for months.

More troops and better policing would be a cheaper and quicker way to provide security. "There should be much more proactive policing," said an officer from the Royal Ulster Constabulary who arrived in Mitrovice a week ago.

"But the hatred is far worse than in Northern Ireland."

As the Serb rally ended, Bovan, a 40-year-old who did not wish to give his last name, acknowledged that emotions had risen too high. The Serb attacks on Albanian flats only began after Albanians threw a grenade into a Serb bar a fortnight ago, he said.

"The glass was full of violence. Then it overflowed. It was stupid retaliation by Serbs but the Albanians deliberately provoked it. Serb nerves are on edge. It was a bad night. I accept that."

Like many Serbs in Mitrovice, Bovan is convinced that Albanians want to evict all Serbs from Kosovo. Some 6,000 of the roughly 16,000 Serbs in the northern part of the city are refugees from the south or nearby villages which have been ethnically cleansed.

Mitrovice has become a symbol of Serb resistance. "There weren't so many Serbs here eight months ago. We didn't know what our fate would be. Now we know there is no question but that Serbs will stay," Oliver Ivanovic, a leader of the local Serb National Council told the crowd. "We couldn't succeed in Kraljevo or other towns in Serbia, or in refugee camps there. We call on other Serbs to show more courage and come back to Kosovo."

"We Serbs are living here like on an Indian reservation," declared Marko Jaksic to cheers. "Is this justice? We only have this town in Kosovo, or just one-fifth of this town. But should we leave here so that other people are allowed to establish a new state?"

 Macedonian police have found more than two tonnes of weapons and ammunition bound for neighbouring Kosovo, two independent television stations reported yesterday. Sitel and A1 said that police confiscated 120 boxes with automatic weapons and more than 100,000 bullets from a motel in the village of Kravari, 120 miles south of Skopje. The weapons are believed to have been smuggled in from Albania.

webTitle: Banks squaring up for high noon

fields.headline: Banks squaring up for high noon
fields.standfirst: Tuesday's shoot-out to decide whether to accept Barclays' proposal to charge all non-customers for using cashpoints could mean life or death for the Link network, reports Tony Levene
fields.trailText: It will be high noon for cash machine users on Tuesday, when members of the Link hole in the wall machine meet in Harrogate. Coming from one end of the high street is Barclays, the prime mover of the "scheme to charge non-customers a fee for using our machines" brigade, and its close ally the Woolwich.
fields.body:
It will be high noon for cash machine users on Tuesday, when members of the Link hole in the wall machine meet in Harrogate. Coming from one end of the high street is Barclays, the prime mover of the "scheme to charge non-customers a fee for using our machines" brigade, and its close ally the Woolwich.

And from the other end of the street, the banks and building societies which want all machines to be free, will be edging forward. Marshalling this side are the Nationwide, the Co-op Bank and the Royal Bank of Scotland.

The shoot-out will be over whether to accept the Barclays proposal to charge all non-customers for taking cash out of its ATMs - an argument that could unhinge the Link network.

The likely charge is £1 - on top of the "disloyalty" fees some banks already charge their customers for using other machines.

The Consumers' Association says it could be more than £1 in areas where Barclays has a local monopoly - perhaps as much as £4. And Barclays admits that the £1 fee proposal is not the last word. It calls it "a stake in the ground" and admits that prices could end up on both sides of that figure.

But these are banks, not cowboys, so the distinction between the goodies and the baddies is not so clear-cut.

There has been some changing of positions - partly as the banks try to present a united front and partly as a result of the battle for NatWest. And the major report by former Oftel boss Don Cruickshank on the banks could get in the way. It is due for publication as early as next Wednesday and its probable contents could force banks to think again.

It seems likely that Cruickshank will recommend that the provision of cash to consumers should be opened up to include retailers such as petrol stations and supermarkets, which would be able to install their own brands of cash machines. This would undermine the banks' attempts to spread their wings into superstores, railway stations and other remote sites. Supermarkets, for instance, could make cash machines an attractive perk for loyalty card holders. And they know that providing them would help bring in customers.

Tesco would certainly like more control. This week it told Barclays to take its 184 ATMs away from its sites if it introduced fees. As a retailer, Tesco does not want customer complaints nor would it want long queues outside one machine and few people in front of the Barclays hole in the wall on sites where there is a choice.

Barclays' contract with Tesco is up for renewal. But there are suggestions that Tesco Personal Finance is at loggerheads with the retailing arm because Barclays could be replaced by Nationwide, which is seen as a more direct competitor to Tesco's bank.

The Cruickshank inquiry may also call for the scrapping of the £50 limit on the cashback service available at supermarket checkouts. Offering larger sums out of the till would again undermine cash machines and help attract more customers.

But the killer recommendation - and one that could send representatives of every bank and building society scurrying home from Harrogate to rethink their positions - is that cash machine providers should make a maximum charge of around 30p to consumers who are "disloyal" to their own bank. It would then be up to the bank to pass it on or absorb, just as they do now.

The Consumers' Association believes 30p is a fair charge. But with many set five times as high, it suspects the banks of profiteering.

It says: "Despite what they say, the real reason is self-interest. They want to be able to dictate the size of the charge so they can make extra profit." The banks have constantly refused to reveal the true cost. Now Cruickshank could do it for them.

The Consumers' Association says it comes down to freedom of choice: "At the moment you can choose between a bank that charges disloyalty fees and one that does not. You could even negotiate these charges away with your own bank if you are big customer. But if you have to pay to a third party, you are powerless."

Disloyalty fees are complicated: Abbey cash machine users pay £1.50 to use a TSB machine, but TSB customers can use Abbey's 2,781 machines free of charge.

NatWest and HSBC customers pay £1 for most machines other than their own. And bank customers are not warned of the disloyalty fees.

The Woolwich already has some machines in "locations where there is not enough business to support a traditional cash machine" which levy a £1 "convenience" fee. It has an on-screen warning about the charge.

Barclays says it wants "transparency of charges". It claims to be losing £2m a month on cash machines which it could recoup from a fee. And it believes charges would be good for consumers.

"They have charges in the US and they have doubled the network in three years while fees have fallen. Competition will prevent any bank taking advantage of monopoly locations," it says.

webTitle: Time to deal yourself a new hand of cards

fields.headline: Time to deal yourself a new hand of cards
fields.standfirst: As cut-throat competition among the flexible friends forces down interest rates, Rupert Jones looks for the best offers
fields.trailText: As cut-throat competition among the flexible friends forces down interest rates, Rupert Jones looks for the best offers
fields.body:
While the official cost of borrowing is on the rise -four interest rate increases in six months, and more expected - many credit card rates have been steady for some time and some have actually fallen.

Providers that have chopped interest rates lately include Tesco Personal Finance, which has cut its introductory APR (annual percentage rate) twice in the last five months. Even Barclaycard, the UK's most popular card but also one of the most expensive, was this month forced to cut its rate for balance transfers in a bid to stay competitive.

Switching to a cheap credit card deal could be one of the best ways of spring-cleaning your finances if you racked up some Christmas and New Year spending debts.

There are some very good offers for people ready to transfer outstanding credit card balances to another provider offering a better rate. But scan the small print carefully as the terms can vary considerably from provider to provider.

Internet bank Egg boasts the lowest introductory APR on debt transfers - 4.5 - followed by Tesco, RBS Advanta and the Co-operative Bank, which all charge 4.9.

Before making your move, it is important to decide how quickly you want to pay off the card debt. With most of the cards on the market there is a time limit on how long the special offer debt transfer rate is available for. For example, Egg's lasts for only six months, and with some cards it is even less.

If you don't want to be tied in to paying off the debt within a certain period, go for a card where the balance transfer rate is valid until the debt is cleared. These include Barclaycard, Alliance & Leicester Diamond, Capital One Bank Premier and Lloyds TSB Asset Advance.

Financial data magazine Moneyfacts looked at how much interest would be charged in the case of someone transferring £1,000 to a new card, and repaying it over 12 months from March 1 this year.

Barclaycard came out best at £58.32, because its low special offer balance transfer rate is available for the whole 12-month period. Tesco, RBS Advanta and Egg came second, third and fourth (£64.12, £68.46 and £69.84 respectively). However, if the person repaid their debt within six months, the Egg card would be cheapest.

If you are going to use the card to buy goods, you will probably want to go for one with a low rate for purchases. Barclaycard scores badly here: it is one of the very few providers that has recently raised its interest rate for purchases - by 0.7%

It has been accused of trying to hide this by changing the way it quotes its APR. Its basic headline APR was 19.9 before but is now quoted at 19.4. It seems lower. But it isn't.

This is because the company is now excluding the £10 annual fee from the APR whereas before it was included. Barclaycard argues this is perfectly fair because all new customers recruited this year are exempt from the annual fee for 12 months, as are existing cardholders who spend more than £2,000 a year.

Growing numbers of people are card-hopping, often only staying with a card until its introductory rate runs out, and then flitting to the next cheap offer. Such people have been dubbed rate surfers, and there is a lot to be said for this approach - if you can be bothered with all the chopping and changing.

With an introductory APR for both purchases and balance transfers of 4.9 until January 1 2001, it's no wonder that the Tesco Visa card is proving phenomenally popular among the surfers. Last month alone 250,000 applications were received for the card. The company has reduced the introductory APR three times since May last year, when it was 9.9 for six months. The new offer rate is pretty good - but come next January, the APR will rise sharply to 14.9.

If you're not keen to see the rate you pay jump in this way, it might be worth focusing on the standard rate rather than the short-term "teaser" rate.

Cards with competitive standard APRs, where what you pay won't leap alarmingly, include Egg (one standard APR for purchases of 9.9), Northern Rock (introductory APR for purchases of 8.8 for the first 12 months, then 11.9), and Hamilton Direct Bank (introductory APR for purchases of 5.9 for the first six months, then 11.9).

fields.headline: The importance of being normal
fields.standfirst: Life insurance sales material sometimes seems to be written in an Alice in Wonderland language of its own, reports Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Life insurance sales material sometimes seems to be written in an Alice in Wonderland language of its own.
fields.body:
An international development campaign worker thought he understood basic English when he was sold a Legal & General endowment mortgage to back a late 80s home purchase.

But with around half the 25-year mortgage term already past, policyholder Ivan Nutbrown, aged 51, and his partner Jennie Kitteringham, a further education officer aged 52, have discovered the Alice in Wonderland world of life insurance language.

Here words mean exactly what their writers mean them to mean - neither more nor less. The word "normal", in particular, seems to have a special meaning in Legal & Generalese - leaving the policyholders to ask themselves just what normal is.

Mr Nutbrown's story is the latest episode in the long running saga of endowment mortgage holders who had been lulled into the product by offers of the full repayment of the mortgage plus a tax-free lump sum. This was on top of a promise that the endowment premium would be unchanged until it matured.

Now the North London couple face the prospect of paying more than a third as much again for the rest of the term if they want the plan to pay off their loan. Based on an L&G review, there will be a £5,300 shortfall on their policy when it matures in May 2012 (using the Personal Investment Authority's 6% investment growth rate). The original plan was intended to repay a £42,000 loan.

Putting the policy back on track, L&G calculated late last year, would require £26.59 a month for the remaining 12 and a half years of the term - a total of £3,988.

Mr Nutbrown was sold the policy by an estate agent in March 1987 when the couple bought a house in North London - not the one they now inhabit, although they kept the policy when they moved five years ago.

He says: "It wasn't our first home purchase but the previous ones had been financed by standard repayment loans. This time, we were persuaded by the estate agent that we would be fools to go for another repayment mortgage and that the endowment root was the only sensible solution. I bought it. The estate agent did give us a couple of quotes from other life companies but they were all very similar."

Helping the couple to "buy it" was some convincing literature. The L&G Build-up Mortgage Plan was, the sales material said, "designed not only to repay your mortgage and protect it with life assurance - it also offers the prospect of a substantial cash sum at the end of the term."

It also stated that "the proceeds of a life assurance policy are used to repay the capital sum at the end of the term."

Mr Nutbrown says: "That seems quite clear. When the policy matured, the capital sum would be cleared. There would have been no point signing up for something where there is a question mark. And if it is designed to do something and fails to do it, then the consumer should not have to pay. If I buy a television and the sound does not work, then I would not expect to pay more for a separate loudspeaker."

The L&G leaflet went fur ther. Under the heading "Certainty", the life company told its customers that "you can certainly plan your long term financial commitments with certainty".

But Mr Nutbrown says that is the last thing he can now do. "I thought that the £66.44 a month I was paying would pay off the home loan. And I planned a job move on that basis." fields.headline: Small investors spark revolution
fields.standfirst: More and more Europeans are buying shares, causing changes in the way the stock exchanges work, reports Mark Milner
fields.trailText: More and more Europeans are buying shares, causing changes in the way the stock exchanges work.
fields.body:
Sids, aunt sallys or sans culottes? Small shareholders are readily enough cast as the first two. Take this week's news that 150,000 small investors who piled into British Gas at the height of the privatisation boom have gone walkabout - leaving behind £14m in uncashed dividend cheques. Proof enough surely that the concept of a shareholding democracy needs more behind it than ideology and a health warning that the price of shares can go down as well as up.

But the retail investor may be set to take on a key role in the revolution that is sweeping through Europe's stock markets - propelled by an unlikely combination of new technology and old-age pension provision.

First the revolution. The cosy world of national stock markets is being turned upside down and they are faced with fighting a war on two fronts. For the moment the main focus of the struggle is the institutional investment community. Partly because of globalisation and partly as a result of the introduction of the single currency, institutional investors have become even more demanding. As a group they have always wanted to be able to trade in big volumes, cheaply and anonymously. Now they want to do the same across borders, preferably using just one trading system.

In response the main European exchanges are slowly moving towards an alliance which aims to provide that sort of service. The institutional drive for a single system is understandable. Europe currently has 29 exchanges and 17 settlement systems, so the drive for consolidation is understandable.

The snag is that the exchanges have been moving only slowly. That has left the door open for others. Nasdaq - big in the US - is now looking to be big over here too. Easdaq - a Brussels-based Nasdaq wannabe - is looking to get in on the cross border act, too. So is Tradepoint - tiny by comparison with the LSE but with some heavyweight backers.

As if that were not enough of a challenge the exchanges are facing another threat, from electronic communications networks (ECNs) which allow institutions to "match" buy and sell orders.

So where does the small investor fit in? Uncomfortably at the moment, you might think - not least because the institutional investors are not only the ones driving the change but also funding it by backing some of the rivals to the traditional exchanges.

But across Europe, the number of small investors appears to be growing and they appear to be doing more deals. Greater numbers and greater volumes mean the retail investor sector becomes more attractive.

As a report* commissioned by the Association of Private Client and Investment Managers and Stockbrokers (APCIMS) and published this month noted, the need for change is increasing. "Internationally known online pioneers are now being joined by other houses in the UK and a host of European brokers and banks offering order routing facilities for their private clients."

Stock exchanges are wooing the small investor, too. Germany's Deutsche Börse offers immediate execution for even tiny trades; the Paris Bourse has information centres in some 500 bank branches. Concerns about the sustainability of pension provision in countries where schemes have traditionally been funded on a pay as you go basis, but which are now running into the problem of fewer workers supporting more pensioners, is forcing future pensioners to consider their own arrangements.

Now the internet is making trading cheaper for the private investor. In the UK getting on for a fifth of all execution only trades are now carried out via the internet. Means, motive and opportunity are now all in place.

As Angela Knight, chief executive of APCIMS commented: "In the next few years we are going to see a revolution in international share trading and a huge increase in the number of people investing. All around the world we see individuals taking the initiative to invest for their own futures."

They may need to be somewhat Jacobin in their approach. The APCIMS reports quoted an observer as suggesting that "while all exchanges are primarily responding to the demands of the institutions, some seem to take more notice of the small investor better than others."

Citizens, to the barricades!

*Stock exchanges and the private investor - an international comparison, by Richard Sankey, City University Business School.

fields.headline: Personal plans still going strong
fields.trailText: They've been tainted by the mis-selling scandal and many experts say the new-fangled stakeholder pension will drive them out of existence,  writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
They've been tainted by the mis-selling scandal and many experts say the new-fangled stakeholder pension will drive them out of existence, writes Rupert Jones.

But for a product supposedly on its last legs, the personal pension is looking remarkably chipper.

Money Management magazine looked at the actual payouts, after all charges, for every personal pension that has been on sale for at least five years, and found that the top performers have been delivering very good returns indeed, fuelled by strong stock market growth and the move towards lower charges.

The table below shows the top-performing pensions over five, 10 and 15 years based on a monthly contribution of £200, and gives the fund value today and the annual growth (yield). It also highlights the worst performers. The table is split into three categories: with-profits, managed fund and unit linked.

The magazine has dished out "five-star awards" to a selection of companies it says combine particularly good past performance with low charges. Winners in the monthly premium pension category are Abbey National Life, Eagle Star Direct, Edinburgh Fund Managers, Equitable Life, Friends Provident, Gartmore, NFU Mutual and Professional Life.

Winners in the single premium pension category are Abbey National, Colonial, Eagle Star Direct, Friends Provident, NFU Mutual, Standard Life and Wesleyan Assurance.

Despite the hype surrounding stakeholder pensions some financial advisers reckon higher earners and those with more complex financial affairs may feel a personal pension best caters for their needs.

The March edition of Money Management is on sale now price £5.95.
