webTitle: Why half of us are too broke to save

fields.headline: Why half of us are too broke to save
fields.standfirst: The government wants people to buy more Isas and pensions but the truth is few of us can afford it, reports Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: The government wants people to buy more Isas and pensions but the truth is few of us can afford it, reports Patrick Collinson
fields.body:
Put your savings in Isas, build a stakeholder pension for your future, the government tells us. But a survey this week let the cat out of the bag - half of us are too broke to save a penny.

The findings cast a shadow over the possible success of stakeholder pensions, which the government is targeting at people who earn £9,000-£18,000 a year but who don't have a company pension scheme. The survey, from unit trust company M&G, reveals that 46% of the UK's population spend everything they have in order to make ends meet.

Month in, month out saving is a luxury few can afford, with only one in three adults saving on this basis. As the survey reveals, 25m adults - 54% of the UK's population - have less than £500 in savings stashed away.

Many people want to save, but say that on their incomes it is simply not an option. This is particularly true of adults in the social grades DE, young couples and young families, with 67% saying that all their money goes on paying household bills. The willingness is there, but the means are not.

"I can't afford to put £40 a month into a pension. I don't have that sort of money over," said one of the 2,000 respondents to the survey, carried out by polling organisation Mori.

M&G's Jeffrey Mushens says: "It reveals a savings apathy that is endemic of the whole adult population and not con-fined to a particular age group, sex or even social grouping."

Someone who earns £12,000 a year has a monthly take-home of £790. Even someone who earns £18,000 a year (at the top end of the government's stakeholder pension target market) takes home £1,120 a month. Mortgage payments, typically around £350-£400 per month for a £70,000 home, or council rents (£250 per month for a 3-bed flat in South London) eat up a large chunk of income.

Throw in travel or car costs, "rip-off Britain" prices on the high street, and it's little wonder that so few people in the UK save. Where they will find the money to put into a stakeholder pension, even though they will start at £20 a month, is anybody's guess.

Not surprisingly, the most popular method that most Britons use to build up a future nest-egg is not Isas or pensions but lottery tickets. Seven in 10 people buy lottery tickets each week, with many buying £5-£10 worth each time, according to the survey.

Nonetheless, take-up of stakeholder schemes could be high - but the buyers may not be who the government expects. The rules allow, for the first time, someone who has no taxable income to contribute to a scheme and enjoy the tax privileges that go with it. Already financial advisers to the wealthy have identified this as a huge new opportunity for tax avoidance. What is likely to happen is that high-earning men in their 50s who are taking maximum advantage of their existing pension tax breaks will set up schemes in their non-working wife's name, and pay in as much as possible.

So stakeholders may be a "success" - but only because they are being manipulated by high earners. The DSS is aware of the loophole, but believes the resulting loss of rev-enue will not be significant.

Perhaps the government is hoping that even though most low earners don't have any spare cash to put into a pension, there are a substantial number of "can save, won't save" individuals who will be tempted to start putting aside money for the future.

But here the M&G survey provides little comfort. It shows that many of us adopt an ostrich mentality. Nearly two-fifths of the population say that they live for the day and save the minimum possible in order to finance their current standard of living.

The 18-24 year old is the least likely to save. "You just want holidays and a nice car and nice clothes and you can get them - often on plastic - and your savings go by the board," said one respondent.

And if they really want something, one in four say they will take out a loan rather than save up. It's not just the young - half of over-55 year olds are what M&G labels as "savings shirkers".

But putting off the day of reckoning is just not worth it, according to M&G. If you want an income of £12,500 a year in retirement, you need to build up a nest-egg of £180,000 at current values. "Getting into the savings habit does require discipline, and getting rid of the 'live for now' mentality may be difficult. People need to wake up to reality today, rather than keeping their fingers crossed and hoping that it's all going to be all right," says M&G.

When debt proves a way of life
Connie Harvey, 28, is part of the generation of low paid public sector workers who find that the sky-high cost of living in the south east makes regular saving impossible, writes Patrick Collinson.

Many are quitting essential jobs such as nursing and community care in the capital because wages have fallen far behind the house price spiral that has taken the average cost of a home in London to £157,000.

Ms Harvey, a mental health worker in Camden, north London, is relatively fortunate. She bought a two-bed flat in Twickenham nearly three years ago - before prices began to rocket. She has a mortgage of £50,000 which costs her £360 per month, but home insurance and council taxes take the real monthly cost of her home to around £500. Travel costs to Camden set her back a further £80 per month.

Once home and travel are paid for, Ms Harvey is left with between £300 and £400 per month to finance all her other expenses. "Debt has just become a way of life. Saving on my money is out of the question," she says. She's been tempted to move out of London to a cheaper area but knows she obtained a reasonably good deal when she bought her flat.

"If I was starting a job now and didn't already own a flat, there's no way I could afford to live in London."

Just as well she doesn't expect to live in Camden. Prices there have now risen to an average of £241,000 - or about 15 times the salary of a nurse working at a local hospital.

fields.headline: Local lads make good
fields.standfirst: A small lender has come out top in a national survey of mortgages, writes Patrick Sherwen
fields.trailText: Your choice of mortgage lender could make a difference of £17,000 over the term of the loan. But how much you end up paying could depend on where you live.
fields.body:
Your choice of mortgage lender could make a difference of £17,000 over the term of the loan. But how much you end up paying could depend on where you live.

A survey of 100 mortgage lenders, published this week by What Mortgage magazine, showed that a gap of £17,000 yawned between the best and the worst lenders based on the cost of repayments on a £70,000 interest only mortgage paid back over 25 years.

The lenders are ranked on the basis of repayments over 10 years and at the top of the bargain loan list was a building society with only three branches, just under 2,000 borrowers, which is ranked only 53rd out of 70 societies in the UK by the size of its asset base - the Lancashire-based Chorley & District (C&D) building society. The cost to a borrower over 10 years is £62,182.32.

Stephen Bullock, C&D chief executive, is delighted to have won for the second year in a row. He put the success down to the society's ability to focus on its strengths. "I can't speak for the other mutuals, and I certainly can't speak for those at the other end of the table, but to put it bluntly we have stuck to our knitting. We concentrate on our services to our core members," he says.

The most expensive lender was the Household Mortgage Corporation (HMC) a subsidiary of Abbey National with a nationwide customer base. An interest-only borrower at HMC with a mortgage on the same terms would pay £69,167.80. Over the full term, What Mortgage calculates the spread between these two lenders would stretch to £17,000.

One important difference is that HMC does a large part of its business with customers who have impaired credit records - such as county court judgements of up to £3,000 - so it is not strictly a mainstream lender. Ron Howell, a sales director at HMC, says the survey is also unfair because much has changed in the last 10 years. "We're not comparing like for like. We're looking back here at the positioning of HMC 10 years ago and that's no longer representative today," he says.

For the first time, the best value mortgage available nationally was a direct lender - First Direct with a repayment figure of £63,098. C&D was the only organisation to beat First Direct over 10 years - by a margin of just under £1,000. Halifax, the country's largest mortgage lender, ranked fourth in the national bank category with a repayment of £66,475.98. But it was not placed at all in the overall rankings. The best national bank in the survey was HSBC. Its borrowers find themselves with a bill that totals £64,978.61 after 10 years.

Eight out of the top 10 lenders overall were mutual societies. Defenders of mutuals are likely to use this as proof of their advantages over banks and plcs. However, since three out of the five most expensive lenders were also mutuals - Chelsea, Ecology and Swansea - the results suggest that the key factor is the quality of management rather than the lender's corporate status.

The result will be a blow for Chelsea, in particular, which is in the midst of a battle against the organisation behind Carpetbagger.com. Any evidence that it cannot maintain competitive rates against rival organisations will weaken its arguments against those seeking windfalls from conversion, notwithstanding its strong annual results announced this week.

Another strong trend was the dominance of the best value table by local lenders such as the C&D (see table). This may put off borrowers who do not live in the area since it may seem an inconvenience to be so far away. The internet is likely to change this situation by giving even the smallest lenders national scope. Mr Bullock of C&D says his society hopes to have a site up and running in no more than 10 weeks. This will provide mortgage quotations and investment information but applications will have to be made on paper.

fields.bodyText: Your choice of mortgage lender could make a difference of £17,000 over the term of the loan. But how much you end up paying could depend on where you live. A survey of 100 mortgage lenders, published this week by What Mortgage magazine, showed that a gap of £17,000 yawned between the best and the worst lenders based on the cost of repayments on a £70,000 interest only mortgage paid back over 25 years. The lenders are ranked on the basis of repayments over 10 years and at the top of the bargain loan list was a building society with only three branches, just under 2,000 borrowers, which is ranked only 53rd out of 70 societies in the UK by the size of its asset base - the Lancashire-based Chorley & District (C&D) building society. The cost to a borrower over 10 years is £62,182.32. Stephen Bullock, C&D chief executive, is delighted to have won for the second year in a row. He put the success down to the society's ability to focus on its strengths. "I can't speak for the other mutuals, and I certainly can't speak for those at the other end of the table, but to put it bluntly we have stuck to our knitting. We concentrate on our services to our core members," he says. The most expensive lender was the Household Mortgage Corporation (HMC) a subsidiary of Abbey National with a nationwide customer base. An interest-only borrower at HMC with a mortgage on the same terms would pay £69,167.80. Over the full term, What Mortgage calculates the spread between these two lenders would stretch to £17,000. One important difference is that HMC does a large part of its business with customers who have impaired credit records - such as county court judgements of up to £3,000 - so it is not strictly a mainstream lender. Ron Howell, a sales director at HMC, says the survey is also unfair because much has changed in the last 10 years. "We're not comparing like for like. We're looking back here at the positioning of HMC 10 years ago and that's no longer representative today," he says. For the first time, the best value mortgage available nationally was a direct lender - First Direct with a repayment figure of £63,098. C&D was the only organisation to beat First Direct over 10 years - by a margin of just under £1,000. Halifax, the country's largest mortgage lender, ranked fourth in the national bank category with a repayment of £66,475.98. But it was not placed at all in the overall rankings. The best national bank in the survey was HSBC. Its borrowers find themselves with a bill that totals £64,978.61 after 10 years. Eight out of the top 10 lenders overall were mutual societies. Defenders of mutuals are likely to use this as proof of their advantages over banks and plcs. However, since three out of the five most expensive lenders were also mutuals - Chelsea, Ecology and Swansea - the results suggest that the key factor is the quality of management rather than the lender's corporate status. The result will be a blow for Chelsea, in particular, which is in the midst of a battle against the organisation behind Carpetbagger.com. Any evidence that it cannot maintain competitive rates against rival organisations will weaken its arguments against those seeking windfalls from conversion, notwithstanding its strong annual results announced this week. fields.headline: Get shot of cowboys
fields.standfirst: How do you avoid being ripped off for repairs or bilked over building work? Patrick Sherwen has some advice
fields.trailText: If a job's worth doing, it's worth doing wrong, with a nail too short, and a screw too long... don't trust cowboys. So sang Chas 'n' Dave in 1981 for Granada TV's comedy Cowboys, starring the late Roy Kinnear.
fields.body:
If a job's worth doing, it's worth doing wrong, with a nail too short, and a screw too long... don't trust cowboys. So sang Chas 'n' Dave in 1981 for Granada TV's comedy Cowboys, starring the late Roy Kinnear.

Views may differ on how many laughs this series about dodgy tradesmen ever got, but it is certain that even after the court of appeal granted Katherine Saigol compensation of almost three quarters of a million pounds this week, for the "unimaginable stress" she suffered at the hands of a firm of builders, that she was in no mood for jokes.

The decision to renovate her flat in South Kensington, London, led to a nightmare of uncompleted work, a law suit from her fellow residents, the loss of her flat and bankruptcy. No doubt Ms Saigol would have been overjoyed if she could have avoided all this by using the online service for home owners, launched this week, that guarantees to supply high quality contractors.

Web users who go to www.hi-revolution.com will find a database of contractors covering all types of tradesmen including builders, carpenters, electricians, plumbers and roofers.

The list contains 3,000 names but Kim Rehfeld, the founder of the service, says he hopes to build it to 10,000 before the end of the year. Those on the database have passed through a rigorous vetting procedure. The first filter comprises three elements:

They must have been in business for at least three years under the same name; They must have a clean bill of financial health approved by the credit rating agency Dun & Bradstreet.

They must have a clean legal history with no county court judgments against them.

Next, the trader must produce 10 references from former customers which will be checked by hi-revolution. These must cover the quality of the work completed; the timeliness of the job and the tradesmen during the working period; the level of courteousness to the customer; and value for money.

Finally, each tradesman must be a member of the relevant trade association.

Once the customer has picked a contractor from three names provided, they will be interviewed by hi-revolution to find out their reasons for turning down the other two. The vetting procedure is continuous as hi-revolution will contact the customer later to find out if the work was carried out to their satisfaction.

Mr Rehfeld says the idea is based on recommendations by a trusted friend, on a massive scale. Any work done is underwritten by Pinnacle Insurance. "We are the only organisation that is allowed to guarantee our jobs," says Mr Rehfeld, "It's an insurance backed guarantee that comes with the job for free. If, God forbid, the contractor goes out of business five years down the line for example, the job is still covered."

Mr Rehfeld says he is also applying to TrustUK, a website consumer accreditation scheme launched last week by the Consumers' Association to protect web users from rip-off merchants.

The scheme is financed by the traders who pay a commission to hi-revolution for every contract they receive. This will vary between 1.5% for large jobs and 6% for smaller ones. Since Monday, when the site became operational, 150 jobs have been commissioned with values up to £60,000.

Crown Trade, best known for its paints, offers guidance on reputable decorators. The Crown Decorator Link scheme was conceived after a survey said 19% of DIY home-improvers would use a professional if they could find one that seemed suitable.

Those on Crown's list come with four previous customer references and must prove that they carry public liability insurance. Crown says that their traders provide fair and competitive quotes in advance, will not deviate from pre-arranged timescales and treat customers courteously.

As with the hi-revolution scheme, the idea is to offer contractors the incentive of a good stream of business that having their name on the list will ensure. The consumer hotline for the service is 0845-6018383.

fields.headline: Property market pursues pink pound
fields.standfirst: When it comes to housing, gays have very different needs to heterosexual couples, writes Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: In the fictional Manchester of Channel 4's Queer as Folk, lead character Stuart Jones lives in a loft-style shag palace straight out of the pages of an interiors magazine. Reality is following not far behind. This week a south London property developer began marketing £370,000 apartments targeted directly at the gay community.
fields.body:
In the fictional Manchester of Channel 4's Queer as Folk, lead character Stuart Jones lives in a loft-style shag palace straight out of the pages of an interiors magazine. Reality is following not far behind. This week a south London property developer began marketing £370,000 apartments targeted directly at the gay community.

Bosch stainless steel appliances, home gyms, spacious entertaining areas, bedrooms with ensuite bathrooms and separate dressing areas, plus good security systems are what the developer, Sunley Estates, hopes will attract gay men and lesbians to Auckland Heights, its gothic-style apartments in Crystal Palace. Its tongue-in-cheek press pack, labelled "bedrooms for bachelors" lists Elton John, George Michael and Steven Gateley as "high-profile confirmed bachelors" among the 10% of the UK population who are "long term single people" with special housing needs.

The idea of "gay homes" may strike many as bizarre a concept as gay restaurants (can the food be any different?) but Ivan Massow, the millionaire gay financial adviser and one-time London mayoral hopeful, insists there really is a difference.

"Two things mark out gays differently from heterosexuals when it comes to buying houses," he says. "We're not looking at local schools and we're not obsessed with the number of bedrooms. The number of times I've been shunted around developments where they've only thought about families and adding more and more bedrooms. You know that if you buy it, you're going to have to rip out the inside walls. Gay men much prefer huge, open plan loft affairs to boxy bedrooms.

"Gays are much more likely to see beauty in areas which others think are tips. They're not worried about public transport - more often than not we're coming home after the tube has shut. You often see gay men moving to the decaying areas of Manchester, Edinburgh, Bristol and London, buying up dilapidated old Georgian houses. The area then improves and heterosexuals start moving in."

He cites Brixton in South London. "It's a brilliant area where lots of gays live and it used to be fairly cheap. Gays moved in at a time when straight people were terrified about living there."

A postcode and property analysis by his company, Ivan Massow Associates, of its 15,000 mortgage clients found that 70% live in what property researchers Data Geographics classify as "urban venturer" homes. Only 10 % of the whole UK population live in such properties.

The vast majority are in London, Manchester and Edinburgh, although this has more to do with the location of the firm's offices. Within London, certain postcodes predominate. "Stoke Newington is top for lesbians, while rich queens head for Islington, Clapham and Balham. Dalston seems to be the area that's coming up at the moment. Clerkenwell is also big - it's all large open plan spaces and Trade [a gay nightclub] is just round the corner. We also have a lot of clients who have bought in Acton. Perhaps it's a gay man's idea of living in the country."

He's not sure that Auckland Heights will appeal to gays. "Crystal Palace is just not on the gay map," he says, although Sunley says it has already sold a number of apartments to gay purchasers.

The Pink Paper, a gay weekly newspaper, has carried a number of adverts from property agents. One of its most frequent advertisers has been Manchester city council, which targets gays for its council flats close to the Canal Street gay district made famous by Queer as Folk.

Gay letting agents have also sprung up around London's Soho. Outlet began five years ago and has matched up thousands of gays looking for flatshares in the capital, and recently launched a lesbian-only company, Homegirls.

It has on its books around 250 shared accommodation properties at prices from £55pw to £200pw across the city, although it says flatseekers aim largely for central locations. It adds that rooms with single beds tend to stay longer on its books than doubles.

Lesbian and gay accommodation bureau

webTitle: Traffic delay on road to tragedy

fields.headline: Traffic delay on road to tragedy
fields.standfirst: Richard Colbey on the precedent set by a court award to an asthma sufferer brain damaged after an ambulance turned up late
fields.trailText: Richard Colbey on the precedent set by a court award to an asthma sufferer brain damaged after an ambulance turned up late
fields.body:
The award of compensation earlier this month to David and Dawn Feldman, whose wedding car did not turn up on time, will have cheered those of us who have frequently experienced the frustrations caused by unreliable taxi firms.

Coincidentally, at almost the same time, another far more important decision was made on liability when a vehicle turns up late.

The Court of Appeal ruled that Tracey Kent was entitled to at least £362,000 damages for serious brain damage she suffered after an ambulance called to her home took 34 minutes to arrive. She was having a severe asthma attack, which was restricting the supply of oxygen to her brain.

There was evidence that if the ambulance crew had got there and treated her within 14 minutes, which is the national standard for the seven mile journey, or even 20 minutes, she wouldn't have suffered long term harm.

Indeed, Mrs Kent's husband had been assured by the operator that the ambulance would arrive promptly; if he hadn't been told this he would have taken her to hospital himself. The London Ambulance Service argued that it should not be liable as there is technically no duty on the service to actually send out ambulances. There might be circumstances where no ambulance is sent because one simply isn't available. In that situation it might be harsh to impose liability on the service.

However, that wasn't the case here. The court found it was sheer incompetence that led to the delay. Perhaps, not surprisingly, the Court of Appeal thought the need to compensate someone who had suffered catastrophically from a public authority's incompetence outweighed the desirability of protecting that authority from possibly unjustified claims.

Had a decent explanation for the delay, most obviously a serious traffic jam, been advanced then the decision might have been different. However, there was no explanation given here. The judge actually found the ambulance crew had falsified their arrival time in the logbook when they realised the magnitude of what had happened.

The case does set a precedent that could be of assistance to anyone whose condition deteriorates as a result of a late arriving ambulance. Proving that the late arrival was critical will often be very difficult, and it is unlikely damages will be awarded merely for being left in pain while the ambulance is awaited.

The Feldmans' case is likely to be an example many people will want to follow. They had booked their cab four months in advance telling the company, Trafftax, that it was for a wedding. The fare was only to be £4.50, but that makes little difference to liability. Once a contract is made and it is known why the other party requires the service, the other party is liable for the predictable consequences of not providing it.

Here it was the disappointment and disruption to their big day that was caused when they had to beg a lift in a neighbour's clapped out three-wheeler. If they had merely been going to an ordinary party, say, their disappointment would have been less and they would probably not have recovered as much as the £250 they got in this case.

On the other hand, if they had been going to an airport and missed flights, the cost of replacement tickets could be much greater. Companies who try to use notices saying they are not liable for such loss will receive short shrift from the courts. Nor is the passenger obliged to look to their own insurance, rather than the company, for compensation in this situation.

The Feldmans' claim does not really set any precedent, the law was already clear that a taxi company can be liable, though surprisingly there is no similar reported decision.

Taxi companies, like ambulance services, would be well advised to insure against the consequences of failing to turn up, as passengers do clearly have potential rights to compensation when things go wrong.

The quick fix for credit
Credit cards tend to be one of the best methods of borrowing relatively small amounts over relatively short periods. Most offer up to eight weeks' interest-free credit before bills must be settled.

It may also be worth talking to your bank about an authorised overdraft.

For many people the interest rate charged by a credit card is not that important. Around 50% of all cardholders pay off their bill in full each month, and avoid interest charges. For them, a loyalty programme may well be more important.

Many cards let you collect points and redeem them for items in a catalogue. Others have "cashback" schemes based on how much you spend with them.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: Builders warn of new leap in house prices

fields.headline: Builders warn of new leap in house prices
fields.standfirst: A proposal to levy VAT on new homes could add as much as £35,000 to a £200,000 property, reports Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: The cost of newly built homes will shoot through the roof if government plans to tax developers see the light of day, house builders said last week.
fields.body:
The cost of newly built homes will shoot through the roof if government plans to tax developers see the light of day, house builders said last week.

The warning comes as deputy prime minister John Prescott's super-ministry, the department of the environment, transport and the regions, is reported to be pressing the treasury to consider levying VAT on new homes. The move could add as much as £35,000 to the cost of a new £200,000 home, or £10,000 if a suggested plan to harmonise VAT on refurbishment and new building at 7.5% goes through.

Under current rules, new homes and conversions of commercial premises for housing are zero-rated for tax purposes. Renovations of empty homes, on the other hand, are charged at 17.5%, an anomaly that environmental campaigners say encourages developers to build new homes on greenfield sites as opposed to recycling dilapidated properties.

Industry body the House Builders Federation, says the move would neither protect the countryside or stimulate the regeneration of urban sites. "As brownfield sites are often more costly to develop, the effect of VAT would be greater," says a spokesman.

Developers claim that the move would create a surge in house prices as the developers, unable to absorb the cost of the new tax, would pass it on to house buyers.

The lacklustre new build housing market could be sent into decline by extra costs, say builders. The latest official figures show the number of new homes completed in 1999 fell by 1% to 167,800. Supply is the problem: builders claim that there are too few sites to build on and long planning delays prevent new sites coming on stream quickly.

The House Builder's Federation says a hike in VAT could pull the rug out from underneath the industry and lead to a fall in the number of new buildings.

Tony Burton, assistant director of the Council for the Protection of Rural England disagrees: "The additional cost of VAT would be by and large absorbed into the cost of the land."

The price builders are happy to pay for land depends on how much they expect to earn from the houses they plan to build on it, explains Mr Burton. If builders had to pay VAT on new homes they would pay less for the land, he says. "We wouldn't see huge increases in house prices. It is landowners who would be squeezed."

This is not the first time the VAT issue has been discussed as a means of increasing the pace of urban regeneration. The government-appointed body the Urban Taskforce, charged with dreaming up the future for British cities, raised the issue in its report, Towards an Urban Renaissance, published last year. The taskforce, led by celebrity architect Lord Rogers, proposed removing the anomaly.

"Ideally, refurbishment and conversion work should be zero-rated. If EU policy rules this out, we would propose applying the minimum rate of 5% VAT to all housebuilding and conversion. A significant proportion of the extra revenue raised should then be used to fund regeneration and development on recycled land," the report said.

The taskforce proposed the introduction of financial penalties for owners of empty properties and incentives to bring derelict space back into use. Shop owners could be offered a reduction in business rates if they make better use of space over shops, refurbishing empty or derelict floors and turning them into housing.

Tony Burton believes fiscal policy could be used to discourage greenfield development. "We want a creative use of financial carrots and sticks together with a positive use of the planning system. Buildings on greenfield sites could be levied a charge for extra roads, sewage or could go to another urban site."

It is not just saving greenfield sites that is on the government's mind; ministers said last month that too many homes are badly designed. Housing minister Nick Raynsford has signalled the end of the traditional British semi and called for housebuilders to come up with more imaginative dwellings.

The British are too "land greedy" and builders squander large tracts of land on homes that are too far apart. Mr Raynsford told builders: "Some of the most popular, sought after, homes such as Georgian terraces and the Victorian terraces and squares with family gardens were built at four to eight times the number of homes than would typically be built on the same space today. The fact that they have stood the test of time shows that the designers got it right."

Mr Raynsford may want buyers to embrace compact living but in the upper earning brackets buyers are anxious to hang on to their space, says Thirlstone Homes which specialises in bespoke homes.

Inland Revenue figures show nearly 75% of the 2,600 people who earned more than £1m last year worked for their fortunes. Of these, 65% are based in the south-east. Thirlstone Homes claims they buy customised new homes.

The Urban Taskforce stopped short of recommending the introduction of a tax on greenfield sites. Instead it said the planning system remains the most productive tool for managing land.

While the government's response isn't expected until the autumn, revised planning guidance for local authorities is imminent. Its release will no doubt spark a further round of mud-slinging as the battle over where we should live rages on.
fields.bodyText: The cost of newly built homes will shoot through the roof if government plans to tax developers see the light of day, house builders said last week. The warning comes as deputy prime minister John Prescott's super-ministry, the department of the environment, transport and the regions, is reported to be pressing the treasury to consider levying VAT on new homes. The move could add as much as £35,000 to the cost of a new £200,000 home, or £10,000 if a suggested plan to harmonise VAT on refurbishment and new building at 7.5% goes through. Under current rules, new homes and conversions of commercial premises for housing are zero-rated for tax purposes. Renovations of empty homes, on the other hand, are charged at 17.5%, an anomaly that environmental campaigners say encourages developers to build new homes on greenfield sites as opposed to recycling dilapidated properties. Industry body the House Builders Federation, says the move would neither protect the countryside or stimulate the regeneration of urban sites. "As brownfield sites are often more costly to develop, the effect of VAT would be greater," says a spokesman. Developers claim that the move would create a surge in house prices as the developers, unable to absorb the cost of the new tax, would pass it on to house buyers. The lacklustre new build housing market could be sent into decline by extra costs, say builders. The latest official figures show the number of new homes completed in 1999 fell by 1% to 167,800. Supply is the problem: builders claim that there are too few sites to build on and long planning delays prevent new sites coming on stream quickly. The House Builder's Federation says a hike in VAT could pull the rug out from underneath the industry and lead to a fall in the number of new buildings. Tony Burton, assistant director of the Council for the Protection of Rural England disagrees: "The additional cost of VAT would be by and large absorbed into the cost of the land." The price builders are happy to pay for land depends on how much they expect to earn from the houses they plan to build on it, explains Mr Burton. If builders had to pay VAT on new homes they would pay less for the land, he says. "We wouldn't see huge increases in house prices. It is landowners who would be squeezed." This is not the first time the VAT issue has been discussed as a means of increasing the pace of urban regeneration. The government-appointed body the Urban Taskforce, charged with dreaming up the future for British cities, raised the issue in its report, Towards an Urban Renaissance, published last year. The taskforce, led by celebrity architect Lord Rogers, proposed removing the anomaly. "Ideally, refurbishment and conversion work should be zero-rated. If EU policy rules this out, we would propose applying the minimum rate of 5% VAT to all housebuilding and conversion. A significant proportion of the extra revenue raised should then be used to fund regeneration and development on recycled land," the report said. The taskforce proposed the introduction of financial penalties for owners of empty properties and incentives to bring derelict space back into use. Shop owners could be offered a reduction in business rates if they make better use of space over shops, refurbishing empty or derelict floors and turning them into housing. Tony Burton believes fiscal policy could be used to discourage greenfield development. "We want a creative use of financial carrots and sticks together with a positive use of the planning system. Buildings on greenfield sites could be levied a charge for extra roads, sewage or could go to another urban site." It is not just saving greenfield sites that is on the government's mind; ministers said last month that too many homes are badly designed. Housing minister Nick Raynsford has signalled the end of the traditional British semi and called for housebuilders to come up with more imaginative dwellings. The British are too "land greedy" and builders squander large tracts of land on homes that are too far apart. Mr Raynsford told builders: "Some of the most popular, sought after, homes such as Georgian terraces and the Victorian terraces and squares with family gardens were built at four to eight times the number of homes than would typically be built on the same space today. The fact that they have stood the test of time shows that the designers got it right." Mr Raynsford may want buyers to embrace compact living but in the upper earning brackets buyers are anxious to hang on to their space, says Thirlstone Homes which specialises in bespoke homes. Inland Revenue figures show nearly 75% of the 2,600 people who earned more than £1m last year worked for their fortunes. Of these, 65% are based in the south-east. Thirlstone Homes claims they buy customised new homes. The Urban Taskforce stopped short of recommending the introduction of a tax on greenfield sites. Instead it said the planning system remains the most productive tool for managing land. While the government's response isn't expected until the autumn, revised planning guidance for local authorities is imminent. Its release will no doubt spark a further round of mud-slinging as the battle over where we should live rages on.

webTitle: Take cheaper holidays with home comforts

fields.headline: Take cheaper holidays with home comforts
fields.trailText: If you own a home in the UK, be it a substantial house, a modest flat or even a houseboat, it can be your key to taking cheaper holidays. By joining a home exchange agency and arranging to swap homes with other homeowning holidaymakers from around the world, you can cut accommodation costs from your vacation budget.
fields.body:
If you own a home in the UK, be it a substantial house, a modest flat or even a houseboat, it can be your key to taking cheaper holidays. By joining a home exchange agency and arranging to swap homes with other homeowning holidaymakers from around the world, you can cut accommodation costs from your vacation budget. Savings can also be made on car hire expenses if you agree to exchange cars.

Home exchange holidays offer other benefits too. You get to stay in the comfort of a real home instead of an impersonal hotel or sparsely equipped self-catering accommodation - a particular boon for young families who have easy access to equipment and toys they may otherwise have to hire or lug away with them on holiday.

Home exchange also gives you the chance to get off the beaten track to more unusual places and immerse yourself in another family's local cul ture and lifestyle; home swappers often get to know their counterpart's friends, neighbours and even babysitters for example. Alternatively, it can offer a way of staying in expensive locations you could not otherwise afford.

On the home front, it means that instead of leaving your property empty, it is occupied and cared for by people who, on the basis of mutual trust, are expecting you to do the same for them. Most home insurers see this as a benefit and will cover your home at no extra cost while non-renting exchangers are in residence, but do check with your insurer first. Also inform your motor insurer of your plans before agreeing to exchange cars. Some charge an extra premium to provide cover for exchange drivers while others won't cover US drivers at all.

The quid pro quo of getting a low-cost exchange holiday is the time and effort it takes to arrange. You'll need to find the right exchange partner and prepare a folder containing details of how all your appliances, burglar alarms and so on work, information on local transport, restaurants, places to visit and a list of useful phone numbers.

It's also common for exchangers to arrange for a friend or relative nearby to act as an agent, handing over the keys to your exchange partners and serving as someone they can turn to in emergencies.

Finding an exchange partner is best done through joining a home exchange agency which will list your home and exchange requirements in printed directories and, increasingly, on their websites. They will also provide you with advice on organising a successful exchange. Remember, though, that fixing an exchange is a DIY process - agencies won't do it for you. To get the best chance of finding a suitable exchange, go for an established agency offering a large database of exchange offers across a wide geographical spread. Homelink and Intervac, for example, the largest players in the field, each have more than 12,000 listings spanning more than 50 countries.

Homelink's directory comprises five books of members' listings with photos and contact details published between December and July.

Full international membership, costing £89 plus £10 if you want to include a photo of your home, buys you a copy of all five books, a listing in the next book published after the date you join plus an ongoing listing on Homelink's website which can be altered or deleted when you want.

For £69 plus £10 for a photo, you can opt for an internet-only listing. And, for those who want to swap within Britain, there's the option of UK-only listings with 200-300 members for £12 plus £5 for a photo.

Intervac also prints five books of listings per year plus internet listings, but operates an updating system where a member's listing runs for just two months on both before being deleted. Rhona Nayar of Intervac argues that, as most members fix up their exchanges within a few weeks of being listed, regular updating of the listings makes sure each book contains a fresh batch. "If we left listings going for the year, new members would find they were contacting a high percentage of members who'd already made their arrangements," she says.

A £92 membership package buys a listing in the next available directory, a copy of the directory and two months' internet listing including photos. A repeat listing costs £27 as do copies of previous books.

Other large, reputable agencies include Home Base Holidays (HBH) and Green Theme International. But, as these two belong to the same group and share the same 3,000 or so listings, there is no point in joining both.

If you've got access to the internet, check out agencies' online listings to see what's on offer before joining (anyone can access these listings, but only members can retrieve contact details).

Virtually no types of home are "unexchangeable", say agencies, though you are likely to get more offers if you live near popular tourist spots such as London, Cambridge and Stratford-on-Avon. While having a small property will limit the size of exchange families you can accommodate, location is generally more important than size. And having the perfect home in tip top condition is not necessary. Most families simply want a clean and comfortable base.

If you live in an out of the way place, the key to attract ing exchange offers is to include details of travelling distances to well-known places and play up local attractions in your directory listing. "Remember, North Americans and Australians think nothing of distances, so a US exchanger would consider a place in the Midlands as being close to London, for example," says Lois Sealey of Home Base Holidays.

"The most successful exchangers are those who are proactive and send out many invitations to prospective exchange partners," says Jim Anderson of HomeLink. "Be as flexible as possible. It's more difficult to get a match if you are very specific about the location and time you want."

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Your coverline asked 'Do we really need 360,000 listed buildings?' (February 19). Surely a more relevant, and rather sad, question is why the other 20 million are so bad that they're not worth preserving.
Martin Adams
Much Hadham, Herts
fields.body:
Your coverline asked 'Do we really need 360,000 listed buildings?' (February 19). Surely a more relevant, and rather sad, question is why the other 20 million are so bad that they're not worth preserving.
Martin Adams
Much Hadham, Herts

The contents of last week's cover story were fortunately more balanced than the rhetorical question on the front might have suggested. The answer can be found in a quotation from Chairman Mao: 'The nation that forgets its past forfeits its future.'
Malcolm Airs
Chairman, Institute of Historic Building Conservation, Oxford

Andrea Levy's This Is My England (February 19) should be compulsory reading for PSE courses in British schools. Let's also have Tebbit's criteria for true citizenship available as a reminder of sad old thinking.

I have spent most of my adult life in England, and now that I could move back to my native France I consider myself lucky to be able to share my two countries equally. My dual-nationality children all made mixed or different race marriages. Five grandchildren later, I am more than ever convinced of the enrichment of our lives. But when the ref disallowed a try in Paris last weekend, I knew that it was unfair, disgusting and that we should have won.
Guy Richeux
richeux@clara.net

I wonder how Andrea Levy fares with ethnic-monitoring forms? When faced with 'white, black or other', is there anyone who does not fall in the 'other' category? I have not heard of the country White, or Black. Also, when asked what race I am, the only appropriate answer is human.
Gita Prasad
Norwich

What a refreshing pleasure it was to read Stefan Buczacki's The Good, The Fad And The Ugly (Garden, February 19). I was beginning to think I was the only person in the world who doesn't want a garden where ground that might be used for planting is covered in decking, where the walls or fences are painted bright blue, and where the planting plan is based either on bamboo or tree ferns.
Pete Whittle
Canterbury, Kent

What an old curmudgeon Stefan Buczacki has become. Gardening in England has always been a matter of fashion: just look at Capability Brown, who swept whole landscapes away in creating new gardens. Bamboos, far from being new, were imported by Victorians, along with a host of other exotic imports that make our gardens so rich and interesting. We have always been inclined to 'plonk something alien' into our gardens. This is the English tradition.
Tony Danford
London SE20

Julie Burchill's public vilification of the fashion industry gave me a great sense of relief (February 19). She articulated just about everything I've ever wanted to say on the subject and thus saved me the bother. Thanks.
Rob Childs
Great Cransley, Northants

The Knowledge (February 19) recommends Coleman's mustard, as it 'really is the one'. Taylor's is the only English mustard worthy of mention - it just tastes better. You've got me all hot under the collar now.
ben@haberdasher.demon.co.uk

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: Lights, camera, election
fields.standfirst: Alex Cox knew that politicians meddled with Mexico's films. But he was still astounded by what happened when he played the gringo in Herod's Law
fields.trailText: Alex Cox knew that politicians meddled with Mexico's films. But he was still astounded by what happened when he played the gringo in Herod's Law
fields.body:
In Mexico I am thought of as an actor rather than a director, and in late 1998 I was offered the second lead in a movie called The Law and the Gun. This was filmed in a fake town in a forest of giant cacti about an hour from Tehuacan, a city in southern Mexico. The story concerns a humble rubbish dump operative hired by the ruling political party to fill in as temporary mayor after his predecessor has been mysteriously killed.

The actor playing the mayor was Damian Alcazar, whom I had directed in Highway Patrolman. Damian is a brilliant actor - intuitive, intelligent - and one handsome dude. The director was Luis Estrada, known as "el Perrito", who had previously directed two regular films, The Long Road to Tijuana and Bandidos, and a weirder third one, Ambar.

Luis is popular within Mexico's film community, but at the time he was viewed as a not-great director embarking on his final film. Quite early in the shoot it was apparent this was not the case. First, the script - by four writers including Luis - is good: a satire on political corruption in the 40s with modern parallels. Second, the cast, assembled by Claudia Becker, Mexico's top casting director, is one of the best I've ever seen. And third, Luis was going for broke: encouraging us to be both serious and mad. "If the whole film is like this it will be quite insane," I wrote in my diary.

At this stage I didn't know what the film was about, having only - in true coarse actor fashion - read the scenes in which my character, the villainous "Gringo", appeared.

The film wrapped just before Christmas. In February 1999 I was back in Mexico playing a bent cop in another film. Luis showed me an early edit of The Law and the Gun, now called Herod's Law after a Mexican saying, "O te chingas, o te jodes" (politely, screw or be screwed). The film seemed long, but good, and I was delighted that all the Gringo's scenes had made it to the screen.

Cut to last September. Luis had asked for my help in translating the screenplay into English, so I was in Mexico again. The film was tighter, and there was already a buzz about it. The word was that Herod's Law was very funny, and was about to run into serious political trouble.

Mexican cinema has a sensitive relationship with politics. The industry receives considerable support from the government, which views film as a serious art form and cultural ambassador. Along with this support comes a certain deference and self- censorship.

Until the late 80s, foreign films shot in Mexico had state censors on the set, and there was an unspoken prohibition against showing potent images such as the president's face or the national flag. Then, in 1989, the talented director Jorge Fons secretly made a brilliant picture called Rojo Amanecer (Red Sunrise), about the government's massacre of students on the eve of the 1968 Olympics. President Salinas de Gortari (currently a fugitive in Dublin while his drug-money-laundering brother Raul resides in Almoloya jail) tried to ban it, only to be defeated by a wave of intellectual and popular protest. Rojo Amanecer eventually received wide distribution, and was popularly viewed as having broken the back of state censorship.

But Salinas had his revenge. His signature on the North American Free Trade Agreement unleashed a flood of American pictures into the domestic market. Simultaneously the Americans threatened to sue Mexico and Canada, claiming that state support of cinema was a restraint of trade. In just a few years, Mexican cinema was driven to the wall, unable to compete with a massive influx of gringo movies that distributors could pick up cheaply. Several Mexican directors gave up on their own country and moved to Hollywood. The success of Alfonso Arau's Like Water for Chocolate meant nothing: it was simply a "calling card" so that its director could join the drift to LA.

By the end of last year, a confrontation over Herod's Law was imminent. Unlike Highway Patrolman - where we agreed not to show the actual Mexican highway patrol, but to create a fictitious one - Luis's picture pulled no punches. It named the ruling party, the PRI; showed the PRI's bloodstained colours (not coincidentally, the colours of the Mexican flag); and accused it of corruption and political assassination. In a completely credible scene, the state governor (Ernesto Gomez Cruz) instructs his assistant (the formidable Pedro Armendariz Jr) to murder a party rival who has secured the presidential nomination. The parallels with Luis Colosio and Francisco Ruiz Massieu - PRI officials killed, allegedly, on the orders of the Salinas brothers - are lost on no one.

In December, Luis told me that he had been offered distribution by a major Mexican distributor - on condition that he delay the film's release until after the presidential election, due this July. The head of the company also owned a vast TV conglomerate and - like all Mexico's billionaires - was one of the ruling party's faithful. Could a comedy set in the 40s really unseat a power bloc that has never lost a presidential election?

It seemed unlikely. But there was fear in the air. Luis refused to delay the film's release. A week later, Herod's Law was screened unannounced by the financier, the state film board Imcine. The screenings were not advertised. After two days the run was cancelled and the film was canned.

In Hollywood, that would be that. Many are the films that the studios have financed, then turned against and stashed in dusty vaults. But films in Mexico aren't just about money or corporate politics. They're also about art, and the right of artists to be heard. The leading lady, the valiant Leticia Huijara, organised a campaign against Imcine's suppression of Herod's Law. The actors all sent faxes of protest to the appropriate authorities. And somehow a miracle occurred. Imcine washed its hands of the whole business, and gave Luis the negative of his film. He was to distribute it himself, if he could. If the film made money, Luis would then repay Imcine's investment.

That seemed like a tall order. I once "four-walled" a film of Borges's Death and the Compass. "Four-walling" means you rent the cinema and pay for the prints and adverts yourself. It is a thankless, time-consuming task. You cannot possibly compete with the majors, or even the minors. There is little money to be made.

But, for Herod's Law, a second miracle happened. I don't mean the premiere at Sundance, where it won the best Latin American picture prize (though this was good news), but the mysterious appearance of an "angel" who offered Luis enough money to strike 250 prints and open the picture nationwide.

That's a lot of prints. Herod's Law opened more widely, with more fanfare and more full-page ads, than any previous Mexican film. I went to Mexico City for the opening a week ago. The media reaction (apart from those papers that ignored the film) was generally good. I accompanied Luis, Claudia and Damian to two screenings, and the public response was even better. The houses were 90% full; the audience roared with laughter at the awful goings-on, booed the gringo, and applauded at the end.

The movie has confirmed Luis Estrada as a major directorial talent. One hopes he will not decamp to the US but continue making films in Mexico, whose cinema can only benefit from his particular brand of irony.

But there is something strange about his big break. Normally a distributor would be anxious to publicise itself, especially if it had just embarked upon the most ambitious opening campaign in Mexican film history. Yet no name appears on the posters or in the film. The only credit is for Luis's company, Bandidos Films, whose empire consists of two rented rooms in Churubusco Studios.

The distributor of Herod's Law is behaving with unusual modesty - keeping itself a secret, almost. But secrets are hard to keep, and there is speculation that the financial entity behind this release has a stake not only in the film but in the outcome of the July election.

It would not be surprising if this angel were connected to one of the opposition parties. Of these, the left-wing PRD has little money, while the right-wing PAN has lots of money (some of it allegedly from the United States: the PAN's presidential candidate is the former head of Coca Cola in Mexico).

Can a film make a political difference? Hard to say. Rojo Amanecer was certainly part of a wave of greater artistic freedom, but the PRI remained in power all the same. Even a work as brilliant as Peter Watkins's The War Game had little political impact, and was forgotten last year in the BFI's list of 100 influential British films.

But somebody - previously an importer of American films, they say, "trying out" a Mexican movie for the first time - is paying for all those 35mm prints, double-page newspaper ads, TV commercials and cinema rentals.

It would be ironic if Luis's film - which comes from a leftist, progressive viewpoint - helps bring down a reactionary, repressive government - so that a more reactionary, more repressive regime even more acceptable to the gringos can take its place.

But isn't that Herod's Law?

At this stage I didn't know what the film was about, having only - in true coarse actor fashion - read the scenes in which my character, the villainous "Gringo", appeared. The film wrapped just before Christmas. In February 1999 I was back in Mexico playing a bent cop in another film. Luis showed me an early edit of The Law and the Gun, now called Herod's Law after a Mexican saying, "O te chingas, o te jodes" (politely, screw or be screwed). The film seemed long, but good, and I was delighted that all the Gringo's scenes had made it to the screen. Cut to last September. Luis had asked for my help in translating the screenplay into English, so I was in Mexico again. The film was tighter, and there was already a buzz about it. The word was that Herod's Law was very funny, and was about to run into serious political trouble. Mexican cinema has a sensitive relationship with politics. The industry receives considerable support from the government, which views film as a serious art form and cultural ambassador. Along with this support comes a certain deference and self- censorship. Until the late 80s, foreign films shot in Mexico had state censors on the set, and there was an unspoken prohibition against showing potent images such as the president's face or the national flag. Then, in 1989, the talented director Jorge Fons secretly made a brilliant picture called Rojo Amanecer (Red Sunrise), about the government's massacre of students on the eve of the 1968 Olympics. President Salinas de Gortari (currently a fugitive in Dublin while his drug-money-laundering brother Raul resides in Almoloya jail) tried to ban it, only to be defeated by a wave of intellectual and popular protest. Rojo Amanecer eventually received wide distribution, and was popularly viewed as having broken the back of state censorship. But Salinas had his revenge. His signature on the North American Free Trade Agreement unleashed a flood of American pictures into the domestic market. Simultaneously the Americans threatened to sue Mexico and Canada, claiming that state support of cinema was a restraint of trade. In just a few years, Mexican cinema was driven to the wall, unable to compete with a massive influx of gringo movies that distributors could pick up cheaply. Several Mexican directors gave up on their own country and moved to Hollywood. The success of Alfonso Arau's Like Water for Chocolate meant nothing: it was simply a "calling card" so that its director could join the drift to LA. By the end of last year, a confrontation over Herod's Law was imminent. Unlike Highway Patrolman - where we agreed not to show the actual Mexican highway patrol, but to create a fictitious one - Luis's picture pulled no punches. It named the ruling party, the PRI; showed the PRI's bloodstained colours (not coincidentally, the colours of the Mexican flag); and accused it of corruption and political assassination. In a completely credible scene, the state governor (Ernesto Gomez Cruz) instructs his assistant (the formidable Pedro Armendariz Jr) to murder a party rival who has secured the presidential nomination. The parallels with Luis Colosio and Francisco Ruiz Massieu - PRI officials killed, allegedly, on the orders of the Salinas brothers - are lost on no one. In December, Luis told me that he had been offered distribution by a major Mexican distributor - on condition that he delay the film's release until after the presidential election, due this July. The head of the company also owned a vast TV conglomerate and - like all Mexico's billionaires - was one of the ruling party's faithful. Could a comedy set in the 40s really unseat a power bloc that has never lost a presidential election? It seemed unlikely. But there was fear in the air. Luis refused to delay the film's release. A week later, Herod's Law was screened unannounced by the financier, the state film board Imcine. The screenings were not advertised. After two days the run was cancelled and the film was canned. In Hollywood, that would be that. Many are the films that the studios have financed, then turned against and stashed in dusty vaults. But films in Mexico aren't just about money or corporate politics. They're also about art, and the right of artists to be heard. The leading lady, the valiant Leticia Huijara, organised a campaign against Imcine's suppression of Herod's Law. The actors all sent faxes of protest to the appropriate authorities. And somehow a miracle occurred. Imcine washed its hands of the whole business, and gave Luis the negative of his film. He was to distribute it himself, if he could. If the film made money, Luis would then repay Imcine's investment. That seemed like a tall order. I once "four-walled" a film of Borges's Death and the Compass. "Four-walling" means you rent the cinema and pay for the prints and adverts yourself. It is a thankless, time-consuming task. You cannot possibly compete with the majors, or even the minors. There is little money to be made. But, for Herod's Law, a second miracle happened. I don't mean the premiere at Sundance, where it won the best Latin American picture prize (though this was good news), but the mysterious appearance of an "angel" who offered Luis enough money to strike 250 prints and open the picture nationwide. That's a lot of prints. Herod's Law opened more widely, with more fanfare and more full-page ads, than any previous Mexican film. I went to Mexico City for the opening a week ago. The media reaction (apart from those papers that ignored the film) was generally good. I accompanied Luis, Claudia and Damian to two screenings, and the public response was even better. The houses were 90% full; the audience roared with laughter at the awful goings-on, booed the gringo, and applauded at the end. The movie has confirmed Luis Estrada as a major directorial talent. One hopes he will not decamp to the US but continue making films in Mexico, whose cinema can only benefit from his particular brand of irony. But there is something strange about his big break. Normally a distributor would be anxious to publicise itself, especially if it had just embarked upon the most ambitious opening campaign in Mexican film history. Yet no name appears on the posters or in the film. The only credit is for Luis's company, Bandidos Films, whose empire consists of two rented rooms in Churubusco Studios. The distributor of Herod's Law is behaving with unusual modesty - keeping itself a secret, almost. But secrets are hard to keep, and there is speculation that the financial entity behind this release has a stake not only in the film but in the outcome of the July election. It would not be surprising if this angel were connected to one of the opposition parties. Of these, the left-wing PRD has little money, while the right-wing PAN has lots of money (some of it allegedly from the United States: the PAN's presidential candidate is the former head of Coca Cola in Mexico). Can a film make a political difference? Hard to say. Rojo Amanecer was certainly part of a wave of greater artistic freedom, but the PRI remained in power all the same. Even a work as brilliant as Peter Watkins's The War Game had little political impact, and was forgotten last year in the BFI's list of 100 influential British films. But somebody - previously an importer of American films, they say, "trying out" a Mexican movie for the first time - is paying for all those 35mm prints, double-page newspaper ads, TV commercials and cinema rentals. It would be ironic if Luis's film - which comes from a leftist, progressive viewpoint - helps bring down a reactionary, repressive government - so that a more reactionary, more repressive regime even more acceptable to the gringos can take its place. But isn't that Herod's Law?

fields.headline: English smoothie
fields.standfirst: Wedgwood is synonymous with fine porcelain. But by the 90s, Jasper - the firm's trademark design - looked fogeyish. Now, after a radical face-lift, the range is set to seduce style-seekers once more. Charlotte Abrahams on the rebirth of a classic
fields.trailText: Stoke, circa 1775: Josiah Wedgwood invents Jasper clay, marking the first key innovation in ceramic composition since the Chinese discovered porcelain some 1,000 years before. Gritty blue cabinet pieces with white relief decoration become the height of fashion, and an English institution is born.
fields.body:
Stoke, circa 1775: Josiah Wedgwood invents Jasper clay, marking the first key innovation in ceramic composition since the Chinese discovered porcelain some 1,000 years before. Gritty blue cabinet pieces with white relief decoration become the height of fashion, and an English institution is born.

Wedgwood retail concession, circa 1990: Sophie and Richard choose a set of Jasper vases for their wedding list; Great Aunt Ethel buys yet another Jasper figure to put in the corner cupboard. Young, fashion-conscious shoppers cut through on their way to Habitat.

Stoke 2000. I am standing in an over-heated office at Wedgwood headquarters, looking at a collection of contemporary, functional tableware. No blue, no white mouldings, no pieces designed for display only. Just a collection of nine black-and-white items to use and enjoy. These are ceramics for the 21st century: the modern face of Jasper. Sophie, Richard and Great Aunt Ethel may need a dose of smelling salts to help them recover from the shock, but, frankly, they've had more than 200 years of Josiah's vision of Jasper, and now it's time to do something new.

Enter Nick Munro, an industrial designer and creator of simple, modern pieces such as flat-but-round teapots and wire-spiral egg cups. His brief was to break out of classical Jasper and make it more relevant for today. There were strict rules about the number of items he could produce - and even stricter deadlines - but, other than that, he could do as he liked.

And he did. Looking at the pieces in isolation, you don't see anything all that radical. But looking at them on the factory floor, surrounded by sets of floral tableware and traditional Jasper trinkets (they have no intention of stopping production - they go a bomb among tourists who want to buy a little bit of England), then Nick Munro's take on Jasper seems very radical indeed.

I was hoping to hear stories of battles between blue-and-white-loving Luddites and thrusting creatives with visions of the future, but apparently not. Jill Sharrock, Wedgwood's creative director, admits to some problems in the early stages. "In theory, persuading people in the company that Jasper needed a face-lift wasn't difficult," she says, "but persuading people to take action, to take the risk, was." But once the project was underway, it seems everything went swimmingly. In fact, according to Munro, everyone's been happily on-message and the whole project has been a joy from beginning to end.

If this is true, then Munro can afford some self-congratulation. He could have been a remote designer, a guy in an unstructured suit who sent new-fangled ideas down the phone lines and expected the workers to produce. But that isn't his way. He has been on site almost all the time, and the project has been conceived and created on the factory floor. "I've never found, in all the things that I've done, that being remote from the factory is an efficient way of developing a project," he explains. "Quite the opposite. It takes much longer, it's much more expensive and you don't get what you want."

And he does like to get what he wants. Not that he's a bully; he has a great respect for the craftsmanship of mass-production and believes very strongly in meeting everyone involved and listening to their points of view. But when he knows something's right, then he expects to get it done. For example, one of the main problems with traditional Jasper, as he saw it, was that gritty, fingernails-down-the-blackboard texture - a real off-putter in this sensuous age. So Munro told Wedgwood to buy a few Vibro machines (chipping-filled drums that smooth out roughness by shaking violently) at a cost of about £50,000 each.

Another problem was the perceived impracticality of old- style Jasper, which, because it's rough, is thought to stain - hardly a great asset in a working teapot. So Munro decided to glaze the insides of his pieces (see photograph, p47). However, the problem with glazes is that millions of tiny particles float around in the air. If they're white, that's okay, but if black, they threaten to ruin anything in their path. But Munro was adamant and the glaze stayed. And did it cause a problem?

"Probably," he smiles. This re-launch of Jasper has been a long process (I first heard about it 18 months ago, and by then it was well underway) and has cost Wedgwood a considerable amount of money, so you can't help wondering why they didn't just ditch Jasper as a has-been and turn to something more intrinsically modern.

The answer, of course, lies in its history. All that historical baggage may be the reason things stood still for so long, but it's also the reason that Wedgwood still has a reputation worth a costly re-launch. "It's their icon," Munro explains. "If you took that historic blue-and-white thing away, it wouldn't be any different as a company from Royal Doulton or whatever. Wedgwood invented it."

Munro is keen on the history thing; keen to point out that Josiah Wedgwood was a real pioneer. "The irony is," he says, "that the tradition of the company really is all about change. That is fundamental to the success of it originally. It was a very competitive company, very commercial, very switched on with regard to marketing and PR, skilful in product development, innovative, all that.

"But when one looked at some of the products that are in the company's portfolio right now, that tradition was just not there. The opportunity with this project was to say, 'Well hang on, we don't have to do that, there's a big opening to do something that really is closer to the spirit of the business than some of the products which are normally thought of as defining what the company's about."

So, Sophie, Richard, Aunt Ethel, and all you tourists who think you can capture England in a piece of scratchy blue china, you need to think again. If Josiah Wedgwood could see that bookend he'd turn in his grave. But this stuff, this is very Wedgwood.

Munro has done his time in the archive, and each of the pieces (with the exception of the cat bowl, which was put in to partner the dog bowl) has historical precedence. And as for the colour? Well, it doesn't say anywhere that Jasper should be blue with white relief - in fact, the stone colour Munro has used in this collection is Jasper clay in its original, undyed state. (That no one had considered using the clay in its natural state before is truly amazing.)

The colour of the collection is interesting and does give it the unmistakable stamp of Nick Munro - those black-and-white tea cups are straight out of his personal design studio - but while he does accept this, he also points out that changing the colour of Jasper was the obvious thing to do and, given the stone colour of the clay, black was the only choice. "There would have to have been a very good reason for doing something else," he says. He also believes he has stayed true to the tradition of innovation.

"Technically," he says, "the project has a lot of genuine merit. The vases aren't going to transform anyone's idea of what a vase should be, that wasn't the point. But as a Jasper vase, it's quite an interesting project - the spiral shape [inspired by Keith Murray's work for Wedgwood in the 30s] employed the full resources of the computer-aided design department and the mould had to be re-designed to accommodate it."

Listening to Munro and the Wedgwood team list the collection's historical credentials, you realise that they feel forced to justify the legitimacy of what they are doing lest they provoke a public outcry. Classic Jasper is, after all, a British institution, and even those of us who would never dream of buying a piece can still experience feelings of nostalgia for those little cameos and ashtrays that cluttered our grandparents' homes.

There is little doubt that this new collection is a triumph - it is everything a contemporary ceramic collection should be, with Wedgwood quality on top - but they have taken a risk. Strong sales are not a certainty. The modern young things at which the Nick Munro Jasper collection is aimed are not in the habit of thinking Wedgwood when they shop for tableware. Preconceptions formed over generations are not changed overnight. And what about that traditional market of county couples and maiden aunts? What will they make of relief- mould-free black-and-white Jasper? Has Wedgwood regained its past only to ruin its future?

Jill Sharrock thinks not. "New directions are risky," she says, "but what Nick has produced is so simple in its modernity that I believe it is a modern classic. I do not believe the range is contrived or difficult, but handles sculptural, functional form in a way that good design transcends time. Context will make the product modern or traditional."

And clever marketing will make it a success or failure

Prices for the items pictured in this article are as follows: infuser teapot, £65; cup and saucer, £35; cat bowl, £50, lemon juicer, £60; small spiral vase, £55. Prices for the collection range from £35-£80.
