fields.headline: It must be love...
fields.standfirst: Why else would a dog be treated to such luxuries as a Paul Smith bowl, a Campari soda and its own pet goldfish? Mock not, says Jon Ronson, this is an affair of metaphysical communication we're dealing with here
fields.trailText: Why else would a dog be treated to such luxuries as a Paul Smith bowl, a Campari soda and its own pet goldfish? Mock not, says Jon Ronson, this is an affair of metaphysical communication we're dealing with here
fields.body:
At first glance, the dog lovers described below might look as if they treat their animals as if they were their own children. But they pour scorn on that comparison, and so do I. The fact is, a child is human and a dog is a creature. There is an intriguing world of a difference. When we say, "Fetch", and the dog fetches, we are reaching out to a whole other species and finding common ground.

We have always been desperate to forge contact with other worlds, something outside humanity that can give us context. Sadly, God, ghosts and space aliens have so far been loath to break their indomitable silences. Dogs are the only non-humans among us that are willing - indeed excited - to lollop over and provide some inter-speciel accord.

Far from being a child replacement, the dog offers us an insight into our place in the infinite. We have conquered, through communication, a creature with inhuman characteristics, with a whole different set of genes and chemicals. We have made them love us so much that they'll wait at the window for us to come home; they'll even lie on our graves when we die. This is profound and transcendental.

It's hardly surprising, then, that we sometimes go that extra mile and buy them a few little gifts - Gucci dog-collars and pet aromatherapy balms - or even give them their own bedrooms with specially designed, dog-friendly wallpaper and bedclothes.

Anti-dog naysayers may shun this analysis, but how about this: experiments undertaken by Professor Rupert Sheldrake have proved beyond any doubt that dogs possess psychic abilities way beyond our comprehension. This is how the experiment works. Sheldrake gives his dog-owning assistant a bleeper. She then goes about her daily duties - she sits in a cafe, or visits friends, or gets her hair cut. In the meantime, her dog is filmed with a hidden camcorder as he goes about his canine routine. Some random hours later, Sheldrake, sitting in a third location, bleeps the assistant. This is her signal to come home. The moment this happens, the dog instantaneously leaps to the window and waits, tongue a-lolling, until she pulls up in the driveway. The success rate of this experiment is roughly 80%. (The two times out of 10 that it fails, by the way, is most often explained by the nearby presence of a bitch on heat. Only sexual opportunities come between a dog and its owner.) Dog lovers, such as those in these photographs, will not be surprised by these findings. Affectionate little psychic moments occur every day. "Shall I give him a walk?" they think to themselves. And the dogs immediately leap to their feet and rush towards the door.

It could have all gone so wrong. We cannot overlook the fact that dogs have it well within their power to tear chunks out of us with their teeth so, when an inter-speciel equanimity occurs, it is only right that we reward it.

But in some other countries, it has all gone so badly wrong. They are killing the dogs in Bucharest. Nobody opposes this systematic, state-sanctioned slaughter programme. Diseased or not, they are all fair game. Why should this be? On a dog-to-dog basis, they are, on the surface, no less delightful than our own. They are similarly droopy, they carry themselves with an adorable bathos. They are not particularly dangerous - most are too hungry to muster up the requisite energy needed to attack. They just lie there in wastelands in the sun. Yet their death-row status is unanimously endorsed. The Romanian people are alarmed by the dogs, and so the dogs must die. I am alarmed by them, too. They are in some ways different from the dogs that bound up to me on Hampstead Heath. What makes the dogs of Bucharest so horrifying is their sheer volume. There are too many of them. In bulk, anthropomorphism cannot take place. They are menacing strangers without endearing traits. Their crime is that they are not owned.

It is our ownership of dogs, our control over them, that endears us to them. "No!" we shout. "No! No! No!" And then we whack them on the nose. This is very different from our relationship with, say, horses. We do not like dogs to possess an overpowering majesty. We do not stand back in awe while they gallop across fields. If dogs behave like horses (ie with uncontrolled majesty), we yell, "Come back! No! No!" And then we whack them on the nose. I witness this nose-whacking on a daily basis - in the cafe, or on the street. Who hasn't? Most often, this punishment seems too harsh for the crime. The nose-whackers are not common thugs. They are you and I. This makes me presume that nose-whacking is not a rational act. It is not something that we humans reluctantly do to domesticate our dogs. I think that we are helplessly drawn to the act of nose-whacking in as profound a way as the dogs are drawn to the window to wait for us to come home. The momentum is that of imperialism, of conquering another life form. In this, our relationship with dogs can be perverse and sadistic.

Of course, not all dog-owners are sadistic perverts. The people in these photographs, for instance, seem very nice. Dawna Walter is considered crazy for providing her poodles with dog chairs, dog toys, framed photographs of dog pals and even a little goldfish pet of their own. Others treat their dogs to manicures, Perspex Gucci beds, Paul Smith fauna conditioner, £135 cashmere coats from Browns of South Molton Street, foie gras at Christmas, and Campari and soda after dinner.

Some of them say that being around a dog makes us recognise our own animality. When we see a dog pissing outdoors or jumping a bitch on heat, it reminds us of the animal that lives within us all. But this is disingenuous. We love to anthropomorphise our dogs. We love to humanise them. This is animality-recognition lite. This is tourism. If we really wanted a mirror on our bestial instincts, we wouldn't be killing the dogs in Bucharest. They're the ones that really reflect our animalistic temperament - scrawny and bleak and inhuman and purposeless. But perhaps that's too close to home. Maybe that's why we're really killing them - they remind us too much of the beast that lives within us.

Some say that dog-owners have a lower blood pressure than the rest of us. This is, of course, more proof that owning a dog is nothing like raising a child. I haven't slept in a year-and-a-half since my son was born. My nerves are shattered. Dogs don't do that to you. If they did, you could just whack them on the nose and put them in the shed. The thirtysomething dog-owning couples I see on Hampstead Heath seem a damned sight less stressed out than me.

But I, in turn, seem a damned sight less stressed out than those thirtysomething couples who have neither a baby nor a dog, who wander the paths of the heath without purpose, who are taking nobody but themselves for a walk.

Around a year ago, I approached a woman from Congelton called Barbara McGarry because I wanted to write about the search for her lost sheepdog, Noah. Barbara told me the story. The weather was beautiful the day that Noah vanished. It was a lovely sunny day. But two freak claps of thun der rang out, startling Noah, who bolted over a nine-foot gate. Noah was a popular and well-known dog in the village, and within an hour the police and a hundred locals were searching the fields for him.

I met Barbara two years later. She's a sensible-looking farmer. "This is literally the first day off I've had in two years looking for him," she said. "I've done everything. I've combed the area with scent cloths attached to my body. We've advertised and advertised and searched and searched. I can't believe we haven't found him. I've done silly things. I even wrote to Brigitte Bardot."

She laughed, sadly. "I mean, what could she do in France? But I have to do something every day. The day I wrote to Brigitte Bardot was a low-ebb day." She paused. "And then somebody suggested Camilla." I looked over at Camilla, a dog psychic, sitting in a long purple velvet dress in the corner. She nodded, in all seriousness.

"What does your husband think of this?" I asked Barbara. "He's doing everything he can to make me stop," she said. "He's bought me two llamas, some pygmy goats, a parrot, a cat, lots of other dogs. He says, 'Enough now. Give your love to all these other animals.' But how can I stop? I've even walked the llamas around the countryside hoping Noah will pick up the scent."

"And how do you know that Noah is alive?" I asked Camilla, the dog psychic.

"I've tuned into my spirit guides and Noah's spiritual guides," she replied, "and when he bolted in the thunderstorm he went into a time warp and he became a little boy. He used to be a little boy in a school uniform in a previous life . . ."

Barbara smiled. For a while, Camilla carried on talking about Noah's previous lives. My eyes glazed over. I was finding it hard to follow, and I was annoyed by Camilla's nonsense. "So Noah thought he was a little boy again, so he sped off to a boarding school," she continued. "He found this independent boarding school, and now he's being looked after by a lady in her early 50s, of Swedish or German origin, I feel, and he's being looked after well . . ." Barbara nodded.

"But he would like to come home now," said Camilla. Barbara began to cry. "I've started looking at all the independent boarding schools in my county," she said. "Now I'm starting to go further west . . ."

I left them both that afternoon with bad thoughts for Camilla. How could she keep Barbara hoping, with all that rubbish about time warps? I elected then not to write their story. It was too sad, and Camilla was, for me, too unsympathetic a character.

Now that I recall the tale, I remember something else that Barbara said to me: "You can't help who you fall in love with," she said. "I'm not mad. I didn't plan my emotions. I just happen to have fallen in love with Noah."

You can look at the photographs here and see eccentrics with more money than sense, willing to lavish huge sums on their dogs. Perhaps these photographs tell us something about our current economic boom. But in them I see love affairs; strange love affairs, based on metaphysical communications and the most primordial of human instincts. I see rational people whose hearts have led them in irrational ways

Barking permit

Serena Rees and Joe Corre, of the lingerie store Agent Provocateur, have a wire-haired fox terrier called Roman, a sharp urban hound who nevertheless enjoys lavish attention at the company's London office.

'He sits under the table on a red sheepskin, and I'm sure everyone likes having him around,' says Rees (pictured left). 'But he's not really a designer, diamanté-collar sort of dog.'

One of Roman's two baskets has Vivienne Westwood lining - the celebrated designer is Corre's mother - and he regularly attends a top salon called Peter's Posh Pets for a manicure.

'He looks incredible when he's just been quiffed,' says Rees, who has taken him to several gala openings and drinks parties. Roman also receives a lot of attention on the street.

'Loads of people say, "I used to have one of those toy dogs with a handle and wheels",' says Rees. 'And Japanese people go mad and even film him.'

And Roman does not receive expensive gifts. 'He's not a glitzy dog,' she adds. 'Anyway, I'm sure he wouldn't be seen in Gucci or Prada - although I'm sure he'd make an exception for Hermès.'

Roman has no special favours at suppertime, though she does withhold the Pedigree Chum.

'I can't bear opening the tin. And it makes him fart a lot, which we don't like.' Instead, Roman eats dry food made by Hills. 'We eat organic ourselves, but I'm not about to buy organic food for him. He is loved and cared for; but let's face it, he's a dog.'

The interior designer Cath Kidston, who runs a shop in London's Notting Hill, has a Lakeland terrier called Stanley, upon whom she dotes. 'He's the nearest thing you can get to a live teddy bear,' she says.

Brought up as a dog nut, she has owned Stanley for two years, since she bought him in Gretna Green. 'I'm lucky that I live very close to a park, so we can go for walkies easily,' says Kidston. 'He comes into the shop, then he goes to this lovely lady called Jo, who takes him and 10 friends to the park.' So regal is Stanley that, on the way, he insists on sitting in the front seat of the car.

At home, Kidston treats him 'exactly like a person'. He is allowed on sofas and beds - it helps that his breed doesn't moult. She is careful to give both Stanley and her seven-year-old stepdaughter equal attention, but she no longer takes him to parties. 'It was rather like those people who turn up everywhere with a baby on their hip,' she says.

Foodwise, Stanley has authentic northern tastes - his favourite is tripe. 'Sadly, he loves it. The people before me fed him from the local abattoir - I think he developed a fashionable taste for offal.'

Like the new urban dogs, Stanley is well-groomed - if somewhat reluctantly. 'A fantastic woman called Sharon comes around and gives him a topiary . . . He always seems to be a bit embarrassed afterwards.' And he owns clothes, though Kidston insists that he shies away from designer goods. 'He has a polo-neck jumper that really suits him.'

While he is at the shop, so many people take pictures of Stanley that Kidston is considering a range of T-shirts with his picture on. 'He gets attention wherever he goes,' she says. 'Old ladies love him, and even tough builders coo, "Isn't he cute?" '

Does Stanley cost a lot? 'The dog-walking is the real extravagance, but as I gave up cigarettes, I see it as my old smoking money,' says Kidston. The only time that she feels like disowning him, she confesses, is when he 'wees on sports bags in the park'.

Dawna Walter, a Bostonian who runs the storage chain The Holding Company, spends more than £100 a week on her two magnificent poodles - Sydney and Lola. But the pleasure she takes from her fluffy charges outweighs any misgivings. The dogs receive birthday presents, and 'get to open Paul Smith packaging, which is pretty cool.'

'You do sometimes anthropomorphise,' she says. 'But I am aware that they are dogs and treat them accordingly.' 'They know more people than I do. I walk down the road and people say "Hi" to them, not to me. Kylie Minogue is a friend of Sydney.'

Do they force compromise on to her interior decor? 'I would not have wall-to-wall carpeting, as puppies make mistakes; no poisonous plants, such as poinsettias; and heavily- polished wooden floors often get scratched.' But, despite the pampering, she keeps them in check. 'Dogs are pack animals, and you have to let them know who is the alpha dog in the house, otherwise they walk all over you. I'm the boss here.'

The fact is, a child is human and a dog is a creature. There is an intriguing world of a difference. When we say, "Fetch", and the dog fetches, we are reaching out to a whole other species and finding common ground. We have always been desperate to forge contact with other worlds, something outside humanity that can give us context. Sadly, God, ghosts and space aliens have so far been loath to break their indomitable silences. In the meantime, her dog is filmed with a hidden camcorder as he goes about his canine routine. Some random hours later, Sheldrake, sitting in a third location, bleeps the assistant. We cannot overlook the fact that dogs have it well within their power to tear chunks out of us with their teeth so, when an inter-speciel equanimity occurs, it is only right that we reward it. fields.headline: Healing in Harmony
fields.standfirst: As some of the post-war miracle drugs lose their lustre, complementary medicine - once dismissed as mumbo-jumbo - is gaining ground. Special diets, herbs and massage may never replace life-saving surgery, but a new partnership is growing between orthodox and alternative practitioners. Jerome Burne gives a patient's guide to what to take and who to see
fields.trailText: Last autumn, that mouthpiece of the medical profession, the British Medical Journal, began publishing a peace treaty. It took the form of a 12-part series on complementary medicine. This is the same BMJ that 20 years ago declared, in a dismissive editorial, that alternative medicine "ought to be as extinct as divination by examination of bird's entrails". The BMJ series was a belated recognition of a victory by a ragged guerrilla army that, starting far beyond the medical pale, has gradually marched on the capital and is now sitting around the tables with the generals of the medical empire, discussing exactly how many positions it will have in the new government.
fields.body:
Last autumn, that mouthpiece of the medical profession, the British Medical Journal, began publishing a peace treaty. It took the form of a 12-part series on complementary medicine. This is the same BMJ that 20 years ago declared, in a dismissive editorial, that alternative medicine "ought to be as extinct as divination by examination of bird's entrails". The BMJ series was a belated recognition of a victory by a ragged guerrilla army that, starting far beyond the medical pale, has gradually marched on the capital and is now sitting around the tables with the generals of the medical empire, discussing exactly how many positions it will have in the new government.

Today, every high street has its health-food shop, and it's hard to open a newspaper or a magazine without finding a cure that involves mega doses of vitamin C, a stress-reducing massage or a tincture of St John's Wort. We can buy soya snack bars that claim to fight off both prostate cancer and the menopause, eat ginkgo biloba-enriched crisps that boost the flow of blood to the head, and relax in the evening with a couple of tabs of (perfectly legal) kava kava.

So how has it happened? How have the health irregulars - homoeopaths with their weird belief in minuscule doses, acupuncturists locating undetectable meridians, and herbalists mired in the Middle Ages - conspired to storm one of the great professional citadels? Scientific medicine now seems like some fallen empire. Despite all its pharmacological weaponry and coffers stacked with gold, it is having to make peace with bands of amiable civilians. What is this going to do to our health? Is it a good thing, or have we succumbed to a dreadful delusion?

Part of the explanation lies with Clara, and the hundreds of thousands like her, who found that modern medicine wasn't providing what she wanted, so, sophisticated shopper that she is, took her business elsewhere. A 48-year-old freelance accountant, Clara had gone to her GP complaining of being tired and irritable. She was working very hard and also putting on weight. He prescribed hormone-replacement therapy (HRT). Then she developed irritable-bowel syndrome and was offered steroids. So she went to see the naturopath, Elizabeth Gray Gibaud, who has a practice at the Hale Clinic in London, and specialises in "face diagnosis".

"A particular puffiness beneath the eyes suggested problems with her colon, and a strong cubical fold below the tip of her nose, plus a reddish-brown colour, suggested trouble in the region of her womb," says Gibaud. "A different colouring around her mouth indicated a mineral deficiency, which checked out when I asked about rough skin." So Clara went on a detox diet for six weeks. She found she had various food allergies - to coffee, red wine and wheat - and she took a range of herbs, vitamin supplements and minerals. It was a big success: "I've lost about two-and-a-half stone, my son says I'm a different person, and I'm happier and have more energy than ever before."

This is precisely the sort of thing that orthodox medicine (OM) has for years been lumping with divination. Mere anecdote, say the hardliners, and if the regimen does have an effect then it is probably as a placebo - if you believe that you will get better, then you probably will, however cranky the treatment you get. Where are the clinical trials that show the value of this treatment on a controlled group? What is the active ingredient in the herbs? Large doses of vitamins are just a way of producing expensive urine.

But the Claras took no notice. Guerrilla armies depend on popular support and, while the establishment jeered, the patients voted with their wallets. Five million to nine million of us in the UK use complementary medicine (CM) regularly; two years ago (the last date for which figures are available) at least 15 million CM consultations took place.

Faced with this widespread dissatisfaction among its patients, the tone of the medical empire became more shrill. Here is Dr Eric Rose, of the British Medical Association, responding to a report in 1998 that there were now more complementary practitioners than GPs in the UK: "My main concern is the dogma surrounding this type of medicine. You see some ridiculous claims - eat six tins of stewed rhubarb and you will get better." In-house magazines felt free to be even more disparaging, employing a little racism along the way: "Medications of the mysterious East" is how a columnist writing in Doctor magazine recently described Chinese herbal treatments for eczema. They were, he wrote, "the inscrutable Dr Fu ManChu's magic eczema potion". The echoes of other empires that ignored a rising tide of demand and suffered for it can be heard all too clearly: British Telecom before privatisa tion, British Airways in the face of the smaller and nimbler Virgin, IBM ignoring the threat of the PC.

But the CM irregulars weren't just supplying a need; their style chimed perfectly with wider social changes. The consumer revolution and the rise of the entrepreneur, although possibly distasteful to many of the practitioners personally, meshed perfectly with their philosophy. A greater concern with the body beautiful brought a greater concern with personal health. It was a small step from the fixed weights and the treadmill to vitamins and supplements. What was going on in the gyms and juice bars marched in step with one of the big ideas in medicine in the 80s and early 90s - the link between lifestyle and heart disease. But while OM, in the authoritarian style of the industrial giants of the past, instructed the nation to cut back on fat, the CM irregulars offered a personal service: just as mail-shots target particular postcodes, or loyalty cards enable supermarkets to track your personal spending patterns, so they could satisfy the Claras by tailoring a package for each one.

"People are changing the way they relate to authority figures. The doctor is there to serve you, just as banks and the phone service are." CM practitioners also tapped into one of the greatest sources of medical power since ancient times. Until five years ago, doctors had a lock on medical information. Even though your rash never seemed to clear up or your joints remained painfully stiff, the local doctor was the only one who could diagnose the problem and provide a remedy. That all changed with the advent of the internet.

Suddenly, a wealth of information on every condition imaginable was just a few clicks of a mouse away. Within hours, if you were determined enough, you could know more than your GP about the causes of those blinding headaches and possible remedies. What's more, on the net, the divisions between orthodox and complementary vanish: every treatment is just one of dozens that come up in the window of your search engine. Of course, there are dangers, and misinformation is a problem, but OM's secret weapon, omniscience, had been disabled.

The medical establishment has always liked to claim that its expertise is based on scientific evidence. Treatments are tested and based on the most rigorous research, so the story goes, while beyond their orthodoxy is the world of cranks and charlatans, making wild claims, relying on mere anecdote.

"The greatest appeal of complementary medicine is not scientific or practical," argues Marcia Agnell, editor of the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine and a long-time opponent of alternative medicine. "It is religious. Like most religions, it has charismatic personalities, who instead of doing research or publishing in scientific journals, promote their beliefs in books for the public, largely composed of inspirational testimonials."

But the struggle between the establishment and the health irregulars has not just been a war of words. In the US, the Federal Drugs Administration (FDA) has a long history of taking legal action against those practising CM. And in 1992, the consulting rooms of a nutritionist and doctor Jonathan Wright were raided by armed police officers and FDA officials who took away vitamin and mineral supplements. In Britain, an equally virulent campaign against CM practitioners has been conducted, largely through the media. It peaked about a decade ago when OM mounted what can now be seen as a desperate rearguard action. In 1989, the Campaign Against Health Fraud (CAHF), later renamed HealthWatch, was set up. Modelled on the self-styled "quackbusters" of the American National Council Against Health Fraud, its stated aim was to protect the sick and vulnerable from being exploited by ruthless quacks, peddling unproven and useless or dangerous cures. Its launch was marked by a newspaper article alleging, with no evidence, that "a growing number of women were dying of breast cancer because they were putting themselves in the hands of quacks rather than orthodox specialists". In his remarkably detailed book, Dirty Medicine, which exhaustively chronicles this time, Martin Walker claims that many of those involved in the campaign were linked in various ways with the large pharmaceutical and food companies, which had a vested interest in demolishing any alternative medical approaches that threatened their supremacy.

Walker alleges that talk about scientific testing and rigour was actually a cloak for a far more commercial agenda. He shows how the most relentless rubbishing of alternatives - and the character-assassination of practitioners that went with it - occurred during the years that the Aids drug AZT was being trialled in the UK between the late 80s and 1992. The organisers of an Aids-information group, Positive Health, for instance, were attacked for "exploiting people with Aids". Their crime? Providing a forum to discuss orthodox and alternative treatments, and to organise workshops that taught basic meditation and provided information on diet and vitamins. At the same time, attempts by perfectly respectable scientists to set up proper trials of promising herbal or supplement-based Aids treatments were rejected out of hand.

Perhaps the most compelling example that what was going on was not a battle between science and superstition, but one between establishment power and would-be reformers, is what happened to the Bristol Cancer Help Centre. Based on the idea that your best chance of living with, or even surviving, cancer lay with a healthy, effective immune system, the centre advocated an organic, largely vegetarian diet. By the mid-80s, it was confident enough to agree to a clinical trial of its effectiveness by the Imperial Cancer Research Fund. This looked like one of the few serious attempts to test an alternative approach, yet it proved to be the basis of yet another highly damaging and totally irresponsible assault. In 1990, with maximum publicity, the Lancet published some "interim" results, based on data from only 18 months of a study supposed to last five years. Its devastating conclusion was that women who had been treated with the Bristol Cancer Help Centre's diet were, in fact, twice as likely to die as those who received conventional treatment. The press had a field-day. Headlines such as "Danger in a veggie cure for cancer" and "Double death risk at veg diet cancer clinic" filled the papers.

Over the succeeding weeks, it became clear that the interim report was seriously flawed. Nearly one-third of the patients classified as having been treated at Bristol had visited the centre only once and had not been on any special diet. Even the OM journal, Hospital Doctor, declared the study "a fraud". Eventually, the authors of the report themselves wrote to say they regretted "that their paper created the impression that the Bristol regime worsened patients' chances", but the damage had been done and the credibility of the centre was almost destroyed.

The evidence is overwhelming that CAHF and its allies were not interested in exploring the scientific basis of such CM approaches as focusing on the role of food allergies in chronic disorders. A considerable body of respectable research supports this approach, known as clinical ecology. Yet the 1990 World In Action investigation into Breakspear Hospital, which specialised in allergies, ignored it all and instead concentrated on the cost of treatment and quoted OM experts who claimed the patients were deluded. The programme relied heavily on CAHF sources.

The reaction of the patients involved in all this is very revealing. Instead of thanking the OM spokesmen for saving them from exploitation, in the wake of the attacks on both the Bristol Centre and Breakspear, they formed support committees and tried to get media coverage to put their side of the story. Aids activists forced many conventional doctors in the field to rethink the whole idea of clinical trials and this, too, was a major factor in CM's eventual success.

It is against this background that the often-repeated charge that CM is potentially dangerous needs to be examined. Hardline medics regularly tar all CM treatments with the same sceptical brush. While some do require a leap of faith - personally, I find the use of crystals unbelievable, and many theories, such as the idea that high doses of vitamins C and E reduce the risk of strokes, are unproven - the evidence for others is increasingly impressive. It has been slow in coming, for reasons discussed below, but in clinical trials comparing drug and herb treatments, for instance, some herbs have been coming out on top. St John's Wort, for example, has been proven to be as good as pharmaceutical anti-depressants for mild depression - notwithstanding recent concern that there may be dangers in taking it in conjunction with conventional medicines; there is evidence that large doses of the mineral selenium can protect against cancer; and children brought up in a Rudolf Steiner vegetarian community, where they are not treated with drugs or vaccinated, had 40% fewer allergies.

There is a strong whiff of hypocrisy in OM's assertion of high scientific principles: its own record of untested and dangerous treatment dwarfs anything achieved by CM. Indeed, according to Dr Ian Chalmers of the UK Cochrane Centre, set up to test medical procedures, about 60% of standard OM treatments have never been subject to proper trials. A dramatic example occurred in September last year, when it was revealed that the conventional treatment for patients with severe shock or burns - albumin - which has been used for the past 30 years, caused an estimated 1,200 extra deaths a year in the UK.

An even more shocking departure from the gold standards of science was exposed in October 1999, when we learned of the problems that can follow from not publishing the negative results from clinical trials - a basic scientific requirement. According to Dr Chalmers, had the negative results on the heart drug lorcainide been published at the time, up to 80,000 deaths in the US in the 80s could have been prevented.

Meanwhile, the CM camp is trying to establish firm evidence for its claim to treat successfully many of the chronic conditions - such as skin problems, auto-immune disorders and malfunctioning of the gut - with which OM seems to have a particularly poor track record. An estimated 4,000 randomised trials of CM treatments have been carried out, not all to a very high standard, but the number is doubling every five years and the design is improving. In the US, the National Centre for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, part of the National Institutes of Health, has a $50-million research budget and last year funded 43 studies, including one investigating the effectiveness of acupuncture in treating alcoholics and another on the value of melatonin in treating Parkinson's disease.

There is a very good reason why CM is far more poorly researched than OM: money. The NHS spends roughly 85p on investigating CM for every £100 it spends on conventional medical research, while pharmaceu- tical companies, the other main source of funding, are not interested in testing the effectiveness of, say, garlic in cutting down heart disease or how diet can lower blood pressure, because they can't take out a patent on it.

It is easy to see a conspiracy here, and it's true that, until CM began to gain popularity, the medical profession tended to the view that it was a waste of time to test its treatments. There is a deeper organisational problem, too. "Unlike doctors in big NHS hospitals," says Andrew Vickers of the Research Council for Complementary Medicine, "alternative practitioners have no research back up. In an NHS hospital, you have not only a ready supply of patients to put into trials, but also a department specifically devoted to research, with statisticians, secretaries, computers, photocopying and so on. So, even if the alternative practitioners do have the training and the inclination to write up research proposals and calculate the statistics, which most of them don't, they still face a big handicap."

Despite these practical difficulties, a new style of medicine is emerging that aims to cherry-pick the best of both OM and CM. Dubbed integrated medicine, this is the CM practitioners' third name-change in as many decades, each reflecting a change in their status. During the wilderness years, they were alternative; then, as they won some recognition, they turned complementary; now, pushing for a merger, they've become integrated. "Of course we need to run trials to find out what works best," says Dr Mosarif Ali, director of the Integrated Medical Centre in London, "but we also need to reconnect medicine to its roots. The body is more than just a piece of bio-engineering, and there is more to healing than prescribing drugs."

So at Ali's clinic, as in many others, you'll get antibiotics, if you really need them, but you'll also get a package of dietary changes, exercise, lifestyle advice and massage. "Just that package alone clears up 80% of cases," Dr Ali claims. However, if it doesn't work on its own, you'll be offered a CM treatment that best fits you and your problem. "If you had stomach pains," he says, "you might be treated conventionally for a peptic ulcer, but an acupuncturist might treat you for 'deficient liver Qi' and a homoeopath for a 'pulsatilla constitution'."

Like a medical Luther, Ali is calling for a return to the original medical text. Back to Hippocrates. "He taught that doctors should fortify the body so that its natural healing power becomes more effective," he says. "Modern medicine has been so blinded by powerful drugs, increasingly minute measurements of cell activity, enzyme levels and suchlike, that it has forgotten the basics."

Only a few CM diehards would claim that the complementary approach is suitable for every condition. If you are in a car crash, you don't need aromatherapy or echinacea to boost your immune system; you need a casualty ward, heart monitors, anaesthetics and people with a good knowledge of blood chemistry. If your kidneys pack up, you need dialysis and a transplant, and if you develop meningitis, you need antibiotics, fast.

But OM's very success - and scientific medicine is undoubtedly one of the triumphs of the past hundred years - can blind us to just what a new kid on the block it is. Just 60 years ago, before the second world war, doctors were pretty impotent. They could make a careful diagnosis and say what the likely outcome was, but, after that, nature was pretty much allowed to take her course. About the only effective remedies in the pre-war OM medicine cabinet were aspirin from willow bark for rheumatic fever, digoxin from foxglove for heart conditions, immunisation for some infections, and salvarsin for syphilis. Meanwhile, children died from diseases such as polio, diphtheria and whooping cough, and adults succumbed to various infectious diseases such as tuberculosis, or puerperal fever, which killed 1,000 women a year in childbirth.

Then, within an astonishing 40 years - roughly between 1930 and 1970 - this bleak situation was transformed. Medical breakthroughs dating from that era include penicillin, pap smears for cervical cancer, kidney dialysis, general anaesthesia with curare, cortisone, a cure for tuberculosis, open heart surgery, polio vaccination, the contraceptive pill, hip replacement, kidney transplants, heart transplants and the cure of childhood cancer. "Magic bullets came cascading out of the lab," writes medical journalist James Le Fanu in his recent book, The Rise And Fall Of Modern Medicine, that surveys this period.

It was the very success of that revolution that created the conditions that allowed CM to flourish. For instance, two of the stars of those post-war breakthroughs - antibiotics and cortisone - have now come to symbolise much that is wrong with conventional medicine. Antibiotics were undoubtedly a miraculous discovery, vanquishing such major killers as septicaemia, meningitis and pneumonia, but their indiscriminate use and the rise of bacterial resistance has diminished their effectiveness. Cortisone at first appeared to be another astonishing breakthrough, providing immediate relief from the inflammation caused by more than 200 diseases, including rheumatoid athritis, asthma, eczema, gut disorders and kidney problems. But now, 50 years after its first use, cortisone is seen as typical of the failure of conventional medicine: it deals with symptoms, not the underlying disease, and it has a range of unpleasant and damaging side-effects.

Two more subtle changes at the heart of the scientific revolution have dramatically altered the way doctors think about patients and what treatments to use. Modern medicine rejected the notion that the doctor should be paramount in deciding how a patient should be treated, and instead turned to statistics. Statistical analysis of double blind trials is both the way to tell if a treatment works and to spot the causes of some diseases, such as the link between lung cancer and smoking. Although this approach has had undoubted success, it has not made medicine as rational and scientific as hoped. "Statistically derived knowledge has consistently shown itself to be unreliable," says Le Fanu. "It's been shown to result in the adoption of ineffective treatments in 32 per cent of cases or rejection of useful treatment in 33 percent."

Le Fanu is no friend of CM - he dismissively describes it as a treatment for the "worried well" - but his diagnosis of what has gone wrong chimes exactly with the more human and individual approach adopted by integrated medicine. "Scientific progressivism," he says, "has undermined medicine's most important asset - knowledge-based, practical experience."

Perhaps even more important in terms of alienating patients has been the transformation of the doctor from patient's advisor to scientific investigator. If you wanted to make a name for yourself during conventional medicine's golden post-war period, it was no good just looking after your patients, you had to research. The heroes of the age no longer just treated patients, they studied them to trace the variations in heart rhythms or to plot the chemical changes during liver failure. "Patients became interesting clinical material," says Le Fanu, "on which an ambitious young doctor could plan his experiments."

As one doctor confesses: "A lot of research you do is of no benefit to the patient, and there is a real possibility you can do them harm." Much of research undoubtedly paid of in new treatments, but a bond of trust was put in jeopardy, too. So it was that an entirely new approach to medicine - one that undoubtedly brought incalculable benefits in saving lives and reducing suffering - also alienated the doctors from their client base and created a vacuum at the heart of the profession that CM practitioners have now begun to fill.

Will the gentle revolution of CM transform medicine as completely as the scientific revolution did half a century ago? For all its current popularity, its hold is far from secure. On the one hand, a counter-revolution from Europe, inhibiting CM, is a very real possibility. The British are allowed to take higher doses of vitamins and supplements than any other Europeans, and the EU has been pushing for standardised vitamin levels for many years - which would mean a big drop in the legal levels here. (This is what may have lain behind the puzzling and hugely controversial decision by the Labour government, soon after coming to power, to propose a ban on over-the-counter sales of vitamin B6 - commonly used to treat PMT - in doses higher than 10mg. The storm was such that the government backed down.) On the other hand, it is conceivable that the new genetics might eventually provide scientific medicine with the fresh supply of magic bullets that it has been promising: growing new personalised body parts, harvesting human antibodies from transgenic pigs, modifying mutated genes to cure disease, and so on. If it does live up to the hype, CM might be sidelined.

Yet the deciphering of the human genome, promised for next year, has implications beyond new, improved drugs and surgery. Writer and genetic activist Jeremy Rifkin suggests that the new genetics has the potential to transform CM, too. Even the best run clinical trials of a drug or herb tell you that people in general get better with it, not whether it will benefit me rather than you. "With a print-out of your genetic structure, medics will know the kind of diseases and disabilities you are susceptible to," says Rifkin. "Now, suppose that we combine that information with all the new genetic knowledge about plants, and apply it to herbal therapies. We could begin to see exactly who would benefit from soy, who might be better helped with vitamin E and so on."

Others have a less grandiose view: "I don't think CM will have the impact of antibiotics or vaccination, which completely transformed medicine," says Vickers, "but it could change the way doctors treat some patients. Many GP's regard CM as the perfect way to deal with 'heart-sink' patients - the ones who keep coming back with vague symptoms they can't do anything about. However, treating them with yoga or art therapy or singing can work wonders. Depending on your point of view, this is either simply the placebo effect at work, or it is a way of responding much more appropriately to the needs of the patient."

CM could also help develop a hi-tech dimension. Already, the Americans are experimenting with herbal medicines in injectable form: electronic devices, as yet untested, that run weak electronic currents through the body, will, it is hoped, identify a broad spectrum of allergies, deficiencies and weaknesses by analysing the resulting wave forms.

The internet will certainly play a much greater part in every sort of medicine, and CM practitioners are just as worried about the dissemination of misleading information as orthodox ones. "We often have patients turning up with very dodgy supplements that they have found on the web," says Dr Rajendra Sharma of the 101 Practitioners Network. So he has raised £17 million from the City to set up a website that he intends to be the definitive place to discover what integrated medicine treatment works best for what disorder.

"If you have a cold, you could discover that your first step should be echinacea or some other plant with anti-viral properties, such as pomegranate, plus vitamin C. Only much later, with bronchial complications, might you take antibiotics." For meningitis, meanwhile, you immediately need strong antibiotics, combined with probiotics, a supplement of the beneficial gut bacteria that are killed off by antibiotics, to protect the lining of the gut.

For many practitioners, this coming-together of two strands of medicine can only be beneficial. "We really need to get away from the commplementary-orthodox split," says Vickers. "What everyone wants is a form of medicine that has trials showing that it works, that gives practitioners a code of conduct and that allows patients choice and respect."

Medicine is both an art and a science, but science has been firmly in the driving seat for 40 years. The arrival of CM practitioners may allow some of the more intangible aspects of the healing profession to re-emerge into the light, such as the power of the doctor's own belief. "When I was starting out as a doctor, my professor told me about a new migraine drug," recalls Marshall Marinker, professor of general practice at the University of London. "I prescribed it to a number of my patients, and it worked brilliantly. Many were completely cured. But then I began thinking about its mechanisms and how to design a trial, and it somehow stopped working so well. I never again got such good results as when I totally believed in it. I don't think you can measure that sort of thing in clinical trials, but it is absolutely vital to the way medicine should work."

The evidence is overwhelming that CAHF and its allies were not interested in exploring the scientific basis of such CM approaches as focusing on the role of food allergies in chronic disorders. A considerable body of respectable research supports this approach, known as clinical ecology. Yet the 1990 World In Action investigation into Breakspear Hospital, which specialised in allergies, ignored it all and instead concentrated on the cost of treatment and quoted OM experts who claimed the patients were deluded. The programme relied heavily on CAHF sources. The reaction of the patients involved in all this is very revealing. Instead of thanking the OM spokesmen for saving them from exploitation, in the wake of the attacks on both the Bristol Centre and Breakspear, they formed support committees and tried to get media coverage to put their side of the story. Aids activists forced many conventional doctors in the field to rethink the whole idea of clinical trials and this, too, was a major factor in CM's eventual success. It is against this background that the often-repeated charge that CM is potentially dangerous needs to be examined. Hardline medics regularly tar all CM treatments with the same sceptical brush. While some do require a leap of faith - personally, I find the use of crystals unbelievable, and many theories, such as the idea that high doses of vitamins C and E reduce the risk of strokes, are unproven - the evidence for others is increasingly impressive. It has been slow in coming, for reasons discussed below, but in clinical trials comparing drug and herb treatments, for instance, some herbs have been coming out on top. St John's Wort, for example, has been proven to be as good as pharmaceutical anti-depressants for mild depression - notwithstanding recent concern that there may be dangers in taking it in conjunction with conventional medicines; there is evidence that large doses of the mineral selenium can protect against cancer; and children brought up in a Rudolf Steiner vegetarian community, where they are not treated with drugs or vaccinated, had 40% fewer allergies. There is a strong whiff of hypocrisy in OM's assertion of high scientific principles: its own record of untested and dangerous treatment dwarfs anything achieved by CM. Indeed, according to Dr Ian Chalmers of the UK Cochrane Centre, set up to test medical procedures, about 60% of standard OM treatments have never been subject to proper trials. A dramatic example occurred in September last year, when it was revealed that the conventional treatment for patients with severe shock or burns - albumin - which has been used for the past 30 years, caused an estimated 1,200 extra deaths a year in the UK. An even more shocking departure from the gold standards of science was exposed in October 1999, when we learned of the problems that can follow from not publishing the negative results from clinical trials - a basic scientific requirement. According to Dr Chalmers, had the negative results on the heart drug lorcainide been published at the time, up to 80,000 deaths in the US in the 80s could have been prevented. Meanwhile, the CM camp is trying to establish firm evidence for its claim to treat successfully many of the chronic conditions - such as skin problems, auto-immune disorders and malfunctioning of the gut - with which OM seems to have a particularly poor track record. An estimated 4,000 randomised trials of CM treatments have been carried out, not all to a very high standard, but the number is doubling every five years and the design is improving. In the US, the National Centre for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, part of the National Institutes of Health, has a $50-million research budget and last year funded 43 studies, including one investigating the effectiveness of acupuncture in treating alcoholics and another on the value of melatonin in treating Parkinson's disease. There is a very good reason why CM is far more poorly researched than OM: money. The NHS spends roughly 85p on investigating CM for every £100 it spends on conventional medical research, while pharmaceu- tical companies, the other main source of funding, are not interested in testing the effectiveness of, say, garlic in cutting down heart disease or how diet can lower blood pressure, because they can't take out a patent on it. It is easy to see a conspiracy here, and it's true that, until CM began to gain popularity, the medical profession tended to the view that it was a waste of time to test its treatments. There is a deeper organisational problem, too. "Unlike doctors in big NHS hospitals," says Andrew Vickers of the Research Council for Complementary Medicine, "alternative practitioners have no research back up. In an NHS hospital, you have not only a ready supply of patients to put into trials, but also a department specifically devoted to research, with statisticians, secretaries, computers, photocopying and so on. So, even if the alternative practitioners do have the training and the inclination to write up research proposals and calculate the statistics, which most of them don't, they still face a big handicap." Despite these practical difficulties, a new style of medicine is emerging that aims to cherry-pick the best of both OM and CM. Dubbed integrated medicine, this is the CM practitioners' third name-change in as many decades, each reflecting a change in their status. During the wilderness years, they were alternative; then, as they won some recognition, they turned complementary; now, pushing for a merger, they've become integrated. "Of course we need to run trials to find out what works best," says Dr Mosarif Ali, director of the Integrated Medical Centre in London, "but we also need to reconnect medicine to its roots. The body is more than just a piece of bio-engineering, and there is more to healing than prescribing drugs." So at Ali's clinic, as in many others, you'll get antibiotics, if you really need them, but you'll also get a package of dietary changes, exercise, lifestyle advice and massage. "Just that package alone clears up 80% of cases," Dr Ali claims. However, if it doesn't work on its own, you'll be offered a CM treatment that best fits you and your problem. "If you had stomach pains," he says, "you might be treated conventionally for a peptic ulcer, but an acupuncturist might treat you for 'deficient liver Qi' and a homoeopath for a 'pulsatilla constitution'." Like a medical Luther, Ali is calling for a return to the original medical text. Back to Hippocrates. "He taught that doctors should fortify the body so that its natural healing power becomes more effective," he says. "Modern medicine has been so blinded by powerful drugs, increasingly minute measurements of cell activity, enzyme levels and suchlike, that it has forgotten the basics." Only a few CM diehards would claim that the complementary approach is suitable for every condition. If you are in a car crash, you don't need aromatherapy or echinacea to boost your immune system; you need a casualty ward, heart monitors, anaesthetics and people with a good knowledge of blood chemistry. If your kidneys pack up, you need dialysis and a transplant, and if you develop meningitis, you need antibiotics, fast. But OM's very success - and scientific medicine is undoubtedly one of the triumphs of the past hundred years - can blind us to just what a new kid on the block it is. Just 60 years ago, before the second world war, doctors were pretty impotent. They could make a careful diagnosis and say what the likely outcome was, but, after that, nature was pretty much allowed to take her course. About the only effective remedies in the pre-war OM medicine cabinet were aspirin from willow bark for rheumatic fever, digoxin from foxglove for heart conditions, immunisation for some infections, and salvarsin for syphilis. Meanwhile, children died from diseases such as polio, diphtheria and whooping cough, and adults succumbed to various infectious diseases such as tuberculosis, or puerperal fever, which killed 1,000 women a year in childbirth. Then, within an astonishing 40 years - roughly between 1930 and 1970 - this bleak situation was transformed. Medical breakthroughs dating from that era include penicillin, pap smears for cervical cancer, kidney dialysis, general anaesthesia with curare, cortisone, a cure for tuberculosis, open heart surgery, polio vaccination, the contraceptive pill, hip replacement, kidney transplants, heart transplants and the cure of childhood cancer. "Magic bullets came cascading out of the lab," writes medical journalist James Le Fanu in his recent book, The Rise And Fall Of Modern Medicine, that surveys this period. It was the very success of that revolution that created the conditions that allowed CM to flourish. For instance, two of the stars of those post-war breakthroughs - antibiotics and cortisone - have now come to symbolise much that is wrong with conventional medicine. Antibiotics were undoubtedly a miraculous discovery, vanquishing such major killers as septicaemia, meningitis and pneumonia, but their indiscriminate use and the rise of bacterial resistance has diminished their effectiveness. Cortisone at first appeared to be another astonishing breakthrough, providing immediate relief from the inflammation caused by more than 200 diseases, including rheumatoid athritis, asthma, eczema, gut disorders and kidney problems. But now, 50 years after its first use, cortisone is seen as typical of the failure of conventional medicine: it deals with symptoms, not the underlying disease, and it has a range of unpleasant and damaging side-effects. Two more subtle changes at the heart of the scientific revolution have dramatically altered the way doctors think about patients and what treatments to use. Modern medicine rejected the notion that the doctor should be paramount in deciding how a patient should be treated, and instead turned to statistics. Statistical analysis of double blind trials is both the way to tell if a treatment works and to spot the causes of some diseases, such as the link between lung cancer and smoking. Although this approach has had undoubted success, it has not made medicine as rational and scientific as hoped. "Statistically derived knowledge has consistently shown itself to be unreliable," says Le Fanu. "It's been shown to result in the adoption of ineffective treatments in 32 per cent of cases or rejection of useful treatment in 33 percent." Le Fanu is no friend of CM - he dismissively describes it as a treatment for the "worried well" - but his diagnosis of what has gone wrong chimes exactly with the more human and individual approach adopted by integrated medicine. "Scientific progressivism," he says, "has undermined medicine's most important asset - knowledge-based, practical experience." Perhaps even more important in terms of alienating patients has been the transformation of the doctor from patient's advisor to scientific investigator. If you wanted to make a name for yourself during conventional medicine's golden post-war period, it was no good just looking after your patients, you had to research. The heroes of the age no longer just treated patients, they studied them to trace the variations in heart rhythms or to plot the chemical changes during liver failure. "Patients became interesting clinical material," says Le Fanu, "on which an ambitious young doctor could plan his experiments." As one doctor confesses: "A lot of research you do is of no benefit to the patient, and there is a real possibility you can do them harm." Much of research undoubtedly paid of in new treatments, but a bond of trust was put in jeopardy, too. So it was that an entirely new approach to medicine - one that undoubtedly brought incalculable benefits in saving lives and reducing suffering - also alienated the doctors from their client base and created a vacuum at the heart of the profession that CM practitioners have now begun to fill. Will the gentle revolution of CM transform medicine as completely as the scientific revolution did half a century ago? For all its current popularity, its hold is far from secure. On the one hand, a counter-revolution from Europe, inhibiting CM, is a very real possibility. The British are allowed to take higher doses of vitamins and supplements than any other Europeans, and the EU has been pushing for standardised vitamin levels for many years - which would mean a big drop in the legal levels here. (This is what may have lain behind the puzzling and hugely controversial decision by the Labour government, soon after coming to power, to propose a ban on over-the-counter sales of vitamin B6 - commonly used to treat PMT - in doses higher than 10mg. The storm was such that the government backed down.) On the other hand, it is conceivable that the new genetics might eventually provide scientific medicine with the fresh supply of magic bullets that it has been promising: growing new personalised body parts, harvesting human antibodies from transgenic pigs, modifying mutated genes to cure disease, and so on. If it does live up to the hype, CM might be sidelined. Yet the deciphering of the human genome, promised for next year, has implications beyond new, improved drugs and surgery. Writer and genetic activist Jeremy Rifkin suggests that the new genetics has the potential to transform CM, too. Even the best run clinical trials of a drug or herb tell you that people in general get better with it, not whether it will benefit me rather than you. "With a print-out of your genetic structure, medics will know the kind of diseases and disabilities you are susceptible to," says Rifkin. "Now, suppose that we combine that information with all the new genetic knowledge about plants, and apply it to herbal therapies. We could begin to see exactly who would benefit from soy, who might be better helped with vitamin E and so on." Others have a less grandiose view: "I don't think CM will have the impact of antibiotics or vaccination, which completely transformed medicine," says Vickers, "but it could change the way doctors treat some patients. Many GP's regard CM as the perfect way to deal with 'heart-sink' patients - the ones who keep coming back with vague symptoms they can't do anything about. However, treating them with yoga or art therapy or singing can work wonders. Depending on your point of view, this is either simply the placebo effect at work, or it is a way of responding much more appropriately to the needs of the patient." CM could also help develop a hi-tech dimension. Already, the Americans are experimenting with herbal medicines in injectable form: electronic devices, as yet untested, that run weak electronic currents through the body, will, it is hoped, identify a broad spectrum of allergies, deficiencies and weaknesses by analysing the resulting wave forms. The internet will certainly play a much greater part in every sort of medicine, and CM practitioners are just as worried about the dissemination of misleading information as orthodox ones. "We often have patients turning up with very dodgy supplements that they have found on the web," says Dr Rajendra Sharma of the 101 Practitioners Network. So he has raised £17 million from the City to set up a website that he intends to be the definitive place to discover what integrated medicine treatment works best for what disorder. "If you have a cold, you could discover that your first step should be echinacea or some other plant with anti-viral properties, such as pomegranate, plus vitamin C. Only much later, with bronchial complications, might you take antibiotics." For meningitis, meanwhile, you immediately need strong antibiotics, combined with probiotics, a supplement of the beneficial gut bacteria that are killed off by antibiotics, to protect the lining of the gut. For many practitioners, this coming-together of two strands of medicine can only be beneficial. "We really need to get away from the commplementary-orthodox split," says Vickers. "What everyone wants is a form of medicine that has trials showing that it works, that gives practitioners a code of conduct and that allows patients choice and respect." Medicine is both an art and a science, but science has been firmly in the driving seat for 40 years. The arrival of CM practitioners may allow some of the more intangible aspects of the healing profession to re-emerge into the light, such as the power of the doctor's own belief. "When I was starting out as a doctor, my professor told me about a new migraine drug," recalls Marshall Marinker, professor of general practice at the University of London. "I prescribed it to a number of my patients, and it worked brilliantly. Many were completely cured. But then I began thinking about its mechanisms and how to design a trial, and it somehow stopped working so well. I never again got such good results as when I totally believed in it. I don't think you can measure that sort of thing in clinical trials, but it is absolutely vital to the way medicine should work."

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Let's all talk rhubarb
fields.trailText: The subject
fields.body:
The subject

Rheum rhabarbarum, R. rhaponticum and a couple of other members of the family Polygonaceae. Immortalised by Monty Python in The Rhubarb Tart Song - 'Even Martin Heidegger agrees on one thing: eternal happiness is rhubarb tart.' A favourite cooking fruit at this time of year, except it's not a fruit but a vegetable. Not only that, it's not even so favourite any more - this old stalwart of the country kitchen has lost some of its cachet. And not only that, it can make you ill, if you're not careful. Oh dear.

The basics

Rhubarb has been used in China for medicinal purposes (accentuate the purgative) for at least a couple of thousand years, and came our way (purge! purge!) in the 16th century. Only since the 19th century has anyone thought of actually eating the stuff, however, mostly in the US and over here. The Special Rhubarb Relationship. Check out http://members.aol.com/mathled/pie.html for a swell rhubarb pie recipe from the Wyoming Rural Electric News.

The details

Rhubarb, like spinach and sorrel, contains significant quantities of oxalic acid. Oxalic acid can make you ill, though scare stories about fatal ODs are somewhat overdone. Don't eat the leaves, which can make you ill in a hurry. Early spring brings us forced rhubarb - short, slim stalks that are sweeter and more tender than the tough-stringed, Schwarzenegger-size model growing outdoors later in the season. These are your partners in rhubarb crumble. In Geraldene Holt's Compte of Rose-Scented Rhubarb (reprinted in Sri Owen's Exotic Feasts, Kyle Cathie, £16.99). In rhubarb sauce to serve with fish, especially those oily dudes such as herring and mackerel. (If you eat spinach and sorrel with fish, then why not rhubarb?)

The easy way out

Aperol, an Italian liqueur made from rhubarb, if you can get your hands on a bottle. And if you dare.

Where to buy

The usual fruit-and-veg suspects.

fields.headline: All sown up
fields.standfirst: Get it right at the very start, and the rest will fall into place, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: How best to deal with seeds and seedlings this spring
fields.body:
So, how will you deal with seeds and seedlings this spring? Ready-made seedlings bought in plantplugs are becoming increasingly popular. They are ideal for haven't-the-time gardeners, who want easy gardening all along the line.

The range of plants obtainable in plugs is, perhaps inevitably, limited to those the supplier can expect to sell easily. It won't delve into the huge range of species whose seeds you could buy from, say, Thompson & Morgan or Chiltern Seeds.

Again, if you rely entirely on plantlets, you are missing out on a whole experience. It is exciting to examine your seed-sown containers each morning and see germination happening. Every seedling becomes your baby (with attendant worries, of course). You learn to handle each seedling and treat it as an individual, even when quite tiny, picking it up gently by one seed leaf and dropping it into the hole made ready for it by your dibber, so that the seed leaves (cotyledons) are resting just at the compost's surface.

If you catch them young and have not sown them too thickly, you can successfully handle seedlings of even such "impossibly fragile" subjects as poppies. Let's take the example of poppies: it may be, say, from T&M's 'Angels' Choir' strain, or the ladybird poppy, Papaver commutatum ; or it might be one of the equally fragile poppy tribe, such as eschscholzias, the Califor-nian poppies; or hunnemannia, the gloriously yellow tulip poppy with glaucous foliage; or argemone, the prickly poppies, yellow or white; or the charming little cream cups, Platystemon californicus . You could sow now, very thinly, into a number of modules, reducing the seedlings to one in each as soon as they show themselves. Then, when large enough, move them without any need for disturbance into 7cm or 9cm pots, planting out from those. Alternatively, you could, say at the end of March, sow a batch of seeds, thinly, into one pot and prick out seedlings individually into modules as soon as you can handle them. When large enough and hardened off, they can be planted out.

I keep emphasising the importance of sowing thinly. There is no temptation to do otherwise, if you start off with only a few seeds, but there is a temptation to sow too thickly, which will make the seedlings harder to separate when the time comes to handle them individually - this is especially so with poppies, whose seeds are tiny, campanulas, whose seeds are tinier still, and begonias, whose seeds are tiniest of all. If there are more seeds in a packet than you immediately need, keep them by you and don't just sow them because they're there.

Should your seeds be germinated in darkness or in light? The advantage of sowing them in darkness is that their compost is more easily prevented from drying out. But, if they germinate and do not then immediately have their wraps removed, the seedlings will become long and lanky, which is just what you least want and always indicates a shortage of light or space just when they most need it.

The other point is that many seeds actually need some light in order to germinate at all. They don't need a great deal, so one compromise that works is to germinate them under close conditions (ie, under unventilated glass) and to cover the containers with brown paper, which will keep out direct sunlight but will not impose total darkness. Or, if only a few pots are in question, you could tightly cover each with a plastic bag and forget about darkness altogether. But do avoid direct sunlight.

Still, it helps if there is sunshine to keep things snug, and, from March onwards, few seeds actually need artificial heat in order to germinate. It isn't that you want to whip up daytime temperatures to a high level with the help of the sun. That's easily done, and isn't clever if sunshine is then followed by a cold night and none of the sun's heat is retained where the seeds are, so think about insulation that will retain daytime heat into the night - for instance, a frame or greenhouse with solid walls rather than glass at the sides as well as over the top. This may be more laborious to instal, but gives far better results.

I have double-walled frames for propagation, with a double skin of glass. And we can spread mats or hessian over the glass at night if the temperature is likely to be low. Not that fluctuating temperatures, within reason, are necessarily a bad thing. Alstroemerias, for instance, need some low temperatures following sowing, if they are to germinate. Kept uniformly warm, they will not germinate. Simplest, I find, is to keep the sown seed in a close cold frame (just one skin of glass), so it may drop to freezing at night but warms up by day. This way, you'll have the first seeds germinating three weeks from sowing.

There is a most effective annual for late season, Polygonum orientale (T&M), that grows 6ft or more and carries deep-pink, drooping spikelets on a well-branched plant. Sow it in the next month, and let its container be night-chilled, but not frozen. You'll get good germination and can bring seedlings on under warmer conditions to plant out in May

 Christopher Lloyd's Gardening Year, is published by Frances Lincoln at £25. To order a copy at the special price of £22, plus 99p UK p&p, freephone CultureShop on 0800 3166102.

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort reads between the lines at Chapter II
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort reads between the lines at Chapter II
fields.body:
Things hadn't started too well. I'd had to abort two attempts to get to Chapter II in Blackheath, south-east London, and there I was again, waiting for Rowbotham, and not a sign of her, and time getting on. Then Rowbotham turned up and we got stuck in glutinous traffic around the Elephant & Castle. And then in even worse traffic further on, and I was losing my temper and despairing of ever getting anywhere ever again, let alone to Blackheath, and Rowbotham was busy telling me not to be so cantankerous and that there were worse things in life and that I shouldn't be having a panic attack just because I might miss a meal, which wouldn't do me any harm, anyway, and I said - well, I won't tell you what I said because, looking back, it didn't show me up in a particularly good light.

But we did get to Blackheath, and not too late, either, and there was Chapter II in a little terrace of shops sloping at 45 degrees just down from the heath, shining like a beacon on a dank night, styling itself as a "Modern European Restaurant". For a moment, I was tempted to debate the Empsonian ambiguity of this description - that is, whether this meant that Chapter II was a restaurant for a modern Europe or a modern restaurant that happened to be in Europe or a modern restaurant in a modern Europe, or what - but Rowbotham did not share my grammatical obsessions, having become very keen to get among the vittels.

Anyway, I knew full well what Chapter II meant by those words. Rather like Parade, which I reviewed last week, it is thoroughly contemporary in all its parts: bleached-pine flooring, cool wall shades, chromatically florid pics, chairs in primary colours, inset spotlights in the ceiling, small flower displays, busy waiters with gelled hair, all brisk, bright, smiling, and sophisticated - ish. In other words, tailored to today's expectations for a neighbourhood restaurant, of a piece with power-suiting, snatched lunches, mobile phones and no time for home cooking.

The menu pretty much keeps pace, what with grilled sole with lentil-and-coriander broth; deep-fried saltcod, garlic mash and roast red peppers; fricasée of chicken, peas and morels with tarragon cream; roast peach, rice pudding and white-chocolate cheesecake. On second thoughts, that last panders more to the traditional British appetite for pudding overkill. And there are other signs of a recidivist, gutsier sensibility at work, what with duck-and-black-pudding faggot with split peas and apple sauce, and slow-cooked lamb with cassoulet. Perhaps this isn't that surprising, as the chef, Adrian Jones, has rubbed chef's jackets with, among others, Shaun Hill and Gary Rhodes - both smart exponents of highly-flavoured cooking that places Britain firmly at the centre of Europe.

You can probably guess which dishes I fancied. Yes, the faggot and the lamb with cassoulet, but I separated them with a dish of warm skate and crab with parsley salad, having decided to pass when the time came for pudding. All this was distinctly above average, highly pleasing tucker.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck refuses to take a break
fields.body:
This is the parliamentary recess time of year for the wine scribe, but, of course, I never take a break, and so never require of this newspaper that it contrives another column in place of this one with the shameful notice appended, 'Mr Gluck has a hangover and is on holiday for a fortnight'. How splendid those days must have been when that sort of thing was routine in journalism (hangovers, as well as notices of temporary abstention).

In the confused times in which we live - when the froth is often mistaken for the beer, New Labour for compassionate government, email for literature, celebrity for worth - wine is a solace and an important component, properly applied, of a healthy and civilised life. I see no reason to pause, though I may travel: indeed, if you read this on the morning of publication, I shall be sky-high coming back from a close inspection of the vineyards of Melbourne. I can find no ready excuse to explain away the desolation of late February, when the new-world wines of last year's vintage are yet to arrive, when yesteryear's old worldies need another few months to be ready for bottling, and when the post-Christmas bargain clearouts have dwindled to zilch. What does this leave us with? Tesco and Sainsbury.

The best of the latter's seasonal price reductions were covered last week, and so it is with Tesco we must begin. All of the eight Tesco wines below are on offer, at the prices stated, until March 7, when, I trust, the first faint signs of spring should creep over the southern portion of these islands. Tesco's South African Reserve Cabernet Sauvignon 1996 (15 points, out of 20) has been featured here before, but it cost £4.99 then. Now, it's £1 less. Not enough to win it Weightwatcher of the Year, but good enough to rate 15.5 points at that price, because it is engagingly well flavoured - dry, characterful, richly styled yet controlled - and excellent with food. Undurraga Pinot Noir 1998 (14.5 points, down to £3.99), from Chile, is hardly classic pinot, but it is immensely drinkable with its cherry, plum and blackberry ripe fruit. From Argentina, there is the non-vintage Chimango Tempranillo Malbec (14 points, nigh rock bottom at £2.99), a straightforward construct: fruity and rich, and as simple and vulgar as David Beckham, though not so mixed-up. Chilean Merlot Reserve 1998 (16 points, reduced to £4.49) shows the lovely subtle sweetness of young merlot, gentle yet gripping tannins, and well-developed, balanced fruit of some energy. Domaine de la Grande Bellane Valreas 1998 (15.5 points) is an organic red on offer at £4.99. Brusque to begin, it develops lovely flowing plums, cherries and blackberries, and finishes with a savoury/sweet tang.

Arniston Bay Chenin Chardonnay 1998 (15.5 points, down to £3.49) is extremely forward, but not flashy. It has warmth and piles of soft fruit, yet manages to stay refreshing and engagingly plump without being obscenely Rubenesque. Tesco's own-label Coonawarra Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 (16 points, reduced to £5.99) elegantly demonstrates that this Australian region is uniquely capable of turning out finely textured, gently minty/spicy, very fine reds. Last at Tesco, there is the Rosé Cava, a Spanish bubbly that, rating 15.5 points, has been slashed to £3.99. Deliciously dry and gently fruity, this sassy specimen is - if you'll forgive me - a fab bubbly for a bleak Feb. It makes many a much-vaunted Champagne blush to be so much more expensive but no more classy.

Sainsbury's has three, non-discounted reds worth the detour. They are Nero d'Avola Connubio 1998 (15.5 points, £4.99) and Zagara Nero d'Avola & Sangiovese 1998 (15.5 points, £3.99), from Italy, and Château Agram Corbières 1996 (15.5 points, £3.99). The first offers up a leather-and-tobacco aroma, the tobacco edge carrying through to the very dry fruit that has a faint echo of dried figs - an unusually characterful, sturdy wine. The second unites lovely rich tannins with juicy, medium-paced fruit, and it's generous and firm. The French wine, number three, is remarkable value, offering, as it does, highly civilised, Midi-typical quaffing with gentility and warmth, and soft restraint on the finish.

fields.headline: Kids' stuff
fields.standfirst: Bread-and-butter pudding
fields.trailText: Bread-and-butter pudding
fields.body:
Serves four

500ml milk

3 eggs

60g sugar

4 slices white bread, crusts removed

100g butter, softened

60g sultanas

100g icing sugar

Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Warm the milk gently. Whisk the eggs and sugar in a bowl, then add the milk. Strain. Spread the bread with butter, and cut into quarters. Arrange over the bottom of an oven-proof dish, pour over the milk-and-egg mixture, and top with a sprinkling of sultanas.

Place the dish in a tray half-filled with water (bain marie), and bake for an hour until set. After half an hour, dust with icing sugar, to crisp up the top.

 Recipes devised and cooked at Petit Cordon Bleu. Call 020-7935 3503 for details of children's classes.
