fields.headline: How to... grow up
fields.trailText: Growing up is so profoundly difficult that most people choose not to go through with it. Losing in love is a vital part of growing up.
fields.body:
Growing up is so profoundly difficult that most people choose not to go through with it. Losing in love is a vital part of growing up.

First, you have to be convinced that the world has never seen a love such as yours, even though it involves a lot of time hanging around in coffee shops playing with packets of sugar. Then, just as you're feeling secure in the relationship, the love has to end, so you can learn that not all women love you as unconditionally as your mother does.

Next, there's the economic wake-up call, which comes when you can't find the tree on which money grows and you're forced to go out and get a job. That's when peer-group pressure suddenly becomes what you feel in a crowded commuter train.

To grow up, it is essential to put your entire wardrobe into a backpack and set off somewhere that is big on scenery and low on social security. On your trip, you will need to have a brief and unsuitable relationship, some form of bodily mutilation (tattoo, body piercing, bad haircut) and to get shockingly ripped off by someone who is doing you the favour of showing you that it's a big, bad world out there without your mum and dad.

Obviously, you need to leave home to discover that toilets are not self-cleaning, that the magical missing link between shopping and eating is cooking, and that your parents were not put on earth simply to embarrass you in front of your mates. There are also certain things you need to have under your belt to qualify as a grown up: you need to be able to use an automatic ticket barrier without fear, you need to have refused a swig of cider from a plastic bottle and you need to have 90% of your toys in the attic.

Growing up is when you understand that you get what you give, not what you're given. Then you realise that you get something only if you've already got it. In work, love and money, everyone has a built-in credit status: you may not know what it is, but, like a low sperm count, it can profoundly affect your future. The really tough one to learn is that if you really, really want something, you have to let it go (this doesn't apply to helium-filled balloons.)

Finally, you can test how grown up you are by your position in a double-decker bus: kids at top front, teenagers top back, grown-ups middle top, older adults bottom back, really old bottom front.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'Open eyes to find young man engaged in a profane kind of organ recital'
fields.trailText: 'Open eyes to find young man engaged in a profane kind of organ recital
fields.body:
Awake from terrifying dream that my cup of tea was haunted. You could see by the way the surface heaved and rippled that it was possessed by the Devil. Not so much PG Tips: more 18 and Over. Heave myself out of bed, recalling wise words of internet astrologer, Lorelei Dove: "There is nothing to fear but fear itself." Gaze into bathroom mirror and discover that I, too, am possessed by the Devil.

I have started to resemble Cliff Richard - although I look slightly more masculine and a great deal more elderly. Just another of the Devil's little jokes.

Someone hammers on the bathroom door - it is Satan's representative on earth, ex-Spouse. "I want a bath," he growls. "If it's not too much to ask." He is supposed to live downstairs with his own en-suite shower. "Your shower would be a lot more environmentally-friendly," I scold. Sod that, is the reply. Ex-Spouse is reading the anti-eco-Bible, Hard Green. Yesterday, he informed me that he will never recycle anything again. "Not even clapped-out old ex-wives?" I quipped - tastelessly, no doubt. Anyway, as far as the environment is concerned, he has informed me we should leave it all to the rich countries and market forces.

Admit ex-Spouse into bathroom. We are a post-modern, post-Eros family. He doesn't even glance sideways at my cute old bottom as he runs his bath. "I've just been listening to Aunt Elspeth drivelling on," he snarls, as if she is some impediment to his liberty and happiness and not our generous benefactor. "She's in love. She's met some geezer down that OAPs' Club." Aunt has been attending an upmarket social club for seniors. No bingo. Instead, whist, tea-dances and coach trips to Stourhead. "He's called Alec." Do not like the name Alec. Too phalec.

"Apparently, he executes a mean foxtrot and hails from Stoke Poges." Leave ex-Spouse to wallow in his bath. Hope great-aunt will not go all the way on her first date. And it was Harriet I was worried about.

Post arrives - lasagne of horrifying bills. What will happen if aunt decides to cohabit with Alec and takes her liquidity with her? Run upstairs and burst into bathroom. "Why don't you get up off your arse and earn a few quid?" I yell. "Why don't you ?" is the reply. Decide I bloody well will, then, but first consult internet astrologer, Lorelei: "Today, you might meet a dark stranger, who will ask you a challenging question, Virgo," she warns. So I might even get as far as an interview? Encouraged, I rush out, exhilarated by the possibility of a new life stacking shelves in Tesco's or being a dinnerlady (now a glamorous career option, thanks to Victoria Wood.) Yes! This is the first day of the rest of my life. If an opportunity arises, I shall seize it with gusto.

Trot off towards Tesco's. Something reassuring about pavements. Town. Comforting cafes. Moving back to town is back to the womb. Behind Tesco's, I stumble upon ancient church tucked away among evergreens. Enjoy box pews, splendid misericords and emerge into sunshine and settle down on bench with all the satisfaction that comes from a bloody good font. Bit of a sun-trap, so shut eyes and bask.

Hear a footstep. Young man looking like El Greco saint enters church. The organist, perhaps, going in to practise. Maybe I'll be treated to a recital. Close eyes again and wait for Bach. Ten minutes later, footsteps echo again, approach, and voice demands, "What d'you think of that, then?" Open eyes to discover that saintly young man has returned and is standing before me engaged in a rather more profane kind of organ recital than I had anticipated. Leap up and run off, as I have never regarded masturbation as a spectator sport - although when the Devil finally takes over the world from his HQ in Croydon, perhaps it will find a niche among the domestic competitions such as darts and snooker.

"Did you find a job, then?" enquires ex-Spouse, looking up from his newspaper. Inform him that instead I was a victim of sexual harassment.

"Oh well," he yawns, "I suppose it's a step in the right direction."

fields.headline: Britney Spears
fields.standfirst: Britney Spears, 18, appeared in TV commercials as a child. At 11, she joined Disney's Mickey Mouse Club, and three years later began a pop career. In 1998, she was the first female artist to have a simultaneous Billboard Number 1 single and album with a debut release. In the UK, Baby One More Time was the fastest selling debut single in history. Spears was recently named best rock or pop newcomer at the US Music Awards.
fields.trailText:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Finding a true soul-mate.
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Finding a true soul-mate.

What is your greatest fear?
Not being able to find a true soul mate.

Which living person do you most admire?
My mom, because she's loved me unconditionally.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I worry too much.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My fingernails - I bite them terribly.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Biting my fingernails.

What is your favourite word?
'Amazing'.

What objects do you always carry with you?
A prayer book.

What makes you depressed?
When I hear about bad things happening to children.

What is your favourite journey?
I believe the journey I'm on now will be my favourite.

What is your favourite book?
The Bible.

Do you belive in capital punishment?
Yes.

Which living person do you most despise?
I try to find good in all people and try not to despise anyone.

For what cause would you die?
My beliefs.

What is your greatest regret?
None at this moment - thankfully.

How do you relax?
I light candles, put on a great CD and take a bubble-bath

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
The promise of continued good health.

What would your motto be?
Always smile.

What keeps you awake at night?
Missing my family.

Do you believe in life after death?
Yes.

How would you like to be remembered?
As someone whose music touched many lives.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Be true to yourself.

webTitle: Prince beats drum for the commonwealth

fields.headline: Prince beats drum for the commonwealth
fields.standfirst:
Charles gets a big welcome on Caribbean tour, and starts setting out his stall to take over job the Queen has made her life's work

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Charles gets a big welcome on Caribbean tour, and starts setting out his stall to take over job the Queen has made her life's work.
fields.body:
When the Prince of Wales picked up a pair of drumsticks in a game attempt to beat out a tune on the steel pans, his Trinidadian audience was enthralled. The gesture of enthusiasm, from a man who was once held to be so lacking in the common touch, caught them off-guard.

Before his Caribbean tour, the only impression that most people here had of the prince was that of a cold and uncaring man who had allowed his marriage to wither away. Now the local newspapers are full of pictures and stories about his meet-the-people manner.

"They are stunned," said a reporter. "It is not what they expected at all." In the streets of Trinidad and among the shacks of Guyana, Prince Charles has gone out of his way to present himself as an approachable and down-to-earth royal who is concerned about the problems in the poorest reaches of the commonwealth. He has dropped in to a school for underprivileged children, a centre for battered women, witnessed the front-line fight against the drugs trade, and launched branches of his youth business trust in all three countries on his tour - Trinidad and Tobago, Guyana and Jamaica.

He has plunged into the local culture, and in turn been feted as a man who is at ease with the Caribbean communities.

"I feel very much at home here," the prince told council members at the Tobago assembly, "because we have so many of your countrymen living and working in Britain. I come across them on many different occasions, in Brixton and in Hackney." It may have been a clumsy way of playing the race card, but the intention was clear.

For this is a game plan with a serious goal. The passing of the Queen, whether sooner or later, does not just involve the monarchy in Britain: her position as head of the commonwealth does not move automatically to her heir. Privately, many of the poorer nations of the former British empire would much rather a Mandela-figure take over the ceremonial role: to them, Charles is as much an irrelevance as his mother is seen as the crucial bond holding the disparate nations together.

The Queen regards the commonwealth as her life's work; but Charles, clearly a modernist, is perceived to hold little interest in an institution rooted in the discredited colonial past. "What has he ever done for us?" asks a senior member of the commonwealth secretariat.

It is, of course, a charge unfairly framed. The prince is in a no-win situation: if he suddenly starts championing the cause of the commonwealth with as much public enthusiasm as the Queen, he risks opening a rift between them, which could threaten the future of the monarchy. But if he continues his low profile work behind the scenes, he is casti gated for not showing enough commitment.

So the prince's Caribbean tour provided an opportune time to speak out. The foreign office chose the Caribbean as the venue for the prince's first tour of the new millennium. At the same time, the work of a high-level group charged by the last commonwealth heads of government meeting in Durban with undertaking a whole-scale review of the institution's future is getting under way.

It is in this context that Prince Charles chose the future of the commonwealth as the theme for his keynote speech, to an audience at the University of the West Indies in Port of Spain, Trinidad. "I have long had an instinctive sense of the value of the commonwealth. It encourages and celebrates cultural diversity and makes no attempt to homogenise - and in this it teaches those of us living in multi-racial societies like Britain or Trinidad and Tobago a valuable lesson."

He likened the workings of the commonwealth to the wiring in an old house: "You sometimes wonder why the wiring goes where it does; but wherever, it is there to be used." The commonwealth was the ideal way to realise the aims of a successful modern society in the fields of trade, environment, youth development and education. "The house does not necessarily need rewiring to achieve them."

These final words will have echoed hollow in Downing Street: Tony Blair is a key member of the commonwealth working party and laid down a marker in Durban that the principle of reform was not negotiable. Some government ministers are said to regard Charles as a dangerous maverick over his stance on issues such as GM foods and foreign policy: now, a clash over the monumental issue of Britain's colonial legacy looms.

But the prince's net is cast far wider. It appears he is determined to find more ways of answering the question which follows him everywhere: "What is the point of the Prince of Wales?"

fields.headline: Whitehall shuns £100m for change
fields.trailText: Whitehall departments have failed to bid for millions of pounds of treasury cash to reform the white, male domination at the top of the civil service.
fields.body:
Whitehall departments have failed to bid for millions of pounds of treasury cash to reform the white, male domination at the top of the civil service.

With the deadline next Tuesday, no ministry has applied for a £100m pot of cash put aside by Tony Blair to tackle a culture of patronage which has led to three out of four top civil servants believing that promotion depends on networking and contacts rather than merit.

Last year, Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, promised to sweep aside old Whitehall as part of a "modernising government agenda". The pledge followed a survey of 1,700 senior civil servants and fast-stream entrants which showed huge dissatisfaction about the internal culture.

Only 25% believed promotion was based entirely on merit, falling to about 19% among women and to 10% among ethnic minorities. Instead, those surveyed believed that patronage and networking - belonging to the right Whitehall clubs and golf clubs - played a substantial role. One senior woman said: "I didn't join a club in Whitehall, I haven't got the time or interest to play golf, and so I don't do the out of hours networking or bonding."

The survey found that 81% - 91% in the case of ethnic minorities - believed the civil service was bad at identifying people with high potential. They also thought that unless people worked long hours they had little chance of promotion.

Despite family-friendly policy intentions many civil servants have told mandarins they are afraid of working part-time because it will be seen that they have no commitment. Asian civil servants in top jobs also felt underrated.

Ministers were told that middle management is poor and that young high-flier recruits are offered no support or guidance. Others saw bad managers getting automatic promotion.

Mandarins were told some 46% of white male civil servants did not want any radical change - while 68% of ethnic minorities wanted big changes.

The cabinet office yesterday said that there was still time for ministries to submit bids before next week's deadline.

webTitle: Old heads with new fix for infant health

fields.headline: Old heads with new fix for infant health
fields.trailText: Arthur and Margaret Wynn published their most recent scientific paper last week. The centrepiece of their research is the belief that a mother's diet has most effect on her baby's health not during pregnancy, but around the time of conception.
fields.body:
Arthur and Margaret Wynn, dietary experts
Arthur and Margaret Wynn published their most recent scientific paper last week, 30 years after they started writing about maternal nutrition, and a little less than a month after Arthur's 90th birthday; Margaret is 86. "We've been married for 61 years," she said. "Beat that!" The only palpably old-fashioned thing about them is their belief in government as an engine of progress, where people should be concerned about the welfare of even the poorest.

The centrepiece of their research is the belief that a mother's diet has most effect on her baby's health not during pregnancy, but around the time of conception. It is not controversial that low birthweight is bad for babies; but using statistics on poverty and famine in Europe, going back as far as 1848 in Paris, they believe they have established that the crucial factor is bad or inadequate food around the time of conception.

Arthur first came across the problem, he says, in 1927, when his father sent him to Vienna to learn languages. "There was great hostility to Britain then because of the blockade we had imposed in the first world war."

The famine was terrible: "It wasn't just that every animal in the zoo, including the lions and tigers and so on, were all killed and eaten. You have to ask who really did suffer and who died. Well, the old people died, and the other thing was that the babies died. Women's reproduction was seriously affected. They produced little babies and malformed babies. This was put down to starvation."

He spent the second world war working for the ministry of defence, and afterwards became head of safety in the mines research establishment, trying to achieve decent standards in the newly nationalised coal industry.

Margaret continues: "When I was a child in Barns ley the maids in my house were all miners' daughters. Many a time my mother would find them weeping in the kitchen because their father or brothers had said 'there's going to be an accident'. And whenever there was one later, the phone would ring at six in the morning for Arthur. It took me back to the maid weeping because her father had said there was going to be an accident; and there was, and her brother was killed."

Eventualy Arthur became a board member of the national coal board and a very senior civil servant indeed.

Margaret, meanwhile, was raising four children, and working for the Catholic Housing Association trying to find housing for fatherless families. "They often didn't remarry. They had handicapped children which had helped drive the husband away. So I asked myself could you prevent accidents which happened in the reproduc tive process. I went to different countries and looked into the systems they had for the care of children. All the time learning that the origins of these problems were earlier than birth."

It is, they now believe, the four weeks surrounding conception that are really crucial for a baby's future health; and what matters then is not just the quantity of food, but its quality, which is the hardest thing for poor women to manage. But despite 30 years of official indifference, they are fiercely optimistic. "If Yvette Cooper [public health minister] wants to go down in history and to make her mark, she could have a task force for the parts of the inner cities that are producing the most low-birthweight babies. If they could join up everyone who's needed for the area and reduce the low-birthweight rate, it would only take nine months or a year. It's so quick, and so unanswerable."

Christina Rees: American at the top in English church politics
There is a delightful symbolism in the muddy drive up to Christina Rees's house: on the one side is a field of rare Jacob's sheep and on the other, some flop-eared goats. This separation is how a follower of Jesus should arrange her farm. But the peacocks in a ramshackle greenhouse suggest a less controlled imagination.

Next week she will be in London at a meeting of the Church of England's general synod. She has been a member there for 10 years, and is one of the elected members of the archbishops' council, a committee that is meant to have taken over the direction of the church from the synod. She's also the chair of Watch, a pressure group for women bishops.

I wondered what someone so abundantly sane is doing in church politics. Part of the answer lies in her childhood. Her family was American, cultured, and bohemian: in her living room is a massive neoclassical statue of a naked woman draped across a flute-playing faun, carved by her grandmother. When she was five, her parents threw up their jobs in New York and bought a sailing boat, and for the next nine years she grew up on a small boat cruising in tropical waters with her parents and two siblings.

She lives in Hertfordshire because when she was 23, and taking a degree in communications, she met Chris Rees, a BBC producer, in Cambridge, and married him.

"I never meant to get into church politics. I didn't know what they were, because I had travelled so much and grew up with an 'any church in a port' kind of attitude."

Christina started preaching when she was 17, "having had a charismatic experience."

What, exactly? "I had an emotional sense of God's love for me in a new way. I just felt completely utterly loved in every cell of my body."

Nonetheless, this doesn't really sound like training for a life on church committees.

"When we moved to the village nearly 20 years ago I was asked if I would join the parochial church council because I was young and female. Of course, every suggestion I came up with, they said I couldn't possibly understand because you are young and female and foreign." So she decided to change things from the inside.

webTitle: Hat trick Moschino's Mardi Gras headgear lightens the mood in Milan

fields.headline: Hat trick Moschino's Mardi Gras headgear lightens the mood in Milan
fields.trailText: Moschino lightened the mood of Milan Fashion Week with a characteristically humorous collection inspired by the film The Wizard of Oz. Skirts with prints of Toto the dog, handbags made in the image of Dorothy's Kansas   home, and glittering ruby slippers kept alive the wit for which Franco Moschino was famous until his death in 1994.
fields.body:
Moschino lightened the mood of Milan Fashion Week with a characteristically humorous collection inspired by the film The Wizard of Oz. Skirts with prints of Toto the dog, handbags made in the image of Dorothy's Kansas home, and glittering ruby slippers kept alive the wit for which Franco Moschino was famous until his death in 1994.

The designer, who launched his eponymous label in 1983, was loved for his visual puns, including hats shaped like shoes and dinner suits with knives and forks appliqued on the bodice. Moschino's close colleague Rossella Jardini has designed the label since his death.

This was a savvy collection that incorporated most of the big trends seen in Milan this week. There were red and pink silk stripy coats, knee-length black dresses with Minnie Mouse collars, and a raft of mannish tailoring in red, grey or black. Evening wear conjured up visions of the Wicked Witch of the West: pointed hats topped off diaphanous black chiffon gowns with narrow bodices and fluted shoulders.

Hats are huge news for autumn/winter. Moschino has always favoured them, so it was no surprise to see so many. Here were the largest hats in Milan - giant square-brimmed creations flopping seductively over models' faces .

 LVMH continued its eclectic spending spree yesterday with the acquisition of cult US make-up brand Urban Decay. The brand is sold in LVMH's Sephora chain of beauty stores in the US, and has concessions in several London department stores. Last week LVMH also took a majority stake in Emilio Pucci, whose collection featuring customary swirly prints in pink and purple was shown in Milan yesterday.

webTitle: Spy goes to court over press bar

fields.headline: Spy goes to court over press bar
fields.trailText: Conditions of strict secrecy yesterday surrounded the launch of a high court application by a convicted spy who penetrated one of Britain's most sensitive defence contractors and sold military secrets to the Russians.
fields.body:
Conditions of strict secrecy yesterday surrounded the launch of a high court application by a convicted spy who penetrated one of Britain's most sensitive defence contractors and sold military secrets to the Russians.

Electronics engineer Michael John Smith, who is serving a 20-year jail sentence for spying, is fighting for the right to contact the press from prison.

Mr Justice Jackson, sitting in open court in London, gave Smith, 51, the go-ahead to seek a judicial review against the ministry of defence at a hearing which will probably take place in secret.

He said the MoD had taken an "eminently sensible" decision not to oppose a full hearing at yesterday's preliminary stage, when Smith only had to establish that he had "an arguable case".

The judge added that he had read the documents and concluded "there are matters which require to be properly argued" at a full hearing.

A long-term Communist, Smith was jailed for 25 years in November 1993 for selling military secrets about radar systems to the former Soviet Union between 1990-92 while he was working for the GEC group. He was said to have been paid £20,000.

His sentence was reduced on appeal in June 1995 to 20 years.

The crown could not prove during his nine-week trial exactly what material Smith, a quality assurance audit manager, had given away.

But at the time of his arrest his car contained documents relating to radar for the Rapier missile system and military surface acoustic wave radar technology, which scientific experts agreed at his trial might be of use to the Russians.

In 1995 the security com mission criticised MI5 and the MoD, saying the handling of Smith from a security viewpoint was characterised by delays and errors and incorrect judgments.

Yesterday, Mr Justice Jackson ordered that the court file for the pending high court challenge "be held in secure conditions" by the treasury solicitor.

He also ordered that Smith should not reveal to anyone the material filed by him, or the MoD, for use in the proceedings.

The full hearing should be heard in camera, subject to any contrary order of the court, said the judge.

He said the MoD had taken an "eminently sensible" decision not to oppose a full hearing at yesterday's preliminary stage, when Smith only had to establish that he had "an arguable case". The judge added that he had read the documents and concluded "there are matters which require to be properly argued" at a full hearing. A long-term Communist, Smith was jailed for 25 years in November 1993 for selling military secrets about radar systems to the former Soviet Union between 1990-92 while he was working for the GEC group. He was said to have been paid £20,000. His sentence was reduced on appeal in June 1995 to 20 years. The crown could not prove during his nine-week trial exactly what material Smith, a quality assurance audit manager, had given away. But at the time of his arrest his car contained documents relating to radar for the Rapier missile system and military surface acoustic wave radar technology, which scientific experts agreed at his trial might be of use to the Russians. In 1995 the security com mission criticised MI5 and the MoD, saying the handling of Smith from a security viewpoint was characterised by delays and errors and incorrect judgments. Yesterday, Mr Justice Jackson ordered that the court file for the pending high court challenge "be held in secure conditions" by the treasury solicitor. He also ordered that Smith should not reveal to anyone the material filed by him, or the MoD, for use in the proceedings. The full hearing should be heard in camera, subject to any contrary order of the court, said the judge.

fields.headline: Dissidents try to bomb barracks
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Dissident republicans returned to the scene of one of the greatest atrocities of the Troubles early yesterday when they tried to bomb an army barracks at Ballykelly, County Londonderry.
fields.body:
Dissident republicans returned to the scene of one of the greatest atrocities of the Troubles early yesterday when they tried to bomb an army barracks at Ballykelly, County Londonderry.

Police believe the bombers were interrupted as they breached security to plant the 15kg device, made up of home-made explosives packed into gas canisters, close to soldiers' sleeping quarters. They said that there would otherwise have been heavy loss of life.

One part of the bomb did explode, a timer attached to one of three gas cylinders, causing some damage. But two other canisters found nearby had not been been connected to the ignition unit.

The Irish National Liberation Army killed 17 people, including 11 soldiers, in a bomb attack on the Droppin' Well disco in Ballykelly in December 1982.

The early morning attack yesterday was linked to Continuity IRA, which has been growing in strength in nearby Derry. It was behind a blast three weeks ago on Mahon's Hotel in Irvinestown, County Fermanagh. The group's political wing, Republican Sinn Fein, is today opening premises on the Falls Road, in west Belfast. It is inviting dissident republicans from all over Ireland to attend in an attempt to deliver a snub to mainstream republicanism in its heartland.

The bombing attempt highlighted the crisis surrounding the peace process. That was fuelled further as the political parties showed more signs of returning to their respective bunkers.

A leaked Progressive Unionist Party document signalled it was contemplating withdrawing its support for the Good Friday agreement. It said it was disenchanted with Sinn Fein. The PUP is allied to the Ulster Volunteer Force and Red Hand Commando, on ceasefire since October 1994. The document gave no hint of what might happen to the loyalist cessation.

Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams, meanwhile, called on supporters of the Good Friday agreement to embark on street protests to force Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to return power to Stormont. Ulster Unionists and the SDLP were aghast. They felt the move could spark widespread disorder.

 Armed guards could soon be needed at schools in Northern Ireland to deal with the rising tide of violence that has followed the paramilitary ceasefires, the president of the province's biggest teaching union claimed yesterday.

"It is clear that schools paradoxically have become more violent since the ceasefires," Jim McDaid told the National Association of Schoolmasters and Union of Women Teachers' Northern Ireland Conference in Belfast. "If something is not done to contain this problem, we will soon have to consider following the practice of some New York schools by recruiting armed guards."

fields.headline: Savage reality of peace, Ulster-style
fields.standfirst:
Long-simmering loyalist feud led to butchering of two teenagers
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Teenagers Andrew Robb and David McIlwaine each wore a favourite polo neck when they were buried in Kernan cemetry in Portadown, Co Armagh this week. The undertaker had insisted.
fields.body:
Teenagers Andrew Robb and David McIlwaine each wore a favourite polo neck when they were buried in Kernan cemetry in Portadown, Co Armagh this week. The undertaker had insisted.

He had worked around the clock, refusing to allow the youngsters' parents to see their bodies for more than 30 hours after they were found. They had been tortured, murdered, and mutiliated.

Robb, 19, had all his teeth kicked out. He had a gaping hole in his head, and, of the half-dozen stab wounds, the pathologist believed it was the thrust through the heart which was the fatal blow.

McIlwaine, 18, too was so badly wounded that police at first thought the youngsters had been shot. His hands were ripped to pieces as he tried to defend himself.

And the polo necks? The boys' murderers slashed their throats several times when they were already dead or dying, so they were to cover up the gaping wounds, allowing family to kiss them farewell.

Welcome to peace, Northern Ireland-style. The paramilitaries are supposed to have laid down their weapons.

But in Portadown a long-simmering loyalist dispute is now descending into murderous war. Ceasefires are proving elastic. Had this happened in the home counties, it would have been big news. As it is, the teenagers are quickly forgotten statistics.

The origins of the loyalist dispute date to August 1996, when the Ulster Volunteer Force leadership stood down its most feared operative, Billy Wright.

His support for the 1994 loyalist ceasefire evaporated after the IRA ended its 17-month cessation with the Docklands bomb that February.

He shrugged off the UVF leadership's death threat, and with his Mid-Ulster brigade, founded the Loyalist Volunteer Force. It was an uncompromising opponent of attempts to find a political solution, trying to wreck all-party talks by murdering several Catholics.

The turf tensions have simmered since, erupting at Portadown FC's Sharmock Park on December 27 last year on the second anniversary of Wright's murder at the Maze prison. LVF members retired there after a memorial service at Wright's grave, and a pitched battle broke out with UVF members, leaving several LVF men seriously injured.

The LVF took a fortnight to wreak revenge. Richard Jameson, 46, who led the attack, was shot dead. Security sources described him as UVF leader in Mid-Ulster. His fam ily denied it. Portadown has been anticipating retaliation. But no one quite expected it to come like this.

Robb, who was this year to have married Sandra Burton, mother of his nine-month-old daughter Megan, spent some of his last day at Craigavon magistrates court. He was facing a grievous bodily harm charge, and police wanted him to be refused bail.

Their bid failed, but bail came with restrictions. He was subject to a nightly curfew, was to stay away from licensed premises, and was forbidden to drink alcohol.

He knew McIlwaine, but the pair were far from friends. Robb was convicted of an attack on him three years ago, apparently over McIlwaine's relationship with a Catholic girl.

Robb, though, had offered McIlwaine an apology and a drink when they met at the Spot Nightclub in Tandragee a few weeks back.

They were to run into each other again on Friday of last week.

According to the LVF, the UVF was lying in wait outside the club. Its plan was to attack two LVF members on its eight-name death list, but the would-be targets had left earlier than expected.

Robb was with his girlfriend and another couple. He offered a lift to McIlwaine, but the taxi driver refused to take five people. So Robb stayed with McIlwaine to wait for the next taxi. They were last seen at 1.30am.

Police and loyalist sources agree Robb was, at most, a groupie. They say he was no paramilitary.

McIlwaine, a graphic design student, was without a political thought. He had friends across the religious divide, as the 600 sympathy cards pouring into his family's home testify.

Sources close to the LVF in Portadown said: "The UVF in Belfast were putting a lot of pressure because nothing had been done after Jameson. They just wanted something done.

"The boy Robb was known to Tandragee UVF. So they decided to do him, and McIl waine was just in the wrong place at the wrong time."

UVF sources say Robb was dealing in drugs, and was the victim of an LVF assassination over unpaid money. His family angrily rejects that.

Police, led by Detective Chief Inspector Alan Todd, at first played down suggestions that the incident was related to a loyalist fued. But now six people, believed to include several UVF members, are in custody under the prevention of terrorism act.

In a blue bedroom with burnished floorboards and posters of Courtney Cox, Bart Simpson and David Ginola on the walls, Paul McIlwaine, 39, picks his way through his younger son's belongings.

He lays down the mobile phone he bought last Saturday. The first call he received on it was to tell him David was dead.

"His friends were from all over, Catholic or Protestant. He was brought up that way.

"I keep getting flashbacks about what it must have been like for him as he tried to escape. He was never a fighter, and I know he would have been terrified..."

"I just don't know how we are ever going to get through this."

webTitle: Ex-boss of shamed agency tears 'unbearable' models off a strip

fields.headline: Ex-boss of shamed agency tears 'unbearable' models off a strip
fields.trailText: Top models such as Naomi Campbell are nothing but a bunch of "unbearable shits surrounded by leeches", according to John Casablancas, the man from Paris's Elite agency, which was the focus of a damning BBC documentary in November.
fields.body:
Top models such as Naomi Campbell are nothing but a bunch of "unbearable shits surrounded by leeches", according to John Casablancas, the man from Paris's Elite agency, which was the focus of a damning BBC documentary in November.

Although spared the sex and drug allegations that forced the resignation of some executives, Mr Casablancas, 57, has given up his post as the agency's chief executive and moved to Rio de Janeiro with his Brazilian wife. The modelling world is "detestable", he says.

Among the "mean and ungrateful" women he regrets having turned into world stars, Naomi Campbell was the most "odious". "You can't imagine the pleasure it gave me to sack her," he told the French people's magazine, VSD. "She went out every night. She had four dresses in her bag so that she could change in the car during nights out. She never slept and God knows how she kept in form.

"All (top models) are so arrogant. An agent is no more than a lackey. During 25 years in the job, only Linda Evangelista has praised me for getting her to the top. None of the others even thanked me."

Mr Casablancas, who said his departure was directly linked to the fallout from the BBC documentary, described Heidi Klum as a "German sausage without talent". "She hardly earned a million francs (about £100,000) a year before we made her a star earning 20 times that much," he added.

Saying he had left Paris because he could not stand being with any of the great names on the fashion platforms, he added: "When I'm with one who gets on my nerves, I sack her with a kick up the bottom. My time of being an arse-licker for famous 'tops' is over."

Despite his apparent disgust for the profession, Mr Casablancas said he would start recruiting for Elite's South American agency, Elsa, forecasting that the region would be the main supplier of models during the next five years.

"When I started in the 1970s, fashion demanded blonde girls with blue eyes from Britain, America and Scandi navia. I gamble on exotic beauties with a dark look, but there is no one more unsure of herself than a fashion professional. They all wear black because they are afraid of committing a dress faux-pas."

webTitle: Private work ruling may cost doctor dear

fields.headline: Private work ruling may cost doctor dear
fields.trailText: A famous infertility expert may be forced to pay his former university employers hundreds of thousands of pounds after a high court judge ruled he had profited from a private practice using the university's staff.
fields.body:
A famous infertility expert may be forced to pay his former university employers hundreds of thousands of pounds after a high court judge ruled he had profited from a private practice using the university's staff.

Simon Fishel, an embryologist who pioneered treatment for infertile couples, ran clinics abroad which brought in fees from patients of up to £10,000 each.

His former employers, Nottingham university, sued him for "secret profits" reaped while he was a university employee after he had later left to set up a rival clinic.

But the court case is expected to leave an even bigger hole in the finances of the university, which is thought to have spent over £500,000 pursuing Dr Fishel, who mortgaged his farmhouse at East Bridgford, Notts, to fight the case.

The university, which sued Dr Fishel for £400,000, succeeded on only part of its claim.

Mr Justice Elias ruled that Dr Fishel had breached his employment contract in failing to secure permission to carry out infertility treatments in Italy, South Africa and the Middle East, but awarded no damages to the university.

The judge decided that Dr Fishel, who was scientific di rector of the university's Nurture clinic, had breached his duty to the university in using its staff embryologists to carry out treatments. He had to pay the university the profits he made from supervising their work. But a claim for the profits from Dr Fishel's own work was rejected.

A separate hearing will quantify the sums involved, but the judge said Dr Fishel could offset the payments he had made to the embryologists and the tax he had paid on the profit. Dr Fishel said yesterday that he believed the final figure would be less than £75,000.

A future hearing will decide how much he will have to pay to the university in profits. A judge will also have to decide how the huge costs of the hearing should be split, since neither side won a clear-cut victory.

After the judgment, Dr Fishel, 47, called on the higher education funding council to launch an inquiry "so that the council at Nottingham and at other universities can learn the lessons from this case and never waste public money again".

He said he had made several attempts to reach a settlement with the university and provided full details of his assets and income so the university could see the costs being built up were beyond his means.

Keith Jones, the university registrar, rejected suggestions by the infertility expert that he had not made much money from his private ventures.

The judge accepted that Dr Fishel had benefited the university through the knowledge he and his colleagues gained by using techniques abroad which were not permitted by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority in Britain.

Despite Dr Fishel's salary - £138,000 in 1996 - Mr Justice Elias was told he charged patients for treatment at foreign clinics and kept the money for himself and to pay the Nurture embryologists and other staff.

His profit-making business used the Nurture name and the university's employees, secretarial facilities, fax machine, computers, paper and equipment, the judge was told.

The judge said he was satisfied that Dr Fishel's trips abroad did not prejudice the university clinic or lead to a reduction in the number of patients.

Mr Justice Elias said Dr Fishel did not make "secret profits" as alleged by the university because the outside bodies were employing him not as a university employee but because of his reputation.

But the judge said Dr Fishel's use of university embryologists in his work abroad was making use of his position to "further his own interests" and there had been no consent for this from his superiors.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Sergeant on sex offenders list
fields.body:
Sergeant on sex offenders list

Police sergeant David Jewell, 41, of Newcastle, was yesterday fined £400 at Doncaster crown court for indecently assaulting a boy of 16 in a public toilet.

A Northumbria police spokesman said he would be the first officer in the force placed on the sex offenders' register.

Millionaire TV quiz for Japan

Who Wants to be a Millionaire? yesterday became the first British TV quiz to be sold to Japan.

The top-rated series will be restyled for a Japanese audience after Celador Productions struck a deal for an initial 26-episode run.

Dome hits new high

The Millennium Dome has recorded its best ever week with seven sold-out days over the half-term holidays.

Dome bosses say at least 25,000 people have passed through the gates each day during the holidays.

Train strikes averted

A series of strikes by train drivers threatened against Connex, which runs trains in London and the south east, was called off yesterday after an industrial relations row was settled.

The drivers' union, Aslef, had planned 24-hour walkouts starting next Tuesday.

Anaesthetist quits

Anaesthetist John Evans-Appiah, censured by an inquiry into the death during treatment of Darren Denholm, 10, has left his job with an east London GP.

fields.headline: Foreign workers flock to London
fields.trailText: London is becoming the number one choice of destination for foreign workers with more than one in seven of its workforce now non-British.
fields.body:
London is becoming the number one choice of destination for foreign workers with more than one in seven of its workforce now non-British.

Some 482,000 foreign workers are employed in the capital, and with their families they swell the population by nearly 1m.

According to the most-recent labour force survey, the figure accounts for almost half of the 1,043,000 foreign workers in Britain. Across the nation, just one in 25 workers are non-British.

London has always been viewed as a transient destination for casual workers from the continent and from "old" Commonwealth countries - Australia, Canada, New Zealand and South Africa - who have traditionally taken shop and bar work while imbibing the capital's culture and using it as a stepping stone to explore the rest of Europe.

But while casual work remains popular, those flocking to the capital are increasingly young professionals working in the City.

The new migrant population comes predominantly from Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, the US, France and Germany. And, while the lure of "cool Britannia" may hold sway, so do more hard-headed, fiscally-sound motives. Better tax breaks, higher salaries and the kudos of working in Europe's foremost financial centre - with the associated career benefits - are more important.

As Adele Fitzgerald, of the recruitment agency Robert Walters Resourcing, which gleans 60% of its 3,000 workers from Australia and New Zealand and 20% from South Africa, said: "Young professionals know they can come over here and work hard for a couple of years and make a lot of money."

Desley Lumsden, an Australian IT worker in a major investment bank, is one of the new breed. The 26-year-old came to London from Sydney three years ago and swiftly saw her salary quadruple.

"The opportunities are definitely greater over here and I know that if I go back home I'll be able to get a much better job, having worked with high-profile overseas companies," she said.

The financial benefits are also felt by EU nationals for whom the British tax system is more preferential. London has become the eldorado for young French and German business people forced to pay up to 60% of their salary in tax - in contrast to Britain's 40% - once they earn the equivalent of £40,000.

"Certainly, London's seen as a very attractive place to live at the moment - the equivalent of New York in terms of kudos - but I'm here because it's good for my career, to be able to go back with this experience."

"People in their twenties tend to come over because of the City of London, because the capital markets are more developed and the transactions are more complex.

"Take the recent Vodafone Mannesman transaction: that took place in London not Frankfurt. There's more activity, more to do, more to get involved with."

webTitle: Paul Foot named journalist of decade

fields.headline: Paul Foot named journalist of decade
fields.trailText: The Guardian writers, Paul Foot and Clare Hollingworth, were yesterday honoured for their campaigning journalism in the annual What the Papers Say awards at London's Savoy Hotel.
fields.body:
The Guardian writers, Paul Foot and Clare Hollingworth, were yesterday honoured for their campaigning journalism in the annual What the Papers Say awards at London's Savoy Hotel.

Mr Foot, honoured for his tenacious work on the Hanratty hanging investigation, arms to Iraq and the Bridgewater Three, was named Journalist of the Decade, while Ms Hollingworth, whose exclusive on the defection of Kim Philby to the USSR shook the establishment, was given a lifetime achievement award.

The judges' citation with Mr Foot's award, which was pre sented by the Tory leader, William Hague, read: "At the end of the 1990s we look back and see how many times Paul Foot's campaigns have made a difference.

"His persistence is a lesson to all journalists."

Ms Hollingworth, who famously broke the news of the outbreak of the world war two, was called "the doyenne of war correspondents" whose career "reads like a history of conflict in the 20th century".

The other awards at the ceremony, which will be shown on BBC2 at 5.30pm today, included:

Scoop of the Year: News of the World, for Rob Kellaway's exclusive on Lord Archer which revealed he had made a false alibi on the night he was accused of sleeping with a call girl and which led to him quitting the election race for London's mayor.

Newspaper/Editor of the year: The Times, Peter Stothard.

Interview of the year: Ginny Dougary, The Times, for her Michael Portillo interview in which he admitted homosexual experiences.

Columnist of the year: Deborah Orr, The Independent.

Foreign correspondent of the year: Robert Fisk, The Independent.

Critic of the year: A.A. Gill, The Sunday Times.

webTitle: Army rifles which jam and 'fail in extreme weather' are recalled

fields.headline: Army rifles which jam and 'fail in extreme weather' are recalled
fields.trailText: A total of 300,000 rifles used as a standard weapon throughout the armed forces will be recalled and their defects remedied in a rolling modification programme that will begin soon, the ministry of defence said yesterday.
fields.body:
A total of 300,000 rifles used as a standard weapon throughout the armed forces will be recalled and their defects remedied in a rolling modification programme that will begin soon, the ministry of defence said yesterday.

The SA80 rifles are prone to jamming and are unreliable in extreme weather. They are also unable to fire US or European ammunition.

Government sources yesterday said problems with the weapon had been inherited and Geoff Hoon, defence secretary, was determined to solve them. Mr Hoon insisted that "in most circumstances this is a highly effective weapon, light, easy to use and it is extremely accurate."

He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "We've been aware for some time that this rifle had problems in extremes of heat and the extremes of the Arctic and very hot weather in the desert."

The SA80 was designed by Royal Ordnance in the 1980s when the company was state-owned. Though it is now the responsibility of Heckler and Kock, a subsidiary of BAE Systems, the cost of modifying the weapon - which could reach tens of millions of pounds - will be met by the taxpayer.

Bruce George, chairman of the Commons defence committee, said he had followed the "sorry saga" of the SA80 since the early 1980s. His committee had reported on the rifle in 1993, chronicling its "unbelievable" problems. Anyone firing the gun from the left shoulder had great difficulty, he said.

After the 1991 Gulf war, when soldiers reported problems with the rifles in desert conditions, they were modified in a £28m programme.

Mr George said many servicemen were not as unhappy as the media: "They say as long as they look after it, clean it every day, it's a good weapon."

Menzies Campbell, Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, asked: "Isn't it time that someone took responsibility for these embarrassing and inadequate procurement projects?"

webTitle: Police search shell of Tory MP's home

fields.headline: Police search shell of Tory MP's home
fields.standfirst: More about Michael Colvin MP
fields.trailText: The children of Tory MP Michael Colvin and his wife Nichola paid tribute to an "inseparable" couple yesterday as investigators searched the area where they perished in a ferocious house blaze.
fields.body:
The children of Tory MP Michael Colvin and his wife Nichola paid tribute to an "inseparable" couple yesterday as investigators searched the area where they perished in a ferocious house blaze.

Police, fire officers and forensic scientists were able to enter for the first time the burnt-out shell of the Romsey MP's £3m home in Tangley, Hampshire.

The 20-strong team sieved through debris in the cellar of the mansion's west wing. The fire on Wednesday morning destroyed the roof, attic, the first floor - where Mr and Mrs Colvin were believed to have been sleeping - and ground floor of the building.

Their children held a minute's silence yesterday inside the gutted building, accompanied by a priest, overlooking the spot where the couple are believed to be.

The son, Jamie Cayzer-Colvin, 24, accompanied by his sisters Arabella Gaggero, 39, and Amanda Ponsonby, 42, their mother's sister Elizabeth Gilmour, and their father's brother Alistair Colvin, later read from a prepared statement outside the home.

The family were "overwhelmed by the amazing warmth and kindness that has been shown to us by so many people during these dreadfully sad hours," said Mr Cayzer-Colvin.

"My parents touched countless people's lives but none more so than all those at Tangley who meant so much to them and who did so much to help on Thursday morning.

"We would also very much like to express our profound gratitude to all those men and women of the emergency services who worked tirelessly in such painful circumstances.

"Mamma and Dadda were devoted to each other. They were inseparable in life and our only consolation is knowing that they died together in the home they loved."

Fire officers said they were unlikely to find any recognisable remains of the couple. Police and fire officers were last night still unable to establish a cause of the blaze and the forensic effort will continue for several days.

With police yet to rule out arson, sniffer dogs were brought in. Layers of rubble and dust reached four feet and parts of the remains were still hot despite heavy rain.

webTitle: Rugby team has Joneses by the dozen

fields.headline: Rugby team has Joneses by the dozen
fields.trailText: It might be a crucial rugby match between two fierce opponents, but once the referee blows the whistle to let battle commence it could be described as a case of keeping up with the Joneses.
fields.body:
It might be a crucial rugby match between two fierce opponents, but once the referee blows the whistle to let battle commence it could be described as a case of keeping up with the Joneses.

When the Bala rugby club takes to the field against Fairwater today, it promises to be every commentator's and referee's nightmare with no fewer than 10 of their 15 players starting the match all called Jones, and with another two players bearing the same surname sitting on the subsitutues bench.

All seven Bala backs are called Jones. To make matters even more complicated, their opponents have four Morgans.

Dilwyn Morgan, a Bala second-row player, said: "There are so many Joneses it gets us confused, so we have nicknames. It's a common name around here, but it's still unusual to have so many in one side."

The Worthington Welsh districts quater-final match will take place in Cardiff and the referee has been warned that he might have a few problems once he has seen the team sheet.

Ray Hobby, treasurer of Fairwater rugby club, said he was amazed when he was sent the team sheet. "The 12 Joneses are all listed together and our programme could become something of a collector's item. I never known some many Joneses to be in the same team.."

The competition, for lower league Welsh rugby teams, culminates with a final at Cardiff's newly built Millennium Stadium.

webTitle: BT software failure cuts off emergency services

fields.headline: BT software failure cuts off emergency services
fields.trailText: The failure of a key part of British Telecom's network yesterday left millions of people unable to use emergency numbers to report gas and water leaks, contact the Samaritans and NHS Direct or use company help lines.
fields.body:
The failure of a key part of British Telecom's network yesterday left millions of people unable to use emergency numbers to report gas and water leaks, contact the Samaritans and NHS Direct or use company help lines.

Calls to banks, railway timetable inquiries, the AA and RAC emergency services and the internet were also severely disrupted. Last night problems were still being experienced.

A BT spokesman said a computer in Leeds, used to route 0800, 0845 and 0834 calls, had crashed at 10.30am. The company did not know the cause of the crash and attempts to reboot the system had failed.

"Calls to organisations including Railtrack, Virgin, the AA, British Gas and some of the major banks have been affected," he said.

"This problem affects our derived services network which sits above the public telephone network. The impact has only been on this part of our business. But this is one of the worst problems we have had with this network which is designed to reroute traffic."

Although the failure was causing congestion elsewhere on the network, 999 emergency calls were unaffected.

Many companies have a single 0845 or 0345 number that enables customers throughout the country to call them for the cost of a local call.

The RAC said half the calls to its freephone numbers, including its breakdown and accident services, were not getting through. "We are urging BT to put a message on the system explaining what has happened," a spokesman said.

Transco, responsible for the country's gas pipelines, said several customers using its emergency reporting number had got either an engaged tone or a dead line. Some calls had got through, however, and it urged customers to keep trying the emergency number.

"We have occasionally had problems like this, though usually for not more than half an hour," a spokesman said. "We get a few calls passed on to us through the emergency services because customers sometimes call them."

British Gas Trading, the gas and electricity supply business, said: "We had hoped that BT would have solved their fault by now. It is very inconvenient for our customers."

NatWest Bank said it was asking radio stations to give out alternative numbers for its branches and its telephone banking and internet services.

BT refused to comment on possible compensation for companies that had lost business. "We have contracts with these companies and will be talking with them about the impact it has had," the spokesman said.

By last night, despite scores of software engineers attempting to correct the fault, BT admitted a third of all calls to the affected numbers were still not getting through.

A spokesman said: "We are still not sure what the originating cause is but it was definitely a software glitch and nothing more sinister."

webTitle: Fancy a loan ... only seven times your salary

fields.headline: Fancy a loan ... only seven times your salary
fields.standfirst: More about house prices
fields.trailText: Mortgages at seven times the borrower's income, loans at 120% of a house's value, first-time buyers clubbing together to buy a home... lenders may insist they are keeping the purse strings tight as house prices soar, but brokers are telling another story.
fields.body:
Mortgages at seven times the borrower's income, loans at 120% of a house's value, first-time buyers clubbing together to buy a home... lenders may insist they are keeping the purse strings tight as house prices soar, but brokers are telling another story.

"We had Northern Rock in here a couple of weeks ago almost bragging that they've arranged mortgages at five times income," Mike Cook, broker for London & Country in Bath, said.

"They will also give you a 95% loan and then let you borrow another 25% at the same rate."

Mortgage "stretch" is the buzzword among brokers, who regularly bypass published maximum lending criteria. Halifax says its average loan to value level has fallen over the past year, but yesterday leapfrogged competitors and raised its published maximum loan to 97% from 95%, in order to help first-time buyers.

Some lenders will not even ask how much you earn and the average size of mortgage has leapt dramatically. "Our typical mortgage size is now £125,000-£150,000. Two years ago it was £75,000-£100,000," Sandy Paterson of Millfield Partnership in West Byfleet, Surrey, said.

Clubbing together to buy a house, common in the 1980s, is gaining in popularity again.

But lenders insist that high-risk lending is under control. "These loans are the exception rather than the rule," the Woolwich said.

webTitle: Greenpeace climbers board GM soya ship

fields.headline: Greenpeace climbers board GM soya ship
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Five Greenpeace climbers were last night continuing the occupation of a Greek-owned grain ship which is carrying up to 60,000 tons of GM soya beans from the United States to Britain.
fields.body:
Five Greenpeace climbers were last night continuing the occupation of a Greek-owned grain ship which is carrying up to 60,000 tons of GM soya beans from the United States to Britain.

The three men and two women - who Greenpeace claims are all experienced climbers - attached lines to the 71,749 ton Iolcos Grace early yesterday when it was anchored one mile off Anglesey preparing to catch the tide to enter and discharge its cargo of soya beans in Liverpool.

Boarding from three inflatables, the activists met no resistance from the mainly Filipino crew.

Although Greenpeace has occupied government boats and oil platforms before, it is thought to be the first time the environmental group has boarded a privately-owned cargo vessel. In 1995 it occupied the redundant Brent Spar oil platform for 23 days.

Last night three of the activists, all British, were hanging off the bows and anchor chain preventing the Panamanian-registered vessel from moving, and two were on deck having failed to persuade the captain to return to New Orleans.

Greenpeace refused to say how long the occupation would last but said the activists were determined and equipped to stay for a considerable time.

Keeping a ship the size of the Iolcos Grace at sea is thought to cost at least £5,000 a day.

Cargill's, the owner of the soya cargo, is the largest private company in the world and dominates the global trade in grains and seeds.

Last night the company said that some of the soya was ge netically modified but argued that it was legal and that it was responding to the UK demand for the beans.

As most British food processors have declared themselves GM-free, it is likely that almost all the soya will be used in animal feed.

Greenpeace last night called for an end to the importation of all GM crops, saying that the shipment was unwanted and should be returned to America immediately.

"Apart from Cargill's and some animal feed makers, there's no public demand whatever for GM soya in Britain," said Blake Lee-Harwood of Greenpeace.

"We are on the ship, we don't want it to move, and we want Cargill's to turn it around," he added.

"It is pointless bringing in thousands of tons of GM soya only to contaminate the food chain."

webTitle: Call to cap charges for cash machines

fields.headline: Call to cap charges for cash machines
fields.trailText: The price of withdrawing money from cash machines should be capped at 30p - a cut of up to £2.20 for some customers, according to the man hand-picked by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to investigate the high street banks.
fields.body:
The price of withdrawing money from cash machines should be capped at 30p - a cut of up to £2.20 for some customers, according to the man hand-picked by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to investigate the high street banks.

Don Cruickshank, a former telecoms regulator, also recommended that cash machines should warn customers of any charge they face and insisted his ideas would see cash machines installed in rural and isolated communities around the country.

Mr Cruickshank also said non-financial institutions, such as the supermarkets and the oil companies that own petrol stations, should be able to set up a network of cash machines.

His investigation, prompted by a public bust-up between Barclays bank and the Nationwide building society over the way charges should be levied on customers, found it cost cash machine owners just 29p to process a transaction.

The figure is disputed by the major owners of cash machines, primarily the high street banks, who argue it costs them hundreds of millions of pounds to keep the 27,000-strong network running.

"Increased competition will ensure that charges, where levied, are driven closer to costs than at present," said Mr Cruickshank, who does not have any direct powers. But he made it clear yesterday he would call for a competition commission investigation into cash machines if the charges did not fall.

His recommendations will be considered by the treasury and the department of trade and industry.

The banks and building societies face a showdown on Tuesday when they try to hammer out a solution to the overcharging. Nationwide, which allows its customers to use any cash machines in the Link network for free, objects to a new £1 "surcharge" which Barclays wants to inflict on its rivals' customers using its cash machines.

Until the Barclays move, the Link network had operated on a "disloyalty" basis where customers were charged up to £1.50 by their banks for using rivals' machines.

The Barclays plan raised the prospect of some customers paying up to £2.50 to withdraw cash.

webTitle: Guardian's Foot is journalist of decade

fields.headline: Guardian's Foot is journalist of decade
fields.trailText: The Guardian columnist Paul Foot yesterday received the prestigous journalist of the decade award in the annual What the Papers Say awards at the Savoy hotel in London. Clare Hollingworth, the Guardian's former defence correspondent, won the lifetime achievement award.
fields.body:
The Guardian columnist Paul Foot yesterday received the prestigous journalist of the decade award in the annual What the Papers Say awards at the Savoy hotel in London. Clare Hollingworth, the Guardian's former defence correspondent, won the lifetime achievement award.

The judges said Foot had always stuck to his principles "and to the chagrin of the authorities has been proved right time and time again". They cited investigations into the Hanratty case, the Bridgewater three, arms to Iraq and the Archer and Aitken stories as examples of his tenacity. They went on: "At the end of the 90s we look back and see how many times Paul Foot's campaigns have made a difference. His persistence is a lesson to all journalists."

webTitle: Editor of Mirror in new share claims

fields.headline: Editor of Mirror in new share claims
fields.trailText: Speculation over the future of the Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, intensified last night after fresh evidence emerged surrounding his controversial purchase of £20,000 worth of shares in the hi-tech company Viglen Technology last month, a deal which is now the subject of a department of trade and industry inquiry.
fields.body:
Speculation over the future of the Mirror editor, Piers Morgan, intensified last night after fresh evidence emerged surrounding his controversial purchase of £20,000 worth of shares in the hi-tech company Viglen Technology last month, a deal which is now the subject of a department of trade and industry inquiry.

Mr Morgan was cleared by the newspaper's owners, Trinity Mirror, after explaining that he bought the shares - on which he made a profit of 100% - without knowing they were about to be tipped in the paper by his City Slickers columnists.

After the story appeared in the Mirror the next day the value of the shares soared. In his defence, Mr Morgan said he had purchased the shares six hours before the columnists obtained the story.

But last night that version of events was being contradicted. It emerged that the columnists Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, who have been sacked, met the chief executive of Viglen on Friday January 14. Mr Morgan bought his shares on the following Monday.

Mr Morgan said the story about Viglen's new internet venture was not written and ready for the paper until after the markets had closed on Monday January 17. But it is now claimed that the piece in question was prepared by mid-afternoon.

Mr Bhoyrul's lawyers are also understood to be in possession of an email from Mr Morgan which they will claim presupposes an earlier conversation between the two about Viglen on the day he bought the shares. The lawyers are claiming compensation after Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Hipwell were accused of gross misconduct for tipping shares that they owned. They were sacked without a payoff a week ago.

They will aim to prove that their actions were part of a culture endemic in the Mirror and that they have been used as scapegoats. They are expected to claim they misled the group board in their initial disciplinary hearings to cover Mr Morgan.

Viglen has supplied a letter to the stock exchange detailing when the information was passed to the journalists.

Mr Morgan, who spent last week in the Caribbean with his family, was unavailable for comment. He is expected back in the office on Tuesday. A spokesman for Trinity Mirror denied widespread rumours that Mr Morgan had offered to resign and reiterated that the board had cleared him of any wrongdoing.

Jonathan Silverman, who is representing Mr Bhoyrul, would not discuss details of the case but said: "We are taking the stance that while he still worked for the Mirror, Anil felt a certain, albeit misplaced, loyalty but he will now tell the whole story. Anil believes he has been used as a scapegoat."

Claims of up to £50,000 can be made through employment tribunals.

The internal investigation at the Mirror is understood to have led to a number of staff being questioned, including the deputy editor Tina Weaver.

Mr Morgan also bought shares in at least two other companies which featured in the City Slickers column: Wiggins and Corporate Executive Search.

fields.headline: Suspended term on toxic waste
fields.trailText: A former director of two companies which handled radioactive materials yesterday received a suspended prison sentence for illegal disposal of toxic waste.
fields.body:
A former director of two companies which handled radioactive materials yesterday received a suspended prison sentence for illegal disposal of toxic waste.

Jenny Seward, who was director of CSW Engineering Ltd and P Jenson & Company, became the first individual to be prosecuted for the offence, the environment agency said.

Ms Seward was given a 12 month sentence suspended for two years, and fined £4,000 by St Albans crown court for illegally disposing of depleted uranium on publicly accessible land.

The cost of the clean-up and disposal of the radioactive waste is expected to exceed £250,000, the agency said.

The former director, who had operated from premises in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, was found guilty under the radioactive substances act at Hemel Hempstead magistrates court last November.

The agency said Ms Seward had arranged for over half a tonne of depleted uranium waste to be secretly removed from company premises and illegally disposed of in 1993 after both firms had ceased trading.

An investigation launched in 1994 after several kilos of the toxic waste were discovered at a scrapyard in Sheffield led to the discovery of several hundred kilos at Poplar's Farm, Chelveston, Northamptonshire.

The agency removed the depleted uranium from both sites and arranged for its safe storage.

fields.headline: Lenders given mortgage warning
fields.standfirst: City watchdog fears rerun of early 90s repossession crisis as borrowings soarMore about house prices
fields.trailText: The City's top regulator yesterday warned mortgage companies that they are lending homebuyers too much money, raising fears of a rerun of the early 1990s repossession crisis.
fields.body:
The City's top regulator yesterday warned mortgage companies that they are lending homebuyers too much money, raising fears of a rerun of the early 1990s repossession crisis.

Against a backdrop of national house price rises of 16%, the Financial Services Authority has found "worrying signs" that mortgage lenders - who between them are owed nearly £450bn - are adopting laxer lending policies than in recent years.

After scrutinising the loans granted by nine of the biggest mortgage lenders, Howard Davies, chairman of the FSA, urged lenders to be more cautious when making loans to home buyers.

While making it clear the market did not yet resemble the late 1980s and early 1990s, when thousands of people faced having their homes repossessed, Mr Davies was clearly concerned about mortgage market lending trends.

In a speech to the country's major lenders yesterday, he "strongly counselled prudence and called on lenders to review their lending practices".

At the annual Council of Mortgage Lenders lunch he also issued a warning to house buyers that they could no longer rely on house inflation to reduce their debts.

Mr Davies' comments carry extra weight if, as is expected, the FSA takes over the regulation of the mortgage market. He sounded the alarm bells after an FSA survey of the nine major lenders, who between them account for 54% of the mortgage market. The survey found they were giving loans to customers at increasing greater multiples of their salaries. At the same time, they were offering borrowers loans against a greater proportion of their new homes than in past.

This was causing the regulator increasing concern in an environment where house buyers also owe a record £83bn of money on an increasing amount of "non mort gage" debt, for instance on car loans.

Mr Davies urged mortgage lenders, who have all introduced more flexible products for borrowers, not to let "the hard learned lessons of the last recession to recede from corporate memories".

His comments come at time of heated debated in the City about the speed at which the Bank of England will raise interest rates this year. Rates could rise from the current 6% to just 7.5% - still well below the double figures inflicted on lenders at the height of the last housing boom. That could take mortgage rates to above 9% from today's standard variable rate of 7.9%, causing hardship to first time buyers and other homeowners who have taken on large mortgages.

However, commentators say that in real terms, with inflation just 2%, the impact of mortgage rates could be just as painful for some borrowers.

The housing market itself is also patchy, with hotspots such as London leaping 25- 30% despite the 16% average.

The FSA survey found that homebuyers are being offered loans worth 3.5 to 3.75 times their income, compared with 3 to 3.25 before the boom. It also found that one in eight loans are for more than 95% of the value of a house, which means lenders are suffering higher risk on their mortgage books which could take five years to recede.

Mr Davies called on lenders to make their products simpler and eradicate difficult conditions such as tie-ins and redemption penalties. "It is in all our interests to clear up in those areas and to ensure that borrowers know what they are getting into," he said.

Halifax, Abbey National and Nationwide, the big three lenders, all insist that their average maximum lending percentages have been static or falling over the last year. They admit they do "stretch" their lending criteria in special circumstances but say this only makes up a tiny proportion of their total lending.

webTitle: Best man admits murder of bride

fields.headline: Best man admits murder of bride
fields.trailText: A best man yesterday pleaded guilty to the murder of a bride whose body was found in a swimming pool at her £400,000 home.
fields.body:
A best man yesterday pleaded guilty to the murder of a bride whose body was found in a swimming pool at her £400,000 home.

Darren Lake, 30, of Peterborough, admitted killing beautician Diane Emerson-Hawley in October last year. Her battered body was found in the water alongside that of her pet cat at the home in Uffington, Lincolnshire, she shared with her husband Colin Harrold.

A post-mortem examination later confirmed she had died from drowning.

During a 10-minute hearing at Lincoln crown court, Lake, broke down in tears as he was asked how he pleaded to charges of murdering and conspiracy to murder 36-year-old Mrs Emerson-Hawley. He pleaded guilty to both charges.

Lake had been the best man at Mr Harrold's wedding to his first wife Annette in Peterborough in 1989. Mrs Emerson-Hawley was Mr Harrold's second wife.

James Hunt, QC, prosecuting, said there were no reporting restrictions covering Lake's case and that a future trial of Harrold would hear that Lake had pleaded guilty. Businessman Harrold, 35, later pleaded not guilty to her murder.

During a five minute hearing at Lincoln crown court he denied charges of murder and conspiracy to murder his second wife.

Harrold, an entrepreneur and dealer in secondhand books, climbed the stairs to the dock in court number one carrying a pair of crutches - the result of a broken ankle which he had sustained recently playing badminton on remand in Nottingham prison.

Lake, 30, of Peterborough, Cambridgeshire, will be sentenced at the conclusion of Harrold's trial.
