webTitle: Ideals that bridge the generation gap

fields.headline: Ideals that bridge the generation gap
fields.standfirst: As Labour prepares to mark its 100th anniversary tomorrow, young and old party members speak of their hopes for the futureNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: As Labour prepares to mark its 100th anniversary tomorrow, young and old party members speak of their hopes for the future
fields.body:
Rebecca Foot, an 18-year-old student from Hindley, near Wigan in Lancashire, joined the Labour party three years ago through the internet.

She said: "I'm one of Thatcher's children. I wasn't even alive when we last had a Labour government, I was two when we had the longest suicide note in history, and apart from my A level politics studies, I only know about the miners' strike from what my grandma told me.

"But I took a bit of a keen interest in politics and I realised it was something on my own doorstep and that I could make a difference, so when I was 15, I got my dad to print off the application form from the website."

The decision to join Labour was an easy one to make. "This is a very staunch Labour area. I just looked at how awful the area where I live is, at the poverty and people with nothing to do and no hope in life, and I thought: why can't we do something?

"It's not idealism. If you believe you can't change things, what's the point of anything?"

With ambitions to be a Labour MP one day after she finishes her A-levels and her politics degree, she is a keen activist, attending meetings, leafleting and canvassing for votes.

"I go along to branch meetings and they are mostly full of older men. There are a few women who organise cups of tea, but I don't ever do that. It's changing and getting better, but slowly."

As a member of the national policy forum, Rebecca attended her first party conference last October. "It was a bit of an awakening, meeting members from London. Where I live, Labour politics is nothing like that. People my age aren't disillusioned with the party. They are just apathetic."

Rebecca, who describes her politics as "very much left wing", has nevertheless been in favour of the modernisation of the party which has taken place over her lifetime.

"What's the point in being a political party when people aren't going to vote for you? I don't think anybody could deny that Blair is a control freak but it's necessary to a point.

"I've only met Tony Blair once, when he spoke at Wigan town hall. He looked very tired and I felt quite sorry for him."

His best achievements had been the constitutional changes, the Northern Ireland peace process, and the partnership in power initiative, involving grassroots members in policy debate. "People feel they have more influence over policy now.

"The rank and file party members are still just as important as they always were."

Ted Redgrave, 94, is Labour's longest serving member. He joined the party in 1922 at the age of 16.

With 78 years as a party activist under his belt, he has met every Labour prime minister since Ramsay MacDonald and can still be found on the streets of Romsey, in Hampshire, delivering leaflets and canvassing voters.

"I got in by subterfuge. At that time, you had to be 21 to be a member, but I joined the Royal Arsenal Co-operative Society which was directly affiliated to the party."

The son of a tram conductor, Mr Redgrave grew up in Peckham, south London, where his mother stood as a Labour candidate in local elections.

His late wife, Annabella, also had an impressive political heritage from both her father, the Cannock Chase MP, William Adamson, and her mother, the suffragette, Jenny Adamson.

Mr Redgrave became a Labour activist during the 1920s. "I was out of work at the time and I believed in the theory behind co-operation. I had ideals at the time. We've come a long way but we've still got a lot to achieve.

"I still do a fair amount for the party as a leg man. I've always been a rank and file member but it's been an abiding passion. "My hero is Attlee. He came at a time when we only dreamed of getting power.

"We accomplished some amazing things but the health service has been our crowning glory and it's what I am most proud of. But we also got recognition of the workers and I'm proud of the attitudes the party has on racism.

"Blair has got the potential to be greater even than Attlee. I hope that the next century will be largely Labour - I can't see any reason why it shouldn't."

The last 78 years had seen a lot of change in the party membership. "When I joined it was all cloth caps and scarves - there were no young women. Only a few people had telephones and there was no radio, television or pagers so the role of the party activists was far more important. But the young members today are still as idealistic."

Mr Redgrave, who was invited to meet Tony Blair in Downing Street last year, said: "I think he's on the right line, he's just got to be careful about his priorities. "I've never thought of leaving the party. As people get older there is a tendency to look back wth rose-tinted spectacles on the past and think that nothing better can happen in the future. I don't - I think there's always still hope."

Mr Redgrave, who was invited to meet Tony Blair in Downing Street last year, said: "I think he's on the right line, he's just got to be careful about his priorities. "I've never thought of leaving the party. As people get older there is a tendency to look back wth rose-tinted spectacles on the past and think that nothing better can happen in the future. I don't - I think there's always still hope."

fields.headline: Blair woos disillusioned party activists
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will intensify his efforts to reach out to Labour's heartland supporters tomorrow when he lavishes praise on local activists as the "biggest heroes" throughout the party's 100-year history.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will intensify his efforts to reach out to Labour's heartland supporters tomorrow when he lavishes praise on local activists as the "biggest heroes" throughout the party's 100-year history.

Amid growing alarm in No 10 at New Labour's failure to inspire its traditional voters, Mr Blair will use a keynote speech marking the party's centenary to say that his modernisation programme is consistent with Labour's core values.

But the prime minister will emphasise that there can be no going back to the party values of the 1980s, when Labour was out of office after losing touch with "the needs of the nation".

The prime minister will open his speech in London by praising heroes of the left, such as Keir Hardie and Nye Bevan. But he will say that Labour's foot soldiers deserve the greatest praise.

"The people who may not think of themselves as heroes, but in many ways are the biggest heroes of all, are the party members who stuck with us through the hard times as well as the good.

"It is you, after all, who saw us through the periods of deepest despair, stuck with the party and helped see it back to power. Even when we were written off we bounced back and that was down to members and trade unions is every community continuing to fight for us."

His message will be aimed directly at core supporters who complain that the prime minister gives the impression that he holds party stalwarts in contempt.

Many Labour MPs have complained to Millbank that the party's "fortresses" are feeling neglected because of Downing Street's apparent disregard for their efforts and its habit of distancing itself from Labour's core beliefs.

Their anger is articulated today by the former Labour leader Michael Foot. Writing in the Guardian, he says: "A Labour movement which turned its back on the deepening gulf between rich and poor, just at the moment when it seemed to be becoming even more severe, would not be worthy of the name."

The prime minister will attempt to soothe this anger by saying that Labour should be proud of past achievements.

"It was our reforms that civilised the 20th century," Mr Blair will say. "We were the civilising force even when not in power, when we forced onto the agenda our ideals of decency and justice."

The prime minister will single out Clement Attlee's 1945 government, which presided over the creation of the NHS, as the greatest peacetime government of the last century. But he will use the example of Attlee's government, which failed to achieve a full second term, as a warning to today's party of the dangers of allowing feuding to break out.

Turning to his own record, Mr Blair will say that he shares the frustration of supporters at the speed of change. "Progress is slower than I would like, but we will get there."

Mr Blair will hold up the minimum wage and Gordon Brown's successful management of the economy as areas in which the demands of core voters are being met.

The prime minister's centenary speech is his most dramatic attempt to reach out to core supporters who appear to have deserted Labour in a succession of byelections.

webTitle: The people's party, from 1900 to Tony Blair

fields.headline: The people's party, from 1900 to Tony Blair
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: 1900 A start. Labour representation committee founded. Two MPs elected.
fields.body:
1900 A start. Labour representation committee founded. Two MPs elected.

1906 The road to power. Twenty-nine Labour MPs work in informal Lib-Lab pact after Liberal landslide victory over the Tories.

1918 A good idea at the time. Labour writes a socialist constitution, committing itself to "common ownership".

1924 The first government. Ramsay MacDonald's minority adminstration is voted out after 10 months.

1931 The worst moment of all. MacDonald breaks with his party over the financial crisis to head the Tory-dominated national government. Labour reduced to 52 MPs at the election.

1945 At last. Labour wins real power at the end of the second world war. With a majority of 143 it launches sweeping social reform.

1955 More feuding. Hugh Gaitskell's leadership victory after Clement Attlee's retirement triggers more infighting with the Bevanite left.

1966 Another high point. At his second attempt Harold Wilson wins a 99-seat majority. But economic problems quickly engulf his government.

1974 Back in power at the height of the coal and oil crisis. Five years of uninterrupted problems - and no majority. Result ? Thatcherism.

1983 Michael Foot goes down to a combination of Margaret Thatcher, victory in the Falklands and the breakaway SDP. Neil Kinnock starts the long road to recovery.

1992 Cruel disappointment. Kinnock expects to win, the polls and pundits say he will. But John Major snatches victory. A good election to lose.

1994 John Smith, the Labour leader, dies suddenly, ahead of an expected election win, just as Gaitskell did in 1963.

1997 Tony Blair wins the left's biggest election landslide of the 20th century, 179 seats. New Labour takes charge.

fields.headline: Mellow yellow
fields.standfirst: It could only be the Versace show
fields.trailText: It could only be the Versace show
fields.body:
Snakeskin mules, skin-tight dresses, backcombed hair, and a soundtrack by Boy George. It could only be the Versace show. For autumn/winter 2000, Donatella Versace chose to experiment with her favourite colour, green, on a galaxy of sexy evening dresses crying out to be worn to the Oscars, or any other occasion where flashes are sure to pop.

Bold aqua, olive and emerald prints were splashed over chiffon column dresses with plunging backs. In a collection remarkable for its marriage of contrasting fabrics, thin bands of leather were worked into sheer lace dresses and panels of suede patchworked on to finest jersey columns. Perfect if you're Amber, Gisele or Liz, but fantasy for the rest of us

Evening wear apart, the collection was more restrained than usual with enough easy daywear to keep the average woman happy. Shantung silk trousers in pale yellow or eau de nil were worn with printed blouses or narrow-shouldered jackets with peplum waists. Only the accessories screamed Versace: quilted gold bags with chain-link straps and wide suede belts emblazoned with the Medusa logo. Like so many collections in Milan this week, this one relied heavily on graphic patterns. Hair backcombed into a beehive gave a 60s feel.

Since taking over at Versace, Donatella has been praised for modifying her brother's sometimes extreme vision of womenswear into something more in tune with women's needs.

This collection confirmed that, and will further establish her as a designer in her own right.

Rumours abound in Milan that Versace, one of the city's biggest family-owned businesses, has been in talks with LVMH and may be putting itself on the market. Both sides have denied it.

fields.headline: Death cannot wither him
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
Sauntering around Virgin Megastore this week, I was elated to hear the in-house news jockey announce that Kevin Spacey is to play the lead in the forthcoming Bobby Darin biopic. The rest of the store took the news with comatose composure. "Come on! Think!" I felt like shouting. "Bobby Darin. You know. Little bloke. Wrote Dream Lover and sang Mack the Knife. Not quite handsome enough to be a true 50s teen idol. Not quite tall enough to be Sinatra. Probably seeing out his final days living in a trailer and working in a Kwiki-Mart in Spotted Horse, Wyoming."

That last bit's not true, but when you tell someone about Bobby Darin, you've got to start slow, begin with the distorted perception and build towards the truth. Darin has, in fact, been dead since 1973, but in his 37 frenetic years he managed to live a rock'n'roll life that rivals the most infernal heavy metal band for hellraising, the most industrious sonic architect for productivity, and the most agitated chameleon for diversity. But I wouldn't want to hit anyone with that kind of information straight away. If I told you that he made 18 albums in his first four years as a household name, starred in and directed countless movies, was nominated for an Oscar, campaigned for the counter-culture, hosted student protests, saw out a turbulent relationship with an alcoholic child movie star, and thought his sister was his mum until he was 32, you might not be able to cope.

When lost heroes are reappraised, Darin is usually overlooked - partly, perhaps, because he came of age long before cult music was acknowledged as a powerful force, and partly because people don't see his several personalities as belonging to the same man. How can the impudent Ray Charles Darin of Dream Lover be the same Darin who tearfully elevated If I Were a Carpenter to new levels of fractured emotion? Next to Darin, David Bowie's eclecticism and willingness to change with the times merely qualify him as an errant member of Status Quo. Lounge lizard, protest singer, folk rocker, children's entertainer, blue-eyed soul singer, rock'n'roller - Darin's mission was to be "musically all things to all people".

Darin's story is inspiring enough on musical evidence alone, but the brave gestures that back it up - peeling off his hairpiece in Vegas and affronting a stunned, strait-laced crowd with Blowin' In The Wind, enduring relentless touring schedules despite a failing heart, giving away all his possessions as a tribute to Bobby Kennedy - make it unmatched in the pop canon. The dicky-tickered Darin, once told he would not live to be a teenager, combined an insatiable hunger to be the best and the knowledge that every show, every song, every outlandish stunt, might be his last. If Spacey can convey even half of that, we may be awaiting the greatest rock'n'roll story never told.

fields.headline: Just point and shoot
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle  samples the Citibank photography prize
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle samples the Citibank photography prize
fields.body:
The Citibank Private Bank Photography Prize, worth £15,000 to the winner, is now in its fourth year. The name is a mouthful, and it isn't exactly the Turner, but it has become synonymous with an attitude to photography closer to the international art world than that of the pro photographer. Tim Macmillan, from Britain, Anna Gaskell and James Casebere, both from the US, Jitka Hanzlova from the Czech Republic and Australian Tracey Moffatt are this year's shortlist - cramped into the less than adequate confines of London's Photographers' Gallery.

Is James Casebere a photographer? He builds little table- top models of entire buildings, abandoned interiors, cavernous tunnels, flooded worm-holes and bleak cells, which he then turns into mysterious, unpeopled places of the imagination. These prisons, asylums, sewers and buried cities are the kinds of places you want to wake up from. Photography for him is a way of recording what he has already imagined, already built, already seen. Casebere has a concurrent, larger show at the Lisson Gallery, which makes one painfully aware of how compromised the displays in the prize show are, both for the contenders and for their audience.

Casebere makes us think of ancient oubliettes, old movies and fresh nightmares. Moffatt and Gaskell invent their photographic mises en scène too, but use live models to intimate narratives and play on different genres of photographic representation. They ape the manners of old photogravures, movie stills, fashion shoots and advertising images. What a tired old game this has become.

Moffatt's Laudanum, a series of grainy vignettes, uses the props and the manner of Victorian erotica, something professional pornographers have been doing for an entire century. Depicting the life of a servant and her mistress in a reverie of submission and humiliation, Moffatt leaves dangling the question of who these fantasies are for, and how we should feel about them. Another group, Scarred for Life, focuses on the everyday childhood humiliations of youngsters in small-town Australia. These images are supplemented with texts to explain them, which points up the weakness of the photographs and the leadenness of Moffatt's humour.

Anna Gaskell's images of young women dressed as nurses and performing odd, vaguely disturbing actions, have a mild frisson of the transgressive about them, and we learn that the series, By Proxy, has something to do with a real nurse, and sufferer of Munchausen's syndrome, who committed several murders in Texas in the 80s. More than one of these warmly lit, glossily produced images features little girls. Gaskell evokes complex, difficult issues without saying anything about them. It is all very well to present these images as "Freudian", as though to explain them, but then again, what isn't Freudian? What do we have to have explained, before we can know what we're looking at?

Both Moffatt's and Gaskell's works are seductive: they know about sheen, they know about inventing a drama. For me, their images have only a kind of fake power, fake drama. Like everyone else, I'm seduced by lots of images every day - but whatever stories they tell, or intimate, or photographically illustrate, nothing takes away my gut feeling that these are only people having their nice careers in the art world. Photography is big in art, it is omnipresent. They're just adding to the stockpile.

Tim Macmillan has invented a way of producing a composite image that appears to be three-dimensional. The image itself is static, but he directs us around it, making what I can only call still movies. The work here presents us with a real event - a horse in an abattoir caught at the moment of its death, all four legs off the ground, the worker holding the reins to still the horse in one hand, raising a rifle aloft with the other. The cameras circumnavigate the death. Macmillan's "time-slice" camera is much in demand for advertising and natural history projects. It's a great invention, and Dead Horse is a powerful, spectacular image, but in the end it still isn't as profoundly shocking or as moving as Eli Lotar's 20s photos of abattoirs.

As soon as you observe something, you change it. As soon as someone knows they are being photographed, they are altered by that fact. Like every happy snapper, Jitka Hanzlova knows this, and carries on anyway. In the context of this show, her work is the most refreshing, and in the particular sense that her work records her return to her homeland, to photograph places that she has left behind, her work carries with it a feeling of necessity. It isn't so much the individual photographs themselves that have particular resonance, more their cumulative effect, and our sense of the journey she has taken. They're awkward snapshots of places and people, of distance and proximity. These are stories without any imposed narrative. They're not trying to say anything much, except to concentrate on the quotidian: washing on a line in the snow, a woman on the street, a hunter with his trophy, a clock on the wall and flowers on the table. I want them to win.

webTitle: Will he be the next big wheel?

fields.headline: Will he be the next big wheel?
fields.standfirst:
Once called a 'garagiste arriviste' by fellow Tories, he didn't actually sell cars, but he had a winning way with car companies, and, notoriously, women. Now he wants Londoners to make him their mayor. John Cunningham on the former transport minister who thinks he can make the capital run on time
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Once called a 'garagiste arriviste' by fellow Tories, he didn't actually sell cars, but he had a winning way with car companies, and, notoriously, women. Now he wants Londoners to make him their mayor.  John Cunningham  on the former transport minister who thinks he can make the capital run on time
fields.body:
In the coming weeks, crowds in London will gasp at the skills of a solo performer who takes more risks than a dome aerialist, does slicker routines than a Fosse hoofer, and cracks more gags than Bob Monkhouse. Enter the official Conservative challenger to become the capital's first elected mayor: Steven Norris.

To secure the nomination, Norris has had to demonstrate wondrous powers. First he was defeated by Jeffrey Archer, but re-entered the contest after his main rival was disgraced. Having jumped head first through blazing hoops held by his opponents to get back on the shortlist, he was vanquished a second time when his former constituency denounced him as a liability in a letter to party activists. But eventually he got the nomination, while Archer was banished to the wilderness.

For both main political parties, the business of choosing a mayoral runner has been a murky one. Since Labour announced the result of its ballot, it has had to endure a week of farcical knock-about between Frank Dobson and Ken Livingstone, which hasn't done Norris's chances any harm at all.

So is Norris gloating at all this? "I've just been trying to wipe the grin off my face and not intrude on private grief," he says. The grin, though, is a wry one, for Norris had a spot of bother with the selection process himself, since both he and Archer had embarrassing histories. Archer differed from him in that he was as famous for concealing his past as Norris was for letting his be paraded publicly. Just before the Daily Mail began serialising Changing Trains, the auto-biography of the former minister and serial philanderer four years ago, Norris was interviewed over lunch by the Mail's doyenne, Lynda Lee-Potter. The resulting piece was a curtain-raiser for the book's spicy tales - "How the Tory toffs destroyed Thatcher"; "Why I threw darts at Heseltine's poster"; and "My brief fumble that so excited Edwina Currie".

At the time Norris was on the road to oblivion. He'd given up his career at Westminster; his finances were a shambles; he was separated from his wife. In short, he was a politician who'd been famous for five minutes - and for five mistresses. That might have been unfair, but the public were more likely to remember his amatory exploits and his penchant for making ill-advised quips than for anything he'd achieved in almost five years as minister in charge of transport in London.

True to form, that Mail interview ended with Norris remarking that, as he hadn't been recognised by anyone at the Royal Garden Hotel in Kensington during lunch, "if I ever was to have another affair, this would be the place to come". Norris claims he did not say it, that the theoretical possibility of the hotel as a trysting place was put to him by Lee-Potter, and, in a tone of strained politeness at a tasteless remark, he gritted his teeth and said "Er, yeeeess".

Poor Steven Norris; once you've got a reputation for a tearaway tongue, it's hard to plead innocence even if someone's put words into your mouth. Once, as transport minister, he said he preferred cars to buses, because public transport meant sitting alongside awful people (but the irony was lost on the tabloids). As an MP, he joked that his Epping constituency had fallen off the back of a lorry (luckily Essex voters have a sense of humour). Mr Blair and I are not going to fall out about yellow box junction management. On which, as far as I know, neither Marx nor Lenin had much of an opinion. He's a big man - a bit below the 17 stones he peaked at last year; he's lost the rather nerdish look he used to have - the shiny slick of hair; the slightly pinched features. Now, at 55, he looks relaxed and confident enough to jolly a frustrated crowd of tube travellers into a better mood, or to lay down the law to rail managers when commuter services foul up.

He's a cheerful, cheeky chappie with a hard-to-resist line in self-deprecation: "I've got more chins than the Beijing telephone directory." Or, regarding those personal failings: there are no skeletons in his closet - they're all in the graveyard. We both agreed that what business wanted was much less of the DTI which, in those days [early 90s], was even more interventionist than it is now. He was an iconoclast; a Thatcherite before Thatcher."

He became an enthusiast because " it's an attempt to introduce an executive efficiency into the management of a city, as distinct from introducing a great layer of political debate into a city, which is probably not hugely beneficial".

"There's no merit whatsoever for me in distancing myself from the party I'm perfectly comfortable with, and whose support I very much want in order to appeal to some middle-ground voters."

Norris is good at giving the impression that he's a fresh-thinking politician, capable of throwing caution to the winds, but he never lets go of a basic craftiness, and he knows, when asked for his list of London's high spots and low spots, that, while his choices won't satisfy everyone, they highlight his passion for the turf.

So, his likes: London's variety, its villagey feel, from Brick Lane to Belgravia; all-night take-aways, "the garage down the road where I can get a bottle of milk for Emma at 2am"; Docklands "now that it's more oasis than desert"; the City, with its institutions and traditions; black cabs.

And dislikes, some of which, as mayor, he could improve: the seediness of the West End; the bus ser vice; property prices, which mean that "a teacher married to a nurse can't afford anything decent"; parks - he knows about scruffiness, Clapham common is the eyesore on his doorstep; education. Expect him to weigh in on the subject, even though schools are not part of the Greater London Authority's duties.

So his instinct for popular causes is intact, even though he stood down at the last general election after serving as MP for Oxford East, 1983-7; and Epping Forest, 1988-97. He's followed his own simple rule: he entered politics when he'd made enough in business to live comfortably, and quit when he could no longer afford to live on a ministerial salary.

It's Norris's apparent ability to become rich, pursue a political career, and have an impressive number of liaisons while remaining married that has divided many politicians, and much of the public and media, into the enraged and the envious. The popular idea is that the smoothie from Liverpool has had it all, all of the time. The reality, as he is the first to point out, is different.

"I always, in the classic sense, see money as a liberator, not as a toy. I've no great desire to get more money than I now enjoy." No clues about how much that is, but enough to put a second son through Eton; help his wife financially (she teaches part-time), employ a secretary/researcher and a chauffeur/personal assistant. Home, he says, is "a modest Clapham terrace house". Well, yes, it's a creamy, stylish nook where he lives with his current partner Emma Courtney, 20 years his junior, and their young son Harry.

It all began modestly enough in Liverpool, where Steven John Norris was born on May 24, 1945, while his father was away on active service in Belgium. He grew up, till he was 10, in a three-bedroom terraced house in Aigburth. It wasn't cobble-close poverty; both his parents (who are still alive) had jobs. His father worked for the Inland Revenue, his mother as a teacher. They had, by 1955, saved £550 to buy a modern semi in what Norris calls "a more salubrious part of south Liverpool" - Mossley Hill.

Norris calls the move to the new house - a distant prospect of the Welsh mountains replacing the close view of the Mersey - "my first great leap forward". With loving parents, one younger brother, and being good at school, he continued to jump. First to the famous Liverpool Institute high school for boys (Paul McCartney and George Harrison appear in the same panoramic school photo). Then, with his mum paying for extra tuition so he could pass O-level Latin, to Oxford on an exhibition.

He read law at Worcester college, where the expectation was that he'd have a legal career. But his image of solicitors - all stiff collars and conveyancing - and his relative shortage of funds to read for the bar killed that. So, too, did a characteristic restlessness which began early with the excitement of that move to a new home and a new school. Some of Norris's friends say this wanting to move on in part defines his character. It explains why he's juggled his political and business careers; and why he's had a string of mistresses.

It's when this restlessness dovetails with his talent for making money that Norris's life gets interesting. Oxford left him with a taste for nice motors, the good life, a belief in his own talents, but without any idea how to magic these up, once he'd left the dreaming spires where, interestingly, he had shown no strong interest in politics.

It was a salesman for Burroughs Machines - the brother of Vicky Gibson, the girlfriend he met as a student and married in 1969 - who turned him on to selling. Gibson told him the company was offering a £50 headhunter bonus for each suitable recruit its staff found, and offered to split it if Steven signed up. He did, and sold his first adding machine almost by chance to the owner of a sandwich bar in Cannon Street in the City. He'd wearily dropped in for a cup of tea while doing his rounds; the owner's eye was taken also by the carrying case, which Norris flogged him for the same price as the machine - £87.50 in cash.

With Britain going decimal in 1971, there was a huge market in data processing and business management. Realising this, Norris answered an ad: the Ford Motor Company was looking for business management representatives. He had found his métier.

He landed on a map of Britain drawn not by the ordnance survey's cartographers, but by Ford chiefs. This divided the country into commercial fiefdoms - highly profitable dealerships licensed to sell their cars. All the big car manufacturing barons had similar maps (Norris later had VW/Audi dealerships), but the game was the same: favoured vassals could get rich in return for their allegiance to the company. True, there were occasional economic downturns, but if Ford smiled on you, additional fiefdoms, sometimes ailing and in need of commercial revival, could come your way. Norris and his fellow directors took every opportunity: "We were about the most voracious sharks in the Ford ocean at that time", he says.

It was a colourful, cutthroat and fraternal world. One of Norris's early fellow directors, Doug Wimpress, recalls that the philosophy of their boss, Sydney Wood, was "buy a company that's 40% efficient, take it up to 80% efficiency, sell it, and buy another company at 40%". Norris says he learned much from Wood, a legend in the business, whose strongest reproof to some of his protege's off-beam ideas was just two words: "silly boy".

On one occasion, when Wimpress complained that Norris had given him an accurate but incomplete account of a deal he was putting together, Wood cautioned, "You must always remember that Steve is destined to be a politician." That was prescient, because Norris himself at the time didn't acknowledge the lure of politics. In fact, he didn't enter local politics till he was 33, when he became a Berkshire county councillor. What he never did, contrary to popular belief, was sell cars. His skill was with business plans and balance sheets. "Steve didn't work in the showroom, but he would sell cars to his friends in the pub," says Wimpress.

And Norris himself confesses that dealing with punters wasn't his forte: "I was always far too generous to be a good salesman, who has to be absolutely ruthless about having one objective only, which is to relieve you of the largest amount of money, whereas I'd have got you to buy it [a car] then given you far too much off. I'm sorry to say I found selling boring. But the marketing and promotion of ideas was massively satisfying. The ability to encapsulate ideas comes reasonably naturally to me, and if you present things in an accessible form that people can relate to, that's eternally satisfying."

The rewards, though, were anything but tedious. Even in the 70s, an average Ford dealership would have a turnover of at least £15m, with a standard profit of 18.5% per vehicle, says Wimpress. No wonder he adds, "The motor trade is like a disease. Once it's in your blood, you never get rid of it."

He resigned last summer to enter the mayoral lists, but was scolded recently by the Mail on Sunday for setting up a lavish office in London. Off went a solicitor's letter to the paper with an exasperated Norris muttering about the pettiness of it all: "£3,000 is what a good sofa costs these days."

Norris would come to the mayor's office with a clean personal balance sheet. In the early 1990s, he was hit heavily when a company of his, Glentronic (it made equipment for countries with poor mains electricity) went under, owing £800,000. He lost heavily on property and on his motor business, and he paid a partner to take it off his hands. He went from an income of £150,000 to an MP's salary, then around £30,000. He explained all this to the apparent satisfaction of the five-man Tory inquisition that vetted his candidature. It would be "clinically insane" to lie, he said at the time. Old debts have been cleared; and he has pledged to give up all his directorships if he becomes mayor.

But what about the emotional balance sheet? Four ex-mistresses on the debit side; one current partner in the credit column, with the (separated) wife as a carried-over item? Norris's attitude to women is more complex than he lets on. The explanation he offers for the string of long affairs he's had during his marriage is that, though he married for love, he was too young (at 23); that moving to different parts of the country with his motor trade jobs put a strain on him and his wife.

What's more, despite the other woman, he's remained on good terms with Vicky, who wouldn't divorce him anyway because she is a devout Catholic. He portrays himself as a martyr to indecision, who could never make the irrevocable decision between spouse and lover; that he can't bear to hurt people; that the messes he used to get himself into were all his fault.

At the heart of it all lies his insistence that he wasn't and isn't a philanderer. Though serial, the affairs were separate, he says. "Separate but overlapping," counters one of the famous five: Lynne Taylor, a divorcee who had a three-year fling with him from 1986. She was 39 when they met, and appears to be the only girlfriend, apart from Emma, who managed to get Norris to give her a ring, to which she attached more significance than he did. She thought they were engaged; he didn't.

Before Lynne, there was Clare Marx, a doctor; after Lynn there was Sheila Gunn, a political journalist and hopeful Tory parliamentary candidate; and after Sheila, Emma Courtney, with a brief interlude with Jennifer Sharp, a magazine executive. All were seduced by Norris's intelligence, charm, thoughtfulness, humour, and drive. And yet Mrs Taylor, who lives in the west country, wonders why they all succumbed: "After all, we were all intelligent, attractive women with our own careers." And then she answers her own question: "I suppose if he walked in now, I'd be delighted to see him."

Norris is quite rueful about all this. He has had to put up with some awful mockery from the media ("Mr Norris changes dames" is a favourite headline; a typical cartoon shows a customer buying condoms being asked if he wants a pack of medium, large or Norris). And he's had to put up with a bit of mischief-making. It was perhaps mean of his father-in-law, Rear-Admiral Peter Gibson, to go thundering to the Times last September that Steve could hardly fulfil his intention to marry Emma while not divorced from his daughter, Vicky.

"Clearly, the promise of a marriage to the mother of his illegitimate son in the run-up to an election would be expedient," were the rear-admiral's cynical words. Norris was hurt; he's not so daft as to be goaded into ringing the wedding bells during his campaign. Certainly the couple will marry, but it won't be till after May.

Meanwhile, Norris seems content. Some men don't grow up till they're in their 50s or 60s, he says. He's matured now, and fortunate. If his luck holds, he could even do the double - getting mayored and married in the same year.

Life at a glance: Steven John Norris

Born: May 24, 1945, Liverpool.

Education: Liverpool Institute High School for Boys; Worcester College, Oxford (MA).

Married: 1969 Peta Veronica (Vicky) Cecil-Gibson (two sons), (separated); current partner Emma Courtney (one son).

Business career: Salesman for Burroughs Machines; director of companies holding motor dealerships for Ford, Audi, VW; director of the Road Haulage Federation, 1997-9; currently director of, and consultant to, firms in the transport sector .

Parliamentary career: MP (Conservative): Oxford East 1983-87, Epping Forest 1988-97; parliamentary private sectretary to William Waldegrave, DoE (1985-7), Nicholas Ridley, trade and industry (1990), Kenneth Baker, home office (1991-2); under secretary of state, department of transport (1992-6).

Gibson told him the company was offering a £50 headhunter bonus for each suitable recruit its staff found, and offered to split it if Steven signed up. He did, and sold his first adding machine almost by chance to the owner of a sandwich bar in Cannon Street in the City. He'd wearily dropped in for a cup of tea while doing his rounds; the owner's eye was taken also by the carrying case, which Norris flogged him for the same price as the machine - £87.50 in cash. With Britain going decimal in 1971, there was a huge market in data processing and business management. Realising this, Norris answered an ad: the Ford Motor Company was looking for business management representatives. He had found his métier. He landed on a map of Britain drawn not by the ordnance survey's cartographers, but by Ford chiefs. This divided the country into commercial fiefdoms - highly profitable dealerships licensed to sell their cars. All the big car manufacturing barons had similar maps (Norris later had VW/Audi dealerships), but the game was the same: favoured vassals could get rich in return for their allegiance to the company. True, there were occasional economic downturns, but if Ford smiled on you, additional fiefdoms, sometimes ailing and in need of commercial revival, could come your way. Norris and his fellow directors took every opportunity: "We were about the most voracious sharks in the Ford ocean at that time", he says. It was a colourful, cutthroat and fraternal world. One of Norris's early fellow directors, Doug Wimpress, recalls that the philosophy of their boss, Sydney Wood, was "buy a company that's 40% efficient, take it up to 80% efficiency, sell it, and buy another company at 40%". Norris says he learned much from Wood, a legend in the business, whose strongest reproof to some of his protege's off-beam ideas was just two words: "silly boy". On one occasion, when Wimpress complained that Norris had given him an accurate but incomplete account of a deal he was putting together, Wood cautioned, "You must always remember that Steve is destined to be a politician." That was prescient, because Norris himself at the time didn't acknowledge the lure of politics. In fact, he didn't enter local politics till he was 33, when he became a Berkshire county councillor. What he never did, contrary to popular belief, was sell cars. His skill was with business plans and balance sheets. "Steve didn't work in the showroom, but he would sell cars to his friends in the pub," says Wimpress. And Norris himself confesses that dealing with punters wasn't his forte: "I was always far too generous to be a good salesman, who has to be absolutely ruthless about having one objective only, which is to relieve you of the largest amount of money, whereas I'd have got you to buy it [a car] then given you far too much off. I'm sorry to say I found selling boring. But the marketing and promotion of ideas was massively satisfying. The ability to encapsulate ideas comes reasonably naturally to me, and if you present things in an accessible form that people can relate to, that's eternally satisfying." The rewards, though, were anything but tedious. Even in the 70s, an average Ford dealership would have a turnover of at least £15m, with a standard profit of 18.5% per vehicle, says Wimpress. No wonder he adds, "The motor trade is like a disease. Once it's in your blood, you never get rid of it." It's certainly true that Norris, who has made and lost a million, has the transport gene. On leaving Westminster in 1997 he began rebuilding his fortune with directorships in half a dozen companies in this sector, and becoming head of the Road Haulage Federation on a salary of well over £100,000. He resigned last summer to enter the mayoral lists, but was scolded recently by the Mail on Sunday for setting up a lavish office in London. Off went a solicitor's letter to the paper with an exasperated Norris muttering about the pettiness of it all: "£3,000 is what a good sofa costs these days." Norris would come to the mayor's office with a clean personal balance sheet. In the early 1990s, he was hit heavily when a company of his, Glentronic (it made equipment for countries with poor mains electricity) went under, owing £800,000. He lost heavily on property and on his motor business, and he paid a partner to take it off his hands. He went from an income of £150,000 to an MP's salary, then around £30,000. He explained all this to the apparent satisfaction of the five-man Tory inquisition that vetted his candidature. It would be "clinically insane" to lie, he said at the time. Old debts have been cleared; and he has pledged to give up all his directorships if he becomes mayor. But what about the emotional balance sheet? Four ex-mistresses on the debit side; one current partner in the credit column, with the (separated) wife as a carried-over item? Norris's attitude to women is more complex than he lets on. The explanation he offers for the string of long affairs he's had during his marriage is that, though he married for love, he was too young (at 23); that moving to different parts of the country with his motor trade jobs put a strain on him and his wife. What's more, despite the other woman, he's remained on good terms with Vicky, who wouldn't divorce him anyway because she is a devout Catholic. He portrays himself as a martyr to indecision, who could never make the irrevocable decision between spouse and lover; that he can't bear to hurt people; that the messes he used to get himself into were all his fault. At the heart of it all lies his insistence that he wasn't and isn't a philanderer. Though serial, the affairs were separate, he says. "Separate but overlapping," counters one of the famous five: Lynne Taylor, a divorcee who had a three-year fling with him from 1986. She was 39 when they met, and appears to be the only girlfriend, apart from Emma, who managed to get Norris to give her a ring, to which she attached more significance than he did. She thought they were engaged; he didn't. Before Lynne, there was Clare Marx, a doctor; after Lynn there was Sheila Gunn, a political journalist and hopeful Tory parliamentary candidate; and after Sheila, Emma Courtney, with a brief interlude with Jennifer Sharp, a magazine executive. All were seduced by Norris's intelligence, charm, thoughtfulness, humour, and drive. And yet Mrs Taylor, who lives in the west country, wonders why they all succumbed: "After all, we were all intelligent, attractive women with our own careers." And then she answers her own question: "I suppose if he walked in now, I'd be delighted to see him." Norris is quite rueful about all this. He has had to put up with some awful mockery from the media ("Mr Norris changes dames" is a favourite headline; a typical cartoon shows a customer buying condoms being asked if he wants a pack of medium, large or Norris). And he's had to put up with a bit of mischief-making. It was perhaps mean of his father-in-law, Rear-Admiral Peter Gibson, to go thundering to the Times last September that Steve could hardly fulfil his intention to marry Emma while not divorced from his daughter, Vicky. "Clearly, the promise of a marriage to the mother of his illegitimate son in the run-up to an election would be expedient," were the rear-admiral's cynical words. Norris was hurt; he's not so daft as to be goaded into ringing the wedding bells during his campaign. Certainly the couple will marry, but it won't be till after May. Meanwhile, Norris seems content. Some men don't grow up till they're in their 50s or 60s, he says. He's matured now, and fortunate. If his luck holds, he could even do the double - getting mayored and married in the same year. Life at a glance: Steven John Norris Born: May 24, 1945, Liverpool. Education: Liverpool Institute High School for Boys; Worcester College, Oxford (MA). Married: 1969 Peta Veronica (Vicky) Cecil-Gibson (two sons), (separated); current partner Emma Courtney (one son). Business career: Salesman for Burroughs Machines; director of companies holding motor dealerships for Ford, Audi, VW; director of the Road Haulage Federation, 1997-9; currently director of, and consultant to, firms in the transport sector . Parliamentary career: MP (Conservative): Oxford East 1983-87, Epping Forest 1988-97; parliamentary private sectretary to William Waldegrave, DoE (1985-7), Nicholas Ridley, trade and industry (1990), Kenneth Baker, home office (1991-2); under secretary of state, department of transport (1992-6).

webTitle: A freewheeling trip for the treat generation

fields.headline: A freewheeling trip for the treat generation
fields.trailText: Her Majesty, the old bat | More mission statements
fields.body:
I suppose it's all to do with greater prosperity, but half-term has moved from being a break in the school year to a full-blown festival. When I were but a lad, half-term meant playing football in the street and going to the library, sometimes twice a day. This week every bus and train was crammed with children being taken to some treat or other.

When the fabulous London Eye wheel is opened to the public next month, that short stretch of riverbank by County Hall will become half-term ground zero, containing the aquarium and the Premiership Hall of Fame, with the Imax cinema a two-minute walk away. How sad that it is presently a blasted urban landscape, a hideous melange of building work, graffiti, industrial waste and dilapidation. The astonishing fact that three times as many French people live in Britain as there are Britons in France seems miraculous when you realise that this modern Gehenna is the first thing most of them see when they get off the Eurostar.

 And of course a trip to the Dome has, overnight, become a half-term tradition. The right-wing papers have acknowledged this in the most grudging way, with tragic pictures of the little boy who missed his birthday treat because the place had filled by mid-morning - clearly the fault of the Dome's management.

It doesn't seem to have occurred to the papers that their endless anti-Dome stories, the pictures of wide empty spaces, and their constant declarations of failure, might have led people to imagine that if they turned up they would be personally greeted by M Gerbeau and Lord Falconer, both weeping with gratitude and offering a personal guided tour.

The fact is that the Dome is full of interesting stuff, it's a delight for children, and excellent value if you buy a discounted ticket. What has happened is word of mouth. If the Daily Mail says it's a catastrophe, and your friend next door had a great time, who are you going to believe?

 In the week that Sir Stanley Matthews died, and David Beckham appeared torn between his wife and his manager, I was reminded of another footballer who married a pop star, Joy, one of the Beverley Sisters, but who remained an old-fashioned gentleman too. Billy Wright, who captained England 90 times, once came to our house.

Like my father, he was a member of the Pilkington committee on the future of broadcasting; in those days such committees usually had at least one celebrity-on-the-Clapham-omnibus figure. They used to move from house to house, possibly fleeing the rapacious ITV bosses who correctly surmised that Pilkington would suggest that making them even richer was not the highest achievement to which British broadcasting could aspire.

The boys in the neighbourhood and I were beside ourselves with excitement. Would he agree to play football with us, or would he be too busy, or too tired? Of course he said yes; he was that kind of bloke. But when we played in our back garden he would let us beat him to the tackle. "Oh dear, you're much too good for me!" he would say as another nine-year old whisked the ball from his feet. That was the disappointment; we wanted to see his skill, and didn't want a victory none of our friends would believe. But he meant it in the kindest imaginable way.

 In this week's Spectator, Charles Moore points out that the Queen Mother and the Labour party are both 100 this year. "Which of the two is the better loved by the British people and has done more good for us?" he inquires.

This is clearly a rhetorical question. As Charles Moore must agree, there can hardly be a choice between, on the one hand, the party which gave British people their first employment rights, created the welfare state and the NHS, and even recently has given us the minimum wage and almost abolished the hereditary peers, and on the other, an overprivileged old bat who has spent five decades since the war doing little except betting and boozing for Britain. No contest.

I fear the worst when she dies, however. The BBC currently plans for us to go into a period of national mourning which will make the bereaved Queen Victoria look like a hedonistic flibbertigibbet. I suspect, though, that anything more than a 90-minute obituary shown after Newsnight and live coverage of the funeral on daytime TV will create deep and lasting national resentment. Especially if a single episode of EastEnders is cancelled.

 Many thanks for the mini-mission statements you've sent in. Geoffrey Ryder of London read last week's item, then 10 minutes later spotted a Thames Water van in the street, boldly declaring, "Running Water For You". "To which might be added, 'Except When It Runs Out'," he writes.

Tony Branson of Newcastle says that his local NHS trust claims tautologically, "Caring Is Our Concern", to which he suggests the addition, "So It's None Of Your Business".

Tom Sandars of London points out that the mission statement of the New York Police Department is "Courtesy, Professionalism, Respect, Unless You're Black". (He made the last phrase up.) Several people have sent in Thames Valley police's own legend, emblazoned on their vehicles, "Tackling crime, disorder and fear".

My favourite so far - others welcome - is a till receipt from the Chelsea branch of Somerfield: "Your store manager is Joe Cacchione. You were served today by Mellaz. Shopping In The Real World." This might merely mean that they don't do email deliveries, but it may simply be an example of the higher nonsense. A fine instance of which comes from Martin Figura of Waterbeach, Cambs. "The best example of management bollock-speak I came across was a document which stated: 'This will be underpinned with an overarching strategy.' I was so inspired, I wrote it on my whiteboard. The author saw it and was delighted that 'someone reads my documents'. I knew then it was time to leave."

 Everyone says that the Blair government is full of control freaks. It isn't. They're not smart enough to be control freaks. Look at the people surrounding the prime minister. At some point, a year or so back, someone (Campbell, Mandelson, Milliband?) must have come to him and said, "Look, our polls show Ken is the overwhelmingly popular choice for mayor. He'd beat every other conceivable candidate. So let's cook up an electoral college so blatantly unfair, so thoroughly rigged, that even Frank Dobson can win. The voters won't notice; they're too dim. They'd vote for a donkey if it had a Labour rosette. And Ken - well, he won't won't kick up a fuss. He's a team player, not an egomaniac..."

And so on. Somebody must have said something very much along those lines. To call this lot Machiavellian is an insult to Machiavelli who at least, like the Chelsea Somerfield, existed firmly in the real world.

 Great headlines: Martin Leach, now of Bath, recalls his former local paper, the Oldham Chronicle, reporting the race between Edmund Hillary and Vivian Fuchs to the south pole in 1958. The sub-editor was a famous local grande dame, Hilda M Williams, of whom Brian Redhead once remarked, "She probably thinks a dildo is an extinct flightless bird". The banner headline she put on to the streets read: "Hillary at Pole: Fuchs 500 on the Way". Mr Leach claims that readers require special permission at Oldham library to see the microfiche of this edition.

fields.headline: The last word on   Nationalism
fields.standfirst: Nationalism is our form of incest, is our idolatry, is our insanity. "Patriotism" is its cult. -   Erich Fromm
fields.trailText: Nationalism is our form of incest, is our idolatry, is our insanity. "Patriotism" is its cult. - Erich Fromm
fields.body:
Nationalism is our form of incest, is our idolatry, is our insanity. "Patriotism" is its cult. - Erich Fromm

This week's campaign to persuade the United Kingdom into closer ties with Europe coincides with renewed trouble in the Balkans. There is a link between the two events: namely, the question of nationalism. The European campaign has to meet or refute nationalistic prejudices among the British - chiefly, among sections of the British press. It would do well to point out that nationalistic prejudice is a major part of the cancer destroying the Balkans.

Nationalism is an evil. It causes wars, its roots lie in xenophobia and racism, it is a recent phenomenon - an invention of the last few centuries - which has been of immense service to demagogues and tyrants but to no-one else. Disguised as patriotism and love of one's country, it trades on the unreason of mass psychology to make a variety of horrors seem acceptable, even honourable. For example: if someone said to you, "I am going to send your son to kill the boy next door" you would hotly protest. But only let him seduce you with "Queen and Country!" "The Fatherland!" "My country right or wrong!" and you would find yourself permitting him to send all our sons to kill not just the sons of other people, but other people indiscriminately - which is what bombs and bullets do.

Demagogues know what they are about when they preach nationalism. Hitler said, "The effectiveness of the truly national leader consists in preventing his people from dividing their attention, and keeping it fixed on a common enemy." And he knew who to appeal to: Goethe had long since remarked that nationalistic feelings "are at their strongest and most violent where there is the lowest degree of culture".

Nationalists take certain unexceptionable desires and muddle them with unacceptable ones. We individually wish to run our own affairs; that is unexceptionable. Most of us value the culture which shaped our development and gave us our sense of personal and group identity; that too is unexceptionable. But the nationalist persuades us that the existence of other groups and cultures somehow puts these things at risk, and that the only way to protect them is to see ourselves as members of a distinct collective, defined by ethnicity, geography, or sameness of language or religion, and to build a wall around ourselves to keep out "foreigners". It is not enough that the others are other; we have to see them as a threat - at the very least to "our way of life", perhaps to our jobs, even to our daughters.

When Europe's overseas colonies sought independence, the only rhetoric to hand was that of nationalism. It had well served the unifiers of Italy and Germany in the 19th century (which in turn prepared the way for some of their activities in the 20th century), and we see a number of the ex-colonial nations going the same way today.

The idea of nationalism turns on that of a "nation". The word is a joke: we British are one of the most mongrel of "nations", a mixture of so many immigrations in the last two millennia that the idea of a British ethnicity is comical, except for the Celtic fringes, whose boast has to be either that they remained so remote and disengaged, or so conquered, for the greater part of history, that they succeeded in keeping their gene pool "pure" (a cynic might say "inbred"). Much nonsense is talked about nations as entities: Emerson spoke of the "genius" of a nation as something separate from its numerical citizens; Giradoux described the "spirit of a nation" as "the look in its eyes". Nations are artificial constructs, their boundaries drawn in the blood of past wars. And one should not confuse culture and nationality: there is no country on earth which is not home to more than one different but usually coexisting culture. Cultural heritage is not the same thing as national identity.

The blindness of people who fall for nationalistic demagoguery is surprising. Those who oppose closer relations in Europe, or who seek to detach themselves from the larger comities to which they belong, need to understand the lesson of the Balkans, or - the same thing writ larger - Europe's tragic history in the last 100 years.

fields.headline: No 42 MPs' freebies
fields.trailText: Hall of infamy
fields.body:
What a wondrous thing is the Register of Members' Interests, published this week. Not only does it give us plebs an insight into the bounteous generosity that flows in one's direction the moment fame and influence are in the bag. But as with the Confessional Box, a simple genuflexion of the Biro in the Parliamentary naughty book and you've got away with it.

John Prescott has make a clean breast of his second freebie limo, William Hague has come clean about having Seb Coe's Range Rover on long-term loan (how peculiar is that?), Mo Mowlam has owned up to the cartoons she collects of herself, and Tony Blair has made his wincingly honest free holiday admission ("August 1999, accompanied by my family, I spent nine days as a guest of Signor Chiti, the president of the Tuscan government"). What more is there to say? That there is hypocrisy in the air? (Hardly.) That our MPs live a life of freeloading luxury? (It's a pretty seedy life, actually, and the ligging barely gets out of the blocks compared with that in corporate - or journalistic for that matter - Britain). As for the possibility that undue influence might be exercised upon the recipient by the donor, well, yes, but the register rather absolves that potential sin by exposing it to public view before it's had a chance to happen.

So if Mr Prescott wants to grant some privilege to Rover (who supply his 800 model for party events and campaigning, when he can't use the government Jag), we will at least have the chance to analyse what lay behind the Blind Eye to Anything Rover Gets Up to Act (2000). For the maintenance of the quality of public life, if nothing else, it is vital that extracurricular goodies be available over and above piddling Parliamentary salaries. Who otherwise would bother going through the humiliation and misery of being selected and elected as an MP? Do we really want a House of Commons peopled by dreary ascetics, whose only virtue is that they are clean? Or is it better to be governed by men and women of the world, who know a thing or two about kickbacks and perks thanks to the experience of being offered them on a daily basis?

To put it another way, the society we have here has a multiplicity of troughs. If the facilities exist, is it such a bad thing that our politicians - people who have sacrificed so much in pay and embarrassment to be our representatives - are occasionally seen with their snout in them? We don't want our MPs to be monks; Harold Wilson's impecunious last days (and he was hardly the most fastidious when it came to associating with freebiemongers) did nothing to embellish either the public good or the future governance of the nation. And the fact that there is a tendency to get sanctimonious about MPs' freebies speaks volumes for the kind of cushy number we are on to in this country. Anyone who has lived under a Mobutu, a Mugabe or a Marcos would laugh at our tut-tutting at Peter Mandelson having jetted away on a few - all right, 13 - freebies, mostly to attend events which would kill the majority of us with boredom. When your leaders appropriate an entire airline for their personal profit, and then have the pilot shot if there's a little turbulence en route, you know what sleaze is. Tony Banks's admission that Chelsea's Frank Leboeuf treated him to three days in Marrakech may be a bit weird, but corrupt it isn't.

fields.headline: Bohemian youth to synod stalwart
fields.standfirst: American at the top in English church politics
fields.trailText: There is a delightful symbolism in the muddy drive up to Christina Rees's house: on the one side is a field of rare Jacob's sheep and on the other, some flop-eared goats. This separation is how a follower of Jesus should arrange her farm. But the peacocks in a ramshackle greenhouse suggest a less controlled imagination.
fields.body:
There is a delightful symbolism in the muddy drive up to Christina Rees's house: on the one side is a field of rare Jacob's sheep and on the other, some flop-eared goats. This separation is how a follower of Jesus should arrange her farm. But the peacocks in a ramshackle greenhouse suggest a less controlled imagination.

Next week she will be in London at a meeting of the Church of England's general synod. She has been a member there for 10 years, and is one of the elected members of the archbishops' council, a committee that is meant to have taken over the direction of the church from the synod. She's also the chair of Watch, a pressure group for women bishops.

I wondered what someone so abundantly sane is doing in church politics. Part of the answer lies in her childhood. Her family was American, cultured, and bohemian: in her living room is a massive neoclassical statue of a naked woman draped across a flute-playing faun, carved by her grandmother. When she was five, her parents threw up their jobs in New York and bought a sailing boat, and for the next nine years she grew up on a small boat cruising in tropical waters with her parents and two siblings.

She lives in Hertfordshire because when she was 23, and taking a degree in communications, she met Chris Rees, a BBC producer, in Cambridge, and married him.

"I never meant to get into church politics. I didn't know what they were, because I had travelled so much and grew up with an 'any church in a port' kind of attitude."

Christina started preaching when she was 17, "having had a charismatic experience."

What, exactly? "I had an emotional sense of God's love for me in a new way. I just felt completely utterly loved in every cell of my body."

Nonetheless, this doesn't really sound like training for a life on church committees.

"When we moved to the village nearly 20 years ago I was asked if I would join the parochial church council because I was young and female. Of course, every suggestion I came up with, they said I couldn't possibly understand because you are young and female and foreign." So she decided to change things from the inside.

fields.headline: Truly confess
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The huge drop in the number of people going to confession, certainly in Ireland, worries both church leaders and churchgoers. To others it seems a return to normality.
fields.body:
The huge drop in the number of people going to confession, certainly in Ireland, worries both church leaders and churchgoers. To others it seems a return to normality. Many believe that the modern attitude to sin is based more on a social code than a moral one, and that religion no longer enters the equation. Others blame the media for creating talk shows, where people bare their souls to millions before a live studio audience instead of in a confession box to a priest.

Media commentary might be changing public perceptions of wrongdoing; it may also simply be reflecting that change. A Sky News presenter commented during the impeachment proceedings against President Clinton that it was surprising such steps were being taken for a "comparatively minor sin or misdemeanour".

These words are important indicators of society. "Comparatively" would indicate a sliding scale, where actions are not viewed by their actual merits or demerits, but in comparison with other actions. "Minor sin" is the title we give after comparative evaluation. And "misdemeanour" is the final, comfortable term which sanitises the action by eliminating the word "sin".

Father Cormac McIlraith, who serves a south Dublin parish, sees a change in society's attitude to sin and guilt. "People are now asking themselves whether lying is the sin - or getting caught," he says. "With changing attitudes and standards, what was seen as sinful in the past by society may not be viewed in the same way today."

To most people, lying is sinful. But are there degrees of lying? Instead of adhering to a strict code given by the church, which brackets sins into venial and mortal forms, people are now subconsciously operating a scale more dependent upon actions and intent.

Father McIlraith believes that instead of attending confession, many are going to psychiatrists. Sheila Porter, a Dublin clinical psychologist, feels that, in the past, priests may have been seen as judges acting on behalf of God, so now "people may feel that psychologists are less likely to judge them."

The church's traditional teachings say that a sinner should seek forgiveness from God through the medium of a priest and then make amends with the person they have sinned against. Today, people are more inclined to believe that seeking forgiveness from the person they have sinned against is the more important. There is now a belief that if we are reconciled to each other we are reconciled to God. Some would say that the decrease in those going to confession should be no surprise, given the overall drop in those attending mass. But most people give up confession long before mass. Confession seems to be the first ceremony to be abandoned. People do not seek confession before a serious operation, while a death-bed confession seems like hypocrisy.

But there are areas where the demand for the sacrament is high. Queues for absolution in some city-centre churches are as long as they ever were. Father Pat Carroll, administrator at St Mary's Pro-Cathedral in Dublin, says that city churches give more time to confession, so people have a greater opportunity. But there is another reason, he says: people find the city more anonymous. "Young people in rural or suburban areas may find it difficult to go to confession because of a fear of being identified by neighbours or the priest. Attending in the city lessens the chance."

Father McIlraith is confident confession will return as a form of reconciliation: "God is needed when times are hard. When everything is going well, people are inclined to live their daily lives without much questioning, but if there is a personal or social disaster, hardship or war, then people think in a different way."

Conor Feehand is a journalist based in Dublin.

fields.headline: Clifton Daniel
fields.standfirst: The sheikh of Fleet Street who introduced lifestyle topics to the grey world of the New York Times
fields.trailText: Clifton Daniel, who has died aged 87, was the kind of journalist who saw the foreign correspondent's role as akin to that of an ambassador. In the London of the second world war, this suave and handsome bachelor kitted himself in Savile Row clothes and, as Gay Talese noted in his memorably feline portrait of the New York Times newspaper, deployed his "Tory manners" to advantage.
fields.body:
Clifton Daniel, who has died aged 87, was the kind of journalist who saw the foreign correspondent's role as akin to that of an ambassador. In the London of the second world war, this suave and handsome bachelor kitted himself in Savile Row clothes and, as Gay Talese noted in his memorably feline portrait of the New York Times newspaper, deployed his "Tory manners" to advantage.

The natural result, in a society suffering an acute shortage of males, was that Daniel "was sought after by London hostesses, was often seen escorting distinguished women to the theatre and ballet, and generally avoided the men's clubs for the drawing room scene where, in the company of Bea Lillie and Noel Coward, Margot Fonteyn and Clarissa Spencer-Churchill, he could listen to the latest gossip about politics and people." His earthy colleagues called him the Sheikh of Fleet Street.

With this background, there was little surprise when, after 25 years on the New York Times, his appointment as its managing editor in 1964 brought greater emphasis on "lifestyle topics" - society comings and goings, food and drink, and broader coverage of the arts. The shift not only reflected Daniel's own interests but those of his wife Margaret, daughter of President Harry Truman. Daniel also added much-needed spice to the traditionally grey tributes of its obituary columns.

It had been a long journey from the village of Zebulon in North Carolina to presidential son-in-law and editor of the country's most influential newspaper. Daniel ascribed his early interest in journalism to his father's ownership of the local drugstore, the gathering point for their 500 neighbours. "The chief of police and the deputy sheriff used to hang round there all the time," Daniel recalled. "I can still remember one night when a fellow walked in, apparently holding his head in his hands. His throat was cut from ear to ear. I got a doctor for him - and a story for the local paper."

Daniel's interest increased at university; he then spent four years working for various North Carolina newspapers. When an application to join the NY Times failed, he spent seven years with Associated Press in New York, Washington, Switzerland and England. He was finally recruited by the Times in 1944, to cover the allied advance through Belgium and Germany.

He emerged unscathed from what he later described as "a good war" and was then sent to Palestine as the British mandate ended and turmoil erupted in the Arab world. This had its lighter moments. In Iran in 1946, he and two colleagues set out for Tabriz to report the arrival of government forces replacing those of the collapsed pro-Soviet regime. When the reporters' advance proved faster than that of the army, jubilant locals sacrificed a sheep in their honour.

Daniel had a far tougher time in Moscow after he volunteered to replace the vet eran but exhausted Harrison Salisbury. Professionally it was a splendid moment to arrive: Khrushchev had just emerged from the post-Stalin confusion and, as the only permanent western reporter, Daniel had a clear field.

He dealt with the twists of official policy and also offered notable commentaries on everyday Russian style. Covering a fashion show dedicated to socialist realism, he reported happily that "bosoms are still bosoms, a waist is a waist, hips are hips, and there is no doubt about what they are and where they are situated".

Beneath this joie de vivre, he was overworking. In Geneva for a Big Four conference, his shocked colleagues reported how ghastly he looked and he was recalled to New York in November 1955. He ascended steadily through the editorial hierarchy and married Margaret Truman.

His term as managing editor was overcast by the continuing presence in the newsroom of his predecessor, Turner Catledge, by then executive editor. One deeply embarrassing example of the tensions between the two came after Daniel had recruited Stanley Kauffmann as the paper's influential drama critic, with the lure of an 18-month contract leading to a permanent appointment. After only eight months Catledge abruptly ordered the critic's dismissal, apparently because he thought Kauffmann's reviews were too negative.

After five years as managing editor, Daniel, in the delicate language of corporate infighting, "yielded" his job to AM Rosenthal and went off to run the paper's syndication services and work for its radio stations. During the Watergate crisis, he wrote commentaries from Washington; drawing on the journalistic lessons of that period, he built up a team of investigative reporters. He retired in 1977.

He is survived by his wife, their four sons, and five grandchildren.

 Elbert Clifton Daniel, journalist, born September 19 1912; died February 21 2000
