webTitle: Livingstone urged to fight from within

fields.headline: Livingstone urged to fight from within
fields.standfirst:
Pressure grows on him to stay out of race to be London mayor

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone is facing intense pressure to resist standing as an independent in the London mayoral election after his local party and the former Labour leader Michael Foot urged him to remain on board.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone is facing intense pressure to resist standing as an independent in the London mayoral election after his local party and the former Labour leader Michael Foot urged him to remain on board.

Amid speculation over Mr Livingstone's plans, his party in Brent East overwhelmingly passed a resolution on Thursday night which called on the former Greater London Council leader to "fight his corner inside the party and not stand as an independent".

The intervention by Mr Livingstone's local party was reinforced by Mr Foot, who warned him that he would be committing a "plain breach of trust" if he abandoned Labour.

"I think it would be quite improper that he should stand after he's said he wouldn't stand in these circumstances," Mr Foot told the BBC.

Mr Livingstone is still making his mind up whether to stand as an independent in the May election after Frank Dobson was handed the Labour nomination at the weekend despite failing to win support from a majority of London party members.

Mr Livingstone, who is expected to wait some time before making an announcement, is said to be genuinely undecided whether to jump ship. Allies say that his anger at the Millbank "stitch up" is tempered by the fear of losing friends and colleagues if he leaves the party.

His local party underlined its strong support for the MP by expressing "extreme anger" over the Labour selection process. "The view of the majority of members of the party in London has been ignored," the resolution said.

But the resolution included a plea to Mr Livingstone not to abandon the party he has supported for 30 years. "We express our support for Ken and call on him to fight his corner inside the party and not stand as an independent outside the party."

Paul Daisley, leader of Brent council, thought the resolution would have an impact on Mr Livingstone. "There was a strong feeling that Ken should not create a scenario where local members are forced to choose between their party allegiance and their allegiance to Ken," he said.

Mr Livingstone gave little clue at the meeting about his intentions. "Ken said that those closest to him were calling on him not to walk," Mr Daisley said. "But he said that he is receiving 1,000 emails a day from people, 95% of whom are calling on him to stand."

The Labour hierarchy, which is worried that an independent Livingstone campaign could split the party in London, is intensifying its efforts to keep him on board. Millbank released the Brent East resolution yesterday even though it condemned the leadership's handling of the selection process.

Margaret McDonagh, the party's general secretary, is also pleading with Mr Livingstone to meet her for talks. The left-winger is refusing to talk at the moment, although intermediaries are said to be in discussions.

Amid the uncertainty over his plans, Mr Livingstone underlined his deep anger with Millbank yesterday when he rounded on Mr Dobson for reversing his transport policy.

Mr Livingstone's criticism came after the former health secretary attempted during a Guardian-sponsored debate to curry favour with Labour left-wingers by distancing himself from Downing Street's plans for a partial privatisation of London Underground. Mr Dobson promised to appoint an independent panel to examine tube funding.

Mr Livingstone, who received a rapturous reception at the Guardian debate in central London on Thursday night, said: "Mr Dobson's announcement ... is an evasion. London wants a mayor who will fight the privatisation and break-up policy of the tube by every legal means."

 Support for extending the principle of directly-elected mayors to London boroughs is running high despite the Dobson-Livingstone wrangle, a new poll suggests, writes Will Woodward .

A survey last week by ICM for the Blairite new local government network shows Londoners - by a 70%-18% margin - want the system of elected mayors devolved further downwards to their local councils. The findings suggest they have not been put off by Labour and the Tories' problems selecting candidates ahead of the capital-wide election on May 4.

But according to the telephone poll, released to the Guardian, support across the country for elected mayors is falling somewhat, with 59% in favour, compared with 64% in May 1999. A spokeswoman for the network said there were now fewer "don't knows" than in the earlier survey.

The findings show that 49% would be more likely to vote in local elections if they were choosing an elected mayor, with turnout increasing most in the north west, west Midlands, Wales and London. Less enthusiastic are Yorkshire, East Anglia and the south west. Legislation expected to receive royal assent in June will allow councils to organise referendums for an elected mayor. The network is pressing local communities to take part in a "Democracy Day" in October or November to hold referendums.

London wants a mayor who will fight the privatisation and break-up policy of the tube by every legal means."  Support for extending the principle of directly-elected mayors to London boroughs is running high despite the Dobson-Livingstone wrangle, a new poll suggests, writes Will Woodward . A survey last week by ICM for the Blairite new local government network shows Londoners - by a 70%-18% margin - want the system of elected mayors devolved further downwards to their local councils. The findings suggest they have not been put off by Labour and the Tories' problems selecting candidates ahead of the capital-wide election on May 4. But according to the telephone poll, released to the Guardian, support across the country for elected mayors is falling somewhat, with 59% in favour, compared with 64% in May 1999. A spokeswoman for the network said there were now fewer "don't knows" than in the earlier survey. The findings show that 49% would be more likely to vote in local elections if they were choosing an elected mayor, with turnout increasing most in the north west, west Midlands, Wales and London. Less enthusiastic are Yorkshire, East Anglia and the south west. Legislation expected to receive royal assent in June will allow councils to organise referendums for an elected mayor. The network is pressing local communities to take part in a "Democracy Day" in October or November to hold referendums.

fields.headline: MI5 to sue renegade spy
fields.standfirst:
Security secrets copyright, lawyers argue
More about MI5
fields.trailText: David Shayler, the former MI5 officer who has made a series of allegations about the security and intelligence agencies, is being sued by the government for breaches of confidence and of contract, and infringing crown copyright, the Guardian has learned.
fields.body:
David Shayler, the former MI5 officer who has made a series of allegations about the security and intelligence agencies, is being sued by the government for breaches of confidence and of contract, and infringing crown copyright, the Guardian has learned.

Having failed to get him extradited from France to face a criminal prosecution here under the official secrets act, it is attempting to silence him by claiming damages in the civil courts for everything he has said about MI5 and MI6.

In a move that has widespread implications for the media, it is also claiming damages from Associated Newspapers, publishers of the Mail on Sunday, for causing "injury to the national interest". The newspaper was the first to publish revelations by Mr Shayler - including how MI5 kept files on politicians and rock musicians - in August 1997.

In a high court writ, the treasury solicitor says the newspaper paid £40,000 for the information as well as paying his legal fees and accommodation in France. It demands an account of the profits made by the Mail on Sunday from extra sales generated as a result of Mr Shayler's revelations. It also demands the return of all MI5 documents Mr Shayler gave to the newspaper.

The writ adds that Mr Shayler was also paid £750 by Punch magazine and unknown sums by other publications.

All the information supplied by Mr Shayler about MI5 and MI6 is crown copyright, the government argues. It also claims that the Mail on Sunday has breached the newspaper's duty of confidentiality to the crown and infringed crown copyright.

Government lawyers have been encouraged by a 1997 appeal court judgment preventing the Soviet spy George Blake from receiving royalties on his autobiography, No Other Choice. Lord Woolf said the attorney general was "entitled to intervene... to uphold the public policy of ensuring that a criminal does not retain profit directly derived from the commission of his crime".

The appeal court overturned a high court judgment by Sir Richard Scott, who ruled the government's claim that Blake could not gain financially from writing anything about his work as a spy amounted to "an interference with his rights of freedom of expression".

The government is claiming in its writ that the media is bound by the same duty of confidence and the same copyright rules as any former crown servant, including spies.

The writ makes clear that the government wants the power to sue newspapers and broadcasters whenever they publish allegations about the security and intelligence agencies without prior authority, whether or not they paid for the information. It would be sufficient, if the government gets its way, for it to claim that publication has caused "injury to the national interest".

Whitehall appears to believe this would be a less controversial course than resorting to the official secrets act and subsequent embarrassing and high- profile criminal prosecutions.

Another advantage for Whitehall is that civil judgments can be enforced in foreign jurisdictions, lawyers said yesterday.

MI5 and MI6 are desperately concerned about the way original injunctions obtained in 1997 have been steadily eroded, largely because the information has been published abroad or on the internet.

This enabled the Guardian last year to publish details of Mr Shayler's allegation that MI6 was involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy - confirmed recently, despite official denials, by an MI6 document placed on the internet.

Mr Shayler also revealed the existence of MI5 reports on the bombing of the Israeli embassy in London in 1994. Two Palestinians convicted of the bombing, Samar Alami and Jawad Botmeh, are fighting a court battle to see the reports.

John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer and director of the civil rights group Liberty, said last night: "The government is set on trying to use the civil courts to shut [Mr Shayler] up. We will fight the case on the basis of freedom of expression and the public's right to know about malpractice in MI5. In the absence of a proper system of parliamentary accountability the public has to rely on whistleblowers to find out what the security and intelligence services are up to."

webTitle: Poorly designed estates to be curbed

fields.headline: Poorly designed estates to be curbed
fields.trailText: Tough planning restrictions to outlaw soulless housing estates in the countryside and curb suburban sprawl will shortly be unveiled.
fields.body:
Tough planning restrictions to outlaw soulless housing estates in the countryside and curb suburban sprawl will shortly be unveiled.

Ministers are preparing to give councils powers to throw out poorly designed developments - with the promise of Whitehall backing if builders force public inquiries.

Under pressure from the vocal countryside lobby and Labour MPs in marginal middle-England, John Prescott, deputy prime minister, will warn big builders they will no longer be allowed to swallow up green fields, particularly in the overcrowded south-east.

Instead they will be forced to examine the potential of recycled land - so-called brownfield sites - before looking at big plots in the countryside. Even then, they will have to cram many more homes on smaller sites while radically changing house designs.

The new guidelines will coincide with the deputy prime minister's long-awaited decision on housing projections in the south-east over the next 16 years.

Inevitably, amenity groups will view the guidelines as an attempt to soften the blow of an announcement signalling that as many as one million homes will be needed up to 2016 to satisfy demand in the region.

Local councils, MPs, Friends of the Earth and the Council for the Protection of Rural England are up in arms because Mr Prescott's advisers have recommended a 64% in crease on plans put forward by the regional planning body, Serplan.

They suggested no more than 914,000 homes up to 2016.

But the government is promising to review housing projections every five years.

fields.headline: Jacqueline Auriol
fields.standfirst: A reconstructed woman at twice the speed of sound
fields.trailText: Jacqueline Auriol, who has died aged 82, was France's first woman test pilot. She had taken to the air for freedom, to fly away from the formality of her life around the Elysée Palace as the daughter-in-law of the president of the French Republic.
fields.body:
Jacqueline Auriol, who has died aged 82, was France's first woman test pilot. She had taken to the air for freedom, to fly away from the formality of her life around the Elysée Palace as the daughter-in-law of the president of the French Republic.

Born in the Vendée, she had gone to Paris to study art at the Ecole du Louvre, and at 21, married Paul Auriol, then a student at Sciences Politiques. His father, Vincent Auriol, was a prominent Socialist and known to be opposed to the Pétain regime under the German occupation of France during the second world war.

After the war, Vincent Auriol became president in 1947, and Paul acted as his press secretary: Jacqueline's function, as a famous beauty, was to socialise in a Paris attempting to regain its worldwide reputation for luxury living and exports. (Christian Dior's New Look fashion collection was shown in 1947.)

Paris also had a reputation for the finest aerodrome in Europe, Orly, which had a civilised identity when Heathrow was still a gathering of huts; French postwar aviation was also experimenting with a new sea plane, the Nord I 400, baptised at Le Havre.

Encouraged by her husband, Jacqueline Auriol learned to fly, gaining her first pilot's certificate in 1948. She took part in a competition flight between Algiers and Dakar and then, in July 1949, demonstrated her skills at the Paris air show. A few days later, she was sitting next to the pilot in a twin-motored hydroplane, SCAN-30 when it crashed into the Seine. She was badly hurt, with severe facial injuries. The press announced that the most beautiful woman in Paris would be permanently disfigured.

But Auriol was determined that this should not happen, and after many operations in France and the US, she emerged with a new face and a new determination to conquer the air. In the US, she had learned how to pilot helicopters and taken a military training course. In May 1951, she took off from Marseilles at the controls of the jet- engined British de Havilland Vampire and became the fastest woman in the world, flying at 818 kilometres an hour over a test course of 100 kilometres. The next year she became a national heroine by improving her time, reaching 855 kph in a French-built Mistral. In 1954, she qualified as a test pilot, claiming to be the first woman to do so, and five years later flew at Mach 2, twice the speed of sound. Auriol and her friend, the American pilot Jacqueline Cochrane, competed for world supremacy. The record passed between them nine times, with Auriol winning five of the records, before the competition finally ended in 1964, when Cochrane reached 2,097 kilometres an hour, beating Auriol's 2,040 kph in a Mirage III-R the previous year.

Auriol was well known for the calm and matter-of-fact way she reported her achievements. In 1956, a Mirage IV that she was testing got out of control, and it was only at the last minute that she was able to recover and effect a rough but safe landing. "I've made a bit of a mess of the grass," was her only comment.

After her retirement from aviation, she continued to support other women pilots, and in 1968 published a book, Vivre et Voler. "Truth is with me when I fly," she once wrote."Now I know that only life and death are important."

She is survived by her two sons.

Jacqueline Auriol, aviator, born November 5 1917; died February 11 2000

fields.headline: Indonesia's chainsaw massacre
fields.standfirst: The world's second richest biodiversity is being raped and pillaged by illegal loggers, poachers and greedy farmers
fields.trailText: Susilawaty has not had a good night's sleep in ages. A field worker with the World Wide Fund for Nature in Kerinci-Seblat national park, she is being kept awake by the incessant high-pitched whine of chainsaws devouring tree after tree in the protected area.
fields.byline: John Aglionby  in Kerinci-Seblat national park, Sumatra
fields.body:
Susilawaty has not had a good night's sleep in ages. A field worker with the World Wide Fund for Nature in Kerinci-Seblat national park, she is being kept awake by the incessant high-pitched whine of chainsaws devouring tree after tree in the protected area.

"It's as if they have an insatiable appetite that cannot be satisfied," she says.

The problem is not isolated to this one corner of Sumatra. Indonesia's wild animals and forestry - as demand for timber outstrips official supply quotas by almost three to one - are being rapidly depleted in unprotected areas, and leading environmentalists and forestry analysts believe that every single one of Indonesia's national parks is being systematically raped of its flora and fauna.

Poachers, illegal loggers and encroaching farmers are active everywhere across the sprawling archipelago. The orangutan population is in rapid decline in Kalimantan, the Indonesian half of Borneo, turtles are sighted much less often off the coasts of Bali, the sparkling array of colourful marine life beneath the waters of north Sulawesi is dulling, and the Sumatran tiger and rhino are fighting for survival.

Rudi Syaf, the programme coordinator for the Conservation Information Forum, a non-governmental organisation based in central Sumatra, shares the widely held view that Indonesia's enormously varied natural beauty - it has the second richest biodiversity in the world - is a victim of the continued political and economic instability that has blighted the country since the former dictator Suharto was toppled in May 1998.

"People were previously very scared of those in power," he says. "Now, with the collapse of law and order and little political will to tackle the issue, they are much braver. They are not afraid to attack people who try to stop them.

"Many people have also suffered massive economic hardship in the monetary crisis. Trees are seen as the easiest way to make money quickly."

Exacerbating the situation is the current government's push to devolve power to the provinces, which many people fear will only increase the opportunities for corrupt people to eat into the country's natural resources.

The key players in the destruction are the security forces and local government officials. In areas where soldiers and police officers are not actually organising the illegal trade they are usually paid to turn a blind eye, while most politicians and civil servants view the national parks as a hindrance to their region's development and care little about their ruin.

"I can't yet say it's an institutional problem," says Wandoyo Siswanto, the head of Kerinci-Seblat and one of the few government officials actively on the side of conservation, "but there are so many individuals involved it makes little difference."

International fight
In many respects, Kerinci-Seblat is typical of the nationwide malaise. Named after the two highest mountains in the park, it is larger than Belgium and has a 1,700-mile long boundary. Once home to thriving populations of the rare Sumatran tiger and even rarer rhino - a woolly two-horned variety that has evolved little over the last few millennia - the park is being attacked by illegal loggers, poachers and farmers wanting to extend their holdings.

Police commanders claim the area is too large and their resources too meagre to tackle the crisis effectively. Few of the 108 park rangers are willing to patrol for more than a few hours and so none of the big players have been arrested.

The political will to address the issue is extremely weak. It is only because police and prosecutors are being paid extra to do their jobs that two dozen illegal loggers who were caught recently are still in detention and likely to face trial.

However Kerinci-Seblat has one huge advantage over other parks. The World Bank has selected it as a key conservation area and is pumping millions of pounds of aid and expertise into fighting the destruction.

Consultants are advising on both short-term crisis management - namely enforcement of law and order - and long-term solutions, in particular raising public awareness of the importance of the park to the area's survival.

There have been some successes. At the end of last year the park became the first in Indonesia to be gazetted, which means its boundaries were officially recognised. Earlier this week, one provincial governor was blocked in his attempt to build a new road through the park.

Local people are also starting to learn about the effects of not conserving the forest, according to Susilawaty, who is paid partly from World Bank funding. "They know that the water levels are dropping in their rice fields and are aware that it's because of the forest disappearing," she says.

"But they, and the government, only think in the short term. There is no long-term vision."

And the international offensive has failed to reach government officials and the security forces who are still apparently impervious to change. "The result is that we are not winning the fight yet," says Mr Siswanto, "we are just not losing as badly as before or as badly as other parks."

Tanjung Puting in Kalimantan and Gunung Leuser in north Sumatra are two of the few places in the world where orangutans continue to live, and both are shrinking rapidly. It was revealed this week that more than half of the 450,000-acre Kutai park, in Kalimantan, has been destroyed in the last few years.

Foreign donors are starting to hold Indonesia to account for the rape of its forests and parks. Aid for the forestry sector has all but been halted until illegal logging is brought under control, and funds for other sectors also might be stopped if no progress is made.

But the problem is so acute and the corruption so endemic, no one is expecting miracles, says Raleigh Blouch, the leader of the World Bank team in Kerinci-Seblat. "There are just too many problems," he says. "There's politics, there's greed, there's corruption, there's poverty. It's what they're used to. We can make some progress but all we can do is hold back the forest destruction. We can't stop it."

webTitle: Pakistan says Indians killed family in Kashmir

fields.headline: Pakistan says Indians killed family in Kashmir
fields.trailText: Indian commandos have been accused by the Pakistani authorities of crossing the line that divides the disputed Himalayan territory of Kashmir and killing 13 civilians in a night raid early yesterday.
fields.byline: Rory McCarthy  in the Dabsi valley, Pakistani Kashmir
fields.body:
Indian commandos have been accused by the Pakistani authorities of crossing the line that divides the disputed Himalayan territory of Kashmir and killing 13 civilians in a night raid early yesterday.

Villagers laid out the bodies later in the day on wooden beds in a square near Lanjot village, in the Dabsi valley, on the Pakistani side. Three were decapitated; one man's arms had been hacked off. Four of the dead were children, the youngest two years old. Three others were elderly men, one with a white wisp of a beard.

There was no independent way to ascertain whether the the killers - described by a survivor as wearing "army dress" - were Indian soldiers, or extremists from either side of the line seeking to destabilise the area or taking vengeance for some local act.

Yesterday in the square a crowd of more than 500 people wept and chanted slogans against India. The killings are the most serious incident in the frontier zone since the Pakistani and Indian armies clashed for 10 weeks last May and June along what is known as the line of control (LoC) between the Indian and Pakistani parts of Kashmir.

New Delhi denied that any of its troops were involved and insisted none had crossed into Pakistani territory. Islamabad called the murders a terrorist attack.

"It was a very open terrorist act against innocent civilians. It was an open attack by Indian army troops," said Brigadier Dilshad Hussain Malik, the local Pakistani army commander. "It was a cowardly act which no soldier should do. The plan was well-conceived with thorough preparation."

By Brig Malik's account, an Indian commando team of around 15 crossed the line of control in the early hours, taking advantage of the nightly electricity shutdown on the Pakistan side. They broke into an isolated house and attacked a large family lying asleep.

Pakistani soldiers in a bunker 400 metres away were taking heavy shelling at the time, he said: "[Indian] army personnel openly crossed the LoC knowing full well our people were already engaged."

Only two men escaped alive. One, Mohammed Younis, 42, said the attackers were in uniform and threw grenades into the house before kicking down the door. "There were about 15 people in army dress. They came inside shooting," he said.

New Delhi has put intense pressure on the US to exclude Pakistan from the tour because of the October military coup there; there have been hints in Washington that Pakistan might be added to the itinerary.

Tensions between Pakistan and India have increased. On Sunday the Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, ruled out talks unless Pakistan gives up the third of Kashmir it controls.

webTitle: US says China's record on rights worsens

fields.headline: US says China's record on rights worsens
fields.trailText: China's human rights record "deteriorated markedly" last year as Beijing cracked down on a fledgling opposition party and on the Falun Gong sect, the US state department reported yesterday.
fields.body:
China's human rights record "deteriorated markedly" last year as Beijing cracked down on a fledgling opposition party and on the Falun Gong sect, the US state department reported yesterday.

The state department's critical assessment of Beijing's record is likely to increase the election-year controversy surrounding President Bill Clinton's open-door policy towards China and his support for the communist state's admission to the World Trade Organisation. But the president defended his policy yesterday.

"I hope all of you will support my attempt to bring China into the World Trade Organisation by giving them permanent normal trading status," Mr Clinton said at a Democratic party meeting. "I think it's very important - not just for economic reasons _ it would be very good for the cause of freedom and human rights in China."

However, the report said that, in violation of international conventions, several thousand people were in Chinese jails for peacefully expressing their political, religious and social views. There were mass roundups of suspected dissidents in May and September, and during the course of the year, fewer political prisoners than usual were released early.

The new political prisoners included almost all of the fledgling China Democratic Party's top leaders, who were either sentenced "in closed trials that flagrantly violated due process" to long prison terms for subversion or were being detained without charge. The crack down left only a handful of dissidents outside prison willing to remain publicly active.

Tens of thousands of Falun Gong members were also rounded up and detained in sports stadiums where they were forced to sign renunciations of their beliefs. Those who refused to recant were imprisoned, sent to "re-education through labour" camps, or confined to psychiatric hospitals, the report said.

Other abuses listed by the report include "extrajudicial killings, torture and mistreatment of prisoners, forced confessions, arbitrary arrest and detention, lengthy incommunicado detention and denial of due process".

The Clinton administration, however, insists that it is maintaining pressure on Beijing in regard to human rights.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 32 dead after bomb blast
fields.body:
32 dead after bomb blast

At least 32 people were killed and scores wounded yesterday when bombs exploded on two buses in the southern Philippines.

The first blast occurred as a ferry carrying a crowded bus was about to dock at Ozamis, on Mindanao island. A second bomb exploded in another bus owned by the same Super Five company in Rizal, in nearby Zamboanga del Norte province.

In January, a bus belonging to the firm was burned by suspected Muslim separatists in Lanao del Norte province, apparently to avenge the death of a rebel commander's son, who was hit by a Super Five bus last year. Agencies, Ozamis

Police free factory workers

Dozens of immigrant workers locked in a garment factory and forced to work while their wages were withheld have been rescued by Cambodian police.

Human rights activists said yesterday that 51 Vietnamese and ethnic Chinese workers, who were lured to Cambodia by promises of eight-hour working days and salaries of about £63 a month, were freed from the GT Garment Co in Phnom Penh last week. AP, Phnom Penh

Israel renews aerial assaults

Israeli jets struck targets in southern Lebanon yesterday in apparent retaliation for a guerrilla attack on an Israeli outpost near the Israel-Lebanon border.

The air raid was the first in southern Lebanon in a week and came amid increasingly acrimonious exchanges between Israeli and Lebanese officials. Earlier this week, the Israeli foreign minister, David Levy, threatened to make Lebanon pay "blood for blood, soul for soul, child for child" if his country was attacked. AP, Beirut

Rebellious pot smoker jailed

A French tourist has been sentenced to one year in jail for smoking cannabis in a Kenyan government office, a local newspaper reported yesterday.

After being refused a visa extension at the provincial commissioner's office, Thierry Pradel lit a joint out of frustration. On being questioned, Pradel said he had no respect for the Kenyan police force and that he would smoke as he wished. Reuters, Nairobi

webTitle: NYPD quartet cleared in 41 bullet killing of immigrant

fields.headline: NYPD quartet cleared in 41 bullet killing of immigrant
fields.trailText: Four New York City police officers were acquitted of murder and all other charges yesterday in the shooting of an unarmed African immigrant who died in a barrage of 41 bullets a year ago, sparking charges of police brutality against minorities.
fields.body:
Four New York City police officers were acquitted of murder and all other charges yesterday in the shooting of an unarmed African immigrant who died in a barrage of 41 bullets a year ago, sparking charges of police brutality against minorities.

The New York State Supreme Court jury in Albany cleared the four white officers of the top charge of second-degree murder and five lesser charges, including first-degree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide in the racially charged shooting of Guinean immigrant Amadou Diallo.

City residents reacted emotionally to the eagerly awaited verdict and end of the trial after a year of tension in New York and public debate about the mostly white New York Police Department's often-troubled relationship with blacks and Hispanics.

"There is no justice for blacks and Latinos," said Timothy Ford, an activist from Brooklyn who was outside the courthouse in the state capital Albany. "We might as well not expect it. How can a man be shot 41 times and not get justice?"

The four plainclothes officers of the NYPD's elite Street Crime Unit all testified that they thought Diallo, 22, was pulling a gun when they saw him standing in his Bronx apartment building vestibule in the early hours of Feb. 4, 1999. They told the jury that they feared for their lives and acted in self-defence, firing 41 bullets.

Officers Sean Carroll, 37, Kenneth Boss, 28, Edward McMellon and Richard Murphy, both 27, said they realised too late Diallo had been reaching for his wallet, not a weapon.

Diallo died after being shot 19 times.

The jury of four blacks and eight whites announced its verdict on the third day of deliberations after a four-week-long trial that began on Jan. 31. New York State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Teresi said after the jury announced the verdict, "the book is closed" on the case.

He said the jurors had requested no contact with the media to discuss the trial or their deliberations.

An appeals court had moved the trial from the Bronx to Albany 150 miles (240 km) away on grounds that pretrial publicity and protests would make a fair trial difficult for the officers in New York City.

But within an hour of the verdict being announced, the U.S. Attorney for New York Mary Jo White said that she, along with the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department, will review all of the evidence to "determine whether there were any violations of the federal civil rights laws."

The shooting prompted weeks of protests and a civil disobedience campaign led by the Rev. Al Sharpton.

On Friday evening, Sharpton appealed for calm.

"I have been asked by the family to go to the street where Amadou lived to let the people know we have not given up," Sharpton said at an impromptu rally outside the Albany courthouse. "But we do not want to tarnish his name with any violence. Let not one brick be thrown, not one bottle be thrown, not one epithet of violence come from us, we are fighting violence, violent men who would shoot an unarmed man 41 times."

Diallo's mother, Kadiadou Diallo, sat rigid in the courtroom while tears rolled down her cheeks as the verdicts were read.

As the defence attorneys stepped out of the courthouse, a growing crowd of protesters stood in driving rain, booing and chanting, "Murderers, murderers."

McMellon's attorney, Stephen Worth, said of the officers, "Obviously, they're relieved. We all recognise the fact that someone died here ... that Amadou Diallo died in this incident. But they're relieved."

In a tense courtroom, the jury forewoman stood up to announce the verdict for each officer. One by one, the four men were found "not guilty" of second-degree murder by intent; second-degree murder by depraved indifference; first-degree manslaughter; second-degree manslaughter; criminally negligent homicide and reckless endangerment.

If the officers had been convicted, they would have received possible sentences ranging from a minimum of probation and no prison time to a maximum of 25 years to life in prison on the murder charge.

New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, a former federal prosecutor who has overseen the steepest drop in crime in a generation with sometimes aggressive police tactics, offered his sympathy to the Diallo family.

"The death of Amadou Diallo was a great tragedy," Giuliani told reporters at City Hall. "We express once again our regret, sympathy and support to Mrs. Diallo and Mr. Diallo."

He also expressed sympathy to the officers and their families.

fields.headline: The quiet revolutionary
fields.standfirst: Interview: Sushil Wadhwani, member, Bank of England monetary policy committee
fields.trailText: Since joining the monetary policy committee little more than six months ago, Sushil Wadhwani, former LSE academic and hedge fund manager, has persuaded the Old Lady of Threadneedle Street to adapt her thinking about sterling and helped to ensure that the four independent members have the same research facilities as their colleagues on the Bank's staff. Now he wants the nine-member committee to wake up to the profound economic effect of the internet.
fields.body:
Since joining the monetary policy committee little more than six months ago, Sushil Wadhwani, former LSE academic and hedge fund manager, has persuaded the Old Lady of Threadneedle Street to adapt her thinking about sterling and helped to ensure that the four independent members have the same research facilities as their colleagues on the Bank's staff. Now he wants the nine-member committee to wake up to the profound economic effect of the internet.

Mr Wadhwani believes that the net could mark a turning pointing in the history of information technology which may transform the British economy along American lines. While he warns against technological utopianism, he believes business on the net could boost productivity growth and help keep the lid on inflation. As a result, the Bank has some thinking to do.

Mr Wadhwani believes it should revisit its assumption that long-term productivity growth remains stuck in the doldrums at 2% a year. He also believes the Bank should make greater allowances for the squeeze in profit margins which would result from increased competition.

If it did so, it might be able to let the economy grow faster than before, with obvious benefits for living standards.

Not all the members of the committee agree with Mr Wadhwani's analysis. DeAnne Julius, former British Airways chief economist, is an ally but Mervyn King, the influential deputy governor for monetary analysis, appears to be a new economy sceptic, arguing that there is nothing in the official productivity data to suggest a net-driven improvement in the economy's supply side performance.

Mr Wadhwani, at 40 the youngest member of the committee, agrees but says there is enough anecdotal and survey evidence to suggest the data may be lagging behind reality. With this in mind he feels that waiting for definitive proof of an increase in productivity is too risky and will restrict growth in the meantime.

Following intuition

Like Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, he is prepared to base policy on intuition rather than following old fashioned rules of thumb about how the economy behaves.

"Chairman Greenspan, back in 1996, was already running monetary policy on the basis that it was possible that productivity growth was going to be higher than it had been, even though at that stage there was not a single study of US productivity growth which showed an uptick," says Mr Wadhwani. The result has been a record-breaking expansion lasting 107 consecutive months.

"I think in some sense when we make our forecast we should form our best judgment of what productivity growth is going to do and... I think the reason we might get an uptick is we have seen it in the US. We are a little bit behind but does give me some confidence," he says.

Mr Wadhwani's optimistic pointers include a small but rapidly expanding and highly productive IT sector, big cost savings being made by companies using the net to shorten supply chains and that the rate of return in manufacturing industry continued to rise between 1995 and 1997 even though measured productivity apparently remained unchanged. His open-minded approach to the job of setting interest rates owes much to the 8 years he spent in the markets, initially as director of equity strategy at Goldman Sachs, when he was ranked number one by Institutional Investor Survey, and latterly as director of research and partner of the Tudor Group hedge fund.

"For me... I think if I got this job straight from the LSE I think I would have relied more on my models than I do now," says Mr Wadhwani. "I think having been in the City and having got things wrong teaches you to be critical of every tool that you use. But it's absolutely critical to have a judgmental override at the end of the day, a kind of commonsense test because otherwise your models can really lead you astray."

His experience in the markets is one of the strengths he brings to the MPC, often criticised for being packed with pointy heads. It enabled him to convince the Bank that sterling may remain stronger than previously predicted by the Bank's model, prompting a rethink which has helped limit the extent to which interest rates have had to rise to contain inflation.

But he is far from being an archetypal City figure. A courteous and gentle Kenyan Indian, Mr Wadhwani was born and brought up in Mombassa. He lived there until the age of nine when his family left the country to escape anti-Asian feeling. He and his sister were sent to boarding school in India, while the rest of the family came to England. He joined them at the age of 16 to do his A levels at a sixth form college in northwest London before getting a place at the LSE in 1977, initially intending to become an accountant but switching to economics.

He stayed on to do his MSc and Phd and joined the LSE staff in 1984. Much of his early research focused on unemployment, wages, profit-sharing and unions. His present job reunites him with several former LSE colleagues. He was taught by Willem Buiter and has written papers with Professor King; Charles Goodhart was his professorial adviser when he was first appointed a lecturer. Stephen Nickell, due to join the MPC in June when Prof Buiter steps down, supervised Mr Wadhwani's theses on inflation and unemployment, and they have collaborated on a number of projects since.

In 1990, Mr Wadhwani was lured from academia to the City, where he remained until the call from the treasury came out of the blue last year. "I knew I had to do it straight away but I couldn't say yes straight away because I had to talk to family and to my employer. I think I made up my mind in the first five minutes."

The new job has freed him of profit and loss stress but he laughs at the suggestion that it is more relaxed than working at a hedge fund. "It's such an important decision that you are helping to make that you obviously agonise over it, at least I do," he says, confessing to not sleeping well the night before the MPC's monthly vote.

He ranks this month's decision as the most difficult he has made. Despite his views on the disinflationary impact of the net, Mr Wadhwani was one of eight committee members to vote for a quarter point increase in the repo rate to 6%.

'Don't get carried away'

Although he says the economic effects of the net could be as profound as the telegraph was in the 19th century, he cautions against getting carried away and assuming it has repealed the laws of supply and demand. "The internet has important disinflationary effects without implying the death of inflation," he says.

In the short term Mr Wadhwani is keeping a wary eye on earnings growth, which hit 5.5% in the latest quarter - an "awfully high" figure if it was reliable and unlikely to be justified by productivity growth. He says it could be a blip due to one-off millennium bonus payments, a distortion which will wash out of the data over the next few months.

Also on his radar screen is the housing market, where prices are rising at the fastest rate since the late 1980s boom. Mr Wadhwani is not panicking yet, pointing out that the ratio of house prices to earnings is not at a crazy level but he fears a destabilising housing market bubble. "If there were signs of it occurring then we would clearly have to act," he says.

Anxious to avoid treading on the chancellor's toes before the Budget, Mr Wadhwani sidesteps a question about whether Gordon Brown should use fiscal policy to damp down the housing market. Pressed, he confesses to thinking the government may be wise to rewrite the MPC's remit to take more explicit account of the danger of asset price booms.

The committee only looks at house and share prices only as far as they effect the outlook for inflation over a two-year horizon. Yet the experience of Japan in the late 1980s and now the US has shown that asset prices bubbles can take longer to feed through into general inflation, by which time the damage to an economy is done.

"It's up to chancellor to set the target and therefore in one sense it is none of my business," says Mr Wadhwani. "Having said that my personal view is that we need to look at this issue and re-examine it. At the moment our overriding objective is price stability but we have subsidiary objectives in terms of output and employment and I think asset prices could be put into that to emphasise their importance."

Now he wants the nine-member committee to wake up to the profound economic effect of the internet. Mr Wadhwani believes that the net could mark a turning pointing in the history of information technology which may transform the British economy along American lines. While he warns against technological utopianism, he believes business on the net could boost productivity growth and help keep the lid on inflation. As a result, the Bank has some thinking to do. Mr Wadhwani believes it should revisit its assumption that long-term productivity growth remains stuck in the doldrums at 2% a year. He also believes the Bank should make greater allowances for the squeeze in profit margins which would result from increased competition. If it did so, it might be able to let the economy grow faster than before, with obvious benefits for living standards. Not all the members of the committee agree with Mr Wadhwani's analysis. DeAnne Julius, former British Airways chief economist, is an ally but Mervyn King, the influential deputy governor for monetary analysis, appears to be a new economy sceptic, arguing that there is nothing in the official productivity data to suggest a net-driven improvement in the economy's supply side performance. Mr Wadhwani, at 40 the youngest member of the committee, agrees but says there is enough anecdotal and survey evidence to suggest the data may be lagging behind reality. With this in mind he feels that waiting for definitive proof of an increase in productivity is too risky and will restrict growth in the meantime. Following intuition Like Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, he is prepared to base policy on intuition rather than following old fashioned rules of thumb about how the economy behaves. "Chairman Greenspan, back in 1996, was already running monetary policy on the basis that it was possible that productivity growth was going to be higher than it had been, even though at that stage there was not a single study of US productivity growth which showed an uptick," says Mr Wadhwani. The result has been a record-breaking expansion lasting 107 consecutive months. "I think in some sense when we make our forecast we should form our best judgment of what productivity growth is going to do and... I think the reason we might get an uptick is we have seen it in the US. We are a little bit behind but does give me some confidence," he says. Mr Wadhwani's optimistic pointers include a small but rapidly expanding and highly productive IT sector, big cost savings being made by companies using the net to shorten supply chains and that the rate of return in manufacturing industry continued to rise between 1995 and 1997 even though measured productivity apparently remained unchanged. His open-minded approach to the job of setting interest rates owes much to the 8 years he spent in the markets, initially as director of equity strategy at Goldman Sachs, when he was ranked number one by Institutional Investor Survey, and latterly as director of research and partner of the Tudor Group hedge fund. "For me... I think if I got this job straight from the LSE I think I would have relied more on my models than I do now," says Mr Wadhwani. "I think having been in the City and having got things wrong teaches you to be critical of every tool that you use. But it's absolutely critical to have a judgmental override at the end of the day, a kind of commonsense test because otherwise your models can really lead you astray." His experience in the markets is one of the strengths he brings to the MPC, often criticised for being packed with pointy heads. It enabled him to convince the Bank that sterling may remain stronger than previously predicted by the Bank's model, prompting a rethink which has helped limit the extent to which interest rates have had to rise to contain inflation. But he is far from being an archetypal City figure. A courteous and gentle Kenyan Indian, Mr Wadhwani was born and brought up in Mombassa. He lived there until the age of nine when his family left the country to escape anti-Asian feeling. He and his sister were sent to boarding school in India, while the rest of the family came to England. He joined them at the age of 16 to do his A levels at a sixth form college in northwest London before getting a place at the LSE in 1977, initially intending to become an accountant but switching to economics. He stayed on to do his MSc and Phd and joined the LSE staff in 1984. Much of his early research focused on unemployment, wages, profit-sharing and unions. His present job reunites him with several former LSE colleagues. He was taught by Willem Buiter and has written papers with Professor King; Charles Goodhart was his professorial adviser when he was first appointed a lecturer. Stephen Nickell, due to join the MPC in June when Prof Buiter steps down, supervised Mr Wadhwani's theses on inflation and unemployment, and they have collaborated on a number of projects since. In 1990, Mr Wadhwani was lured from academia to the City, where he remained until the call from the treasury came out of the blue last year. "I knew I had to do it straight away but I couldn't say yes straight away because I had to talk to family and to my employer. I think I made up my mind in the first five minutes." The new job has freed him of profit and loss stress but he laughs at the suggestion that it is more relaxed than working at a hedge fund. "It's such an important decision that you are helping to make that you obviously agonise over it, at least I do," he says, confessing to not sleeping well the night before the MPC's monthly vote. He ranks this month's decision as the most difficult he has made. Despite his views on the disinflationary impact of the net, Mr Wadhwani was one of eight committee members to vote for a quarter point increase in the repo rate to 6%. 'Don't get carried away' Although he says the economic effects of the net could be as profound as the telegraph was in the 19th century, he cautions against getting carried away and assuming it has repealed the laws of supply and demand. "The internet has important disinflationary effects without implying the death of inflation," he says. In the short term Mr Wadhwani is keeping a wary eye on earnings growth, which hit 5.5% in the latest quarter - an "awfully high" figure if it was reliable and unlikely to be justified by productivity growth. He says it could be a blip due to one-off millennium bonus payments, a distortion which will wash out of the data over the next few months. Also on his radar screen is the housing market, where prices are rising at the fastest rate since the late 1980s boom. Mr Wadhwani is not panicking yet, pointing out that the ratio of house prices to earnings is not at a crazy level but he fears a destabilising housing market bubble. "If there were signs of it occurring then we would clearly have to act," he says. Anxious to avoid treading on the chancellor's toes before the Budget, Mr Wadhwani sidesteps a question about whether Gordon Brown should use fiscal policy to damp down the housing market. Pressed, he confesses to thinking the government may be wise to rewrite the MPC's remit to take more explicit account of the danger of asset price booms. The committee only looks at house and share prices only as far as they effect the outlook for inflation over a two-year horizon. Yet the experience of Japan in the late 1980s and now the US has shown that asset prices bubbles can take longer to feed through into general inflation, by which time the damage to an economy is done. "It's up to chancellor to set the target and therefore in one sense it is none of my business," says Mr Wadhwani. "Having said that my personal view is that we need to look at this issue and re-examine it. At the moment our overriding objective is price stability but we have subsidiary objectives in terms of output and employment and I think asset prices could be put into that to emphasise their importance."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Though sections of Wall Street remained in the doldrums yesterday, with the Dow Jones dipping below 10,000 for the second day in a row, London was in no mood to let US blues spoil a spring-like mood.
fields.body:
Though sections of Wall Street remained in the doldrums yesterday, with the Dow Jones dipping below 10,000 for the second day in a row, London was in no mood to let US blues spoil a spring-like mood.

The FTSE 100 index ended up 111.3 points at 6,198, bolstered by demand among heavyweights in the telecoms and the continuing fashion for "new economy", hi-tech stocks - the latter underlined by the performance of the Techmark index which consolidated its position above 5,000 points.

The heaviest trading was in Vodafone Airtouch amid continued portfolio reweighting. By the close the shares were up 9p at 362p on a turnover approaching 400m shares.

BT resumed its recent progress after Thursday's setback, climbing 46p to £11.50, while AstraZeneca was another to shake off the previous day's problems. Yesterday saw a swift reappraisal of the doubts which surfaced in the wake of full-year results. As a result of more favourable comment on Thursday's figures, the group saw the shares marked up a healthy 347p to £22.83.

The banking sector, however, continues to find it difficult to please investors. Yesterday Abbey National, down 10p at 636p, Lloyds TSB down 17p at 520p and Barclays, off 21p at £14.36, were the latest to be concerned about the impact of internet-based rivals.

In contrast however, HSBC - due to report figures next week - was up 27p at 746p and the Halifax, too, was in demand, with the shares climbing 42p at 585p.

The news that Granada is to join United News & Media and Carlton in front of the competition commission hit the shares of all three. Granada, which has expressed an interest in bidding for either United or Carlton, saw its shares fall 15p to 610p. Carlton and United, which have already announced merger plans, saw stock drop 21p to 734p and 45p to 843p, respectively.

Storehouse shares enjoyed a smart run after the stores group confirmed it was on several shopping lists, moving up 19p to 50p.

Elsewhere Oxford Glycosciences took advantage of the recent boom in biotech shares, announcing a placing and open offer of 1.78m shares at £17 each to raise £33.2m to fund its research into proteins. The shares responded with a 517p rise to £23.40.

fields.headline: Greed is good again
fields.trailText: "Greed is good." Roll the words around your tongue. Try them for size. How comfortable do they feel? If you find yourself choking, you're probably in the minority. Greed is back in fashion, although its guise has altered. And believe me, it's one helluva dangerous emotive force.
fields.body:
"Greed is good." Roll the words around your tongue. Try them for size. How comfortable do they feel? If you find yourself choking, you're probably in the minority. Greed is back in fashion, although its guise has altered. And believe me, it's one helluva dangerous emotive force.

When Gordon Gekko espoused his personal philosophy on life in Oliver Stone's classic immorality tale, Wall Street, he encapsulated the prevailing mood in financial markets in three short words.

The film was released in 1987 - only months before a crash in asset prices. Michael Douglas, as Gekko, was an anti-hero who somehow came to be regarded as an icon by those who occupied the real world that Stone set out to parody.

Never mind Gekko's final reel comeuppance, it was his first reel, balls-out greediness that set trading floor pulses racing.

The crash of 1987 was preceded by a greediness that suffused the populations of the developed world. Rising asset prices - shares, property, art - caught the popular imagination. The peculiarly pure strain of greed that is an everyday driver for brokers and bankers suddenly took hold of people in all walks of life. Many did not know their assets from their elbows.

Participation in financial markets spread far beyond normal boundaries. Not only the taxi driver, but his mechanic also was playing the markets. Credit was easy to acquire and so personal financial leverage reached unprecedented levels. Fear, by contrast, all but disappeared and, for a few brief months, everyone felt like a lottery winner.

Or, more correctly, everyone felt as if they should feel like a lottery winner. The British stock market peaked in July 1987, three months before it crashed. And yet it was these three months that witnessed the greatest investment frenzy among the public.

The collapse, when it came, set the cause of mass investment in British equities back years. The greatest damage, however, was wrought in the housing market, where borrowings were sky-high. Negative equity: a deceptively innocuous term that masked severe financial misery and the rediscovery of fear.

Equity prices took 2 years to recover their previous highs, house prices took eight years. It is only in the past year or so that both have once again become the vehicles for a mass pursuit of instant riches. Fear of loss has become fear of missing out.

Most telling of all, however, is the palpable "dumbing down" of the market. "Stories" (the mainstay of the amateur) have replaced "fundamentals" (the preserve of the professional) as the primary day-to-day mover of share prices.

This is impossible to prove. And I'm obviously exaggerating to make a point - there are numerous private investors whose grasp of valuation theory would shame many "professionals". But I'd defy anyone to dispute the change in the market's nature.

The danger is that an artistic rather than a scientific market allows prices to become grotesquely distorted. The greater fool theory is at work.

In recent months the amateurs have made many professionals appear foolish in missing out on the hottest stocks. But they should be sure they've identified the greater fool.

The smell of greed is unpleasant, and at its extremes a stench. A mass bull market such as this causes innumerable stenches. In time the odour now suffusing the Mirror newspaper may be recorded as marking some sort of peak in the popular investment frenzy.

To watch the equity markets now is to see them at their best and at their worst. At their best they are excellent mechanisms for channelling investment funds to ventures considered too risky by lending institutions. Over long periods returns from equities are higher than those from bonds or cash deposits precisely because the risks attached are greater.

Now, in the midst of a technological revolution, equity investors are prepared to shoot for the moon. As a result, substantial backing is being given to a wide spread of ventures, among which will be the industrial titans of the new age.

At their worst, however, equity markets are prone to bouts of collective greed and mania. For every new age industrial titan there are a host of insubstantial ventures that - because they come with "stories" attached - are able to exploit the present fervour. Disappointment has not been cancelled, merely postponed.

 Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: North Wales
fields.trailText: North Wales
fields.body:
On any clear winter evening you can watch the wonderful light display from the Beaumaris road that's cut into the wooded cliff. It is free. Out across the black waters of Menai we can pick out the navigation lights on Bangor pier and the myriad lights of the town behind. Look away towards the south-east and follow the golden lantern crocodile that is the North Wales expressway, an undulating necklace of light that sways past Abergwyngregyn, Llanfairfechan and Penmaenmawr as far as the Conwy's mouth. Far out to sea are the speckled lights of Llandudno's west shore and the glare beyond that comes from the main town. From this distance, in the semi-darkness of the island, the lights are a wonder to behold. But where man is more tightly packed, such artificial light is sheer pollution. The International Dark Sky Association was founded in America to reduce this light pollution of the night sky. Street lighting and floodlighting isolate us from the wonders that surround us each night.

A simple expedient would be to keep artificial lights facing down to earth, not up into the heavens. But we were far from serious light pollution the other evening, as we wandered in the dusk beyond Penmon and out to the point, where the cold sea was slapping the shelving rocks below the lighthouse. The black whaleback of Puffin Island was just visible against the eastern glow from Llandudno, like a scuttled hulk. It looked most inhospitable, overtopped by the night wind that came racing down Angelsey's eastern coast. Giraldus Cambrensis, the adventurous cleric who travelled through Wales in the 12th century, recorded it as "the ecclesiastical island". It was earlier occupied by Saint Seiriol in the 6th century and the religious community that developed there moved across the water to join the neighbouring community at Penmon in 1237.

We walked back towards Penmon and Llangoed and hadn't gone very far when the bright lights of Beaumaris came into view ahead. It was a welcome beacon on that wild night.

fields.headline: Coral prepares £1bn stock market return
fields.trailText: Bookmaker Coral is planning a return to the stock market with a price that could top £1bn and would generate a £600m profit for its owners of just over 12 months.
fields.body:
Bookmaker Coral is planning a return to the stock market with a price that could top £1bn and would generate a £600m profit for its owners of just over 12 months.

Coral, the third largest chain of British bookies with 850 outlets and a £1bn-a-year turnover, has called in investment bankers Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse First Boston as advisers and aims to cash in on internet betting.

Since its purchase in November of the Eurobet soccer betting group Coral can now offer internet and tax-free offshore betting from Gibraltar. The group is now owned by Deutsche Bank's Morgan Grenfell Private Equity group, which bought it for £395m 14 months ago.

The e-factor has reinvigorated the betting business. Last week Ladbrokes announced it was pouring £100m into on-line betting and its shares have leaped 40%. William Hill which abandoned a flotation last, year has also called in investment bankers to advise on its options.

webTitle: Millions of bars, but no beer

fields.headline: Millions of bars, but no beer
fields.standfirst: Brand values: Cadbury's
fields.trailText: The Bournville village estate in Birmingham is notable for its lack of pubs. It is one of the enduring legacies of George Cadbury, the Quaker chocolate maker, who created the estate as an early experiment in social housing. Equally enduring has been the popularity of many products made at Cadbury's Bournville factory.
fields.body:
The Bournville village estate in Birmingham is notable for its lack of pubs. It is one of the enduring legacies of George Cadbury, the Quaker chocolate maker, who created the estate as an early experiment in social housing. Equally enduring has been the popularity of many products made at Cadbury's Bournville factory.

Cadbury's Dairy Milk, one of the world's largest selling chocolate brands, was launched in 1905, while its plain chocolate counterpart, Cadbury's Bournville, followed three years later.

The 1920s were to see the launch of Cadbury's Creme Eggs, and its Flake, Fruit & Nut, and Crunchie bars. All are still in popular demand by all generations.

It almost never happened. The Cadbury business faltered in the early 1860s and brothers Richard and George Cadbury, then in charge, considered taking up other occupations. One wanted to be a surveyor and the other a tea planter in India.

The business they nearly abandoned had its roots in a tea and coffee shop set up in 1824 by John Cadbury next door to his father's drapery shop in Birmingham's then fashionable Bull Street.

John Cadbury started to sell cocoa and drinking chocolate - very much a luxury for the wealthy at the time. The business thrived and the family moved from retailing into manufacturing.

Gladstone, who was then chancellor, opened the way for a wider market for chocolate when he reduced the tax on cocoa beans in the 1850s. But by the 1860s, the Cadbury business, now in the hands of John's sons, Richard and George, was struggling. The brothers considered calling it a day. Luckily for chocolate lovers, they stayed on to see the business through to more prosperous times.

The family were members of the Society of Friends, the religious group better known as the Quakers. They believed in hard work and social reform and disapproved of frivolous entertainment and drinking alcohol.

When the Cadbury factory was moved from central Birmingham to a greenfield site on the city's outskirts, the family had a golden opportunity to put some of their social and religious beliefs into practice.

They bought a 14-acre estate four miles from the city centre, and named it Bournville - after the Bourn stream which ran through it. They built what has been called "a factory in a garden". It was surrounded by parks and good housing which was not restricted to Cadbury workers. Works committees were set up within the factory, with equal numbers of workers and management being elected by secret ballot.

In 1900 George Cadbury gave the estate, but not the factory, to the Bournville Village Trust, which was charged with enlarging it and promoting housing reform. Today the estate covers about 1,000 acres and includes parks, churches, shops and community halls but no pubs - in deference to its Quaker origins and the wishes of its inhabitants, less than half of whom have links with the Cadbury factory.

Cadbury sells more than 250m Dairy Milk bars, worth about £100m, a year. The recipe has remained virtually unchanged, but the brand has been widened to cover more than 40 different products. Before it was launched, the company had considered other names for it, including Jersey, Highland Milk and Dairy Maid.

Brand names for sweets have great longevity. For example Fry's, a Bristol-based Quaker firm taken over by Cadbury in 1919, launched its Chocolate Cream in 1853. It is still on sale today. George Bassett, acquired by Cadbury in 1989, launched its "Peace Babies" in 1918 to celebrate the end of the first world war before changing the name to Jelly Babies in 1953. Trebor, another acquisition, was its co-founder's name spelt backwards.

Cadbury moved into a new league in 1962 when it merged with Schweppes, the drinks group. Last week Dominic Cadbury, the last family member on the Cadbury Schweppes board, announced that he would be stepping down in May this year.

But the family will still be involved in running the estate beside the Bournville factory - thanks to a condition in the Bournville Village Trust deed. Nine out of today's 12 trustees have a direct link with Richard and George Cadbury.

Today the estate covers about 1,000 acres and includes parks, churches, shops and community halls but no pubs - in deference to its Quaker origins and the wishes of its inhabitants, less than half of whom have links with the Cadbury factory. Cadbury sells more than 250m Dairy Milk bars, worth about £100m, a year. The recipe has remained virtually unchanged, but the brand has been widened to cover more than 40 different products. Before it was launched, the company had considered other names for it, including Jersey, Highland Milk and Dairy Maid. Brand names for sweets have great longevity. For example Fry's, a Bristol-based Quaker firm taken over by Cadbury in 1919, launched its Chocolate Cream in 1853. It is still on sale today. George Bassett, acquired by Cadbury in 1989, launched its "Peace Babies" in 1918 to celebrate the end of the first world war before changing the name to Jelly Babies in 1953. Trebor, another acquisition, was its co-founder's name spelt backwards. Cadbury moved into a new league in 1962 when it merged with Schweppes, the drinks group. Last week Dominic Cadbury, the last family member on the Cadbury Schweppes board, announced that he would be stepping down in May this year. But the family will still be involved in running the estate beside the Bournville factory - thanks to a condition in the Bournville Village Trust deed. Nine out of today's 12 trustees have a direct link with Richard and George Cadbury.

fields.headline: Soap to software riches story
fields.standfirst: This man lost £10bn this week. That hardly matters when you're worth £35bn
fields.trailText: There can't be too many businessmen who don't worry about losing £10bn. One who didn't was Azim Premji as he was worth £35.3bn at one point last week.
fields.body:
There can't be too many businessmen who don't worry about losing £10bn. One who didn't was Azim Premji as he was worth £35.3bn at one point last week.

Mr Premji's soap-to-software conglomerate Wipro has been the star of the Indian stock exchange. Despite stock plummeting from 9,624 rupees (£141) to 6,894 rupees (£101), Wipro is still worth more than £35bn. Mr Premji, who drives a Ford Escort and prefers three-star hotels, owns 75% of the company - valuing his stake at more than $25bn (£16bn).

He ranks alongside Masayoshi Son, the founder of net investment vehicle Softbank who is worth about £38bn, as a pretender to the title "world's richest man" reckoned to be Bill Gates - whose value is estimated at £45bn.

Born in Bombay into a Muslim trading family, Mr Premji is known for playing by the rules. He has already put on the record that one of his sons, Rishad or Tariq, will inherit the Wipro empire.

Originally a small vegetable mill in Maharashtra, Wipro started its rise in 1966 when Mr Premji left Stanford University in the US to take over the family business after the sudden death of his father.

After IBM and Coca Cola were kicked out of India by the government in 1977, the company entered the personal computer market. Wipro began selling through a dealer network and assembling products made by such well-known companies as Canon, Epson, Hewlett-Packard and Sun. It has branched out since then to provide software solutions for companies such as Netscape and Cisco.

Last year, its software division generated $150m of sales. In the past three-quarters it has already managed $160m. The company still makes soap, tube lighting and medical equipment.

Wipro has plans to list on a foreign market - both Nasdaq and the New York stock exchange have visited the company's HQ in Bangalore.

The company's great leap forward came when Wipro cornered the market in Tandem computer expertise. Tandem - which was taken over by Compaq - forms the basis of the switching in telecom systems around the globe. But in the early 1990s Tandem was seen as a dead duck and US firms outsourced their software requirements to India - and Wipro. This ensured Wipro became the only repository of this knowledge - which plays a vital part of Wap (wireless application protocol) mobile phone technology.

Wipro's hi-tech expertise has seen it tie up deals with British microprocessor maker Arm for work on software used on its chips.

The company is working with Fiat to produce a dashboard that can access the internet and with Sony on consumer electronic devices that will be web-savvy. It has also tied up a $30m deal with Britain's Transco for its offshore software operations.

Wipro is about to open a new office in Santa Clara for its technology division and has spun off two new start-ups in California - including Nthink, 20% of which is owned by the software engineers.

Other employees have left to make their fortune elsewhere. Most prominently is Ashok Soota, who built up Wipro's technology division. His start-up, Mind Tree Computing, aims to be worth $10bn in five years.

webTitle: Two vie for Rank theme park stake

fields.headline: Two vie for Rank theme park stake
fields.trailText: Rank chief executive Mike Smith said yesterday that two possible buyers are in the frame for the group's 50% stake in theme park business Universal Studios Escape, which is valued at up to £400m.
fields.body:
Rank chief executive Mike Smith said yesterday that two possible buyers are in the frame for the group's 50% stake in theme park business Universal Studios Escape, which is valued at up to £400m.

He said he hoped to have an offer on the table within three months, adding that further big changes to the group are likely this year.

Mr Smith was speaking as Rank announced a 7.7% fall in annual pre-tax profits to £228m. The results were hit by a lower contribution from the theme parks and a £2m loss at Butlin's holiday camps, despite a major relaunch just over a year ago.

He said: "We know we can do better, all the guys know we can do better and we will drive ourselves hard over the next six months."

Rank indicated last year that it wanted to end its involvement in Universal Studios Escape, which operates two Florida theme parks, as part of a wholesale clear-out of the group.

Seagram, which owns the other 50% of the business, is understood to have decided against bidding.

Rank's share of profits from Universal declined from £27m to £21m.

Mr Smith said: "It's had rather lower attendances than we would like. But please don't take away any thoughts that this is a naff business which has got no future - that's not true."

Since his appointment in April, Mr Smith has presided over the sale of Rank's nightclubs, Odeon cinemas and the Pinewood film studios. The group is left with four main divisions - gaming, film and video processing, Hard Rock Cafes and holiday resorts.

Profits from holiday resorts rose 18% to £72m, despite Butlin's slip into the red. Rank invested £150m in 1998 to improve accommodation and put roofs on large sections of Butlins' camps, in order to attract winter guests. Mr Smith said: "We've realised that these bigger enterprises take a longer period to launch and to get customer repeat businesses than anticipated."

Earnings were also down from video duplication, where Rank's customers had fewer blockbuster releases, although among the titles processed by the business were James Bond thriller The World is Not Enough and the Star Wars film The Phantom Menace.

The group intends to buy back 77m shares. Mr Smith said: "Having learned some lessons over the last six months, I still feel very positive we can extract some value from this company."

The company's shares edged up 2p to 148p.

webTitle: Appeal court ruling closes Barings affair

fields.headline: Appeal court ruling closes Barings affair
fields.trailText: The £850m Barings affair drew to a close yesterday, one day short of the fifth anniversary of the bank's collapse, with judges rejecting former director Ron Baker's appeal against a boardroom ban. Mr Baker had been guilty of a "serious abdication of responsibility" during the crisis, the appeal court said.
fields.body:
The £850m Barings affair drew to a close yesterday, one day short of the fifth anniversary of the bank's collapse, with judges rejecting former director Ron Baker's appeal against a boardroom ban. Mr Baker had been guilty of a "serious abdication of responsibility" during the crisis, the appeal court said.

According to the department of trade and industry, this is the final chapter in the Barings affair, which broke on February 26 1995 as the extent of rogue trader Nick Leeson's wild gambles on Far Eastern markets came to light. The Bank of England stunned the City by announcing that Barings was insolvent and could not be saved.

Australian-born Mr Baker, who was Mr Leeson's immediate London-based boss as head of Barings' financial products division, was disqualified in the high court in December 1998 from acting as a company director for six years. In total, 10 former Barings directors - including former main board deputy chairman Andrew Tuckey and former head of settlements Anthony Gamby - faced varying periods of disqualification.

Seven did not contest the DTI's application for banning orders, but Mr Baker both opposed it and appealed against it.

Yesterday, the ruling from the three appeal court judges stated: "Mr Baker did not take sufficient steps fully to understand the nature of the business Mr Leeson was carrying on.

"It took Mr Baker six months to ensure that at least some limits were imposed on the extent of the activities Mr Leeson was authorised to conduct. Thereafter Mr Baker took no adequate step to ensure that such limits were observed."

Mr Leeson returned to Britain in July last year after his release from prison in Singapore. He had served 3 years of a 6 year sentence.
