webTitle: Banks can resist the Vodafone effect

fields.headline: Banks can resist the Vodafone effect
fields.standfirst: Time to act as shares feel heat
fields.trailText: The banking reporting season is almost over. Of the big names only HSBC is still to come. By and large the various chairmen might have expected to be basking in the sunshine of City approval. After all, the sector made a lot of money in 1999.
fields.body:
The banking reporting season is almost over. Of the big names only HSBC is still to come. By and large the various chairmen might have expected to be basking in the sunshine of City approval. After all, the sector made a lot of money in 1999.

Yet, while it would be an exaggeration to suggest that share prices are bombed-out, the sector has lost some of its lustre. Two factors are at work; one within the banks' control, the second outside it. The latter might be termed the Vodafone effect - though the ramifications run rather wider than one blockbuster bid.

In the short run, Vodafone's sheer size within the FTSE 100 index, post the Mannesmann acquisition, means that many funds have been forced to buy Vodafone shares in order to maintain the appropriate weighting. Buying Vodafone means selling something else, including bank shares.

More broadly, as one leading European banker noted this week, the demand for technology stocks is forcing a reappraisal of investor attitudes towards the financial services sector.

But the banks do have some influence over what it happening to their share prices. Investors are less concerned with the latest set of results than with banks' strategies for e-commerce. In part, that is bound up with the fashion for hi-tech stocks. These days institutions which can show they have a com prehensive online strategy can expect to reap the benefit of the dot.com effect. The banks which are feeling the heat most in terms of the share price are the ones who are deemed, rightly or wrongly, to have most to prove over their approach to online banking.

The e-commerce effect is not just about fashion, however. The internet presents both a challenge and an opportunity for the established banks. Internet banking is much cheaper than the traditional bricks and mortar version. So it offers a low-cost entry route for new players, carving into market shares of the high street banks.

It is not all downside for the long standing players. In a Europe where banking markets are largely delineated on national lines and cross-border deals have been few, the internet offers established banks their own entry routes into markets where they are not yet established and at a price a great deal below the one they would have to pay by taking out an established player.

As more people start to bank via the internet the trickiest question for the banks is one of branding. Do they invent a brash new name, trade on the established title or - if they have moved cross border - seek to promote their own brand or buy an existing one?

As yet there is no sign of consensus. No doubt the banks will be spending heavily trying to ascertain consumers' views. While they are doing so, they might consider working out how to pass on some of the savings they expect to those same consumers.

Bet on the net

What odds would anyone have given 12 months ago that dull, downmarket bookies would become one of the hottest, new economy, internet punts.

Britain's biggest betting business, Ladbrokes, even changed its name in a bid to escape the downbeat image associated with backstreet bookies' shops. How much more glamourous, and investor friendly, it would be to focus on its international hotel operations. And so it was reborn as Hilton Group.

Some 12 months later, and the market is buzzing with excitement about the potential of ventures such as Ladbrokes.com. Online betting, analysts reckon, could drag in millions of new upmarket punters who will be tempted into regular real-time flutters.

The idea is that they will watch soccer on pay-TV and wager 50p here and there throughout the match on things such as which way Alan Shearer is next going to pass the ball or the sum of the shirt numbers of the scorers in the top Premier League match.

Ladbrokes' £100m internet investment plan has added more than £500m to the value of the company. There are even suggestions that Ladbrokes.com could be floated as a separate company, with a £1bn valuation.

Yesterday Coral - bought by venture capitalists from Ladbrokes for £390m a year ago - confirmed that it too is considering a flotation, obviously with another £1bn price tag, on the back of its internet credentials. And William Hill - which was spurned by investors when it attempted to float last year and was snapped up for £825m by (yes, you've guessed it) venture capitalists - has confirmed it is also considering its future, which usually means a flotation.

According to Ladbrokes, internet betting will be worth £1.2bn by 2002, out of a £520bn total worldwide betting market. Just a little slice of that, they reason, will mean mega-profits. In the current market mood there are likely to be plenty of investors prepared to make a bet on it.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: C&W considers Hong Kong bids
fields.body:
C&W considers Hong Kong bids

Cable & Wireless directors are expected to consider bids this weekend for its Hong Kong unit from Pacific Century CyberWorks and Singapore Telecom.

PCCW, a brash young internet firm which two weeks ago launched an attempt to merge with Cable & Wireless HKT plans to make an announcement about its bid on Monday. It requested a suspension of trade in its shares just after Friday's open.

A report suggested PCCW founder and Hong Kong internet entrepreneur Richard Li was in London to present his case to C&W's board.

PCCW, founded 10 months ago by Mr Li, has scheduled a news conference for Monday morning, but a company official said the event would focus on a subject other than C&W HKT.

Japan's reform chief quits

Japan's financial reform chief was forced to stand down yesterday amid reports that he offered to ease up on the regulation of troubled banks.

The resignation of Michio Ochi, head of the financial reconstruction commission, raises concerns about the government's determination to clean up the country's scandal-plagued banking sector, which came close to a meltdown in 1998.

Mr Ochi said he was quitting his post to prevent disruption in parliament, where the opposition parties threatened to block the passage of the budget unless he stood down.

At a recent gathering of financial industry executives he said: "If the method of examination is strict, please bring it to the attention of my office. The utmost consideration will be given."

VW abandons takeover plans

Volkswagen chairman Ferdinand Piech has abandoned plans to bid for rival German car maker BMW after failing to win the support of its controlling shareholder, the Quandt family.

Recent reports that VW was about to make an offer for BMW or its Rover subsidiary have infuriated BMW executives and the Quandts, who own a 47% stake in the business.

Mr Piech told the German paper Die Welt that in meetings with the Quandt family he had been convinced they would not sell their BMW shares. "I accept this position," he was reported as saying. "The owners stand by BMW, no matter how massive the offer might be."

Healthy profits at Nestlé's

Swiss food group Nestlé forecast higher sales and earnings this year after it revealed a robust 12.3% rise in 1999 earnings - twice the gain markets had expected.

Nestlé saw profits rise to 4.72bn Swiss francs (£1.8bn) following rising sales and improved margins. It proposed raising its dividend on 1999 results to 43 francs per share from 38. Sales rose 4.1% to 74.7bn Swiss francs.

webTitle: Byers refers Granada moves on TV rivals takeover bid

fields.headline: Byers refers Granada moves on TV rivals takeover bid
fields.trailText: The government yesterday referred Granada's proposed acquisitions of either Carlton Communications or United News & Media to the competition authorities. The move overshadowed United's announcement of a £370m injection into its internet activities.
fields.body:
The government yesterday referred Granada's proposed acquisitions of either Carlton Communications or United News & Media to the competition authorities. The move overshadowed United's announcement of a £370m injection into its internet activities.

Stephen Byers, secretary of state for trade and industry, said a bid would raise concerns about the share of advertising revenue and television programming broadcasters held. The competition commission, which has already been given a May 16 deadline to report on United and Carlton's plans to merge, has been given until June 26 to report on Granada.

All three broadcasters argue that present laws limiting share of TV audience to 15% and advertising revenues to 25% per company have become outmoded, given convergence and consolidation in the media sector.

United yesterday emphasised the shift beyond traditional television and newspaper media assets by announcing the £370m investment in new internet ventures over the next two years. Media groups Pearson, Reed, BSkyB and Reuters have all announced heavy web investments recently.

However, flat full-year figures which saw pre-tax profits in 1999 drop from £290m to £270m forced United shares down 45p to 843p. Revenues climbed 16% to £2.1bn, while earnings per share edged up 0.2p to 41.8p.

Chief executive Clive Hollick said he planned to place United's European internet interests in a stand-alone new media division and float up to 20% on the stock market in an attempt to realise their value and provide a currency for acquisitions. He said: "Our future as a key media player is with all platforms. Our strong brands, rich content and low-cost promotional opportunities offer a highly attractive engine for creating internet businesses."

Individual companies, notably United's fast growing internet service provider LineOne, which has an estimated value of £1bn, could be floated separately, he said.

CMP.net, United's online hi-tech business which is set to be seek its own Nasdaq listing in the summer, could attract as much as £100m of the available investment funds.

Lord Hollick said United remained committed to investing in new content and was interested in bidding "with partners" for the next contract to broadcast live Premier League football.

United yesterday emphasised the shift beyond traditional television and newspaper media assets by announcing the £370m investment in new internet ventures over the next two years. Media groups Pearson, Reed, BSkyB and Reuters have all announced heavy web investments recently. However, flat full-year figures which saw pre-tax profits in 1999 drop from £290m to £270m forced United shares down 45p to 843p. Revenues climbed 16% to £2.1bn, while earnings per share edged up 0.2p to 41.8p. Chief executive Clive Hollick said he planned to place United's European internet interests in a stand-alone new media division and float up to 20% on the stock market in an attempt to realise their value and provide a currency for acquisitions. He said: "Our future as a key media player is with all platforms. Our strong brands, rich content and low-cost promotional opportunities offer a highly attractive engine for creating internet businesses." Individual companies, notably United's fast growing internet service provider LineOne, which has an estimated value of £1bn, could be floated separately, he said. CMP.net, United's online hi-tech business which is set to be seek its own Nasdaq listing in the summer, could attract as much as £100m of the available investment funds. Lord Hollick said United remained committed to investing in new content and was interested in bidding "with partners" for the next contract to broadcast live Premier League football.

fields.headline: Mystery bidders stalk struggling stores
fields.standfirst: Philip Green and Knutsford ruled out of Storehouse chase
fields.trailText: The struggling Storehouse retail chain, which operates Mothercare and Bhs, has received a number of takeover approaches that could lead to a formal offer.
fields.body:
The struggling Storehouse retail chain, which operates Mothercare and Bhs, has received a number of takeover approaches that could lead to a formal offer.

The group, which plunged into the red last year as sales plummeted, confirmed the approaches in a statement to the stock exchange.

Its shares, which were changing hands at 290p only 18 months ago, have been falling relentlessly and hit a low of 31.75p on Thursday. But as the store confirmed the approaches they jumped 57% to close at 51.75p.

The leap added £84m to the market value of the company, but it is still valued at only just over £210m.

The company's statement prompted speculation about the identity of the predators. A number of financial buyers - British venture capital groups - are known to have shown an interest. Retail entrepreneur Philip Green and the Knutsford takeover vehicle led by former Asda boss Archie Norman were also considered likely candidates.

Until a fortnight ago Mr Green was working on an audacious multi-billion pound hostile bid for Marks & Spencer, but he ditched that plan saying he was shocked at personal attacks and tough tactics M&S had sanctioned to discredit him and his bid.

It is believed he has looked at the potential of Storehouse's brands but last night insisted he was not interested and said he doubted that anyone would be after yesterday's share price leap."At 30p, or £120m, you will get loads of interest", he said. "Then you say you have had lots of interest, the price goes up and no one can afford it.

The Knutsford takeover vehicle has also looked at Storehouse, but sources indicated it was not among the contenders.

A spokesman for discount retailer Peacocks, which was said to have made an approach to Storehouse last year, denied the company was still interested, and Debenhams, which approached Storehouse about the possibility of buying some stores, also ruled itself out as a potential bidder.

One rival retailer said any bid would have to be around 75p to succeed. The company officially has a net asset value per share of 145p, but analysts believe the real value of the stock, plus the cost of breaking lease agreements, means the true asset value is probably much lower than stated. The company has too much retail space, too few prime positions and is paying top rents.

Storehouse was created in the 1980s by entrepreneur Terence Conran but in recent years it has performed dismally. The shares have underperformed the overall market by 77% in the past 12 months and by 93% in the last five years.

Last November the company revealed it had fallen to a £15.7m loss in the previous six months as sales plummeted by 9.4% at Bhs and by 1.2% at Mothercare. The company announced it was splitting in two, with separate chief executives. Mothercare is concentrating on out-of-town and e-commerce developments, while Bhs aims to become a "value" retailer.

The strategy includes plans for the Storehouse parent company to disappear. Chairman Alan Smith said the head office had "no part to play".

fields.headline: Oil on troubled waters
fields.standfirst: BP adds to concessions
fields.trailText: BP Amoco is understood to have offered further concessions to US regulators to salvage its $30bn (£18.9bn) takeover of Atlantic Richfield, the US oil company.
fields.body:
BP Amoco is understood to have offered further concessions to US regulators to salvage its $30bn (£18.9bn) takeover of Atlantic Richfield, the US oil company.

The UK-based company yesterday refused to comment on a reports that it had offered to sell all Arco's assets in Alaska, the focus of disagreements between the two sides. However, sources close to the company suggested that such an option would not necessarily scupper the deal because of Arco's other valuable assets.

Such a stance marks a significant climb-down for BP Amoco, however. The company had previously indicated that the cost savings expected from the Alaskan operations were too important to give up. About a fifth of the $1bn savings expected from the deal were expected to come from Alaska.

Shares in BP and Arco rose yesterday as traders warmed to signs that its acquisition would go ahead. The value of the share-based acquisition had fallen in the past month. The group's previous offer to sell half of the Alaskan assets, or about 160,000 barrels of oil a day, was dismissed as inadequate by the federal trade commission, the US regulator.

The FTC filed a lawsuit against the company to block the merger, citing concerns about the impact of the group's dominance of Alaskan oil production on west coast petrol prices. BP Amoco's offer to maintain a low price strategy made little headway with the FTC and the lawsuit is set to be heard on March 20.

Last week's meetings between the FTC and BP Amoco were not attended by Sir John Browne, the oil group's chief executive.

BP Amoco was surprised at the FTC's position as the regulator had previously agreed the merger of Exxon and Mobil, two US groups, to create the world's biggest integrated oil company.

The failure of its previous concessions is understood to have prompted a reappraisal of its tough line as senior executives are keen to head off a full-scale legal battle.

If the FTC forces a sale of Arco's Alaskan assets, BP Amoco would still produce 400,000 barrels of oil a day in the region.

webTitle: Getting the best out of microwave ovens

fields.headline: Getting the best out of microwave ovens
fields.standfirst: A quick blast in the microwave or grill is many people's favourite style of cooking, not least as it's so easy. But what happens to the food? Peter Barham and Len Fisher conclude their series on the science of cooking methods. Recipes by Jeremy Lee
fields.trailText: A quick blast in the microwave or grill is many people's favourite style of cooking, not least as it's so easy. But what happens to the food? Peter Barham and Len Fisher conclude their series on the science of cooking methods.
fields.byline: Dr Peter Barham and Dr Len Fisher
fields.body:
Dancers in a disco have their own natural rhythms. Some sway gently to the music. Others vibrate violently. In certain cases, different parts of the same dancer may exhibit both modes of motion.

It's the same in cooking: food molecules all have natural frequencies of vibration, and different parts of the same molecule may vibrate with different frequencies. When we heat food to cook it, what we are actually doing is stimulating these vibrations. With sufficient heat, the molecules can be shaken so violently that they come apart or rearrange themselves, and therefore take on new shapes or even form new combinations. These changes give the cooked food new textures and flavours.

The most common way to vibrate food molecules is to use the fast-moving molecules of hot water, oil or air as battering rams. There is, however, a more subtle way to achieve the same effect - and that is to use a vibrating wave of energy; in other words, radiation. There are many types of radiation, such as light, X-rays, ultraviolet rays and so on, but only two that are suitable for cooking. These are infra-red radiation and microwave radiation.

Infra-red radiation comes from hot surfaces such as a glowing fire or a red-hot electric grill. Its usefulness in cooking is that the energy vibrations come with just the right frequency for the food molecules to take up the energy and vibrate more vigorously. The very efficiency of infra-red heating means that it has to be used with some care. Toast, for example, is easily burnt through cooking for just a little too long. With care, though, grilling with infra-red radiation can produce delicious food.

The trick, as so often, is to give time for the heat to penetrate to the centre of the food by conduction without over-cooking the outside. Your chances of doing so can be improved by heating the food from both sides, such as in a vertical grill. Meat, say, can also be cooked by putting it on a metal plate, with the radiant heat source above. The radiation will heat both the food and the adjacent plate, which will then conduct heat to the underside of the cooking food. Again, the food is effectively cooked from both sides. This means that heat has only half the distance to travel (ie, it has only to get to the centre, and not make it all the way across to the other side) - and, by the laws of physics, half the distance means a quarter of the cooking time.

Infra-red radiation is absorbed by molecules on the outside of the cooking food. From then on, all further inside heating is by conduction. Might it be possible, then, to find some form of radiation that penetrates directly to the centre of the food? Unfortunately, it can't be done. The closest we can get is to use microwave radiation, which spins molecules rather than vibrating them.

Microwave ovens selectively spin the water molecules that are present in most foodstuffs. This does not mean that they cook food "from the inside", unless that food happens to be so organised that all of the water is in the middle. Wherever the water is, however, microwaves will quickly heat it, with the water then cooking the rest of the food. The cooking process is accelerated, but it still takes time for the heat to be transferred by conduction from the water to the rest of the food. The waiting times are shorter than with other methods of cooking only because the heat doesn't have as far to travel and - as with all cooking methods that use water - the temperature can never reach more than 100C.

Whether you use microwave or infra-red radiation, the flavours are often improved if the outside of the food is heated briefly to a high temperature (ie, searing). This process enhances flavours via the Maillard reactions. It does not, however, "seal in the juices". This is a myth, disproved repeatedly, but still lives on in many cookbooks. The best way to keep the juices inside food is to cook it slowly. An initial, brief burst of very high heat is all that is needed to drive the Maillard reactions that create the colour and flavour at the food surface, whether that food be meat, vegetable or toast.

 Dr Peter Barham is a reader in physics and Dr Len Fisher is an honorary research fellow in physics at Bristol University.

webTitle: Three recipes for microwaves and grills

fields.headline: Three recipes for microwaves and grills
fields.standfirst: Grilled polenta with creamy onions and cheese, grilled rabbit with trevisse and a curd made from seville oranges. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.trailText: Grilled polenta with creamy onions and cheese, grilled rabbit with trevisse and a curd made from seville oranges. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.body:
All recipes serve six.

Grilled polenta with creamy onions and cheese

Before anyone complains, I have tried instant polenta - it is, with the best will in the world, really dull. The little extra effort required to cook the real McCoy, though time-consuming, is paid back in abundance - using the coarse-grained polenta renders a light texture with a good bite.

For the polenta

1.5 litres water

Salt

300g coarse polenta

30g Parmesan, grated (optional)

For the sauce

Olive oil, for frying

500g sliced onions

1 tsp white-wine vinegar

Sea salt and black pepper

50g unsalted butter

60ml whipping cream

30ml chicken stock (or water)

6 x 25g slices Taleggio, Gorgonzola or grated Parmesan

First, make the polenta. Put the water into a stainless-steel pan, add a little salt, and bring to a boil. Whisking the water constantly, pour in the polenta in a fine shower - this way, you can ensure that no lumps will form in the hot liquid. Once all the polenta flour has been mixed into the water, reduce the heat and cook gently for 40 minutes, stirring all the while. If you have to leave the pan unattended for a minute or so, ensure that you give it a good stir along the bottom and sides beforehand. Once cooked, spread the polenta out on a lightly-oiled baking tray, cover and set aside to cool.

Now make the sauce. In a heavy-based pan, heat the oil, then tip in the onions. Stir for a few minutes, making sure that the onions do not take on any colour, then reduce the heat and leave to sweat down for half an hour, by which time they should be softened and pale. Turn up the heat and add the vinegar, stirring until it has evaporated, then add the salt, pepper, butter, stock (or water) and cream. Leave to simmer for a further 10 minutes, to allow the liquid to reduce and adhere to the onions. Remove from the heat, and keep warm. (This part of the dish can be prepared in advance and reheated gently prior to serving, if needs be.)

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/ gas mark 6. Cut the polenta into 12 slices, sprinkle lightly with oil, then lay them under a low-medium-heat grill (or, if you prefer, on a griddle pan) until a dark crust has formed on one side. Turn over the slices, and cook the other side in the same way.

Lay six of the slices on a lightly-oiled baking tray, spoon over a little of the creamy-onion sauce, lay on a slice of cheese, then top with another slice of polenta. Bake for four to five minutes, and serve at once, with a little grated Parmesan, if you wish.

Grilled rabbit with trevisse

The wonderful, deep red of Trevisse and radicchio lettuces is gorgeous and the flavour is quite bitter. Out of season, that bitterness is even more pronounced, so you can only tell by tasting a leaf if it's suitable for grilling, which intensifies the bitter flavour, or for roasting, which makes it milder. These are prized vegetables, and so need treating with respect - they are most definitely not to be used as a pretty salad leaf. Also, please don't use that cheap balsamic condiment that dominates the supermarket shelves, as it seems more related to vanilla essence than to true balsamic. The good stuff is expensive, sure, but then you need use only a couple of drops at a time.

750g trevisse or radicchio

6 rabbit legs, unboned

120g pancetta (or smoked streaky bacon)

12-18 fresh sage leaves

1 clove garlic, peeled and crushed

Top-quality balsamic vinegar

Olive oil

Milled black pepper

Cut the trevisse lengthways into quarters and wash well, discarding any blemished leaves. Heat up the grill (or a griddle pan). Brush the rabbit with a little oil, then lay them under the grill - keep the heat at a medium level, to avoid any unnecessary charring: blackened foods cause indigestion, not pleasure.

Remove the rind from the bacon, cut the meat into little strips and fry gently in a heavy pan. Add the sage and a pinch of pepper, stir and put to one side. Once the rabbit is marked and coloured all over, and quite cooked within (about 10-15 minutes), put the legs into the bacon pan, along with the garlic and three or four drops of the vinegar. Roll the rabbit pieces around in the pan until they are thoroughly dressed in the bacon, sage and balsamic.

Wipe the grill pan clean, lay on the prepared pieces of trevisse, and place under the hot grill. After five or so minutes, turn the pieces over and drizzle over a little olive oil. Cook until the leaves are soft and tender (they will lose most of their colour). Once done, serve the trevisse on to plates and place the rabbit on top. Spoon over any liquor from the frying pan.

A curd made from seville oranges

A very good dinner recently at the Cow - the current culinary home of the great Juliet Peston and Weekend's very own Kitchen Doctor, Rosie Sykes - was finished with an elegant pastry crust filled with a Seville orange curd. It was splendid. The only time I have ever cooked in a microwave was a very long time ago, when I was working for a catering company: the only good use I found for it was for making a batch of lemon curd, as it meant that you did not have to stand there stirring the mix constantly. It is not revolutionary, I know, but curious none the less.

4 Seville oranges

130g unsalted butter

180g caster sugar

4 eggs

Finely grate the zest from the oranges, taking great care to leave all the pith behind. Juice the oranges and pass it through a fine-mesh sieve. Place the zest, juice, sugar, butter and eggs in a Pyrex bowl and place in the microwave.

I used to cook this at two- to three-minute intervals, then give the curd a whisk, and repeat the whole process until the curd was done. However, as I said, it was an awfully long time ago, and I have no real recollection of just how powerful that particular machine was. As such, it would be best in this instance if you followed the cooking instructions for your own machine. Whatever interval you cook at, each time the pinger goes off, give the curd a good whisk. Continue thus until the curd has thickened and is fully cooked.

Curd must not be in the least bit thin, and even though there are eggs within there is little chance of it splitting. To make a tart, simply roll out a tart case and bake. When the pastry is cool, fill with the curd and refrigerate for half an hour or so. This is very good with lightly-whipped double cream

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.

However, as I said, it was an awfully long time ago, and I have no real recollection of just how powerful that particular machine was. As such, it would be best in this instance if you followed the cooking instructions for your own machine. Whatever interval you cook at, each time the pinger goes off, give the curd a good whisk. Continue thus until the curd has thickened and is fully cooked. Curd must not be in the least bit thin, and even though there are eggs within there is little chance of it splitting. To make a tart, simply roll out a tart case and bake. When the pastry is cool, fill with the curd and refrigerate for half an hour or so. This is very good with lightly-whipped double cream  Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.

webTitle: Kelly takes long winding way to Wembley

fields.headline: Kelly takes long winding way to Wembley
fields.standfirst:
Veteran striker's scoring feats earn him the captain's armband for tomorrow's final flourish
Mystery injury muddles Aldridge's battle plans
Return to Wembley
The stuff of dreams... maybe
Paths to the final
fields.trailText: Veteran striker David Kelly's scoring feats earn him the captain's armband for tomorrow's final flourish.
fields.body:
When, after a gruelling training session, David Kelly tells the younger players of Tranmere Rovers that he will regale them with tales of the good old days, they reach for their mobile phones and cancel all appointments.

As one who has, by his own admission, "been around the block a few times", the 34-year-old Kelly requires plenty of time to deliver his curriculum vitae.

He is the personification of the footballing nomad, a have-boots-will-travel journeyman who accepts jobs much as he accepts chances in front of goal. He still has the knack, as his seven goals in the Worthington Cup - making him the tournament's leading scorer - vividly demonstrate.

The traditional final resting place for sporting Romanies is some gale-lashed outpost where expectations are as low as entrance fees and where mangy old dogs are included in attendance figures. But tomorrow Kelly will buck that trend: he will be at Wembley stadium enjoying his Worthington Cup final appearance against Leicester City.

"At our Christmas party I was having a drink with the lads and I found myself thinking, I'm old enough to be their dad," he says.

"But I have always been one of the fittest players. When we went back to training after the party we were sent on a 20-minute run to blow away the cobwebs. Out in front there was myself, Steve Yates and Stephen Frail, all around, or over, the 30 mark.

"When I was starting out at Walsall it was the young ones leading the way; now it's the old blokes."

Those who know him will be pleased, those who do not will not begrudge him his place on the biggest of stages, for his reputation as a trier, a players' player, has spread during a career which began with non-league Alvechurch back in the early 80s.

Kelly has come a very long way from the ailing child and from the youth sweeping the floor in a Birmingham chocolate factory, and there have been many disappointments, but the former Republic of Ireland forward has little room for regrets or bitterness.

As a child he suffered from a rare disease which caused his left leg to stop growing. At one time it was four inches shorter than his right and, though he jokes about winning all the hopping races at school, mastering the finer points of foot ball while perched on crutches was no laughing matter.

It fostered a resolve to enjoy life to its limits. "I've got a very good friend, who I won't name, though he plays in the Premiership," Kelly says. "He doesn't actually like being a footballer. I love it: the training as well as the playing. I enjoy it just as much when it's pissing down, snowing or freezing cold."

Kelly trained for many clubs before finally landing on the Wirral 2 years ago. After Cadbury's loss had proved to be Alvechurch's gain, he joined Walsall where his scoring exploits brought recognition from the Republic's Jack Charlton and a week's trial with mighty Bayern Munich.

Bayern's coach Uli Höness was keen on the raw-boned 20-year-old with the Brum accent, likening him to Denis Law, but perplexingly Kelly opted instead for a £600,000 move to West Ham. It was hardly his wisest decision and his stay at Upton Park was short and not so sweet. "I scored six goals in my first 10 matches but it was a divided club, full of cliques," he says.

The next seven years were a blur of goalscoring and bag-packing. After West Ham it was Sunday's opponents, Leicester, followed by Newcastle, Wolves and then, before his move to Tranmere, Sunderland.

"Steve Bull at Wolves is the best goalscorer I've played with: so single-minded," he says. "I've known some greedy players; I remember wrestling for the ball with Gavin Peacock when Newcastle had a penalty and I was on a hat-trick, and he's in Christians in Sport for heaven's sake."

Kelly's transfer to Tranmere linked him again with John Aldridge, whom he had both partnered and understudied during his 10-year international career.

"It was odd at first working for someone I'd played with. At first I called him by the rude name I had always called him, and then Aldo. He threatened to fine me if I didn't stop, so now he's Gaffer.

"I see a lot of Big Jack in Aldo. He still behaves like a player and he swears exactly the same. Jack was the same: always your pal rather than your manager."

Tranmere's season has been transformed by their progress in both cup competitions. "Early on there was nothing to look forward to except a battle to stay up," says Kelly. "But things gave changed. We could now qualify for Europe."

Kelly can now savour the tail-end of a career which never realised its full potential. Leicester permitting, the old bloke with the unfashionable club may now discover a silver lining, for, as stand-in captain for the ineligible Wayne Allison, he might just be called upon to collect the trophy.

webTitle: Maverick Hutchison out in the cold

fields.headline: Maverick Hutchison out in the cold
fields.trailText: Everton's Don Hutchison paid a high price for his hard-headedness yesterday when he was stripped of his club's captaincy and put on the transfer list.
fields.body:
Everton's Don Hutchison paid a high price for his hard-headedness yesterday when he was stripped of his club's captaincy and put on the transfer list.

Less than 24 hours after he abandoned all hope of negotiating a new deal at Goodison Park, his manager Walter Smith announced that the Scottish international midfielder would be omitted from the side to face West Ham United at Upton Park thisafternoon, and it seems highly unlikely he will play again for Everton.

Hutchison's attempts to convince the club he was worthy of a 100% pay rise - from £8,000 a week to £16,000 - ended in failure on Thursday when talks collapsed.

"I wanted to stay. I wanted to sign for life. A lot of fans are thinking I'm asking for the earth but that's rubbish," he said yesterday.

"I was just looking for parity with some of the other players. What they offered me was a disgrace. They turned around and said I had a week to accept and if I didn't they'd sell me, but I have rejected it."

"He will definitely not feature against West Ham," said Smith. "I do not believe he will be in the right frame of mind after the events of this week. I think leaving him out of my starting line-up is the best way to handle the situation."

Although the versatile 28-year-old still has 16 months left to run on his current contract, Smith will now seek to sell him for about £3m.

Despite his reputation as a maverick, Hutchison has many admirers, including the Sunderland manager Peter Reid who is anxious to strengthen his squad after the serious injury to Gavin McCann.

"I think Don Hutchison is a good player and we will certainly be monitoring," Reid said. Other clubs who can be expected to express an interest are Newcastle United, Leeds United and Middlesbrough.

Ironically, the man who will succeed Hutchison as Everton captain, the former Scottish international defender Richard Gough, may also be on the move shortly. He has been offered a 12-month extension to his current deal but he too is believed to be unhappy about the financial terms.

Although Gough is one of the oldest players in British football at 37, he is still admired and may receive offers from West Ham, Sheffield Wednesday and Manchester City if he does decide to leave Everton after one highly successful season.

webTitle: Mystery injury muddles Aldridge's battle plans

fields.headline: Mystery injury muddles Aldridge's battle plans
fields.standfirst:
Kelly takes long winding way to Wembley
Return to Wembley
The stuff of dreams... maybe
Paths to the final
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill and John Aldridge swapped scare stories when they met at Wembley yesterday. Both revealed that freak injuries during training threatened to put a key player from either side out of tomorrow's final, but neither would name names.
fields.body:
The rival Worthington Cup final managers Martin O'Neill and John Aldridge swapped scare stories when they met at Wembley yesterday. Both revealed that freak injuries during training threatened to put a key player from either side out of tomorrow's final.

Unwilling to offer any advantage, neither manager would name his injured player, Leicester's O'Neill merely conceding that someone had turned an ankle in training.

Aldridge was more forthcoming about Tranmere. "Unfortunately we had an injury. It would be unfair of me to say who to, but it is likely that one of my players who would normally start will miss out," he said. "If that is the case then I am gutted for him. It was one of those freak training-ground incidents and I am sick for the lad."

Those who have studied Aldridge's pronouncements closely will recall that prior to Tranmere's semi-final against Bolton he was adamant that his long-throw-in specialist Dave Challinor had damaged an ankle ligament. Afterwards he apologised profusely for leading the press up the garden path.

Whoever he has to leave out tomorrow, Aldridge is envious of the firepower Leicester have in Emile Heskey, who made his full England debut on Wednesday. "I always knew Heskey's potential," he said. "My first game as a manager was against Leicester; Emile played that day and you could see he was going to be a star of the future."

O'Neill, who had asked Kevin Keegan to spare Heskey from England duty to keep him fresh, said: "I was slightly concerned about Emile playing for England but he is perfectly fit and will play.

"I thought he did terrifically well and I am sure he is in the England manager's thoughts now for possibly the last 22. I heard Trevor Francis say it was as good an international debut as anybody's, and I wouldn't disagree with him."

But O'Neill would like his main man to be scoring more often than the seven goals he has managed so far this season. "If he wants to be up there with the Alan Shearers and Andy Coles then I have told him to be a little bit more selfish around goal instead of laying the ball off to someone."

Aldridge recalled how close he was to walking away this season, when after a series of league defeats and with their debts mounting Tranmere slumped to the foot of the First Division, leaving the manager questioning all that he believed in. He admitted that it was only the fans who stopped him walking out of Prenton Park.

"The way I felt, I could have walked away," Aldridge said. "But the fans who travelled down to Coventry [for the second leg of the Worthington Cup] constantly chanted my name and the second-half performance left me in good heart." Since then Tranmere have reached the quarter- finals of the FA Cup in addition to their Worthington exploits.

If Tranmere win tomorrow the most disappointed Leicester player will be their 34-year-old striker Tony Cottee, who thought his dreams of winning a major cup final at Wembley had been dashed for good 12 months ago after Allan Nielsen's last-ditch strike won the trophy for Tottenham.

"Someone is looking favourably on me because I've got a chance this year, so I'll try to make it count," he said yesterday. "I felt at the time, that's it, I'm never going to play here again, but I've got a chance to put it right."

fields.headline: Return to Wembley
fields.standfirst:
Tomorrow Ruth Lelacheur, a die-hard Leicester fan attacked at the 1999 final, will attend her first match in a year
Kelly takes long winding way to Wembley
Mystery injury muddles Aldridge's battle plans
The stuff of dreams... maybe
Paths to the final
fields.trailText: For Ruth Lelacheur, a die-hard Leicester fan attacked at the 1999 final, tomorrow's final will be a bitter sweet occasion.
fields.body:
For one Leicester City fan, tomorrow's return to Wembley for the Worthington Cup final is a bittersweet occasion. Although she used to be a season ticket holder, Ruth Lelacheur, her partner Jim Blockley and five-year-old daughter Megan have not been to a match since Leicester's 1-0 defeat by Tottenham Hotspur in last year's final.

Lelacheur has been unable to summon the courage or inclination to push herself through a football turnstile because of a sickening physical assault that day, which destroyed her family outing almost before it had begun. The man who punched her minutes after the kick-off was a Tottenham fan who, on the black market, had illegally purchased tickets for the Leicester family enclosure.

Eleven months on, Lelacheur and her family, who live a long goal-kick from Filbert Street, had planned to watch tomorrow's game against Tranmere Rovers at a local working men's club - until Leicester offered all four of them, including three-year-old son James, free tickets and travel to the game.

The club, of course, rejects the notion that its generosity is anything other than a gesture of sympathy, even though seven of its players have Football Association misconduct charges hanging over them, the result of an investigation into how Spurs fans obtained tickets to the Leicester end of the ground.

"I didn't make my mind up to go to Wembley until a few days ago," Lelacheur says. "It's not that I'm afraid of it happening again, just the bad memories. Megan wouldn't sleep in her own bed for some time afterwards and she was horrified when she saw a photograph of the incident in the newspapers. She said: 'If that man had killed you, I wouldn't have had a mummy, would I?' We had to tell her the man was locked up to stop her worrying."

Police at Wembley last March apprehended her assailant, but opted to eject him rather than charge him. Despite the now infamous photo which shows the thug's fist exploding on Lelacheur's jaw - an image football believed it had eradicated - no one has been charged.

Lelacheur says: "That is what makes me so angry. If he can hit a woman for no reason, what else might he have done at other matches?

"The irony is, we had paid extra to go into the family enclosure because we thought it would be that little bit safer. And we could not have asked for a better position to see the match."

Unfortunately it was only a few minutes old when Lelacheur was sent reeling backwards from a stinging blow to her jaw, at the same time catching a glimpse of Megan being pushed over amid a melee of people.

"Luckily someone scooped Megan up and handed her back to Jim," she says, "but I couldn't stop trembling afterwards, thinking what might have happened. I was in a lot of pain when they took me to the treatment room, but there wasn't much they could do because one of my teeth had all but crumbled away. I was more upset about seeing Megan in tears.

"She looked a right mess, when minutes before she had been such a happy little girl. She looked really lovely in this bright green cagoule and was carrying a little silver cup Jim had made for her. Even the Sky TV cameras picked her out.

Day out in ruins
"It was terrible our day could have been ruined like that. All we wanted to do was go home but we couldn't because we were on an organised trip. So we stayed for the rest of the game, though our hearts weren't really in it, and at the end we just went and sat in the coach, waiting for everyone else."

In response to the incident, the Football League has changed its ticketing rules so that this year no player received more than 25 tickets, a third of last year's allocation. Additionally, according to the Football Association's Steve Double, "each of the finalists had to give a written commitment to distribute their tickets in a responsible manner".

This is Double-speak for players being told not to channel their tickets into the black market - although the habit of flogging them en masse to touts appears to be a hard one to kick.

The practice was an immoral but understandable temptation in the days when relatively poorly paid players saw a Wembley final as a one-off opportunity to bolster their pension funds. Now, however, with the rewards from such spivvery minuscule in comparison with £20,000-a-week wages, it is as indefensible as it is abhorrent.

One would have thought it would have been easy enough for the authorities to make the practice untenable by sweeping touts off the streets, as happened before the England-Scotland Euro2000 play-off at Wembley. But such operations are dictated by the police, not the FA.

After the investigation into last year's shameful scenes, the FA charged 25 Leicester City players and officials with failing to assist the inquiry. Those charges have been dropped but a total of 10 Leicester employees still face charges of misconduct on March 15: the players Steve Guppy, Neil Lennon, Tony Cottee, Andy Impey, Graham Fenton, Arnar Gunnlaugsson and Stuart Campbell, plus the chief scout Jim Melrose, the physio Ian Andrews and the youth academy director David Nish. The club's media relations officer Paul Mace underlines that "all will be protesting their innocence most strongly".

Anyone who is found guilty may be banned from receiving further cup final tickets for either the next couple of years or sine die. Alternatively, according to an FA spokesman, they could escape with a slap on the wristband. Which would only add further insult to the physical and mental injuries already suffered by Lelacheur and her family.

Lelacheur says: "That is what makes me so angry. If he can hit a woman for no reason, what else might he have done at other matches? "The irony is, we had paid extra to go into the family enclosure because we thought it would be that little bit safer. And we could not have asked for a better position to see the match." Unfortunately it was only a few minutes old when Lelacheur was sent reeling backwards from a stinging blow to her jaw, at the same time catching a glimpse of Megan being pushed over amid a melee of people. "Luckily someone scooped Megan up and handed her back to Jim," she says, "but I couldn't stop trembling afterwards, thinking what might have happened. I was in a lot of pain when they took me to the treatment room, but there wasn't much they could do because one of my teeth had all but crumbled away. I was more upset about seeing Megan in tears. "She looked a right mess, when minutes before she had been such a happy little girl. She looked really lovely in this bright green cagoule and was carrying a little silver cup Jim had made for her. Even the Sky TV cameras picked her out. Day out in ruins "It was terrible our day could have been ruined like that. All we wanted to do was go home but we couldn't because we were on an organised trip. So we stayed for the rest of the game, though our hearts weren't really in it, and at the end we just went and sat in the coach, waiting for everyone else." In response to the incident, the Football League has changed its ticketing rules so that this year no player received more than 25 tickets, a third of last year's allocation. Additionally, according to the Football Association's Steve Double, "each of the finalists had to give a written commitment to distribute their tickets in a responsible manner". This is Double-speak for players being told not to channel their tickets into the black market - although the habit of flogging them en masse to touts appears to be a hard one to kick. The practice was an immoral but understandable temptation in the days when relatively poorly paid players saw a Wembley final as a one-off opportunity to bolster their pension funds. Now, however, with the rewards from such spivvery minuscule in comparison with £20,000-a-week wages, it is as indefensible as it is abhorrent. One would have thought it would have been easy enough for the authorities to make the practice untenable by sweeping touts off the streets, as happened before the England-Scotland Euro2000 play-off at Wembley. But such operations are dictated by the police, not the FA. After the investigation into last year's shameful scenes, the FA charged 25 Leicester City players and officials with failing to assist the inquiry. Those charges have been dropped but a total of 10 Leicester employees still face charges of misconduct on March 15: the players Steve Guppy, Neil Lennon, Tony Cottee, Andy Impey, Graham Fenton, Arnar Gunnlaugsson and Stuart Campbell, plus the chief scout Jim Melrose, the physio Ian Andrews and the youth academy director David Nish. The club's media relations officer Paul Mace underlines that "all will be protesting their innocence most strongly". Anyone who is found guilty may be banned from receiving further cup final tickets for either the next couple of years or sine die. Alternatively, according to an FA spokesman, they could escape with a slap on the wristband. Which would only add further insult to the physical and mental injuries already suffered by Lelacheur and her family.

fields.headline: The stuff of dreams... maybe
fields.standfirst:
Cup final in need of early goal when Leicester take on Tranmere
Kelly takes long winding way to Wembley
Mystery injury muddles Aldridge's battle plans
Return to Wembley
Paths to the final
fields.trailText: Tomorrow's Worthington Cup final could be the stuff that dreams are made of. Equally it could have Wembley rubbing its eyes and yawning long before the match is over, writes David Lacey.
fields.body:
Tomorrow's Worthington Cup final could be the stuff that dreams are made of. Equally it could have Wembley rubbing its eyes and yawning long before the match is over, writes David Lacey.

The ingredients look reasonably inviting but much depends on the cooking. The favourites, Leicester City, will be making their third appearance in the final in four years. And the underdogs are Tranmere Rovers of the Nationwide First Division, whose prowess in both domestic cups this season has saved Prenton Park from financial peril. Also thrown into the pot is the appearance of Wendy Toms, who will become the first women to officiate at a final when she runs a line.

League Cup finals tend to be quickly forgotten and are often eminently forgettable. But for one season at least the Worthington Cup can claim the higher ground from the FA Cup, since its finalists have emerged from a full entry of Premiership and Nationwide clubs, even if Manchester United showed little desire to mount a serious challenge and bowed out at the first time of asking.

Leicester, like Aston Villa in the 70s, have found the League Cup a convenient vehicle for a bit of intermediate glory, and the fact that next season's winners will now enter the Uefa Cup has preserved the competition's status for at least another year. The European bonus had been due to expire with tomorrow's final, raising fears that the tournament was about to become even smaller beer.

For the moment, then, Worthington can still offer Wembley a pint with a bit of body. Just how drinkable the ale proves to be tomorrow will depend in part on the approach of Martin O'Neill and his team to the game.

After their stifling tactics of 1997, when Middlesbrough were beaten in a replay, and last season, when a last-minute goal from Allan Nielsen won the cup for Tottenham and prevented a tedious encounter from going to extra-time, Leicester this time will start as favourites and can afford to wag their tails.

O'Neill objects to critics calling his side boring, and when Leicester are at full strength they can play brisk, simple, attractive football. At the same time the Leicester manager will recall how the Nottingham Forest team of which he was a member went into the 1980 final fully expected to complete a hat-trick of League Cup successes only to lose when Andy Gray scored for Wolves after a mix-up between Peter Shilton and David Needham.

O'Neill, therefore, may be loth to allow the opposition space in which to play, and with the Tranmere manager John Aldridge no doubt remembering how Liverpool lost the 1988 FA Cup final to Wimbledon, the game may well need an early goal to end the mutual caution. The sooner either team score the better the match is likely to be.

Leicester's greater pace should take the trophy back to Filbert Street. Tranmere may find it hard to cope with the industry and perception in midfield of Neil Lennon and Muzzy Izzet and even harder to withstand the speed and power of Emile Heskey, especially if he repeats Wednesday's performance against Argentina.

Yet Tranmere have beaten Coventry City and Middlesbrough on their way to the final, and in the high and mighty throw-ins of their centre-half Dave Challinor they have an unusual weapon. Players such as Martin Chivers and Vinnie Jones could reach the far post with fast, flat throws but those from Challinor drop out of the sky like mortars and even O'Neill's lofty defenders may have difficulty dealing with them.

fields.headline: Regal revelations
fields.standfirst:
Annick Massis/ Jory Vinikour
Wigmore Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText: French soprano Annick Massis is a woman with style. Walking on to the platform in a simple yet striking grey dress, she has an assured, almost aristocratic allure, which is mercifully free from the self-dramatisation of divadom. Her accompanist, the Canadian Jory Vinikour, trots behind her. Dressed in a velvet suit and a florid Louis XIV waistcoat, he looks like a bashful valet in the service of some great lady. They make an impressive team.
fields.body:
French soprano Annick Massis is a woman with style. Walking on to the platform in a simple yet striking grey dress, she has an assured, almost aristocratic allure, which is mercifully free from the self-dramatisation of divadom. Her accompanist, the Canadian Jory Vinikour, trots behind her. Dressed in a velvet suit and a florid Louis XIV waistcoat, he looks like a bashful valet in the service of some great lady. They make an impressive team.

Massis first came to prominence at Glyndebourne in 1997, as Adèle in Rossini's Le Comte Ory: her flawless musicianship and impeccable comic timing redeemed what was unquestionably one of the festival's weaker efforts. As if acknowledging that turning point in her career, she closed her programme with Adèle's big act one aria, creating the same magic, laying bare the character's self-deluded sensuality with a combination of spectacular vocalism, verbal innuendo and subtle wit.

Technically, she's staggering. Her voice - bell-like in its upper registers, warm and sweet lower down - is incredibly beautiful. The long, extravagant lines of Monteverdi's Quel Sguardo Sdegnosetto are sculpted with immaculate breath-control. Bel Raggio Lusinghier from Rossini's Semiramide reveals coloratura of dazzling precision and a phenomenal ascent to a gob-smacking top E.

She's also, however, an outstanding actress, nursed in the dramatic tradition that produced Molière and Racine. The latter's Phèdre was the source of Rameau's Hippolyte et Aricie, and there's a touch of the Comédie Française in Massis's version of Aricie's great lament - the restrained yet tragic stance, the sparse, declamatory delivery, the flickering subtlety in which every note and gesture speaks volumes. Handel's Cleopatra (from Giulio Cesare) is often portrayed as a childish sex-kitten; Massis turns her into a regal, sensual figure, and the result is revelatory.

She's fabulous in comedy, too. A wicked smile crosses her face as she exposes the erotic yearnings of Rezia, the heroine of Gluck's Les Pélerins de la Mecque ou La Rencontre Imprévue, the opera on which Mozart drew for II Seraglio. She presents us with Offenbach's Eurydice as an encore, hissing her resentment of Orpheus with gleeful spite.

Throughout, Vinikour is a perfect foil. Recitals of operatic arias with piano or harpsichord accompaniment (he plays both) are tricky to get right and you tend to miss the orchestra. Vinikour - whether enveloping Rameau's Aricie in tendrils of consoling sound, or turning the prelude that heralds Semiramide's arrival into an appealing nocturne - was exemplary throughout and the absence of a band wasn't felt.

webTitle: Help: I'm going down with a sinking ship!

fields.headline: Help: I'm going down with a sinking ship!
fields.trailText: How can you turn a dead-end project into a boost for your career?
fields.body:
I've been assigned to a project which seems doomed to failure and I'm worried that it will take me with it.
Mike M, marketing manager, London

Before giving up on it and yourself, explore the possibility of success. Work out who's keen for this to fail and who wants it to succeed. Investigate whether your pessimism is founded in fact or born of the negative speculation of idle bystanders.

Find someone who wants it to work, revisit the original hopes for the project, then use the value of hindsight to determine how realistic those were. Consider why you've been given this job. Is it an attempt to get rid of you or a sign someone believes in your ability to put things right.

To help you decide whether to stay and fight or make a run for it, write a clear report on your understanding of the current situation. Circulate it to those making the decisions about the project's future. If there's anything worth salvaging include suggestions on how you would do this. Insist on being given the necessary resources and authority to choose what to ditch and what to develop.

This could give you the chance to make a name for yourself as a fixer. If there really is no hope, committing your misgivings to paper can act as a safeguard against future recriminations - and allow you the satisfaction of muttering I told you so. Being involved in a disaster doesn't necessarily harm your career. As well as providing lots of mistakes for you to learn from, there's the opportunity to emerge as a hero showing bravery and resilience in the face of adversity.

fields.headline: A way with the fairies
fields.standfirst:
Queen Adreena
Mass, London
****
fields.trailText: Katie Jane Garside is a complicated heroine. Back in 1991 she caused a storm as the tortured lead singer of Daisy Chainsaw, wearing blonde dreadlocks and ripped antique dresses, and cutting herself on stage.
fields.body:
Katie Jane Garside is a complicated heroine. Back in 1991 she caused a storm as the tortured lead singer of Daisy Chainsaw, wearing blonde dreadlocks and ripped antique dresses, and cutting herself on stage. It's said she inspired in Courtney Love the "kinderwhore" look, and was one of the main precursors of Riot Grrrl. Garside found fame before she was ready, however, and retreated to the Lake District to bellow at the mountains for a few years. She healed herself, and came up with a collection of her own songs.

The new material is more developed than those guttural howlings of yore, and fully fleshed out with her band, Queen Adreena. She and collaborator Crispin Gray (former Daisy Chainsaw songwriter/ guitarist) take to the stage with a theatrical sense of authority. Joined by bassist Orson Wajih and drummer Billy Freedom, they must be the best-looking band on the planet.

Garside is dressed in a lacy pink slip and knee-length brown socks, her mike box unceremoniously strapped to her thigh with thick black tape. She shakes her long tangled hair like a demented fairy, singing metallic dream songs with bluesy intensity and smearing plum lipstick over her face. The rest of the band stand in the strobe lights, all Bowie-ish chiselled cheekbones and punk glam androgyny. Wearing a mod suit and eyeliner, Gray plays sharp, stabbing guitar, while Wajih plucks bass in a long skin-tight dress and peaked cap. Freedom just sits at the back, hitting his drums like a muscled rock monster.

What stops this show from descending into cod Berlin cabaret is the quality of the songs. Soda Dreamer and X-ing off the Day, for instance, are an unearthly mesh of Banshee rock, jazz and Zeppelin-style riffery, while Pretty Polly is pure disembodied folk. With staring, Bambi eyes, Garside conjures up a world each time she sings. In the early 90s there was a disturbing, uncontrolled velocity to her performance, but now she appears more focused.

For the last number the band gradually leave the stage until she is alone in the spotlight, repeating her mantra like a strange figure on a music box: "I only make love to Jesus," she intones. "I only fuck God." With that she slowly walks off, Freedom puts a jacket round her shoulders, and the crowd stand there stunned. There is no need for an encore.

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Record production
fields.standfirst: James Hamilton, product manger with K-tel records, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: As the A&R man here I get sent two tapes a day by budding musicians and listening to some of them can be excruciating. Most of my work is on our dance music label produced in conjunction with the Birmingham club Miss Money Penny's. We aim to produce at least four compilation albums a year and I get involved in every part of the process, from helping in the recording studio to selling the CD to record shops.
fields.body:
As the A&R man here I get sent two tapes a day by budding musicians and listening to some of them can be excruciating. Most of my work is on our dance music label produced in conjunction with the Birmingham club Miss Money Penny's. We aim to produce at least four compilation albums a year and I get involved in every part of the process, from helping in the recording studio to selling the CD to record shops.

Although I don't visit the club as often as I would like, I am in regular contact with the DJs keeping an ear out for what's hot at the moment. Because the dance scene changes so fast we're always trying to find the freshest sounds and almost predicting what'll still be hot three months down the line. In this market the music dates very quickly.

Once we've shortlisted the tracks we want on the album, it's a case of negotiating with the various record companies. When K-tel invented the compilation album in the seventies it was relatively easy to get artists to sign up - today all the big labels run out their own so, as soon as anyone gets big and signs with a major, they're immediately priced out of our range.

As a result we are constantly trying to find the next big artist while we can still afford them, and that's the challenge. A lot of it is talking to the right people and having a bit of luck. Our next album out in April features a track by Joey Negro which has just gone into the chart at number eight this week, a coup for us.

Once the licensing agreements are in place and we've selected and agreed the final 25 tracks I'll go into the studio and we'll produce the master copy for the production run. From there I'll oversee the artwork for the cover and when it's ready to sell, I'll do the marketing. Most of this is getting out to the record stores and negotiating to get a good selling position.

What most people don't realise is the record companies pay the stores for best positions and have their albums heard on listening posts - again we are looking for the best exposure for the least outlay. When you stand in the shop and see someone pick up our CD and go over and buy it, it's a great feeling. Because K-tel is quite a small company I do get to do a bit of everything.

The best thing about the job is dealing with music all day. I actually play guitar but got into dance music while busking my way around the world. I started out temping in the industry and my big break was persuading K-tel that I could do two jobs they had advertised. It's a hard business to get into for everyone so however bad the demo tapes are, I always send a reply.

fields.headline: How to ... celebrate promotion
fields.standfirst: Some colleagues will praise you but others may turn their backs
fields.trailText: Promotion isn't always a bed of roses. The leap from team member to team manager is a huge one and can bring as many problems as pleasures
fields.body:
Katherine Semple was delighted with her promotion - she thought it was the start of something big. As she readily admits: "I have never drunk so much champagne, so often, for so long. When my boss told me that I had been promoted to deputy editor of the magazine I was just over the moon - loads of chances to shape the mag, more money, more responsibility and, if I'm honest, a stepping stone to getting into a higher profile publication."

Or so she thought. One month into the job she was stressed out, miserable and seriously thinking about leaving.

Katherine's experience is far from uncommon. The leap from team member to team manager is a huge one and can bring as many problems as pleasures. "The most important thing about a promotion is realising that you are going to have to make changes to your working style and relationships," says Imogen Daniels, spokesperson for the Institute of Personnel and Development. "It's also hugely important to have clarity, right from the start, on what your new responsibilities are, how far they extend, and what you expect of the people now working for you."

For Katherine two main factors were causing a problem. "One of the people now working for me had also applied for the job and clearly felt it should have gone to him. He challenged every editorial decision I made and clearly resented my new position," she says. "All of which increased what already felt like a huge pressure to prove I was up to the job. For the first couple of months I was there until 10pm every night. I didn't feel I could delegate anything, and wasn't sure what I should and shouldn't consult the editor about."

Newly promoted workers often think they have to cope with everything alone and know, instinctively, how to deal with every new situation otherwise they will appear not up to the job, believes consultant Ben Williamson.

"But it's wrong to assume that simply because you are now a manager, you can't go to the person above you for help and advice. Most bosses will respect you far more if you ask for guidance - it's impossible to know all aspects of a new job or where all your responsibilities start and finish. No-one is psychic and trying to be often ends in disaster."

Often one of the hardest parts of a promotion if you have remained in the same department is how to re-draw relationships with colleagues. Suddenly, instead of being part of a group that moans about the boss, you have become the boss they moan about and it can be a hugely difficult transition.

"When I was promoted to senior project manager the three guys I'd been working with suddenly had to answer to me," says Kevin McFadyen, who works for a property company overseeing conversion projects.

"It was generally assumed the job would be mine, so there was no resentment from the guys - it was me that didn't know to handle it. I still wanted to go to the pub with them, things to stay the same but it became difficult if I had to pull rank. When I tried to tell one of them that their presentation wasn't up to scratch he was outraged. I suddenly realised I wasn't one of them any more and I began to feel very isolated and unhappy."

Generally, a new job means developing new networks, believes Imogen Daniels. "It doesn't mean old friendships can't survive, but to avoid feeling isolated you need to create new relationships with other managers or people who have the same role as you. The best way to re-define existing relationships is to have regular meetings so that they get used to seeing you in your new role. fields.headline: Lloyd's names in final showdown
fields.standfirst: Investors get last chance to put their case as 'victims of fraud' by insurance market which failed to tell them of asbestos claims
fields.trailText: Lloyd's of London next week comes face to face with the very last people allowed to demand a courtroom hearing for their accusations of fraud against the huge insurance market.
fields.body:
Lloyd's of London next week comes face to face with the very last people allowed to demand a courtroom hearing for their accusations of fraud against the huge insurance market.

More than 200 dissident investors, many of whom face bankruptcy because of their decision to become names and underwrite Lloyd's with their own assets, will try to prove that the insurance market attempted to recruit members in the 1980s but failed to let them know of billions of pounds of asbestos claims which were about to crash in and plunge the entire organisation to the brink of extinction.

The so-called Jaffray case -named after Sir William Otho Jaffray, who is being pursued by Lloyd's for huge losses - opens on Monday at Chichester rents and should be the final showdown between the bloodied insurance market and thousands of investors who are trying to resist being ruined. All 1,650 dissident investors around the world who are still in dispute with Lloyd's have been warned by the courts that this is their last chance to allege fraud. So far only 231 have joined the Jaffray action but their Lloyd's losses alone total more than £51m.

Tax breaks

In all Lloyd's is still owed £370m from those individuals who joined a market which offered magnificent tax breaks for the most affluent but at the price of having to accept unlimited liability. A former chairman of the market used to illustrate the point to new members by making them sign a blank cheque which he would then fill in with enough noughts to make most eyes water.

The Jaffray names claim they are not trying to renege on their side of this blank cheque. What they do argue is that Lloyd's went hunting for names deliberately in order to spread the pain of about £4bn of asbestos liability losses which underwriters were keeping secret in their books.

Monday's do or die court case - expected to last for up to six months - will centre on the issue of whether Lloyd's was deliberately fraudulent or simply full of failings. The names will call as witnesses once towering figures in the London market such as Dick Outhwaite - one of the most profitable underwriters the market has seen but one whose business collapsed into the arms of rivals because of galloping liability losses.

Even the market's most stalwart supporters acknowledge that Lloyd's was out of control to some considerable degree during the 1980s as its eventual £8bn of losses mounted remorselessly. The rich who were not already members of the market were clamouring to join in the late 1970s and early 1980s because of the superlative tax breaks on offer to top earners being stung by a 98% rate of supertax.

Lloyd's was also desperate to drum up new members in the United States to compensate for the fact that the pound was dropping against the dollar and putting the squeeze on the amount of US business the organisation could handle.

But the real killer was the strong rise in property prices in London and the south-east. This meant that very "ordinary" homeowners in Islington and St John's Wood could suddenly meet Lloyd's "wealth test" which had been designed years earlier to deter all but the most affluent.

By the end of the 1980s Lloyd's membership hit a peak of 34,000. But a seemingly endless stream of dodgy dealing and malpractice has surfaced in the insurance market in the past couple of decades which have threatened to extinguish the venerable institution which is a major contributor to the UK's invisible balance of payments and which has just embarked on its fourth century of operation.

A successful fraud claim would undermine the market's entire basis of doing business - uberrima fides or utmost good faith - and kibosh its ability to compete with the new breed of global mega-insurers.

Counter claim

But the market has always seen off accusations of fraud and claims the Jaffray action is "an accusation of last resort". The litigation is actually a counter claim to Lloyd's attempts to recover debts from the litigants and Lloyd's says it can disprove the names' claim that a letter by former market chairman, Murray Lawrence, warning of the risks of asbestos losses was never properly circulated. Insiders say although the case has taken two years to prepare, Lloyd's will be able to show that the Jaffray case is "peppered with inaccurancies and misinterpretations".

Although the names' chances of success are regarded as slim, another extensive exposure of the goings on at No 1 Lime Street will be unwelcome exposure for the new broom executive running the market. Any trawl back through the 1980s will rehash evidence of a market run by decidedly second rate people, many of whom had only the most elementary grip on rudimentary business practice. It will not be a helpful image for an organisation - now run by a 39-year-old former management consultant - and trying to promote itself as the owner of one of the world's most prestigious brand names.

But loss for the names - 30 of whom are on legal aid - will be devastating. It is estimated that Lloyd's formidable 50-strong army of solicitors from top London law firm, Freshfields, have already clocked up costs of £20m or so.

And Lloyd's makes no secret of its determination to recover every penny - even if that means tying up Britain's bankruptcy courts for years to come.

The key players

Sir Peter Green Chairman of Lloyd's in the early 1980s, who was widely discredited as his underwriting business was involved in controversial offshore reinsurance deals. An autocratic and evangelical advocate of Lloyd's. His tenure spanned one of the market's most traumatic periods when flamboyant multi-millionaires, such as Ian "Goldfinger" Posgate, were accused of insider dealing at the expense of investors, or Names.

Murray Lawrence An old-style underwriter who moved up from deputy chairman to chairman of the market, thus earning the distinction of being included in both roles as a defendant in the Jaffray action. He is also singled out for his now notorious "asbestos letter" which Lloyd's claims was distributed to underwriters to warn them of the need to check their reserves for mounting losses, but which the Jaffray Names allege was effectively a forgery and never got out of the chairman's office.

Sir Peter Miller An insurance broker who was appointed to chair Lloyd's in an attempt to usher in a new era of openness. He was largely responsible for appointing the market's first outside chief executive, Ian Hay Davison. But the two men never got on and the new spirit, which was supposed to haul Lloyd's towards the wider business practice of the late 20th century, was put on hold until Peter Middletontook over.

Richard Outhwaite At one time his syndicates were among the most popular in the Lloyd's market with Names falling over themselves for a slice of the action. Under pressure to keep so many investors happy, he ventured into uncharted areas of insurance. But when insurance rates plunged these risky policies were exposed and he could not cover the losses. Always outspoken, Outhwaite is appearing for the litigating Names in support of their claim that market insiders knew of the likely landslide of asbestos losses.
