webTitle: Putting the fizz back into tango

fields.headline: Putting the fizz back into tango
fields.standfirst:
Una Noche de Tango
Peacock Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText: The Peacock Theatre was betting heavily on London's love affair with tango when it booked the Argentinian company Tango por Dos for a six-week run. Luckily, sell-out houses are proving the public's loyalty, as are the red carnations tossed during the show's closing bows.
fields.body:
The Peacock Theatre was betting heavily on London's love affair with tango when it booked the Argentinian company Tango por Dos for a six-week run. Luckily, sell-out houses are proving the public's loyalty, as are the red carnations tossed during the show's closing bows.

The company's latest production follows the usual tango format in its semi- theatrical staging of various dance and music styles. It divides neatly in two halves, located first within an Argentinian tango club, and then within a Parisian nightclub, where the dancers, in sleek evening clothes, look more like celebrities than locals.

There's considerable period charm in the Argentinian scenes, which are set and costumed in tones of sepia, and the show does its best to convince us we're in a neighbourhood of Buenos Aires during the 40s and 50s. The first, showy couple dance emerges from some good-natured joshing as two dancers bump the others off the floor. There's a sweet scene of five guys practising their steps with louche competitive grace.

At various points dancers "wander" in off the street or "check" their lipstick and the "barman" Quique Ojeda bursts into deep vibrato song. If this stylised normality sometimes looks stiff-lipped (the show would benefit from an acting coach), it still gives a human face to the dancing, contrasting well with the glossiness of the second half.

Here the numbers feature a great deal of flick-knife leg action and extrovert lifting and slamming back bends, and they come in many costumes. But, ultimately, it's not the dancing that seduces the audience, but the dancers themselves.

Heading this cast is company director Miguel Angel Zotto, who has lips as thin as a blade and the technique of a showman. With his choppy footwork and tensed body he's more soloist than partner; his high spot is a whip-cracking Valentino number. His opposite is Osvaldo Zotto, who tenderly opens his body up to his partner (though unfortunately he and Lorena Ermocida deliver a practised virtuosity that leaves no room for erotic tension).

My personal favourites are called Ricardo Barrios and Natacha Poberaj. He is a thug of a dancer with huge arms and hands who almost hustles her around the floor, but his surprisingly teasing footwork reacts with her tarty, high-stepping style to spell real danger.

The other dancers are less identifiable, and their lack of diversity in age and character makes the evening occasionally bland. The band, however, have bags of personality and in the medley of Piazolla numbers they positively rock.

Until April 1. Box office: 0171-863 8222.

webTitle: You don't have to be an entrepreneur to work here...

fields.headline: You don't have to be an entrepreneur to work here...
fields.standfirst: But can you make a living in a dot job?
fields.trailText: But can you make a living in a dot job?
fields.body:
Ben Fried was taken on by internet auction site GoIndustry in November , a month after the company secured financial backing. Aged 24, he was the company's 13th employee, brought in as manager of e-commerce operations - a job title now under review because of the number of different roles he has since taken.

He has been involved with all aspects of the start-up, helping with the design of the website, developing customer relationship management software and providing IT support. "On my second day here I even helped to move the office," he says.

Working 9am-7pm, plus some weekends, Ben admits that at the moment he can't envisage a time when working life will settle down to anything less demanding. But he's happy with his hectic lifestyle, anticipating future recognition and rewards as the company expands. He's even found himself involved with the recruitment drive and has clear views on what kind of skills people need to work in the company. "You must be able to think on your feet and take on lots of new and interesting work," he says.

"We brought in a couple of IT contractors a few months ago and they weren't prepared for what we wanted. We asked for certain IT skills but more importantly we needed them to think quickly."

The fact is you don't need to be an e-preneur to make a healthy living from the internet. After all where would the e-preneurs be without the skills of the programmers, designers and content editors who do the basic shovel work required to get a site up and running? But does the glamour of cyberland work extend beyond the MD and his multi-million pound shareholding potential?

Charlotte Williams, senior content producer for LineOne sees many benefits of working in such a young industry: "Most of the stress of the work is defrayed because it's a youthful office. There's always someone telling a joke or sending you a bizarre website." With ultimate responsibility for what appears on the entertainment, kids, learning and lifestyle sections of LineOne's 1.5 million pages, Charlotte's day includes any number of diverse tasks - brainstorming content ideas, liaising over financial planning, and monitoring onsite activities.

Project deadlines have to be met on a weekly basis and there are always the occasional unforeseen problems which demand everyone's attention well into the evening.

"I'm not very good at time management," she confesses, "and with the internet there's always something more you can do - add another directory link to the site or whatever. There's a strong temptation to work non-stop." Williams sets herself definite times when she will leave work, sometimes arranging extra curricula activities to ensure this does happen.

"The internet is an ever- evolving beast," says Ben Willmott, "In some ways your work is never done." Ben is dance editor of crunch.co.uk and regularly turns in 10-12 hour days, the occasional late night and weekend. Having transferred from print media he has found advantages and disadvantages to the new medium.

"If you have a deadline on a magazine you can put things off until the last minute," he says. "Here the impetus is on getting the information up on the site asap. It means the deadline stress doesn't really abate, but then, if you don't like something you can change it immediately."

While LineOne employees benefit from a more established company history and management structure, working for a start-up can be anarchic. Creating any new business usually means a 24/7 working existence, and success or failure depends solely on the commitment and skills of the individuals involved. Throughout the wired world it seems impossible for an employee to predict exactly what they are going to work on today.

The property advertising dotcom sherlock4homes is currently the responsibility of eight people: "We have users onsite at the moment who are testing it and giving us daily feedback on what they like or don't like," says new business director Allan Gray. "This means the working day is totally unpredictable. You might have in mind something that you need to do but it then changes entirely because of the feedback you receive." Within such a small organisation, everyone can contribute to any issue which arises so while the work is stressful, it is unlikely that a programmer will be left on their own to sort out a problem.

Founded in 1996, web design company flg21 is past its teething troubles and now boasts a client list including Stif Mountain Bikes, PA Consulting and Internet Magazine's website. The company employs designers and programmers who are assigned to projects which last between three and six months. "What you tend to find is that people do this both as a hobby and as a job," says company chairman Darryn Forster, "They'll go home and mess about with their own PCs and then come into work and get paid for it here."

Certainly this is the case for Phil Grove, a programmer at flg21. Grove came straight to flg21 two years ago having completed a three-year course in electronic imaging and media communications. He anticipates a few more years of trench work, building up skills and experience before considering a consultancy role, but it's a task he looks forward to: "You have a lot of ownership of the projects you're involved in," he says, "So you don't mind the pressure."

As for the hard work, it's something Grove has grown used to: "It can be complete chaos here sometimes but everyone likes it like that," he says. "If you've had a boring day you don't feel satisfied."

What you can expect

 A starting salary of £20K+

 Long working hours and possibly weekend work

 Ever increasing and diverse workload

 Working in a team on a daily basis

 Practically no daily work routine

 A supportive working environment, but not necessarily a clear career path

 Strong demand for web design and programming skills well into the future

Having transferred from print media he has found advantages and disadvantages to the new medium. "If you have a deadline on a magazine you can put things off until the last minute," he says. "Here the impetus is on getting the information up on the site asap. It means the deadline stress doesn't really abate, but then, if you don't like something you can change it immediately." While LineOne employees benefit from a more established company history and management structure, working for a start-up can be anarchic. Creating any new business usually means a 24/7 working existence, and success or failure depends solely on the commitment and skills of the individuals involved. Throughout the wired world it seems impossible for an employee to predict exactly what they are going to work on today. The property advertising dotcom sherlock4homes is currently the responsibility of eight people: "We have users onsite at the moment who are testing it and giving us daily feedback on what they like or don't like," says new business director Allan Gray. "This means the working day is totally unpredictable. You might have in mind something that you need to do but it then changes entirely because of the feedback you receive." Within such a small organisation, everyone can contribute to any issue which arises so while the work is stressful, it is unlikely that a programmer will be left on their own to sort out a problem. Founded in 1996, web design company flg21 is past its teething troubles and now boasts a client list including Stif Mountain Bikes, PA Consulting and Internet Magazine's website. The company employs designers and programmers who are assigned to projects which last between three and six months. "What you tend to find is that people do this both as a hobby and as a job," says company chairman Darryn Forster, "They'll go home and mess about with their own PCs and then come into work and get paid for it here." Certainly this is the case for Phil Grove, a programmer at flg21. Grove came straight to flg21 two years ago having completed a three-year course in electronic imaging and media communications. He anticipates a few more years of trench work, building up skills and experience before considering a consultancy role, but it's a task he looks forward to: "You have a lot of ownership of the projects you're involved in," he says, "So you don't mind the pressure." As for the hard work, it's something Grove has grown used to: "It can be complete chaos here sometimes but everyone likes it like that," he says. "If you've had a boring day you don't feel satisfied." What you can expect  A starting salary of £20K+  Long working hours and possibly weekend work  Ever increasing and diverse workload  Working in a team on a daily basis  Practically no daily work routine  A supportive working environment, but not necessarily a clear career path  Strong demand for web design and programming skills well into the future

fields.headline: Surviving on a starting salary
fields.standfirst: Make a few sacrifices and don't touch what you can't afford
fields.trailText: You've got your first graduate pay cheque. Congratulations! Enjoy it while it lasts ... which won't be long.
fields.body:
You've got your first graduate pay cheque. Congratulations! Enjoy it while it lasts ... which won't be long. As a great Swedish philosopher once said,

"money, money, money, must be funny, in a rich man's world". Ah ha.

Graduates have never had it so good. The average starting salary for 1999 graduates was £17,500, a 4.8 per cent increase on 1998 and four times the rate of inflation. This year's graduates will be taking home around £18,000.

Graduates have never had it so bad. In the good old days of full grants, free tuition and benefits, graduate debts used to reflect the amount of hours spent in the union bar (i.e. it was your own fault). No longer. Today, unless you have very rich or generous parents, you'd have to starve, alone, in a garret to escape from debt.

According to the NUS, the average 1998 graduate left university with debts of £4,500. Under the current loans system, once you start earning a salary of £15,000 or above, you have to start paying back your loan. And you've only got five years to do it.

Once you become an earner, it's time to put away childish things (combat trousers and snakebite and black) and replace them with the trappings of adulthood (suits and good wines). The problem is doing it on a graduate starting salary. No-one warns you about the expenses of working life. You've got to buy a working wardrobe and finance after-work drinks and meals. Not to mention that in order to actually earn your salary, you've got to go get to work, which means forking out for train or bus fares, or petrol money.

Suddenly, your monthly pay cheque looks less like a winning lottery ticket and more like the miserable scrap of printed paper that it is. The good news is you've got a choice. You can either Spend! Spend! Spend! and be in debt till you're 65 or you can be sensible.

Sensible may not be sexy (but neither is Michael Douglas and it hasn't done him any harm), but it works. Donna Bradshaw, director at independent financial advisers, Fiona Price & Partners says the key to surviving on a graduate starting salary is budgeting: "It's all too easy to run out of money before the month is up," she states, "so you need to know exactly how much you have to live on and how much your bills, rent, student loans and council tax etc. will cost.

"Once you know, you can put the money aside. Then, if you're really clever, take out the exact amount of cash you've allowed yourself for each week and live on it. Seeing it physically disappear will make you more aware of your spending habits."

Many companies offer season ticket loans as a perk. If yours is one of them, take them up on it. You'll save a substantial amount on travelling costs. Remember though, that they're treated as a benefit in kind, which means you'll pay slightly more tax.

Getting the hang of this being sensible lark? Then why not cut back on needless spending by bringing in home-made sandwiches and drinks. Avoid ready-cooked meals for one - they're not economical. If you're really organised, Donna suggests cooking up dishes at the weekend, then separating them into portions and freezing them for consumption later in the week.

Building a working wardrobe can be difficult at the start of your career. Many companies are taking a more relaxed attitude to dressing, but in some professions (law, accountancy) you either get suited up or booted out. Either get a job as an artist's model, work only on dress-down Fridays, or learn to shop carefully: "The temptation is to put everything on the credit card," says Donna. "But if you do that, it's all too easy to make debt a habit. Choose a few good investment pieces and if you have no choice but to get them on credit, look for cards with low interest rates."

It's a perverse fact that the more credit you have, the more you can get. If you're someone for whom "credit" is spelt D A N G E R (that is, you see it as the ticket to fancy holidays and designer clothes) you might, Donna says, be better off with a loan.

"Loans are easier to manage than credit cards. You know exactly how much you'll have to pay each month and will have a set date to pay it off by. If you do have a credit card, you can ask for the limit to be reduced, so you don't find yourself on a slippery slope to even more debt."

There's no shame in being less well-off than your more senior (and higher salaried) colleagues. Don't be the first person to jump in and offer to buy a round of drinks, offer to buy your own - or even suggest starting up a kitty for social occasions. "Often, team social events happen at set times of the year, such as Christmas," says Donna.

"This means you can plan for them and save some money in advance. As for leaving collections, put in what you can afford when the envelope comes round, irrespective of other people's contributions. You're not a charity."

Living on a graduate starting salary is hard, but making a few sacrifices at the start of your career is worth it in the long term. One day, you'll be be able to live the life of Riley (nice car, nice house, nice holidays), while your less careful peers are still living like students. Better go ... the bailiffs are knocking on the door.

fields.headline: Cut ATM charges, banks told
fields.trailText: Banks and building societies were threatened yesterday with a full-scale competition inquiry unless they reduced the charge for withdrawing money from cash machines to a 30p maximum.
fields.body:
Banks and building societies were threatened yesterday with a full-scale competition inquiry unless they reduced the charge for withdrawing money from cash machines to a 30p maximum.

Don Cruickshank, who is close to completing a year-long investigation for the government into banking competition, waded into the six-month Link cash machine war claiming a reduced fee would help break the stranglehold by the big four high street banks - Lloyds TSB, Barlcays, NatWest and HSBC - on the market for current accounts.

At the moment the big four banks hold 68% of current accounts. His demands, just days before a crucial meeting on Tuesday of the banks and building societies which make up Link, would involve big cuts in the price some customers pay for taking their money from hole in the wall machines, which currently ranges from £1.50 to nothing.

Mr Cruickshank, who also ruled himself out of the running for the post of director general at the office of fair trading, prompted further controversy in the debate over cash machine charging, which has raged since last summer when Barclays tried to introduce a £1 "surcharge" on its rivals' customers.

The threat of legal action by Nationwide building society delayed the charge, which is yet to be introduced. It would change the way fees are levied on customers, who in the past have been more used to "disloyalty" fees levied by their own bank or building society when they use a rivals' machine.

Some customers, particularly of building societies, do not face any charge at present. Mr Cruickshank made it clear yesterday that he had no preference over either method, provided the fee was in the range of 15p to 30p.

"This isn't saying everyone should be able to withdraw cash from ATMs for nothing But it should be fairer," Mr Cruickshank said after releasing his report earlier after a leak.

Prepared for dissent from the major banks who own most of the country's 27,000 cash machines - or ATMs - he said: "Of course they'll argue the real costs are higher".

His recommendations, being sent to the treasury and the prime minister, also allow non-banks to own cash machines and make the charging mechanism "more transparent" so that the charge should be displayed on the cash machines.

Link insisted that there had been no suggestion that Tuesday's meeting would set mandatory fees which would have raised allegations of competition and charge-fixing allegations.

Nationwide, which wants to keep cash withdrawals free, said: "We welcome his chief recommendation that cash machine charges should be related to their true cost."
